SENTENCES AND THEIR PERPLEXITY


1. thus the transformation of adam	smith's ideal entrepreneur into a mythological detective coincides	closely with the decline of the real entrepreneur in economic life.	4.694668224237273
2. driven	from the marketplace by the course of history our hero disguises	himself as a private detective.	6.246798213044031
3. the birth of the myth compensates	for the death of the ideal.	5.311583065254168
4. even on the fictional level however	the contradictions which give rise to the mystery story are not fully	resolved.	6.2255442657505915
5. the individualism and public service of the private detective	both stem from his dedication to a personal code of conduct:	he enforces the law without being told to do so.	3.589017186915129
6. the private eye is therefore	a moral man; but his morality rests upon that of his society.	5.3535135909338125
7. the basic premise of all mystery stories is that the distinction between	good and bad coincides with the distinction between legal and illegal.	4.253417229130161
8. unfortunately this assumption does not always hold good.	7.721980414858568
9. as	capitalism in the 20th century has become increasingly dependent upon	force and violence for its survival the private detective is placed	in a serious dilemma.	4.009567886504237
10. if he is good he may not be legal; if he is	legal he may not be good.	8.342686079758515
11. it is the gradual unfolding and deepening	of this contradiction which creates the inner dialectic of the evolution	of the mystery story.	4.324068562605547
12. with the advent of sir arthur	conan doyle's sherlock holmes the development of the modern private	detective begins.	7.381362699268692
13. sherlock holmes is not merely an individualist;	he is very close to being a mental case.	5.238478952681291
14. a brief list of the great	detective's little idiosyncrasies would provide dr freud with	ample food for thought.	6.006548844771116
15. holmes is addicted to the use of cocaine and	other refreshing stimulants; he is prone to semi-catatonic trances	induced by the playing of the vioiln; he is a recluse an incredible	egotist a confirmed misogynist.	4.322819788484117
16. holmes rebels against the social	conventions of his day not on moral but rather on aesthetic grounds.	5.636500868665733
17. his	eccentricity begins as a defense against boredom.	5.3285636594893
18. it was in order	to avoid the stuffy routine of middle class life that holmes became	a detective in the first place.	6.891267315594368
19. as he informs watson my life is	spent in one long effort to escape from the commonplaces of existence.	4.806024495060205
20. these little problems help me to do so.	7.675019828375376
21. holmes is a public servant	to be sure; but the society which he serves bores him to tears.	4.219038752925444
22. the curious relationship between holmes and scotland yard	provides an important clue to the deeper significance of his eccentric	behavior.	5.2045335440434215
23. although he is perfectly willing to cooperate with scotland	yard holmes has nothing but contempt for the intelligence and mentality	of the police.	4.388876802914165
24. they for their part are convinced that holmes	is too unorthodox and theoretical to make a good detective.	6.7968013284199404
25. why do the police find holmes unorthodox?	6.2599306038762315
26.  on the face of	it it is because he employs deductive techniques alien to official	police routine.	6.642590907313347
27. another more interesting explanation is hinted at by	watson when he observes on several occasions that holmes would have	made a magnificent criminal.	3.9606173010294836
28. the great detective modestly agrees.	8.243889184727871
29. watson's	insight is verified by the mysterious link between holmes	and his arch-opponent dr moriarty.	4.305414028832856
30. the two men resemble each other	closely in their cunning their egotism their relentlessness.	6.014872247591847
31. the	first series of sherlock holmes adventures ends with holmes and moriarty	grappling together on the edge of a cliff.	4.685492672847348
32. they are presumed	to have plunged to a common grave in this fatal embrace.	6.444201577805812
33. linked to holmes	even in death moriarty represents the alter-ego of the great	detective the image of what our hero might have become were he not a	public servant.	3.888948745898811
34. just as holmes the eccentric stands behind holmes the	detective so holmes the potential criminal lurks behind both.	6.074739403816712
35. in the modern english whodunnit this insinuation of	latent criminality in the detective himself has almost entirely disappeared.	4.421519854325321
36. hercule poirot and lord peter whimsey	have retained	holmes'	egotism but not his zest for life and eccentric habits.	5.454336586728915
37. poirot and	his counterparts are perfectly respectable people; it is true that	they are also extremely dull.	4.538694476440035
38. their dedication to the status quo has	been affirmed at the expense of the fascinating but dangerous individualism	of a sherlock holmes.	5.932861840593582
39. the latter's real descendents were unable	to take root in england; they fled from the victorian parlor	and made their way across the stormy atlantic.	3.5952062133124953
40. in the american hardboiled	detective story of the '20s and '30s the spirit of the	mad genius from baker street lives on.	6.89338490042854
41. like holmes the	american private eye rejects the social conventions of his time.	4.915570261991866
42. but	unlike holmes he feels his society to be not merely dull but also corrupt.	5.763023142066387
43. surrounded by crime and violence everywhere the hardboiled	private eye can retain his purity only through a life of self-imposed	isolation.	3.9378314648561785
44. his alienation is far more acute than holmes'; he	is not an eccentric but rather an outcast.	6.130090302790985
45. with rex stout's nero	wolfe alienation is represented on a purely physical plane.	4.8679888245169085
46. wolfe	refuses to ever leave his own house and spends most of his time drinking	beer and playing with orchids.	5.862034692466262
47. more profound and more disturbing	however is the moral isolation of raymond chandler's philip marlowe.	4.697493264272977
48. in a society where everything is for sale marlowe is the only	man who cannot be bought.	6.378560481820552
49. his tough honesty condemns him to a solitary	and difficult existence.	5.258332511707205
50. beaten bruised and exhausted he pursues	the elusive killer through the demi-monde of high society and low	morals always alone always despised.	5.160513208686437
51. in the end he gets his man but	no one seems to care; virtue is its own and only reward.	4.639577423470684
52. a similar	tone of underlying futility and despair pervades the spy thrillers	of eric ambler and dominates the most famous of all american mystery	stories dashiell hammett's the maltese falcon.	4.848075396919564
53. sam spade	joins forces with a band of adventurers in search of a priceless jeweled	statue of a falcon; but when the bird is found at last it turns	out to be a fake.	4.227974374873775
54. now the detective must save his own skin by informing	on the girl he loves who is also the real murderer.	6.102736897885947
55. for sam spade	neither crime nor virtue pays; moreover it is increasingly difficult	to distinguish between the two.	4.397746574674534
56. because the private eye	intends to save society in spite of himself he invariably finds himself	in trouble with the police.	6.4725253287241316
57. the latter are either too stupid to	catch the killer or too corrupt to care.	4.2940786852662844
58. in either case they do not	appreciate the private detective's zeal.	7.181769965322449
59. perry mason and hamilton	burger nero wolfe and inspector cramer spend more time fighting	each other than they do in looking for the criminal.	4.00908387037386
60. frequently enough	the police are themselves in league with the killer; dashiell	hammett's	red harvest provides a classic example of this theme.	5.640010460811021
61. but even when the police are honest they do not trust the private	eye.	6.096763368712364
62. he is like phillip marlowe too alienated to be reliable.	7.3218104171203
63. finally	in the maltese falcon among others the clash between detective	and police is carried to its logical conclusion: sam spade	becomes the chief murder suspect.	3.725131536371901
64. in order to exonerate himself he	is compelled to find the real criminal who happens to be his girl friend.	6.654941233312143
65. what was only a vague suspicion in the case of sherlock holmes	now appears as a direct accusation: the private eye is in danger of	turning into his opposite.	4.642143928037869
66. it is the growing contradiction	between individualism and public service in the mystery story which	creates this fatal dilemma.	6.416913129421739
67. by upholding his own personal code of behavior	the private detective has placed himself in opposition to a society	whose fabric is permeated with crime and corruption.	4.172309061671211
68. that society	responds by condemning the private eye as a threat to the status quo	a potential criminal.	6.386333281428085
69. if the detective insists upon retaining his	personal standards he must now do so in conscious defiance of his society.	4.276358589295928
70. he must in short cease to be a detective and become a rebel.	7.692273022735672
71. on the other hand if he wishes to continue in his chosen profession	he must abandon his own code and sacrifice his precious individualism.	4.291813781288864
72. dashiell hammett resolved this contradiction by ceasing to write	mystery	stories and turning to other pursuits.	5.659455227543579
73. his successors have adopted	the opposite alternative.	5.958640424998724
74. in order to save the mystery story they	have converted the private detective into an organization man.	7.115329907585144
75. the first of two possible variations on this theme is symbolized by	mickey spillane's mike hammer.	5.123933505978882
76. at first glance this hero seems	to be more rather than less of an individualist than any of his predecessors.	6.46642973636272
77. for hammer nothing is forbidden.	6.838647334942619
78. he kills when he pleases	takes his women where he finds them and always acts as judge jury	and executioner rolled into one.	5.202221248788263
79. it will be shown that the objectives of the cooperative people in	an organization determine the type of network required because the	type of network functions according to the characteristics of the messages	enumerated in table 1.	4.236600823486631
80. great stress is placed on the role that	the monitoring of information sending plays in maintaining the effectiveness	of the network.	5.759684258114675
81. by monitoring we mean some system of control	over the types of information sent from the various centers.	4.250802375529208
82. as a word of caution we should be aware that in actual practice no	message is purely one of the four types question command statement	or exclamation.	6.839524598523699
83. for example suppose a man wearing a $200 watch driving	a 1959 rolls royce stops to ask a man on the sidewalk what	time is it?	4.113005580333434
84.  this sentence would have most of the characteristics	of a question but it has some of the characteristics of a statement	because the questioner has conveyed the fact that he has no faith in	his own timepiece or the one attached to his car.	6.2199572326455606
85. if the man on the	sidewalk is surprised at this question it has served as an exclamation.	4.5310603116709744
86. also since the man questioned feels a strong compulsion to answer	the question	has assumed some measurable properties of a command.	5.530852698708456
87. however for	convenience we will stick to the idea that information can be classified	according to table 1.	5.029032622238009
88. on this basis certain extreme kinds of networks	will be discussed for illustrative purposes.	6.810877061057646
89. some special types of organization	presumably a cocktail party is expected to fulfill the host's desire	to get together a number of people who are inadequately acquainted	and thereby arrange for bringing the level of acquaintance up to adequacy	for future cooperative endeavors.	4.366542727866511
90. the party is usually in a room	small enough so that all guests are within sight and hearing of one another.	5.488500579755457
91. the information is furnished by each of the guests is sent by	oral broadcasting over the air waves and is received by the ears.	4.153382604188301
92. since	the air is a continuum the network of communication remains intact	regardless of the positions or motions of the points	in the net.	5.334219345263066
93. as shown in figure 1 there is a connection for communication	between every pair of points.	5.556441106282921
94. this and other qualifications make	the cocktail party the most complete and most chaotic communication	system ever dreamed up.	5.894445684673533
95. all four types of message listed in table	1 are permitted although decorum and cocktail tradition require holding	the commands to a minimum while exclamations having complimentary	intonations are more than customarily encouraged.	3.688788250534449
96. the completeness	of the connections provide that for n people there are f	lines of communication between the pairs which can become a large number	for a party of fifty guests.	4.667581188675998
97. looking at the diagram we	see that f connection lines come in to each member.	4.649114565222547
98. thus the cocktail	party would appear to be the ideal system but there is one weakness.	9.87734291399977
99. in spite of the dreams of the host for oneness in the group the	f incoming messages for each guest overload his receiving system beyond	comprehension if n exceeds about six.	4.090114001444112
100. the crowd consequently	breaks up into temporary groups ranging in size from two to six with	a half-life for the cluster ranging from three to twenty minutes.	4.874370579408488
101. for the occasion on which everyone already knows everyone else	and the host wishes them to meet one or a few honored newcomers then	the open house system is advantageous because the honored guests	are fixed connective points and the drifting guests make and break connections	at the door.	3.4966617376797364
102. we consider a rural	community as an assemblage of inhabited dwellings whose configuration	is determined by the location and size of the arable land sites necessary	for family subsistence.	5.547965855361084
103. we assume for this illustration that the	size of the land plots is so great that the distance between dwellings	is greater than the voice can carry and that most of the communication	is between nearest neighbors only as shown in figure 2.	4.278942971381647
104. information	beyond nearest neighbor is carried second- third- and fourth-hand	as a distortable rumor.	5.926734816808145
105. in figure 2 the points in the network are	designated by a letter accompanied by a number.	4.7471799043260035
106. the numbers indicate	the number of nearest neighbors.	6.235712268229572
107. it will be noted that point f	has seven nearest neighbors h and e have six and p	has only one while the remaining points have intermediate numbers.	4.24791099411754
108. in any social system in which communications have an importance	comparable with that of production and other human factors a point	like f in figure 2 would be the dwelling	place for the community leader while e and h would	house the next most important citizens.	5.168706588030362
109. a point like p gets	information directly from n but all information beyond n	is indirectly relayed through n.	3.969810750888568
110. the dweller at p is	last to hear about a new cure the slowest to announce to his neighbors	his urgent distresses the one who goes the farthest to trade and the	one with the greatest difficulty of all in putting over an idea or	getting people to join him in a cooperative effort.	4.604647067913598
111. since the hazards	of poor communication are so great p can be justified as a habitable	site only on the basis of unusual productivity such as is made	available by a waterfall for milling purposes a mine or a sugar maple	camp.	3.802941636868106
112. location theorists have given these matters much consideration.	6.806723317680827
113. the networks for military communications	are one of the best examples of networks which not only must be	changed with the changes in objectives but also must be changed with the	addition of new machines of war.	4.10284412684238
114. they also furnish proof that in	modern war message sending must be monitored.	6.669216874232325
115. without monitoring a	military hookup becomes a noisy party.	5.710682204439152
116. the need for monitoring became	greater when radio was adopted for military signaling.	6.2909647459254785
117. alexander the	great who used runners as message carriers did not have to worry about	having every officer in his command hear what he said and having	hundreds of them comment at once.	4.24546844109079
118. as time has passed and science has	progressed the speed of military vehicles has increased the range of	missiles has been extended the use of target-hunting noses on the projectiles	has been adopted and the range and breadth of message sending	has increased.	5.265454996989047
119. next to the old problem of the slowness of decision	making network structure seems to be paramount and without monitoring	no network has value.	5.004068093477943
120. on the parade ground the net may be similar	to that shown in figure 3.	6.371624370053186
121. the monitoring is the highest and	most restrictive of any organization in existence.	4.012715720819275
122. no questions statements	or explanations are permitted- only commands.	7.634707380775526
123. commands go only	from an officer to the man of nearest lower rank.	4.816726569302973
124. the same command	is repeated as many times as there are levels in rank from general to	corporal.	6.158202316404318
125. all orders originate with the officer of highest rank and	terminate with action of the men in the ranks.	5.137765817544385
126. even the officer in charge	be it a captain or a general is restrained	by monitoring.	6.55728352058283
127. this is done for simplicity of commands and to bring the	hidden redundancy up to where misunderstanding has almost zero possibility.	4.500740570834292
128. the commands are specified by the military regulations; are	few in number briefly worded all different in sound; and are combinable	into sequences which permit any marching maneuver that could be	desired on a parade ground.	4.494012173111996
129. this monitoring is necessary because on	a parade ground everyone can hear too much and without monitoring	a confused social event would develop.	3.8848375982832044
130. with troops dispersed	on fields of battle rather than on the parade ground it may seem that	a certain amount of monitoring is automatically enforced by the lines	of communication.	5.27313600315699
131. years ago this was true but with the replacement	of wires or runners by radio and radar these	restrictions have disappeared and now again too much is heard.	4.009542598867207
132. in contrast to cocktail parties military organizations even	in the field are more formal.	6.451727817754432
133. in the extreme and oversimplified example	suggested in figure 3 the organization is more easily understood	and more predictable in behavior.	4.240111483060462
134. a military organization has an objective	chosen by the higher command.	6.226873061589773
135. this objective is adhered to throughout	the duration of the action.	5.00270118030033
136. the connective system or network	is tailored to meet the requirements of the objective and it is therefore	not surprising that a military body acting as a single coordinated	unit has a different communication network than a factory a college	or a rural village.	5.014499935001889
137. the assumptions upon which the example	shown	in figure 3 is based are: one man can direct about six subordinates	if the subordinates are chosen carefully so that they do not	need too much personal coaching indoctrinating etc.	3.7160281244784725
138. a message	runs too great a risk of being distorted if it is to be relayed more	than about six consecutive times.	6.837309468510877
139. decisions of a general kind	are made by the central command.	5.315542350960959
140. and all action of a physical kind	pertinent to the mission is relegated to the line of men on the lower	rank.	6.06704522442152
141. these assumptions lead to an organization with one man at the	top six directly under him six under each of these and so on until	there are six levels of personnel.	3.9359910990999767
142. the number of people acting as one	body by this scheme gives a surprisingly large army of f 55987	men.	5.962021021959122
143. this organizational network would be of no avail if there	were no regulations pertaining to the types of message sent.	4.040813365261647
144. of types	of message listed in table 1 commands and statements are the only	ones sent through the vertical network shown in figure 3.	5.500084735935524
145. a further	regulation is that commands always go down unaccompanied by statements	and statements always go up unaccompanied by commands.	3.9147703487056127
146. questions	and particularly exclamations are usually channeled along informal	horizontal lines not indicated in figure 3 and seldom are carried	beyond the nearest neighbor.	5.103675880876918
147. it will readily be seen that	in this suggested network	greater emphasis on monitoring is implied than	is usually put into practice.	4.369971273748713
148. furthermore the network in figure	3 is only the basic net through which other networks pertaining to logistics	and the like are interlaced.	5.3518427722789905
149. not discussed here are some	military problems of modern times such as undersea warfare where the	surveillance sending transmitting and receiving are all so inadequate	that networks and decision making are not the bottlenecks.	3.9063386102873303
150. such	problems are of extreme interest as well as importance and are so much	like fighting in a rain forest or guerrilla warfare at night in tall	grass that we might have to re-examine primitive conflicts for what they	could teach.	5.061512941749692
151. this is an unsolved	problem which probably has never been seriously investigated although	one frequently hears the comment that we have insufficient specialists	of the kind who can compete with the germans or swiss for example	in precision machinery and mathematics or the finns in geochemistry.	3.8633432354291983
152. we hear equally fervent concern over the belief that we have	not enough generalists who can see the over-all picture and combine	our national skills and knowledge for useful purposes.	5.235567963784882
153. this problem	of the optimum balance in the relative numbers of generalists and	specialists can be investigated on a communicative network basis.	3.8974694797130636
154. since	the difficulty of drawing the net is great we will merely discuss	it.	6.35033167163411
155. first we realize that a pure specialist does not exist.	5.530290547994213
156. but	for practical purposes we have people who can be considered as such.	6.48784583646846
157. for example there are persons who are in physical science in the	field of mineralogy trained in crystallography who use only x-rays	applying only the powder technique of x-ray diffraction to clay	minerals only and who have spent the last fifteen years concentrating	on the montmorillonites; or persons in the social sciences in the	field of anthropology studying the lung capacity of seven andean	indians.	3.49103094867392
158. so we see that a specialist is a man who knows more and more	about less and less as he develops as contrasted to the generalist	who knows less and less about more and more.	5.569380041868006
159. american democratic thought pointed up the relation between the	protestant movement in this country and the development of a social	religion which he called the american democratic faith.	4.930694816698224
160. those familiar	with his work will remember that he placed the incipience of the	democratic faith at around 1850.	5.845089776359451
161. and he describes it as a balanced polarity	between the notions of the free individual and what he called	the fundamental law.	4.733032364702819
162. i want to say more about gabriel's so-called	fundamental law.	8.009210549207303
163. but first i want to quote him on the relationship	that he found between religion and politics in this country and	what happened to it.	4.544539028545792
164. he points out that from the time of jackson on	through world war 1 evangelical protestantism was a dominant influence	in the social and political life of america.	6.083944015032079
165. he terms this	early enthusiasm romantic christianity and concludes that its	similarity to democratic beliefs of that day is so great that the doctrine	of liberty seems but a secular version of its counterpart in evangelical	protestantism.	3.8103494472244352
166. let me quote him even more fully for his	analysis is important to my theme.	7.098915962070048
167. he says: beside the	protestant philosophy of progress as expressed in radical or conservative	millenarianism should be placed the doctrine of the democratic	faith which affirmed it to be the duty of the destiny of the united	states to assist in the creation of a better world by keeping lighted	the beacon of democracy.	4.0031194711043465
168. he specifies in the middle period	of the nineteenth century it was colored by christian supernaturalism	in the twentieth century it was affected by naturalism.	6.672297469319921
169. but in	every period it has been humanism.	7.043609515301075
170. and let me add utopianism also.	8.248291530411178
171. some fourteen or fifteen years ago in an essay i called	the leader follows- where?	4.979090899496442
172.  i used his polarity to illustrate	what i thought had happened to us in that form of liberalism we call	progressivism.	5.67934707496787
173. it seemed to me that the liberals had scrapped the	balanced polarity and reposed both liberty and the fundamental law	in the common man.	4.741920396283683
174. that is to say gabriel's fundamental law had been	so much modified by this time that it was neither fundamental nor	law any more.	6.984704817564926
175. it is a weakness of gabriel's analysis that he never	seems to realize that his so-called fundamental law had already been	cut loose from its foundations when it was adapted to democracy.	4.199564900472011
176. and	with progressivism the religion of humanity was replacing what gabriel	called christian supernaturalism.	5.96331148341506
177. and the common man was developing	mythic power or charisma on his own.	5.193163005726023
178. during the decade	that followed the common man as that piece put it grew uncomfortable	as the voice of god and fled from behind saint woodrow	only to learn from science to his shocked relief that after all there	was no god he had to speak for and that he was just an animal anyhow-	that there was a chemical formula for him and that too much couldn't	be expected of him.	5.352364378525417
179. the socialism implicit in the slogan	of the roosevelt revolution freedom from want and fear seems a	far cry from the individualism of the first amendment to the constitution	or of the jacksonian frontier.	3.7658413879407986
180. what had happened to the common	man?	9.618125492657587
181.    french egalitarianism had had only nominal influence	in this country before the days of popularism.	4.574278808491521
182. the riotous onrush	of industrialism after the war for southern independence and the general	secular drift to the religion of humanity however prepared	the way for a reception of the french revolution's socialistic offspring	of one sort of another.	4.796371071699456
183. the first of which to find important place	in our federal government was the graduated income tax under wilson.	4.73116314099407
184. moreover the centralization of our economy during the 1920s the	dislocations of the depression the common ethos of materialism everywhere	all contributed in various ways to the face-lifting that replaced	mike fink and the great gatsby with the anonymous physiognomy	of the little people.	4.888102437991418
185. however it is important to trace the	philosophy of the french revolution to its sources to understand the	common democratic origin of individualism and socialism and the influence	of the latter on the former.	4.287211291950343
186. that john locke's philosophy of	the social contract fathered the american revolution with its declaration	of independence i believe we generally accept.	5.612383356478478
187. yet after	rousseau had given the social contract a new twist with his notion	of the general will the same philosophy it may be said became	the idea source of the french revolution also.	4.224095289580154
188. the importance	of rousseau's twist has not always been clear to us however.	5.390500575037483
189. this	notion of the general will gave rise to the commune of paris in	the revolution and later brought napoleon to dictatorship.	4.275758007467088
190. and it	is clearly argued by lord percy of newcastle in his remarkable long	essay the heresy of democracy and in a more general way by	voegelin in his new science of politics that this same rousseauan	idea descending through european democracy is the source of	marx's theory of the dictatorship of the proletariat.	4.914590516231284
191. this is important	to understanding the position that doctrinaire liberals found themselves	in after world war 2 and our great democratic victory	that brought no peace.	4.523137096396854
192. the long road that had taken liberals in	this country into the social religion of democracy into a worship of	man led logically to the marxist dream of a classless society under	a socialist state.	4.773269645608744
193. and the ussr existed as the revolutionary	experiment in radical socialism the ultimate exemplar.	4.88380238970701
194. and by the	time the war ended liberal leadership in this country was spiritually	marxist.	7.194262199934479
195. we will recall that the still confident liberals of	the truman administration gathered with other western utopians in	san francisco to set up the legal framework finally and at last to	rationalize war- to rationalize want and fear- out of the world:	the united nations.	3.903127059558352
196. we of the liberal-led world got all set for peace	and rehabilitation.	7.399416397589123

198. during the next five years the leaders of the fair deal reluctantly	backed down from the optimistic expectations of the new deal.	7.321323525209197

200. in 1952 it will be remembered	the gop without positive program campaigned on the	popular disillusionment with liberal leadership and won overwhelmingly.	5.943595135629777
201. all of this i know is recent history familiar to you.	5.885166798098334

207. and i select this sentence as its pertinent summation: in essence	the drama of his presidency can be described	as the ordeal of a nation turned conservative and struggling- thus far	with but limited and precarious success- to give effective voice	and force to that conservatism.	3.569183990754835
208. i will assume that we are	all aware of the continuing struggle with its limited and precarious	success toward conservatism.	6.39214701188648
209. it has moved on various levels it has	been clamorous and confused.	5.402898008017697

222. the contributors	to this testament were all well-known: a former democratic	candidate for president a new deal poet the magazine's chief	editorial writer two newspaper columnists head of a national broadcasting	company a popular protestant evangelist etc.	4.561085688268358
223. what i want	to point out here is that all of them are ex-liberals or modified liberals	with perhaps one exception.	5.777562320037943
224. i suppose we might classify billy	graham as an old liberal.	7.164207487232489

241. does that not suggest to you an uncertain and uneasy not to say confused	state of the public mind?	4.786055715847796
242.    what is the common man's	complaint?	11.834716641108068
243.  let's take a panoramic look back over the course we	have come.	4.535752126583474
244. has not that way been lit always by the lamp of liberalism	up until the turning back under eisenhower?	5.638119140232106
245.  and the basic character	of that liberalism has been spiritual rather than economic.	5.043811773693913
246. ralph	gabriel gave it the name of protestant philosophy of progress.	7.3153663617283256
247. but	there's a subjective side to that utopian outlook.	5.066959048406199
248. does our society have a runaway uncontrollable growth of	technology which may end our civilization or a normal healthy growth?	5.71173842559353
249. 	here there may be an analogy with cancer: we can detect cancers	by their rapidly accelerating growth determinable only when related	to the more normal rate of healthy growth.	4.022950019818483
250. should the accelerating	growth of technology then warn us?	7.644177729071336
251.  noting such evidence is the first	step; and almost the only cure is early detection and removal.	4.2428826407164335
252. one way to determine whether we have so dangerous a technology	would be to check the strength of our society's organs to see if their	functioning is as healthy as before.	5.796730920774668
253. so an objective look at our	present procedures may move us to consider seriously this possibly analogous	situation.	4.3703990134474155
254. in any event whether society may have cancer or merely	a virus infection the disease we shall find is political	economical social and even medical.	5.541690327543543
255. have not our physical abilities	already deteriorated because of the more sedentary lives we are now	living?	5.825600469173731
256.  hence the prime issue as i see it is whether a democratic	or free society can master technology for the benefit of mankind	or whether technology will rule and develop its own society compatible	with its own needs as a force of nature.	5.175546488406842
257. we are already committed	to establishing man's supremacy over nature and everywhere	on earth not merely in the limited social-political-economical context	we are fond of today.	4.117928157721877
258. otherwise we go on endlessly trying to draw	the line color and other as to which kind of man we wish to see dominate.	5.477056434065888
259. we have proved so able to solve technological problems that to	contend we cannot realize a universal goal in the immediate future is	to be extremely shortsighted if nothing else.	3.926696883262048
260. we must believe we have	the ability to affect our own destinies: otherwise why try anything?	6.332678008838961
261. 	so in these pages the term technology is used to include any	and all means which could amplify project or augment man's control	over himself and over other men.	3.8064272287402767
262. naturally this includes all communication	forms eg languages or any social political economic	or religious structures employed for such control.	5.621873948309561
263. properly mindful	of all the cultures in existence today throughout the world we must	employ these resources without war or violent revolution.	4.0214460149307305
264. if	we were creating a wholly new society we could insist that our social	political economic and philosophic institutions foster rather than	hamper man; best growth.	5.105125264061747
265. but we cannot start off with a clean slate.	6.724734441356897
266. so we must first analyze our present institutions with respect to	the effect of each on man's major needs.	6.041272678012878

268. at first glance this appears strange: of all people	was not america founded by rugged individualists who established a new	way of life still inspiring undeveloped societies abroad?	5.3608858112375835

272. their	kind created an american culture superior to any in the world an	industrial and technological culture which penetrated russia as it did	almost every corner of the earth without a nickel from the federal	treasury or a single governmental specialist to contrive directives or	program a series of consultations of interested agencies.	5.426459220126896
273. this favorable	image of america in the minds of russian men and women is still	there despite years of energetic anti-american propaganda h	perhaps the public's present attitude	toward business stems from the fact that the rugged capitalist entrepreneur	no more exists in america.	4.38794163494155

279. businesses	must develop as a result of the ideas energies and ambitions of an	individual having purpose and comprehensive ability within one mind.	4.462330075436692
280. when we forced individuals to assume the corporate structure	by means of taxes and other legal statutes we adopted what i would	term pseudo-capitalism and so took a major step toward socialism.	5.155974627451894
281. the biggest loss of course was the individual's lessened desire	and ability to give his services to the growth of his company and	our economy.	4.0453935335719935
282. socialism i grant has a definite place in our society.	6.289010577019261
283. but let us not complain of the evils of capitalism by referring to	a form that is not truly capitalistic.	4.5110665947081054
284. some forms of capitalism do indeed	work- superb organizations a credit to any society.	6.156002654076167
285. but the pseudo-capitalism	which dictates our whole economy as well as our politics	and social life will not stand close scrutiny.	4.726709562924424
286. its pretense to operate	in the public interest is little more than a sham.	7.809389888590825
287. it serves	only its own stockholders and poorly at that.	5.48553146339856
288. as a creative enterprise	its abilities are primarily in swallowing creative enterprises	developed outside its own organization	.	6.205049250636099
289. as to benefits to employees it is notorious	for its callous disregard except where it depends on them for services.	4.3097642784137244
290. the corporation in america is in reality our form of socialism	vying in a sense with the other socialistic form that has emerged	within governmental bureaucracy.	5.641829999577389
291. but while the corporation has all	the disadvantages of the socialist form of organization	it cannot constructively do much of anything not compatible with its	unluckily it	does not have the desirable aspect of socialism the motivation to operate	for the benefit of society as a whole.	3.692958773174644
292. so we are faced with a	vast network of amorphous entities perpetuating themselves in whatever	manner they can without regard to the needs of society controlling	society and forcing upon it a regime representing only the corporation's	needs for survival.	5.531321959611855
293. the corporation has a limited specific	place in our society.	4.5884307043269414
294. ideally speaking it should be allowed to operate	only where the public has a great stake in the continuity of supply	or services and where the actions of a single proprietor are secondary	to the needs of society.	5.900077004489296
295. examples are in public utilities making	military aircraft and accessories or where the investment and risk	for a proprietorship would be too great for a much needed project impossible	to achieve by any means other than the corporate form eg	constructing major airports or dams.	3.592304240653621
296. thus if corporations are not	to run away with us they must become quasi-governmental institutions	subject to public control and needs.	5.739187692485559
297. in all other areas private initiative	of the proprietorship type should be urged to produce the	desired goods and services.	4.369008233722511
298. avoiding runaway	technology can be done only by assuring a humane society; and for this	human beings must be firmly in control of the economics on which our	society rests.	5.529207946933141
299. such genuine human leadership the proprietorship can	offer corporations cannot.	5.521911988567937
300. it can project long-range goals for itself.	9.260410570929535
301. corporations react violently to short-range stimuli e g	quarterly and annual dividend reports.	4.411891185517149
302. proprietorships can establish	a unity and integrity of control; corporations being more amorphous	cannot.	5.926734816808145
303. proprietorships can establish a meaningful identity representing	a human personality and thus establish sincere relationships with	customers and community.	3.996502389132312
304. corporations are apt by nature to be impersonal	inhumane shortsighted and almost exclusively profit-motivated	a picture they could scarcely afford to present to the public.	5.277774918328408
305. the	proprietor is able to create a leadership impossible in the corporate	structure with its board of directors and stockholders.	4.904461480356293
306. leadership is	lacking in our society because it has no legitimate place to develop.	6.325355777582214

318. 	these proposals would go far toward creating the economic	atmosphere favoring growth of the individual who in turn would help	us to cope with runaway technology.	6.02213621140942
319. individual human strength is	needed to pit against an inhuman condition.	4.681571082223364

322. persons developed in to-day's corporations	cannot hope to serve here- a judgment based on experiences	of my own in business and in activities outside.	5.081898203430707
