397.    frequently we	are given assurance that automatically all ideas will be sifted and resifted	and in the end only the good ones will survive.	4.316874862455529
398. but is that not	like going to a chemistry laboratory and blindly pouring out liquids	and powders from an array of bottles and then after stirring expecting	a new wonder drug inevitably to result?	5.0794247273757565
399.    what of the efficiency	of this natural instrument of free discussion?	5.226306406730656
400.  is there some	magic in it that assures results?	8.652016304207722
401.    when peter b kyne	informed us in 1921 that we had an instinctive	dislike for the japanese did the heated debates of the californians	settle the truth or falsity of the proposition?	3.847719523496325
402.    the	leopard's spots came from the pen of thomas dixon in 1902	and in this he announced an unchangeable law.	5.829360554885174
403. if a child had	a single drop of negro blood he would revert to the ancestral line which	except as slaves under a superior race had not made one step of	progress in 3000 years.	3.856857340852151
404. that doctrine has been accepted by many but	has it produced good results?	6.543411409695642
405.    in the same vein a certain	short-story plot has been overworked.	6.036658669593168
406. the son and heir of a prominent	family marries a girl who has tell-tale shadows on the half-moons of	her finger nails.	5.5403310753232065
407. in time she presents her aristocratic husband with	a coal-black child.	5.111633708755669
408. is the world better for having this idea thrust upon	it?	8.031646573088828
409.  will argument and debate decide its truth or falsity?	5.564802744233753
410. 	for answers to such questions we must turn to the anthropologists	the biologists the historians the psychologists and the sociologists.	5.490937834041936
411. long ago they consigned the notions of kyne and dixon to the scrap	heap.	4.73626395038947
412. false ideas surfeit another sector of our life.	7.089841267945196
413. for	several generations much fiction has appeared dealing with the steprelationship.	5.0796757809000415
414. the stepmother almost without exception has been presented	as a cruel ogress.	5.506908456901043
415. children conditioned by this mistaken notion	have feared stepmothers while adults by their antagonistic attitudes	have made the role of the substitute parents a difficult one.	3.9905686328264047
416. debate	is not likely to resolve the tensions and make the lot of the stepchild	a happier one.	6.346871299028434
417. research on the other hand has shown many stepmothers	to be eminently successful some far better than the real mothers.	4.828292740750911
418. helen deutsch informed us	that in all cultures the term 'stepmother'	automatically evokes deprecatory implications a conclusion accepted	by many.	5.368720319504203
419. will mere debate on that proposition even though it be	free and untrammeled remove the dross and leave a residue of refined	gold?	4.389896519463562
420.  that is questionable to say the least.	8.957861795896598
421. research into several	cultures has proven her position to be a mistaken one.	5.34204388271798
422. most	assuredly ideas are invaluable.	8.978076491592427
423. but ideas just for the sake of having	them are not enough.	5.291128941791104
424. in the 1930's cures for the depression literally	flooded washington.	7.1278079600476945
425. for a time the president received hundreds	of them every day most of them worthless.	6.193536553063118
426. ideas need to be	tested and not merely by argument and debate.	6.693413162276938
427. when some question arises	in the medical field concerning cancer for instance we do not	turn to free and open discussion as in a political campaign.	4.059293662251131
428. we have	recourse to the scientifically-trained specialist in the laboratory.	7.172454775627937
429. the	merits of the salk anti-polio vaccine were not established on the	forensic platform or in newspaper editorials but in the laboratory	and by tests in the field on thousands of children.	4.119284994968473
430. our presidential	campaigns provide much debate and argument.	7.980997087745906
431. but is the result	new barnsful of tested knowledge on the basis of which we can with confidence	solve our domestic and international problems?	4.602507267281483
432.  man we are	told is endowed with reason and is capable of distinguishing good from	bad.	6.588160950671553
433. but what a super-herculean task it is to winnow anything of value	from the mud-beplastered arguments used so freely particularly since	such common use is made of cliches and stereotypes in themselves	declarations of intellectual bankruptcy.	3.9523844582432153
434. we are reminded however	that freedom of thought and discussion the unfettered exchange	of ideas is basic under our form of government.	5.794073306306094
435. assuredly in	our political campaigns there is freedom to think to examine any and	all issues and to speak without restraint.	3.9232053341390984
436. but	have the results been heartening?	8.18656221502958
437.  may we state with confidence that	in such an exhibition a republic will find its greatest security?	4.099633098637963
438. 	we must not forget to be sure that free discussion and debate	have produced beneficial results.	6.795696819098287
439. in truth we can say that this broke	the power of senator joseph mccarthy who was finally exposed	in full light to the american people.	4.281980526592391
440. if he had been liquidated	in some way he would have become a martyr a rallying point for people	who shared his ideas.	7.388609738578666
441. debate in the political arena can be productive	of good.	4.908640007301714
442. but it is a clumsy and wasteful process: it can produce	negative results but not much that is positive.	7.185476579989451
443. debate rid us of	mccarthy but did not give us much that is positive.	5.029792563993042
444. it did something	to clear the ground but it erected no striking new structure; it	did not even provide the architect's plan for anything new.	5.3412299895949245
445. in the field of the natural sciences scientifically verified data are	quite readily available and any discussion can be shortened with good	results.	4.655032325141435
446. in the field of the social sciences a considerable fund of	tested knowledge has been accumulated that can be used to good advantage.	7.457697337550438
447. by no means would we discourage the production of ideas:	they provide raw materials with which to work; they provide stimulations	that lead to further production.	4.598452185023279
448. we would establish no censorship.	10.646346090327292
449. the president's personality would have opened that office to him.	4.200697917275358
450. and for the first time a representative of the highest office in the	land would have been liable to the charge that he had attempted to make	it a successorship by inheritance.	7.410635955511674
451. it is testimony to the deep respect	in which mr eisenhower was held by members of all parties that	the moral considerations raised by his approach to the matter were	not explicitly to be broached.	3.841815967878854
452. these began to be apparent in a	press conference held during the second illness in order that the consulting	specialists might clarify the president's condition for the	nation.	5.6089285426202355
453. and if howard rutstein felt impelled thereafter to formulate	the ethics of the medical profession his article in the atlantic	monthly accomplished a good deal more.	4.5578135093574605
454. it forced us to fix the responsibility	for the position in which all medical commentators had been	placed.	6.052599766277777
455. the discussion of professional ethics inevitably reminded	us that in the historical perspective the president's decision will	finally clarify itself as a moral rather than a medical problem.	4.029552579716923
456. because	the responsibility for resolving the issue lay with the president	rather than with his doctors nothing raises more surely for us	the difficulties simple goodness faces in dealing with complex moral problems	under political pressure.	4.86658010936621
457. for the president had dealt with the	matter humbly in what he conceived as the democratic way.	4.878416799075077
458. but the	problem is one which gives us the measure of a man rather than a group	of men whether a group of doctors a group of party members assembled	at a dinner to give their opinion or the masses of the voters.	5.7845766491081605
459. any attempt to reconcile this statement of the central issue in	the campaign of 1956 with the nature of the man who could not conceive	it as the central issue will at least resolve our confusions about the	chaotic and misleading results of the earnestness of both doctors and	president in a situation which should never have arisen.	4.01796779291438
460. it was a	response to the conflict between political pressure and the moral intuition	which resulted in attempts at prediction.	5.910703310745432
461. in no other situation	would a group of doctors struggling competently to improve the life	expectancy of a man beloved by the world be subjected to such merciless	and persistent questioning and before they were prepared to demonstrate	the kind of verbal precision which alone can clarify for mankind	the problems it faces.	3.6726142901433643
462. and though we can look back now and see their	errors we can look back also to the ultimate error.	5.546666558647055
463. it recurred	in the press conferences: the president's remarks about his running	developed a singular tone one which we find in few statements	made by public individuals on such a matter.	3.8924613163404143
464. the press conference became	a stage which betrayed the drift of his private thinking rather than	his convictions.	5.179076612968885
465. he commented- thoughtfully a reporter told us-	that it was not too important for the individual how he ends up.	4.390469241873004
466. he gave us a simile to explain his admission that even at the worst	period of his second illness it never occurred to him there was any	renewed question about his running: as in the battle of the bulge	he had no fears about the outcome until he read the american newspapers.	5.288882106295726
467. yet the attitude that the fate of the presidency demands in such	a situation is quite distinct from the simple courage that can proceed	with battles to be fought regardless of the consequences.	4.042361556991696
468. in this	case others should not have had to raise the doubts and fears.	7.30564286469221
469. the	presidency demands an incisive awareness of the larger implications	of the death of any incumbent.	5.283874721796487
470. it is of the utmost importance to the	people of america and of the world how their governing president ends	up during the four years of his term.	6.81061730925989
471. only when that term is	ended and he is a private citizen again can he be permitted the freedom	and the courage to discount the dangers of his death.	4.502805911465795
472. ironically enough	in this instance such personal virtues were a luxury.	6.328219112561903
473. at	the national and international level then what is the highest kind	of morality for the private citizen represents an instance of political	immorality.	4.1999034983478225
474. and we had the uneasy sense that the cleavage between the	moral and the political progressed amid the events which concern us.	5.913512036697489
475. for the tone of the editorials which greeted mr eisenhower's	original announcement of his running had been strangely disquieting.	4.376226280713762
476. neither the vibrant enthusiasm which bespeaks a people's intuitive	sense of the fitness of things at climactic moments nor the vital argumentation	betraying its sense that something significant has transpired	was in evidence.	5.0456458315219805
477. nothing testifies more clearly to that cleavage than	the peculiar editorial page appearing in a july issue of life magazine	the issue which also carried the second announcement of the	candidacy.	3.813413654810405
478. the double editorial on two aspects of the u s	spirit was subtly calculated to suggest a moral sanction for gambles	great as well as small reflecting popular approval of this questionable	attitude toward the highest office in the land.	5.170573946827415
479. the moral	creed and the will to risk live happily together if we	do not examine where the line is to be drawn.	3.980022550360199
480. i may possibly be a	greater risk than is the normal person of my age the president had	said on february 29th of the election year ignoring the fact that	no one of his age had ever lived out another term.	5.050084459498972
481. my doctors assure	me that this increased percentage of risk is not great.	4.7848397027513805
482. but by	the time the risk was doubled events had dismissed from his mind both	increased percentages and a previously stated intention of considering	carefully anything more serious than a bout of influenza.	4.889927286386058
483. only infrequently	did the situation color his thinking.	6.257549499398021
484. ironically no president	we have had would have regretted more than president eisenhower the	possibility to which his own words in the press conference held at	the beginning of august testified: that unable as he was himself	to say his running was best for the country unconsciously he had placed	his party before his nation.	4.729488033212702
485. so it is that we relive his opening	statement in the first television address with the dramatic immediacy	of the present.	5.663005591113364
486. no consideration of risk urges itself upon him	now: for this is what the mind does with the ideas on which it has not	properly focussed.	6.281944856149096
487. yet with a mind less shallow if less sharp than	some of the fortune-happy syndicates which back him he feels what	he cannot formulate; and we watch him amid the overtones which suggest	he could never in any conscience urge a risk upon the voters.	3.4802359437154844
488. moving	as he is into the phase of the campaign which demands conviction of	him he adopts a position that is morally indefensible.	5.22382164177904
489. he ascribes	to the mercy of god the peace which this personal matter- the assurance	that he can physically sustain the burden of the office longer	than any individual in the history of our nation has been able to do-	has brought him.	4.137885500129091
490. what is simply an opinion formed in defiance of the	laws of human probability whether or not it is later confirmed has	become by september of the election year a firm conviction.	5.694649366116316
491. as	a means of silencing a discussion which ought to have taken place the	statement is an effective one: we sympathize with the universal confusion	which gives rise to such convictions.	3.9027196485388536
492. but it is also the climax	to one of the absorbing chapters in our current political history.	8.61244341168056
493. in assigning to god the responsibility which he learned could	not rest with his doctors eisenhower gave evidence of that weakening	of the moral intuition which was to characterize his administration	in the years to follow.	3.653096281152304
494. in any other man this reassurance to the electorate	would have caused us a profound moral shock.	6.07472526752081
495. about this man we	had to think twice.	6.207420141660314
496. we knew that it was as reassurance the ironic	fruit of a deeply moral nature.	6.847653787830493
497. but the fact remains that even the unconscious	acceptance of himself as a man of destiny divinely protected	must be censored in any man who evades the responsibility for his major	decisions and thus for imposing his will on the people.	4.290166611160551
498. and in the	context of drifting personal utterances we have examined there was	occasional evidence of the origin of all such evasions.	5.928166786862054
499. when the possibility	that he had not given reconsideration to so weighty a decision	seemed	to disconcert his questioners mr eisenhower was known to	make his characteristic statement to the press that he was not going	to talk about the matter any more.	4.208677120458013
500. thinking had stopped; it was not	to be resumed.	6.806723317680827
501. the portrait that had developed fragmentarily	but consistently was the portrait of a man to whom serious thinking	is alien enough that the making of a decision inhibits when it does not	forestall any ability to review the decision in the light of new evidence.	3.9266702639331332
502. this does not mean that the decision to run for office should	inevitably have been revoked.	6.833616861303515
503. instead it means that the thinking in	which decision issues has the power to determine the morality of the	decision as in this instance the pressure for renewed practical or legislative	attention to the constitutional problems the decision had uncovered	might have done.	4.118079853649343
504. drifting through a third illness apparently	without any provision for the handling of a major national emergency	other than a talk with the vice-president eisenhower revealed the singularly	static quality of his thinking.	4.949478974674249
505. despite three warnings no	sense of moral urgency impelled him to distinguish his situation and	thus his responsibilities from wilson's.	4.250527342589094
506. by contrast the	energetic reaction of the leader to the full demands his decision imposes	upon him strengthens the moral intuition and gives us the measure	of the man.	5.495887886026438
507. only by means of an intensive preoccupation with the detailed	considerations following from any decision can he ensure attention	to the practical details to be dealt with if the implications of immorality	in the major decision are effectively to be checked.	3.9185164689571437
508. in the	incessant struggle with recalcitrant political fact he learns to focus	the essence of a problem in the significant detail and to articulate	the distinctions which clarify the detail as significant with what	is sometimes astounding rapidity.	5.1165147261182105
509. like lincoln he can distinguish	his relation to god from the constitutional responsibilities a questionable	decision exacts of him.	4.3396113034002575
510. like roosevelt he can distinguish an	attitude toward a russian leader he may share with a host of americans	from the responsibilities diplomatic convention may impose upon him.	5.245506757996035
511. he chooses to subordinate one to the other sometimes reluctantly	accepting criticism for the lesser immoralities facts breed.	4.753418289012987
512. the very	nature of a choice so grounded in distinction and fact leads to the	valid convictions which become force of will in the manifest leader.	4.698723859097317
513. the capacity for making the distinctions of which diplomacy is compact	and the facility with language which can render them into validity	in the eyes of other men are the leader's means for transforming the	moral intuition into moral leadership.	3.541882303977171
514. the making of distinctions	like the perception of the great distinctions made is an inordinately	difficult business.	6.001018188517631
515. lincoln's slow progress towards the several	marking his achievement is even now unrecognizable as such and loosely	interpreted as the alternation of inconsistency with vision.	3.777206378781194
516. but	because it is the function of the mind to turn the one into the other	by means of the capacities with which words endow it we do not unwisely	examine the type of distinction in the sphere of politics on which	decisions hang.	5.782470114693109
517. only recently and perhaps because a television debate	can so effectively dramatize president kennedy's extraordinary	mastery of detail have the abilities on which the capacity for making	distinctions depend begun to be clearly discernible at the level of	politics.	4.0131149312663945
518. in his recent evaluation of kennedy's potentialities for	leadership walter lippmann has cited the precision of his mind	his immense command of factual detail and his instinct for	the crucial point as impressive in the extreme; and it is surely	clear that the first of these is the result of the way in which the	individual's command of language interacts with the other two.	5.91321888224582
519. for this change is not a change from one positive position to another	but a change from order and truth to disorder and negation.	4.511407658978617
520. the	liberal-conservative	division we might observe in passing is not of itself	directly involved in a private interest conflict nor even in struggle	between ruling groups.	5.51250816386447
521. rather it is rooted in a difference of response	to the threat of social disintegration.	4.914727848790595
522. the division is not between	those who wish to preserve what they have and those who want change.	6.600599335715112
523. rather it is a division established by two absolutely different ways	of thought with regard to man's life in society.	4.831253758492405
524. these ways are	absolutely irreconcilable because they offer two different recipes for	man's redemption from chaos.	5.926388378734927
525. the civilizational crisis the	third type of change raises the question what are we to do?	3.960945817527352
526. 	on the most primitive level.	8.18656221502958
527. for the answer cannot be derived from any	socially cohesive element in the disrupting community.	4.916964956023117
528. there is no	socially existential answer to the question.	9.156840330164158
529. for the truth formerly experienced	by the community no longer has existential status in the community	nor does any answer elaborated by philosophers or theoriticians.	4.058172256552045
530. in this phase of change no idea has social acceptance and so none	has ontological status in the community.	5.814053034320085
531. an interregnum ensues in which	not men but ideas compete for existence.	4.8657498275719115
532. if we examine the	three types of change from the point of view of their internal structure	we find an additional profound difference between the third and the	first two one that accounts for the notable difference between the	responses they evoke.	5.759753578221466
533. the first two types of change occur within the	inward and immanent structure of the society.	5.0451672426647445
534. the first involves a simple	shift of interests in the society.	6.635711301278465
535. the second involves something	deeper but its characteristic form focuses on a shift in policy for	the community not in the truth on which the community rests.	4.3051318996812045
536. thus in	both types attention is focused on the community itself and its phenomenological	life.	6.335376808678853
537. the third type however wrenches attention from	the life of action and interests in the community and focuses it on the	ground of being on which the community depends for its existence.	3.9630194142788775
538. voegelin	has analyzed this experience in the case of the stable healthy	community.	8.227171719488092
539. there the community faced with the need to formulate policy	on the level of absolute justice can find the answer to its problem	in the absolute truth which it holds as partially experienced.	4.4859273413717835
540. this	however cannot be done by a community whose very experience of truth	is confused and incoherent: it has no absolute standard and consequently	cannot distinguish the absolute from the contingent.	5.121934330609104
541. it has	lost its ground of being and floats in a mist of appearances.	4.726305979836047
542. relativism	and equality are its characteristic diseases.	7.603896187885215
543. precisely at the moment	when it has lost its vision the mind of the community turns out	from itself in a search for the ontological standard whereby it can measure	itself.	4.124226519378827
544. for paradigmatic history breaks rather than unfolds	precisely when the movement is from order to disorder and not from	one order to a new order.	5.64069330826276
545. the liberal-conservative split to define	it further derives from a basic difference concerning the existential	status of standard sought and about the spiritual experience that leads	to its identification.	3.652991529258859
546. when disruptive change has penetrated	to the third level of social order the process of disruption rapidly	reaches a point of no return.	6.168078047703237
547. indeed it is probable that this point	is reached the moment the third level of change begins.	4.794145207271667
548. at that point	we reach the closed historical situation: the situation in	which man is no longer free to return to a status quo ante.	6.324592159409745
549. at that	point men become aware of the mystery of history called variously fate	or destiny or providence and feel themselves	caught helplessly in the writhing of a disrupted society.	4.26358825664759
550. the reasons	for this experience are rooted in the metaphysical characteristics of	such a change.	5.366195161938785
551. of all forms of being society or community	has the greatest element of determinability.	5.236151102699976
552. its ontological status is	itself most tenuous because apart from individual men who are its matter	tradition the form of society exists only as a shared	perception of truth.	5.974091461265218
553. the ontological status of society thus is constituted	by the psychological-intellectual-volitional status of society's	members.	3.93777821379478
554. the content of that psychological status determines	ultimately the content of civilization.	6.286985459309962
555. those social civilizational	factors not rooted in the human spirit of the group ultimately cease	to exist.	5.505761957201393
556. civilization itself- tradition- falls out of existence	when the human spirit itself becomes confused.	5.7836982265615156
557. civilization is what	man has made of himself.	5.3285636594893
558. its massive contours are rooted in the simple	need of man since he is always incomplete to complete himself.	5.740304293160128
559. it is not enough for man to be an ontological esse.	6.794061790742046
560. he needs existential	completion he needs that is to move in the direction of completion.	7.1096309603247505
561. and the direction of that movement is determined by his perception	of the truth about himself.	5.117618747847185
562. he must consequently exist as a	self-perceived substantive developing agent or he does not exist as	man.	7.440527353375066
563. thus it is no mystical intuition but an analyzable conception	to say that man and his tradition can fall out of existence.	4.340248988527027
564. this	happens at the moment man loses the perception of moral substance	in himself of a nature that in maritain's words is perceived as	a locus of intelligible necessities.	5.25558722521868
565. an existentialist is a man	who perceives himself only as esse as existence without substance.	4.466845978350164
566. thus human perception and human volition is the immanent	cause of all social change and this most truly when the change reaches	the civilizational level.	5.299620380403096
567. thus with regard to the loss of tradition	in the change from order to disorder the metaphysics of change works	itself out as a disruption of the individual soul a change in which man	continues as an objective ontological existent but no longer as a	man.	4.183332145108756
568. further change is a form of motion it occurs as the act	of a being in potency insofar as it is in potency and has not yet reached	the terminus of the change.	5.917300152150241
569. with regard to the change we are examining	the question is at what point does the change become irreversible?	4.750881147551966
570. 	a number of considerations suggest that this occurs early in	the process.	6.093123995732186
571. change involves the displacement of form.	6.315558421768847
572. this means that	the inception of change itself can begin only when the factors conducive	to change have already become more powerful than those anchoring	the existent form in being.	5.210873769725668
573. if the existent form is to be retained new	factors that reinforce it must be introduced into the situation.	5.229890370896008
574. in	the case of social decay form is displaced simply by the process of	dissolution with no form at the terminus of the process.	5.3231915568540105
575. now in the	mere fact of the beginning of such displacement we have prima-facie evidence	of the ontological weakness of the fading form.	4.80060074510528
576. and when we consider	the tenuous hold tradition has on existence any weakening of that	hold constitutes a crisis of existence.	6.008924650973398
577. the retention of a tradition	confronted with such a crisis necessitates the introduction of new	spiritual forces into the situation.	3.929403242715979
578. however the crisis occurs precisely	as a weakening of spiritual forces.	7.491293877062617
579. it would seem therefore that	in a civilizational crisis man cannot save himself.	5.59786339536187
580. the emergence	of the crisis itself would seem to constitute a warranty for the victory	of disorder.	5.713334351000642
581. and it would seem that history is a witness to this	truth.	5.784197047028139
582. as a further characterization of the liberal conservative	split we may observe that it involves differences in the formula for	escaping inevitabilities in history.	5.982470506725381
583. these differences in turn derive	from prior differences concerning the friendly or hostile character	of change.	4.411633295274241
584. anxiety and deep insecurity	are the characteristic responses evoked by the crisis in tradition.	5.7836982265615156
585. to experience them it is not necessary for a people to be actively	aware of what is happening to it.	5.335027915560294
586. the process of erosion need only	undermine the tradition and a series of consequences begin unfolding	within the individual while in institutions a quiet but deep transformation	of processes occurs.	5.443420876745886
587. within the individual the reaction has been	called various names all however pointing to the same basic experience.	4.871787224202066
588. weil identifies it as being rootless guardini as being	placeless riesman as being lonely.	5.7836982265615156
589. others call it alienation	and mean by that no simple economic experience	but a deep spiritual sense of dislocation.	4.321626463250261
590. within institutions	there is a marked decline of the process of persuasion and the substitution	of a force-fear process which masquerades as the earlier one	of persuasion.	5.864267734468828
591. we note the use of rhetoric as a weapon the manipulation	of the masses by propaganda the mobilization of effort and	resources.	4.565549884868785
592. within this context of spontaneous and unanalyzed	responses to the experience of civilizational crisis two basic organizations	of response are observable: reaction and ideological progressivism.	5.900499988092923
593. these responses are explicable in terms of characteristics inherent	in the crisis.	5.587050334160066
594. both are predictably destined to fail.	9.543373652638747
595. the	response of reaction is dominated by a concern for what is vanishing.	4.52012790592672
596. its essence lies in its attempt to recover previous order through	the repression of disruptive forces.	5.941747700518562
597. to this end political authority	is called upon to exercise its negative and coercive powers.	4.862266268150484
598. the implicit	assumption of this response is that history is reversible.	5.643027344585572
599. seemingly	order is perceived as a kind of subsistent entity now covered by	adventitious accretions.	5.023380279278678
600. the problem is to remove the accretions and	thereby uncover the order that was always there.	6.229412071837298
601. such a response of	course misses the point that in crisis order is going out of existence.	4.812413651533481
602. moreover its posture of stubborn but simple resistance is doomed	to failure because of the metaphysical weakness of the existent form of	order once the activation of change has reached visible proportions.	5.389372437537448
603. the most reaction can achieve is stasis and a stasis that can be maintained	only by the expenditure of an effort which ultimately exhausts	itself.	4.074003384208211
604. despite the hopelessness of the response it is explicable	in terms of the crisis of tradition itself.	7.056190272241734
605. since a civilizational	crisis involves also a crisis in private interests and in the ruling	class reaction is normally found among those who feel themselves	to be among the ruling class.	4.181331977675531
606. their great error is to mingle the responses	typical of each of the three types of change.	6.745440451575591
607. since civilizational	change is the most difficult to perceive and analyze it seldom is	given adequate attention.	5.043151400155475
608. and the anxiety it generates is misinterpreted	as anxiety over private interest and threatened social status.	6.213271163606078
609. the basic truth in the reactionary response is to be found in its	realistic assumption of the primacy of the real over the ideational.	4.794750011790866
610. but this truth is distorted by its extreme application: the assumption	of the separate existence of tradition.	6.285286965777641
611. the reactionary misses	the point that tradition exists ontologically only in the form of	psychological-intellectual	relations.	5.060157263899384
612. reactionary theories for this reason	usually assume some form of organismic theory.	6.711551604951044
613. in its defensive	formulations the theory will attack conscious change on the grounds of	the independent existence of the community.	4.596529308943678
614. in its dynamic form it	visualizes the community as the embodiment of an ontological force-	the race for instance which unfolds in history.	5.590901441434432
615. in both cases the	individual tends to be treated as an instrument of the organic reality.	5.4666569615862475
616. when the reactionary response is thus bolstered by an intellectual	defense the characteristics of that defense are explicable only	in terms of the basic attitudes of unanalyzed reaction.	5.750332718831702
617. reaction is	rooted in a perception of tradition as a whole.	4.681571082223364
618. it is a total situation	that is defended: the good old days.	7.387880346600035
619. there is no selectivity;	even the questionable features of the past are defended.	6.526923577212336
620. the point	is that the reactionary for whatever motive perceives himself to	have been part or a partner of something that extended beyond himself	something which consequently he was not able to accept or reject	on the basis of subjective preference.	4.930553242817258
621. the reactionary is confused about	the existential status of a decaying tradition but he does perceive	the unity tradition had when it was healthy.	3.8008304176543137
622. all of which brings up another problem in the use of psychoanalytic	insight in a literary work.	8.124126477757036
623. is the oedipus complex the clinical	syndrome material for a tragedy?	5.728453863554091
624.  if we remove ourselves for a moment	from our time and our infatuation with mental disease isn't there	something absurd about a hero in a novel who is defeated by his infantile	neurosis?	5.134217080245011
625.  i am not making a clinical judgment here for such	personal tragedies are real and are commonplace in the analyst's	consulting room but literature makes a different claim upon our sympathies	than tragedy in life.	3.8130211968021737
626. a man in a novel who is defeated in his childhood	and condemned by unconscious forces within him to tiredly repeat	his earliest failure in love only makes us a little weary of man;	his tragedy seems unworthy and trivial.	4.917553402299183
627. now we can argue that	the irresistible fate of oedipus rex was nothing more than the irresistible	unconscious longings of oedipus projected outward but this	externalization of unconscious conflict makes all the difference between	a story and a clinical case history.	4.034381371059583
628. we can also argue that the	three brothers karamazov and smerdyakov were the external representatives	of an internal conflict within one man dostoevsky a conflict	having to	do with father-murder and the wish to possess the father's woman.	4.9768508573249095
629. but	a novel in which one man karamazov explored the divisions within	his personality would scarcely merit publication in the psychoanalytic	quarterly.	4.118041848849638
630. it is a mistake to look upon the oedipus of	oedipus complex as a literary descendant of oedipus rex.	6.119031084294002
631. whatever	the psychological truth in the oedipus myth an oedipus who is drawn	to his fate by irresistible external forces can carry the symbol of	humanity and its archaic crime and the incest that is unknowing renews	the mystery of the eternal dream of childhood and absorbs us in the	secret.	3.365448814554807
632. but a modern oedipus who is doomed because he cannot oppose	his own childhood is only pathetic and for renouncing the mystery	in favor of psychological truth he gives up the claim on our sympathies.	4.981696067893309
633. i am suggesting that a case-history approach to the oedipus	complex is a blind alley for a storyteller.	4.845940847723387
634. the best gifts of the novelist	will be wasted on the reader who is insulated against any surprises	the novelist may have in store for him.	5.101031029827239
635. incest is still a durable	theme but if it wants to get written about it will have to find ways	to surprise the emotions and there is no better way to do this than	that of concealment and symbolic representation.	4.893481881152941
636. and the best way to	conceal and disguise the elements of an incest story is not to set out	to write an incest story.	6.516169878767119
637. which brings to mind another lawrence story	and some interesting comparisons in the treatment of the oedipal	theme.	4.888770173751889
638. the rocking horse winner is also a story about	a boy's love for his mother.	5.647126556024358
639. if i now risk some comparisons with	sons and lovers let it be clear that i am not comparing the two	works or judging their merits; i am only singling out differences	in treatment of a theme and the resultant effects.	3.9256007807148294
640. the rocking horse	winner is a fantasy with extraordinary power to disturb the	reader- but we do not know why.	5.667750778818077
641. it is the story of the hopeless love	of a little boy for his cold and vain mother.	5.178583516631091
642. there are ghostly scenes	in which the little boy on his rocking horse rocks madly toward the	climax that will magically give him the name of the winning horse.	5.569580182119012
643. the	child grows rich on his winnings and conspires with his uncle to make	secret gifts of his money to his mother.	3.841511969386553
644. the story ends in the child's	illness and delirium brought on by the feverish compulsion to	ride his horse to win for his mother.	5.3365206370477365
645. the child dies with his mourning	mother at his bedside.	4.687736147225874
646. i had read the story many times without	asking myself why it affected me or caring why it did.	5.909999475302098
647. but on one	occasion when i encountered a similar fantasy in a little boy who was	my patient i began to understand the uncanny effects of this story.	4.067390480577937
648. it was of course a little boy's fantasy of winning his mother to	himself and replacing the father who could not give her the things she	wanted- a classical oedipal fantasy if you like- but if it were	only this the story would be banal.	5.1775528517662694
649. why does the story affect us?	6.902076960094791
650.  how	does the rocking exert its uncanny effect upon the reader?	6.53689853926529
651.  the	rocking is actually felt in the story a terrible and ominous rhythm that	prophesies the tragedy.	4.3862088763117875
652. the rocking i realized is the single element	in the story that carries the erotic message the unspoken and	unconscious undercurrent that would mar the innocence of a child's fantasy	and disturb the effects of the work if it were made explicit.	5.019836323711328
653. the	rocking has the ambiguous function of keeping the erotic undercurrent	silent and making it present; it conceals and yet is suggestive;	a perfect symbol.	3.9235927278058758
654. and if we understand the rocking as an erotic symbol	we can also see how well it serves as the symbol of impending tragedy.	6.089412067286183
655. for this love of the boy for his mother is a hopeless and forbidden	love doomed by its nature.	4.405590854190543
656. we are also struck by the fact	that this story of a boy's love for his mother does not offend while	the incestuous love of the man paul morel sometimes repels.	5.535386244083807
657. it's	easy to see why.	6.683325264329536
658. this love belongs to childhood; we accord it	its place there and in lawrence's treatment we are given the innocent	fantasy of a child in fact the form in which oedipal love is expressed	in childhood.	5.1049204886359645
659. and when the child dies in lawrence's story	in a delirium that is somehow brought on by his mania to win and to make	his mother rich the manifest absurdity of such a disease and such	a death does not enter into our thoughts at all.	3.925814648810016
660. we have so completely	entered the child's fantasy that his illness and his death are the	plausible and the necessary conclusion.	5.9804141927081425
661. i am sure that none	of the effects of this story were consciously employed by lawrence to	describe an oedipal fantasy in childhood.	4.698601602630068
662. it is most probable that	freud and the oedipus complex never entered his head in the writing	of this story.	5.964248697388575
663. he was simply writing a story that wanted to be told	and in the writing a childhood fantasy of his own emerged.	4.763526575832183
664. he would not	have cared why it emerged he only wanted to capture a memory to play	with it again in his imagination and somehow to fix and hold in the	story the disturbing emotions that accompanied the fantasy.	4.832022106675515
665. in	our own time we have seen that the novelist's debt to psychoanalysis	has increased but that the novel itself has not profited much from	this marriage.	4.1470158989693005
666. ortega's hope that modern psychology might yet bring	forth a last flowering of the novel has only been partially fulfilled.	5.259987859570164
667. the young writer seems intimidated by psychological knowledge; he	has lost confidence in his own eyes and in the validity of his own psychological	insights.	4.957120048503832
668. he borrows the insights of psychology to improve	his impaired vision but cannot bring to his work the distinctive vision	that should be a novelist's own.	5.444110644461038
669. he has been seduced by the marvels	of the unconscious and has lost interest in studying the surfaces	of character.	4.831142905687502
670. if many of the characters in contemporary novels appear	to be the bloodless relations of characters in a case history it is	because the novelist is often forgetful today that those things that	we call character manifest themselves in surface behavior that the ego	is still the executive agency of personality and that all we know of	personality must be discerned through the ego.	4.7198277652235054
671. the novelist who has	been badly baptized in psychoanalysis often gives us the impression that	since all men must have an oedipus complex all men must have the	same faces.	3.4918027873177544
672. i have argued that oedipus of the oedipus	complex has a doubtful future as a tragic figure in literature.	5.902310855349126
673. but a	writer who has a taste for irony and who sees incest in all its modern	dimensions can let his imagination work on the disturbing joke in the	incest myth the joke that strikes right at the center of man's humanness.	4.201693060992019
674. moral dread is seen as the other face of desire and here psychoanalysis	delivers to the writer a magnificent irony and a moral problem	of great complexity.	4.919953094486945
675. there is probably some significance	in the fact that two of the best incest stories i have encountered	in recent years are burlesques of the incest myth.	5.1049783386472
676. the ancient types	are reassembled in gloom and foreboding to be irresistibly drawn to their	destinies but the myth fails before the modern truth; the oracle	speaks false and the dream speaks true.	4.668006763047354
677. in both the farmer's tale	in ralph ellison's invisible man and in thomas mann's the	holy sinner the incest hero rises above the myth by accepting	the wish as motive; the heroic act is the casting off of pretense.	3.687681650763087
678. thomas mann wrote the holy sinner in 1951.	7.192756325807262
679. it was conceived	as a leave-taking a kind of melancholy gathering-in of the myths	of the west bevor die nacht sinkt eine lange nacht vielleicht	und ein tiefes vergessen.	4.120001989639191
680. he chose a medieval legend of	incest gregorius vom stein and freely borrowed and parodied other	myths of the west mixing themes language peoples and times in a master	myth in which the old forms continually renew themselves as in his	previous treatment of joseph.	5.051326848766227
681. but the holy sinner is	not simply a retelling of old stories for an old man's entertainment.	4.5240804713871725
682. mann understood better than most men the incest comedy at the center	of the myth and the psychological truth in which dread is shown as	the other face as longing was for him just the kind of deep and complicated	joke he liked to tell.	4.911567885292779
683. and when he retold the legend of gregorius	he interpolated a modern version in which the medieval players speak	contemporary thoughts in archaic language; while they move through	the pageantry of the ancient incest myth and cover themselves through	not-knowing they reveal the unconscious motive in seeking each other	and in the last scene make an extraordinary confession of guilt in the	twentieth-century manner.	3.632052352745411
684. grigorss is the child of an incestuous	union between a royal brother and sister the twins sibylla and	wiligis.	5.598594048870746
685. he is born in secrecy after the death of his father and cast	adrift soon after birth.	5.477620789442428
686. the infant is discovered by a fisherman who	brings him home to rear him.	5.289832921804139
687. an ivory tablet in the infant's cask	recounts the story of his sinful origins and is preserved for the child	by the monks of a monastery in the fishing village.	3.991701350065349
688. grigorss at	seventeen learns his story and goes forth as a knight to uncover his	origins.	5.762045355417663
689. his sailing vessel is guided by fate to the shores of his own	country at a time when sibylla's domain is overrun by the armies	of one of her rejected suitors.	4.09154634766224
690. grigorss overcomes the suitor in battle	delivers the city from its oppressors and marries sibylla who had	fallen in love with the beautiful knight the moment she saw him.	4.89531030083855
691. sibylla is pregnant with their second child when she finds the ivory	tablet concealed by her husband and the identities of mother and son	are revealed.	3.8976215830956664
692. grigorss goes off to do penance on a rock for seventeen	years.	6.093123995732186
693. at the end of this period two pious christians in rome receive	the revelation which leads them to seek the next pope on the rock.	4.495961999485463
694. grigorss comes to rome and becomes a great and beloved pope.	6.093123995732186
695. in	the last pages of the book sibylla comes to rome to seek an audience	with the great pope and to give her confession.	4.322040792908902
696. mother and son recognize	each other and in mann's version of this legend make a remarkable	confession of guilt to each other the confession of unconscious	motive and unconscious knowledge of their true identities from the	time they had first set eyes on each other.	4.7076844218482155
697. in recollection he has said: natural or man-made objects kept coming	into my head but i would suppress them sternly.	4.204840025513765
698. moreover	he organized the movement of his forms within his rigorously shaped space	into highly complex equilibriums; and used gradations of color	value as well as sharply contrasting elementary colors.	5.374258651899197
699. the worthy	mondrian seeing these pictures said in a tone of kindly reproof:	but you are really an artist of the naturalistic tradition!	helion did not realize it at the time but it was true.	4.116838184930486
700. his	monumental abstraction made up of smooth metallic non-objects	acting upon each other with great tension won helion much	acclaim during the 'thirties.	5.530303556928633
701. the play of novel lighting effects also	entered into these compositions whose controlled power and varied	activity made them well worth meditating.	3.605962185644203
702. as helion's work	showed more and more nostalgia for the world of man and nature the pure	abstractionists expressed some disapproval; but leger arp lipchitz	and alexander calder at the time gave him their blessing.	5.9581966810022235
703. his	canvases nowadays bore titles frankly declaring them to be figures	in space or blue figure or pink figure; and	they had heads and feet.	3.843981842855102
704. exhibited in shows in london in	1935 and in new york the following year the new more elaborated	abstracts were much favored in the circles of the modernists as three-dimentional	dramas of great intellectual coherence.	5.0939235011147685
705. at this period	the thirty-year old helion was ranked as one of the mature leaders	of the modern movement according to herbert read and in the	direct line of descent from cezanne seurat gris and leger.	4.162995474249385
706. in	america meyer schapiro observed that unlike the mondrian school	helion sought a return path to the fullness of nature within the	framework of abstract art.	5.004173005508399
707. it is notable that at this time	he was writing with admiration of cimabue's and poussin's way	of filling space.	4.1564372158642655
708. abstract art was still the right path for him; but	he	held instead of continuing as an art of reduction it must grow	must make a place for the contributions of the raphaels and poussins	as well as for those of the early cubists and mondrian.	5.341571885534955
709. later	helion wrote of this phase: for years i built for myself	a subtle instrument of relationships- colors and forms without a name.	3.8659789941192084
710. i played on it my secret songs unexplained passionate and peaceful.	6.535629654039423
711. but his own work was evolving further.	6.467548231715819
712. the extreme limitations	he sensed in all current abstract art made that seem to him increasingly	arid and cold.	5.13675376062788
713. he was engaged in constant experiments that	searched for new directions.	5.519824192300624
714. where would it all lead?	9.971831355879885
715.  he himself	did not know as he said in 1935.	5.252864107177152
716. but he was afraid of the future-	he would in fact welcome a way back to social integration a functional	art of some kind.	5.786527179210385
717. during the 1920's the abstractionists	the german bauhaus group of industrial designers and the new	architects all had the dream of some well ordered utopia or welfare	state in which their neat and logical constructions might find their	proper place.	3.637157950496672
718. but whereas the postwar american abstractionists seem	to helion to be determined to escape from the real world or simply	to rebel against it the ordered abstractions which he and his	associates of the 1930's were painting embodied the hope of improving	things.	5.076215633264173
719. we were possessed by visions of a new civilization	to come very pure and elevated he has said in fact some ideal	form of socialism such as we had dreamed of since the war of 1914-1918.	4.200057667552675
720. instead of this the 1930's witnessed a tragic economic	depression the rise of fascist dictators in europe the wasting	civil war in spain.	5.601866450089384
721. very much the political man helion felt himself	deeply affected by the increasingly pessimistic atmosphere of france	and all europe whose foundations seemed to him more and more shaky.	4.237292943425052
722. in 1936 he decided to migrate to america.	7.712287370161345
723. the rooseveltian america	was a haven of liberalism and progress and seemed to him to constitute	the last best hope for civilization.	3.745215610467047
724. helion also hoped that	america's mastery of technology and industrial efficiency would be	accompanied by the production of new and beautiful art works.	5.389116624094432
725. i arrived	in the united states with the idea of establishing myself there	more or less permanently and finding inspiration for new compositions.	5.039760471882651
726. in new york he was well received by what was then only	a small brave band of non-figurative artists including alexander calder	george k l morris de kooning holty and a few others.	5.644354892952186
727. after a year in a studio on sheridan square having married an	american girl who was a native of virginia helion moved to a village	in the blue ridge mountains where he produced some of the most	imposing of his abstract canvases.	4.146827829732849
728. the darkening world scene	at the time of the munich pact continued to trouble his mind even in	his remote virginia studio.	5.466256772127599
729. fear possessed me and the certainty	of war he has related.	5.017428852854806
730. i truly smelled blood death heaps of	corpses everywhere.	7.430146395037167
731. in haste he labored to finish some last abstract	paintings: a three-panel frieze with a flying figure and a fallen	figure; a double-figure which went to the chicago art	institute and is considered by him the most successful of his abstracts;	and in early 1939 a fallen figure of very ominous character	which concluded his abstract phase.	3.581360449425205
732. i knew i was carrying	on with abstraction to its very end- for me he said of the two	years' output in virginia.	5.747137976622466
733. with those paintings of big constructions	crashing down he felt he could stop.	4.867013367825509
734. they were in effect his last	testament to non-objective art.	8.217429565858046
735. he had taken out first papers	for american citizenship; but after war came to europe he decided	to return to france arriving there in january 1940.	4.047101943663938
736. i hated	the war he said but thought i ought to go because i was perhaps	one of those who hadn't done enough to prevent it.	5.948879804651741
737. in june 1940 sergeant helion with a company of reserve troops waiting	to go into battle was sketching the hills south of the loire	river when the war suddenly rolled in upon him.	3.8681699742442666
738. its first apparition	was a long gloomy column of refugees riding in farm wagons or pushing	prams.	5.938773946509162
739. his company then carried out a confused retreating movement	until it was surrounded by the germans a few days before france capitulated.	4.3089696759914435
740. after a sort of death march during four days without food	helion and his comrades were shipped by cattle-car to a labor camp	at an estate farm in east germany.	5.535428537004741
741. a year later they were removed to	a stalag in the harbor of stettin.	5.212699550125515
742. at the time of his capture helion	had on his person a sketchbook he had bought at woolworth's in	new york.	6.724268031990166
743. when he was stripped deloused and numbered by his guards	his much-thumbed sketchbook was seized and thrown on a pile of prisoners'	goods to be confiscated.	4.256585952623009
744. it was then i knew that they were	making war against man the individual within!- who questioned	things when given orders.	5.811224889190829
745. at stettin the university-educated	artist who had studied german was chosen to serve as interpreter	and clerk in the office of the stalag commander.	4.689755125798008
746. in secret he also	acted as a member of the prisoners' central committee which plotted	sabotage planned a few escapes and maintained a hidden control over	the wretched french slave-laborers.	5.450827362084791
747. in the stalag helion	came to know and love his comrades most of them plain folk who in	their extremity showed true courage and ran great risks to help each	other.	3.9984520866983906
748. how much they esteemed him is shown by the fact that their underground	committee selected him as one of the few who would be helped	to escape.	7.103667553793056
749. in the prison camp's black market civilian clothes were	quietly bought and forged papers were devised for him; during long	weeks the plan for his flight was rehearsed.	3.7769624810712785
750. every morning	contingents of prisoners would be sent out to labor in nearby factories.	6.412233393147007
751. one evening while a volley-ball game was being played in the yard	among the prisoners remaining there a simulated melee was staged-	just as the gates were opened to admit other prisoners returning from	work.	3.6384863896270114
752. as helion wrote afterward:   their sentry followed	h four hands were stretched toward me by my comrades behind me.	5.629030617195874
753. marquet	held my briefcase; finot held a wallet with my money and papers;	moineau and david held nothing but their fingers h they felt	rough and kind and warm.	3.68775399310451
754. at this moment the volley-ball hit the ground.	9.215859424252136
755. duclos ran toward desprez with fists raised.	5.3285636594893
756. the guards all	rushed up to intervene h   shedding his prison cloak helion	shot through the gates now clad in civilian garments and with the	passport of a flemish worker.	4.616185526079841
757. riding trains hitching hikes on trucks	across germany slipping through guarded frontiers with the help of	secret guides he eventually reached vichy france and by the winter	of 1943 was back in virginia.	3.910450752820992
758. he wrote:   to escape from	a prison camp required a very special state of mind; not only loathing	of captivity but a faith a hope that is even stronger.	4.945258578377656
759. i left	behind me brave men whom captivity had robbed of all hope.	4.711609050204151
760. they too	loved their families longed for their villages: yet lacked the faith	that drove one to dare h the fearful chance of escape.	5.21437600263385
761. it was a time of revelations for him.	6.940746137246689
762. even the most rational of men	under great stress may be transported by a new faith and behave like	mystics.	6.778724118784346
763. helion knew that he owed his freedom as much to the self-sacrifice	of his fellow-men in arbeitskommando 13 stettin as to	his own fierce	will and love of life.	3.9701640087045353
764. after that he declared to return to	freedom was to fall to one's knees before the real world and adore	it.	5.697261940649579
765. in prison he had been able to sketch nothing but figures from	life his guards his companions in misery.	4.942602490347622
766. now all his desires centered	on rediscovering and singing of the prosaic and yet beautiful	world of men and objects so long barred from me by a barbed wire fence.	5.0361009067344416
767. and he added: during the many months in prison camp all	abstract images vanished from my mind.	4.593958408738386
768. before leaving for america	he happened to see his old friend jean arp and confided to	him his new resolutions.	5.868445069450208
769. arp protested: but it is impossible!	everything in the way of representation has already been done by the	old masters.	5.427741175541614
770. helion however clung to the belief that in escaping	from the stalag i had also escaped from abstraction.	6.075372978967674
771. while convalescing in his virginia home he wrote a book recording	his prison experiences and escape entitled: they shall not have	me h published originally in english by dutton	+ co of new york in 1943 the book was received by the press	as a work of astonishing literary power and one of the most realistic	accounts of world war 2 from the french side.	4.197069775308952
772. it was very widely	read too; and the author who seemed the embodiment of france's	rising spirit of resistance to her conquerors was much complimented	for his daring military action.	5.171125939702109
773. but when he showed his new figurative	pictures to his artist friends of the abstract camp they paid him	no compliments and drew long faces.	4.128353550933639

783. if he	sees the heroic in a sartoris or a sutpen he sees also- and he	shows- the blind and the mean and he sees the compson family disintegrating	from within.	3.805623580307793

793. he has employed from	his section rich immediate materials which in a loose sense can be termed	southern.	4.571486595540816
794. the fact that he has cast over those materials the light	of a skeptical mind does not make him any the less southern i rather	think for the south has been no more solid than other regions except	in the political and related areas where patronage and force and	intimidation and fear may produce a surface uniformity.	5.228504457070233
795. some of us might	be inclined to argue in fact that an independence of mind and action	and an intolerance of regimentation either mental or physical	are particularly southern traits.	4.236375856262414

799. the young william faulkner	in new orleans in the 1920's impressed the novelist hamilton	basso as obviously conscious of being a southerner and there is no	evidence that since then he has ever considered himself any less so.	3.7278326799562107
800. besides showing no inclination apparently to absent himself from his	native region even for short periods and in addition writing a shelf	of books set in the region he has handled in those books an astonishingly	complete list of matters which have been important in the south	during the past hundred years.	4.9271929436826865
801. it is more difficult with faulkner	than with most authors to say what is the extent and what is	the source of his knowledge.	4.743479648801278
802. his own testimony is that he has read very	little in the history of the south implying that what he knows of	that history has come to him orally and that he knows the world around	him primarily from his own unassisted observation.	6.088958693697647
803. his denials of extensive	reading notwithstanding it is no doubt safe to assume that he	has spent time schooling himself in southern history and that he has	gained some acquaintance with the chief literary authors who have lived	in the south or have written about the south.	3.8691678413082586
804. to believe otherwise	would be unrealistic.	9.234244616425169

809. my intention therefore is not to say that faulkner's awareness	has been confined within the borders of the south but rather that	he has looked at his world as a southerner and that presumably his outlook	is southern.	4.3009169270176
810. the ingredients of faulkner's novels and	stories are by no means new with him and most of the problems he takes	up have had the attention of authors before him.	6.123825915205746
811. a useful comment	on his relation to his region may be made i think by noting briefly	how in handling southern materials and southern problems he has deviated	from the pattern set by other southern authors while remaining	faithful to the essential character of the region.	3.535532447234592
812. the planter	aristocracy has appeared in literature at least since john pendleton	kennedy published swallow-barn in 1832 and in his genial portrait	of frank meriwether presiding over his plantation dominion initiated	the most persistent tradition of southern literature.	4.6733591971611945
813. the thoroughgoing	idealization of the planter society did not come however	until after the civil war when southern writers were eager to defend	a way of life which had been destroyed.	4.256134624165982
814. as they looked with nostalgia	to a society which had been swept away they were probably no more	than half-conscious that they painted in colors which had never existed.	5.492746640390136
815. their books found no less willing readers outside than inside the	south even while memories of the war were still sharp.	4.3714659090720165
816. the tradition	reached its apex perhaps in the works of thomas nelson page toward	the end of the century and reappeared undiminished as late as 1934	in the best-selling novel so red the rose by stark young.	5.728731858215901
817. although faulkner was the heir in his own family to this tradition	he did not have stark young's inclination to romanticize and sentimentalize	the planter society.	4.486368970135511
818. the myth of the southern plantation	has had only a tangential relation with actuality as francis	pendleton gaines showed forty years ago and i suspect it has had a	far narrower acceptance as something real than has generally been supposed.	5.042349320216564
819. faulkner has found it useful but he has employed it with his	habitual independence of mind and skeptical outlook.	4.520275660025826

822. faulkner's low-class	characters had but few counterparts in earlier southern novels	dealing with plantation life.	5.7836982265615156

824. the chief literary antecedents of the snopes clan appeared in the	realistic humorous writing which originated in the south and the	southwest in the three decades before the civil war.	5.162383741769536
825. these narratives	of coarse action and crude language appeared first in local newspapers	as a rule and later found their way between book covers though	rarely into the planters' libraries beside the morocco-bound volumes	of horace mr addison mr pope and sir walter scott.	3.494330945791169
826. there is evidence to suggest in fact that many authors of the humorous	sketches were prompted to write them- or to make them as indelicate	as they are- by way of protesting against the artificial refinements	which had come to dominate the polite letters of the south.	5.454113186213166
827. william	gilmore simms sturdy realist that he was pleaded for a natural	robustness such as he	found in his favorites the great elizabethans	to vivify the pale writings being produced around him.	3.8403365806594927
828. simms admired	the raucous tales emanating from the backwoods but he had himself social	affiliations which would not allow him to approve them fully.	5.627363645091084
829. augustus	baldwin longstreet a preacher and a college and university president	in four southern states published the earliest of these backwoods	sketches and in the character ransy sniffle in the accounts of	sharp horse-trading and eye-gouging physical combat and in the shockingly	unliterary speech of his characters he set an example followed	by many after him.	3.6991191900627083
830. others who wrote of low characters and low	life included thomas bangs thorpe creator of the big bear of arkansas	and tom owen the bee-hunter; johnson jones hooper whose	character simon suggs bears a close kinship to flem snopes in	both his willingness to take cruel advantage of all and sundry and the	sharpness with which he habitually carried out his will; and george	washington harris whose tennessee hillbilly character sut lovingood	perpetrated more unmalicious mischief and more unintended pain	than any other character in literature.	4.558502894731379
831. it would be profitable i believe	to read these realistic humorists alongside faulkner's works	the thought being not that he necessarily read them and owed anything	to them directly but rather that they dealt a hundred years ago with	a class of people and a type of life which have continued down to our	time to faulkner's time.	3.6147378858192885

833. such characters with their low existence and often low morality	produce humorous effects in his novels and tales as they did in	the writing of longstreet and hooper and harris but it need not be	added that he gives them far subtler and more intricate functions than	they had in the earlier writers; nor is there need to add that among	them are some of the most highly individualized and most successful	of his characters.	3.6919696782603144
834. one of the early humorists already mentioned	thomas bangs thorpe can be used to illustrate another point	where faulkner touches authentic southern materials and also earlier	literary treatment of those materials.	6.011159149450899
835. thorpe came to louisiana from	the east as a young man prepared to find in the new country the setting	of romantic adventure and idealized beauty.	4.447516299211204

838. some years ago julian huxley proposed to an audience made	up of members of the british association for the advancement of	science that man's supernormal or extra-sensory faculties are now	in the same case as were his mathematical faculties during the ice	age.	5.383429981455962

865. mr lyford gives voice to a temper	that represents we think an achieved plateau of reflective thinking.	4.27311739284845

909. copernicus did not question it ptolemy could not.	5.066959048406199
910. given the conceptual	context within which ancient thought thrived how could anyone have	questioned this principle?	5.981496131889986
911.  the reasons for this are partly observational	partly philosophical and reinforced by other aesthetic and	cultural factors.	4.260087042311285
912. the obvious	natural fact to ancient thinkers was the diurnal rotation of the	heavens.	5.390500575037483
913. not only did constellations like draco cepheus and cassiopeia	spin circles around the pole but stars which were not circumpolar	rose and set at the same place on the horizon each night.	4.219059554561502
914. nor did	a constellation's stars vary in brightness during the course of their	nocturnal flights.	7.225383228775741
915. the conclusion- the distances of the constellations	did not vary and their paths were circular.	3.872342767520762
916. moreover the sun's	path over earth described a segment of a great circle; this was	clear from the contour of the shadow traced by a gnomon before and after	noon.	5.419601121845938
917. as early as the 6th century bc the earth	was seen to be spherical.	5.299021402657277
918. ships disappear hull-first over the horizon;	approaching shore their masts appeared first.	6.093123995732186
919. earth being at	the center of the universe would have the same shape as the latter;	so eg did aristotle argue although this may not be an observational	reason in favor of circularity.	5.121987934674431

928. by distinguishing superlunary	and sublunary existence and reinforcing this with	the four-element physics of empedocles aristotle came to speak of	the stars as perfect bodies which moved in only a perfect way viz	in a perfect circle.	4.920976678115593
