932. circular motion however since it is eternal and perfectly continuous	lacks termini.	6.764408985106059
933. it is never motion towards something.	6.638508225341052
934. only imcomplete	imperfect things move towards what they lack.	7.887076528025433
935. perfect complete	entities if they move at all do not move towards what they lack.	4.453324428454441
936. they move only in accordance with what is in their natures.	8.548947920793612
937. thus circular	motion is itself one of the essential characteristics of completely	perfect celestial existence.	5.593412337780835
938. to return now to the four-element	physics a mixture of muddy frothy water will when standing in	a jar separate out with earth at the bottom water on top and the	air on top of that.	5.5036417240789195
939. a candle alight in the air directs its flame and	smoke upwards.	5.1290551501771535
940. this gives a clue to the cosmical order of elements.	7.989676612005167
941. thus earth has fallen to the center of the universe.	6.5610042976687755
942. it is covered	with water air is atop of that.	7.142474654729522
943. pure fire is in	the heavens.	6.094118058689911
944. when combined with the metaphysical notion that pure forms	of this universe are best appreciated when least embodied in a material	substratum it becomes clear that while earth will be dross on a	scale of material-formal ratios celestial bodies will be of a subtle	quickened ethereal existence in whose embodiment pure form will be	the dominant component and matter will be absent or remain subsidiary.	4.636844622962273
945. the stars constitute an order of existence different from what	we encounter on earth.	4.01320189254933
946. this is clear when one distinguishes the types	of motion appropriate to both regions.	6.592151976095505
947. a projectile shot up from earth	returns rectlinearly to its 'natural' place of rest.	4.2705665792608904
948. but the	natural condition for the heavenly bodies is neither rest nor rectilinear	motion.	6.512782700697277
949. being less encumbered by material embodiments they partake	more of what is divine.	5.3393407420809424
950. their motion will be eternal and perfect.	7.89213993478442
951. let us re-examine the publicized contrasts between ptolemaic	and copernican astronomy.	5.475743997089916
952. bluntly there never was a ptolemaic system	of astronomy.	6.806723317680827
953. copernicus' achievement was to have invented	systematic astronomy.	5.936819829599329
954. the almagest and the hypotheses outline	ptolemy's conception of his own task as the provision of computational	tables independent calculating devices for the prediction	of future planetary perturbations.	5.016142848058539
955. indeed in the halma edition of theon's	presentation of the hypotheses there is a chart setting	out otherwise unrelated diagrams for describing	the planetary motions.	4.490365083898234
956. no attempt is made by ptolemy to weld	into a single scheme these independent predicting-machines.	6.294126765188816
957. they all have this in common: the earth is situated	near the center of the deferent.	5.153607870141916
958. but that one should superimpose all	these charts run a pin through the common point and then scale each	planetary deferent larger and smaller	this is contrary to any intention ptolemy ever expresses.	5.095720074203199
959. he might even suppose the planets to move at infinity.	5.208546087917959
960. ptolemy's	problem is to forecast where against the inverted bowl of night some	particular light will be found at future times.	5.270099936804924
961. his problem concerns	longitudes latitudes and angular velocities.	5.5832160523981065
962. the distances of these	points of light is a problem he cannot master beyond crude conjectures	as to the orderings of the planetary orbits viewed outward from earth.	4.846688938190442
963. but none of this has prevented scientists philosophers and even	historians of science from speaking of the ptolemaic system in	contrast to the copernican.	4.164298098226912
964. it is engendered by	confounding the aristotelian cosmology in the almagest with the	geocentric astronomy.	6.199299039213265
965. ptolemy recurrently denies that he could	ever explain planetary motion.	4.855658467968249
966. this is what necessitates the nonsystematic	character of his astronomy.	8.448645893571287
967. so when textbooks like that	of baker set out drawings of the 'ptolemaic system' complete	with earth in the center and the seven heavenly bodies epicyclically arranged	on their several deferents we have nothing but a misleading 20th-century	idea of what never existed historically.	3.7976295671652713
968. it is	the chief merit in copernicus' work that all his planetary calculations	are interdependent.	6.529512050809067
969. he cannot eg compute the retrograde	arc traveled by mars without also making suppositions about the	earth's own motion.	4.26819919707757
970. he cannot describe eclipses without entertaining	some form of	a three-body problem.	6.941114833316636
971. in ptolemaic terms however eclipses	and retrograde motion were phenomena simpliciter to be explained	directly as possible resultants of epicyclical combinations.	4.002551856872899
972. in a	systematic astronomy like that of copernicus retrogradations become	part of the conceptual structure of the system; they are no longer	a puzzling aspect of intricately variable local planetary motions.	5.443235690493521
973. another contrast stressed when discussing ptolemaic vs	copernican astronomy turns on the idea of simplicity.	5.283555738921018
974. it is often	stated that copernican astronomy is 'simpler' than ptolemaic.	6.8419076308501925
975. some even say that this is the reason for the ultimate acceptance of	the former.	6.925052054401465
976. thus margenau remarks: a large number of unrelated	epicycles was needed to explain the observations but otherwise the	ptolemaic system served well and with quantitative precision.	5.746727805424996
977. copernicus	by placing the sun at the center of the planetary universe	was able to reduce the number of epicycles from eighty-three to seventeen.	5.020017169651547
978. historical records indicate that copernicus was unaware of the	fundamental aspects of his so-called 'revolution' unaware perhaps	of its historical importance he rested content with having produced	a simpler scheme for prediction.	4.803644928780919
979. as an illustration of the principle	of simplicity the heliocentric discovery has a peculiar appeal because	it allows simplicity to be arithmetized; it involves a reduction	in the number of epicycles from eighty-three to seventeen.	4.084916057147674
980. without careful qualification this can be misleading.	9.032482521971229
981. if in any one	calculation ptolemy had had to invoke 83 epicycles all at once	while copernicus never required more than one third this number then	ptolemaic astronomy would be simpler	than copernican.	4.001152359370664
982. but no single planetary problem ever required	of ptolemy more than six epicycles at one time.	6.10198581374308
983. this of course results	from the non-systematic 'cellular' character of ptolemaic	theory.	5.293298828795261
984. calculations within the copernican framework always raised questions	about planetary configurations.	6.289010577019261
985. these could be met only by considering	the dynamical elements of several planets at one time.	4.519824559694223
986. this	is more ambitious than ptolemy is ever required to be when he faces	his isolated problems.	6.0812157403541525
987. thus in no ordinary sense of 'simplicity'	is the ptolemaic theory simpler than the copernican.	4.749071605910154
988. the latter required	juggling several elements simultaneously.	7.869571950852667
989. this was not simpler	but much more difficult than exercises within ptolemy's astronomy.	5.542070754542027
990. analogously anyone who argues that einstein's theory of	gravitation is simpler than newton's must say rather more to explain	how it is that the latter is mastered by student-physicists while	the former can be managed only by accomplished experts.	5.222366487848096
991. in a sense einstein's theory is simpler than newton's	and there is a corresponding sense in which copernicus' theory	is simpler than ptolemy's.	4.833804625471466
992. but 'simplicity' here refers to	systematic simplicity.	8.351292733569213
993. the number of primitive ideas in systematically-simple	theories is reduced to a minimum.	5.270828815174544
994. the axioms required to	make the theoretical machinery operate are set out tersely and powerfully	so that all permissible operations within the theory can be traced	rigorously back to these axioms rules and primitive notions.	4.511345546953926
995. this	characterizes euclid's formulation of geometry but not ptolemy's	astronomy.	5.066959048406199
996. there are in the almagest no rules for determining	in advance whether a new epicycle will be required for dealing with	abberations in lunar solar or planetary behavior.	5.701740265778097
997. the strongest	appeal of the copernican formulation consisted in just this: ideally	the justification for dealing with special problems in particular	ways is completely set out in the basic 'rules' of the theory.	3.6932359051115764
998. the	lower-level hypotheses are never 'ad hoc' never introduced ex	post facto just to sweep up within the theory some recalcitrant datum.	5.160513208686437
999. copernicus to an extent unachieved by ptolemy approximated to	euclid's vision.	4.739649730906688
1000. de revolutionibus is not just a collection of	facts and techniques.	6.3597166371299005
1001. it is an organized system of these things.	6.337860894361929
1002. solving	astronomical problems requires for copernicus not a random search	of unrelated tables but a regular employment of the rules defining	the entire discipline.	5.103675880876918
1003. hence noting the simplicity achieved	in copernicus' formulation does not provide another reason for	the acceptance of de revolutionibus another reason beyond its	systematic superiority.	3.966566059426802
1004. it provides exactly the same reason.	10.699778348391193
1005. 1543 ad is often venerated as the birthday of the scientific	revolution.	4.535752126583474
1006. it is really the funeral day of scholastic science.	7.387043418584458
1007. granted	the cosmological philosophical and cultural reverberations	initiated by the de revolutionibus were felt with increasing violence	during the 300 years to follow.	3.841511969386553
1008. but considered within technical	astronomy a different pattern can be traced.	6.724597173527754
1009. in what does the	dissatisfaction of copernicus-the-astronomer consist?	6.205852435676169
1010.  what in the	almagest draws his fire?	9.288350657908774
1011.  geocentricism per se?	7.525342255260206
1012.  no.	14.778306436938408
1013. the	formal displacement of the geocentric principle far from being copernicus'	primary concern was introduced only to resolve what seemed	to him intolerable in orthodox astronomy namely the 'unphysical'	triplication of centric reference-points: one center from which	the planet's distances were calculated another around which planetary	velocities were computed and still a third center from	which the observations originated.	3.3698479754228394
1014. this arrangement was for copernicus	literally monstrous: with the ptolemaists it is as though	an artist were to gather the hands feet head and other members	for his images from divers models each part excellently drawn but not	related to a single body; and since they in no way match each other	the result would be a monster rather than a man.	4.855400601904633
1015. copernicus	required a systematically integrated physically intelligible astronomy.	5.3285636594893
1016. his objective was essentially to repair those aspects of orthodox	astronomy responsible for its deficiencies in achieving these ends.	5.417032158765409
1017. that such deficiencies existed within ptolemy's theory was not	discovered de novo by copernicus.	4.864007363440205
1018. the critical rigorous examinations	of nicholas of cusa and nicholas of oresme provided the context	for nicholas copernicus' own work.	4.939358304713113
1019. the latter looked backward upon inherited deficiencies.	5.497549989974415
1020. without abandoning	too much copernicus sought to make orthodox astronomy systematically	and mechanically acceptable.	6.482924211985938
1021. he did not think himself to be	firing the first shot of an intellectual revolution.	5.137394072181762

2021. the coolidges	did not always live at the white house during the presidency.	4.760605745664949
2022. impressive as this enumeration is it barely hints at the diverse	perceptions of jews collectively or individually that have been	attested by their gentile environment.	5.004173005508399
2023. it is reasonable to affirm	two propositions: jews have been perceived by non-jews as all things	to all men; some jews have in fact been all things to all men.	3.719213850299798
2024. in the arena of power jews have at one time or another been somebody's	ally; they have observed correct neutrality; they have been	someone's enemy.	5.642977039585099

2027. diversity of perception yes; diversity	of fact yes.	5.3285636594893

2029. the conventional image of a particular time	and place is not necessarily congruent with the image of the facts as	established over the years by scholarly and scientific research.	4.429680276733732
2030. conventional	images of jews have this in common with all perceptions of	a configuration in which one feature is held constant: images can be	both true and false.	5.184746832435755
2031. the genuinely interesting question then	becomes: what factors determine the degree of realism or distortion	in conventional images of jews?	3.9907987550274164
2032.  the working test of the facts	must always be the best available description obtainable from scholars	and scientists who have applied their methods of investigation	to relevant situations.	4.8511926235742555
2033. granted such functional images are subject	to human error; they are self-correcting in the sense that they	are subject to disciplined procedures that check and recheck against	error.	4.0029656466882635
2034. in accounting for realism or distortion two sets of factors	can be usefully distinguished: current intelligence; predispositions	regarding intelligence.	5.872973269393318
2035. general grant may have been the victim	of false information in the instance reported in this book; if so	he would not be the first or last commanding officer who has succumbed	to bad information and dubious estimates of the future.	4.118707530803081
2036. but general	grant may have been self-victimized.	10.184963047624784

2038. predispositions in turn fall conveniently	into two categories for purposes of analysis.	6.093123995732186
2039. to some extent predispositions	are shaped by exposure to group environments.	5.562037792528531
2040. in some measure	they depend upon the structure of individual personality.	7.911192314367776
2041. the anti-semitism	of hitler owed something to his exposure to the ideology of	lueger's politically successful christian socialist movement in vienna.	3.7308757087128006

2045. modern psychiatric knowledge provides us	with many keys to unlock the significance of behavior of the kind.	4.744940263061459

2047. undoubtedly one merit of the vast panorama of gentile	conceptions of the jew unfolded in the present anthology is that	it provides a formidable body of material that invites critical examination	in terms of reality.	3.8560412915705333

2051. since we can neither undo nor redo the	past we are limited to the events of today and tomorrow.	4.6151986905465225
2052. in this	domain the simple fact of coexistence in the same local national and	world community is enough to guarantee that we cannot refrain from having	some effect large or small upon gentile-jewish relations.	5.304988145929076

2054.    i am deliberately raising the policy	problems involved in gentile-jewish relations.	7.288966093639867
2055. comprehensive examination	of any policy question calls for the performance of the intellectual	tasks inseparable from any problem-solving method.	4.288908460166186
2056. the tasks	are briefly indicated by these questions: what are my goals in gentile-jewish	relations?	5.289832921804139

2064. my reply is that i associate myself with	all those who affirm that gentile-jewish relations should contribute	to the theory and practice of human dignity.	5.250695337495364
2065. the basic goal finds partial	expression in the universal declaration of human rights a statement	initiated and endorsed by individuals and organizations of many	religious and philosophical traditions.	3.708062179698028
2066. within this frame of	reference policies appropriate to claims advanced in the name of the	jews depend upon which jewish identity is involved as well as upon	the nature of the claim the characteristics of the claimant the justifications	proposed and the predispositions of the community decision	makers who are called upon to act.	5.503825425589501

2068. when decision makers act within this	frame they determine whether a claim put forward in the name of religion	is to be accepted by the larger community as appropriate to religion.	5.441419376275818

2079. social process is always anchored	in past predisposition; but it is perennially restructured in situations	where anchors are dragged or lost.	4.526396268249482

2083. when we consider the disorganized	state of the world community and the legacy of predispositions adversely	directed against all who are identified as jews it is obvious	that the struggle for the minds and muscles of men needs to be prosecuted	with increasing vigor and skill.	4.319774515992898
2084. during moments of intense crisis	the responsibility of political leaders is overwhelming.	7.1556662361468915

2207. thus	burns's my love is like a red red rose and hopkins'	the thunder-purple sea-beach plumed purple of	thunder although clearly intelligible in content hardly present	ideas of the sort with which we are here concerned.	3.834271707492106

2209. understanding a work	of art involves recognition of the ideas that it reflects or embodies.	4.867411545084113

2219. in recent years we have come increasingly to recognize	that ideas have a history and that not the least important chapters	of this history have to do with thematic or conceptual aspects of literature	and the arts although these aspects should be studied in conjunction	with the history of philosophy of religion and of the sciences.	4.129342461765278

2221. here we may observe that at least one modern philosophy of history	is built on the assumption that ideas are the primary objectives	of the historian's research.	4.481378785246418
2222. let us quote once more from r g	collingwood: history is properly concerned with the actions	of human beings h regarded from the outside an action is an event	or series of events occurring in the physical world; regarded from the	inside it is the carrying into action of a certain thought h the	historian's business is to penetrate to the inside of the actions	with which he is dealing and reconstruct or rather rethink the thoughts	which constituted them.	4.966790629708525
2223. it is a characteristic of thoughts that h	in re-thinking them we come ipso facto to understand why they were	thought.	4.277621140432623

2225. history has this in common	with every other science: that the historian is not allowed to claim	any single piece of knowledge except where he can justify his claim	by exhibiting to himself in the first place and secondly to any one	else who is both able and willing to follow his demonstration the grounds	upon which it is based.	3.7366113943198997
2226. this is what was meant above by describing	history as inferential.	7.979718482955946
2227. the knowledge in virtue of which a man	is an historian is a knowledge of what the evidence at his disposal proves	about certain events.	4.115384440461527
2228. it is obvious that the historian who seeks	to recapture the ideas that have motivated human behavior throughout	a given period will find the art and literature of that age one of	his central and major concerns by no means a mere supplement or adjunct	of significant historical research.	5.104238102675317
2229. the student of ideas and	their place in history will always be concerned with the patterns of	transition which are at the same time patterns of transformation whereby	ideas pass from one area of activity to another.	4.039144951665512
2230. let us survey	for a moment the development of modern thought- turning our attention	from the reformation toward the revolutionary and romantic movements	that follow and dwelling finally on more recent decades.	5.474566890757144

2241. in	much the same way we recognize the importance of shakespeare's familarity	with plutarch and montaigne of shelley's study of plato's	dialogues and of coleridge's enthusiastic plundering of the writings	of many philosophers and theologians from plato to schelling	and william godwin through which so many abstract ideas were brought	to the attention of english men of letters.	3.626533878543303

2698. as a reviewer thompson	generally displayed a judicious attitude.	8.120550398711721

2701. he was seldom an unmethodical critic and his reviews generally	followed a systematic pattern: a description of what the work	contained a treatment of the things that had especially interested him	in it and wherever possible a balancing of whatever artistic merits	and faults he might have found.	4.1912360809852816

2974. he composed songs and set them to music and	sang them in a soft melodious voice and when his audience had had enough	of music he would discourse on politics or tell stories of his western	adventures guaranteed to excite the emotions of men and women alike.	4.880732604860364
2975. the bulk of his early reputation however came not from	his poetry or his music but from his excellence as an orator.	3.841083486529009
2976. by 1834	the art of oratory had reached a very high level in the united states	as a literary form.	6.991422076566698
2977. the orator of this period in order to earn a	reputation had to pay close attention to the formal composition of his	speech judging how it would appear in print as well as the effect	it would have on the audience that heard it.	4.011603545412809
2978. very soon after his	arrival in little rock pike had joined one of the most influential	organizations in town the little rock debating society and it	was with this group that he made his debut as an orator being invited	to deliver the annual fourth of july address the club sponsored every	year.	5.119681527856694
2979. samuel gorton founder of warwick was styled by the historian	samuel greene arnold one of the most remarkable men who ever lived.	4.551202605387904
2980. a biographer called him the premature john the baptist of	new england transcendentalism.	5.875779398551443

2983. edward rawson secretary of the colony of massachusetts	bay described him as a man whose spirit was stark drunk with blasphemies	and insolence a corrupter of the truth a disturber of the peace	wherever he comes.	4.159160681577175
2984. nathaniel morton stated he was deeply leavened	with blasphemous and familistical opinions.	6.093123995732186
2985. he was thrown	out more or less from boston plymouth pocasset newport and providence.	5.240635485531085

2987. he was universally	beloved by his neighbours and the indians who esteemed him	not only as a friend but one high in communion with god in heaven.	4.042325542295988
2988. gorton sometimes signed himself a professor of the mysteries of	christ.	6.289010577019261
2989. there is plenty more to recommend gorton the facts	of whose life are given in the life and times of samuel gorton	by adelos gorton.	4.785351244414506
2990. he fought like a fiend for the helpless and	oppressed worked for the abolition of slavery helped the quakers	and indians and worked against the prosecution of witches.	5.0263035462789825
2991. he defied	the boston hierarchy and after they sent a small army to get him	he befuddled the court including john cotton with one of the most	complicated religious discourses ever heard.	4.052592318932048
2992. samuel gorton was	born at gorton england near the present city of manchester about	1592.	6.067783024956384
2993. although he did not attend any celebrated schools or universities	he was a master of greek and hebrew and could read the bible	in the original.	4.434810687253409

2996. with his wife and three or more children he	arrived in boston in march 1637 and soon found it was no place for	anyone looking for liberty of conscience.	5.678858589963851
2997. roger williams had recently	been thrown out and anne hutchinson and her antinomians were slugging	it out with the powers-that-be.	3.9394316778493597
2998. gorton and his family moved to	plymouth.	8.643770004729518

3005. he left in	a storm for pocasset december 4 1638.	5.034885044781751

3008. one can imagine	that with her and gorton there it was no place for anyone with	weak nerves.	6.962344814812963

3011. then he became involved in a ruckus	remarkably similar to the one in plymouth.	5.304194273131964

3018. gorton then moved to providence and soon put the	town in a turmoil.	5.926734816808145
3019. he held that no group of colonists could set up	or maintain a government without royal sanction.	4.375913219968981
3020. since rhode island	at that time did not have such sanction his opinion was not popular.	6.602057121392985
3021. roger williams wrote his friend winthrop as follows:   master	gorton having foully abused high and low at aquidneck is now	bewitching and bemaddening poor providence both with his unclean and	foul censures of all the ministers of this country	and also denying all visible	and external ordinances in depth of familism: almost all suck in	his poison as at first they did at aquidneck.	3.3547475570482597

3024. providence finally	managed to get gorton out of the town and he and some friends	bought land at pawtuxet on the west side of narragansett bay five	miles south but still within the jurisdiction of the providence colony.	5.601557356883713

3026. up to now gorton had been looking	for trouble and now that he was trying to get away from it trouble	started looking for him.	6.530900663170692

3032. if gorton wanted peace and quiet	for his complicated meditations this is where he should have had it.	5.764863593747593

3056. here	was gorton's chance to indulge in something at which he was supreme.	7.015240411539089

3062. four ecclesiastical questions were presented by the	general court to gorton:  whether the fathers who	died before christ was born of the virgin mary were justified and	saved only by the blood which hee shed and the death which hee suffered	after his incarnation?	5.157792092531187

3301. plato feels that man	has two competing aspects his rational faculty and his irrational.	4.305414028832856

3315. in aristotle's analysis of tragedy in the	poetics we find an attempt to isolate the art to consider only	those things proper to it to discover how it differs from other arts	and to deal with the effects peculiar to it.	3.7743457030995953

3336. the second half of	the sixteenth century in england was the setting for a violent and long	controversy over the moral quality of renaissance literature especially	the drama.	5.443414006004779

3359. of the	latter sample 944 persons had been studied two years earlier; hence	changes in attitudes and values can be analyzed for identical individuals	at two points in time.	3.8910754281276856

3361. we find in the first	place that the students overwhelmingly approve of higher education	positively evaluate the job their own institution is doing do not	accept most of the criticisms levelled against higher education in the	public prints and on the whole approve of the way their university	deals with value-problems and value inculcation.	4.197239120243978
3362. it is not our impression	that these evaluations are naively uncritical resultants of blissful	ignorance; rather the generality of these students find their	university experience congenial to their own sense of values.	5.780785063496033
3363. students	are approximately equally divided between those who regard	vocational preparation as the primary goal of an ideal education and those	who chose a general liberal education.	3.912443383382327
3364. other conceivable goals	such as character-education and social adjustment are of secondary	importance to them.	6.241969334573802
3365. the ideal of a liberal education impresses itself	upon the students more and more as they move through college.	4.2558941552361285
3366. even	in such technical curricula as engineering the senior is much more	likely than the freshman to choose as an ideal liberal education over	specific vocational preparation.	4.96038068518468
3367. in the university milieu of scholarship	and research of social diversity of new ideas and varied and	wide-ranging interests socialization into a campus culture apparently	means heightened appreciation of the idea of a liberal education	in the arts and sciences.	4.031056800036264
3368. students' choices of ideal	educational goals are not arbitrary or whimsical.	6.289010577019261
3369. there is a clear	relationship between their educational evaluations and their basic	pattern of general values.	4.969770262711207
3370. the selective and directional qualities of	basic value-orientations are clearly evident in these data: the	success-oriented	students choose vocational preparation the other-directed	choose goals of social adjustment	the intellectuals choose a liberal arts emphasis.	4.570140842607308
3371. the same patterned consistency shows itself in occupational choices.	4.966876954792962
3372. there is impressive consistency between specific occupational	preferences and the student's basic conception of what is for him a	good way of life.	5.961121138541601
3373. and contrary to many popular assertions the goal-values	chosen do not seem to us to be primarily oriented to materialistic	success nor to mere conformity.	4.189344539113909
3374. our students want occupations	that permit them to use their talents and training to be creative	and original to work with and to help other people.	5.584718661503392
3375. they also want	money prestige and security.	6.836918879694162
3376. but they are optimistic about their	prospects in these regards; they set limits to their aspirations-	few aspire to millions of dollars or to imperial power and	glory.	5.939117833975948
3377. within the fixed frame of these aspirations they can afford	to place a high value on the expressive and people-oriented aspects of	occupation and to minimize the instrumental-reward values of power	prestige and wealth.	3.8818821920015356
3378. occupational choices are also useful-	and interesting- in bringing out clearly that values do not constitute	the only component in goals and aspirations.	5.103675880876918
3379. for there is also the	face of reality in the form of the individual's perceptions	of	his own abilities and interests of the objective possibilities open	to him of the familial and other social pressures to which he is exposed.	4.286558051779856
3380. we find reluctant recruits whose values are not in line with	their expected occupation's characteristics.	6.377312788299611
3381. students develop occupational	images- not always accurate or detailed- and they try to	fit their values to the presumed characteristics of the imagined occupation.	3.868849157236362
3382. the purely cognitive or informational problems are often acute.	5.804232386539297
3383. furthermore many reluctant recruits are yielding to social demands	or compromising in the face of their own limitations of opportunity	or of ability and performance.	4.548222403676112
3384. thus many a creativity-oriented aspirant	for a career in architecture drama or journalism resigns himself	to a real estate business; many a people-oriented student who dreams	of the md decides to enter his father's advertising agency;	and many a hopeful incipient business executive decides it were	better to teach the theory of business administration than to practice	it.	4.671394121830456
3385. the old ideal of the independent entrepreneur is extant- but	so is the recognition that the main chance may be in a corporate bureaucracy.	4.130583499244215
3386. in their views on dating courtship sex and family	life our students prefer what they are expected to prefer.	6.691879100807199
3387. for them	in the grim words of a once-popular song love and marriage go together	like a horse and carriage.	4.3660176071062775
3388. their expressed standards concerning	sex roles desirable age for marriage characteristics of an ideal mate	number of children desired are congruent with the values and stereotypes	of the preceding generation- minus compulsive rebellion.	4.909557333864093
3389. they	even accept the double standard of sex morality in a double sense	ie both sexes agree that standards for men differ from standards	for women and women apply to both sexes a standard different from	that held by men.	3.4641780251536765
3390. conservatism and traditionalism	seem implied by what has just been said.	6.289010577019261
3391. but these terms are treacherous.	7.723364728663726
3392. in the field of political values it is certainly true that	students are not radical not rebels against their parents or their peers.	6.21896363507041
3393. and as they go through college the students tend to bring their	political position in line with that prevalent in the social groups	to which they belong.	4.088568834076324
3394. yet they have accepted most of the extant welfare	state provisions for health security and the regulation of	economic affairs and they overwhelmingly approve of the traditional	liberalism of the bill of rights.	5.666286832301243
3395. when their faith in civil	liberties is tested against strong pressures of social expediency in specific	issues eg suppression of dangerous ideas many waver	and give in.	3.891717680490953
3396. the students who are most willing to acquiesce in the	suppression of civil liberties are also those who are most likely to	be prejudiced against minority groups to be conformist and traditionalistic	in general social attitudes and to lack a basic faith in people.	4.645735548018332
3397. as one looks at the existing evidence one finds a correlation	although only a slight one between high grades and libertarian	values.	4.221602047871791
3398. but the correlation is substantial only among upperclassmen.	7.817147942665264
3399. in other words as students go through college those who are	most successful academically tend to become more committed to a bill	of rights orientation.	4.1205120303033285
3400. college in gross- just the general experience-	may have varying effects but the the students who are successful	emerge with strengthened and clarified democratic values.	5.138376222747615
3401. this finding is consistent also with the fact that student leaders are	more likely to be supporters of the values implicit in civil liberties	than the other students.	4.309941998018257
3402. there is now substantial evidence	from several major studies of college students that the experience of	the college years results in a certain selective homogenization of	attitudes and values.	5.738828384258417
3403. detached from their prior statuses and social	groups and exposed to the pervasive stimuli of the university milieu	the students tend to assimilate a new common culture to converge	toward norms characteristic of their own particular campus.	3.8944588261328446
3404. furthermore	in certain respects there are norms common to colleges and universities	across the country.	5.933173114428453
3405. for instance college-educated people consistently	show up in study after study as more often than others supporters	of the bill of rights and other democratic rights and liberties.	3.987932800483113
3406. the interesting thing in this connection is that the norms upon which	students tend to converge include toleration of diversity.	5.568007574027143
3407. to the extent that our sampling of the orientations of american college	students in the years 1950 and 1952 may be representative of our	culture- and still valid in 1959- we are disposed to question the	summary characterization of the current generation as silent beat	apathetic or as a mass of other-directed conformists who are guided	solely by social radar without benefit of inner gyroscopes.	3.6179897780037975
3408. our data	indicate that these students of today do basically accept the existing	institutions of the society and in the face of the realities of complex	and large-scale economic and political problems make a wary and	ambivalent delegation of trust to those who occupy positions of legitimized	responsibility for coping with such collective concerns.	5.391757489288814
3409. in	a real sense they are admittedly conservative but their conservatism	incorporates a traditionalized embodiment of the original radicalism	of 1776.	4.524483683752041
3410. although we have no measures of its strength or intensity	the heritage of the doctrine of inalienable rights is retained.	6.8193597347562225
3411. as they move through the college years our young men and women are socialized	into a broadly similar culture at the level of personal	behavior.	4.532578084573329
3412. in this sense also they are surely conformists.	8.776081634276382
3413. it is	even true that some among them use the sheer fact of conformity- everyone	does it- as a criterion for conduct.	4.103879376007675
3414. but the extent of	ethical robotism is easily overestimated.	7.8167834745989735
3415. few students are really so	faceless in the not-so-lonely crowd of the swelling population in our	institutions of higher learning.	4.20808484142879
3416. and it may be well to recall that to	say	conformity is in part another way of saying orderly human	society.	6.865229110005379
3417. in the field of religious beliefs and values the	college students seem to faithfully reflect the surrounding culture.	4.897827869181466
3418. their commitments are for the most part couched in a familiar idiom.	7.493802445372158
3419. students testify to a felt need for a religious faith or ultimate	personal philosophy.	4.889391497463582
3420. avowed atheists or freethinkers are so rare as	to be a curiosity.	6.093123995732186
3421. the religious quest is often intense and deep	and there are students on every campus who are seriously wrestling with	the most profound questions of meaning and value.	3.4759891800631113
3422. at the same time	a major proportion of these young men and women see religion as a means	of personal adjustment an anchor for family life a source of emotional	security.	6.101532416500554
3423. these personal and social goals often overshadow the	goals of intellectual clarity and spiritual transcendence.	4.411633295274241
3424. the cult	of adjustment does exist.	6.916419102612548
3425. it exists alongside the acceptance of	traditional forms of organized religion	.	5.242557279060353
3426. still another segment of the student population consists	of those who seek in what they regard as religion intellectual clarity	rational belief and ethical guidance and reinforcement.	5.494108820524348
3427. our first impression of the data was that the students were surprisingly	orthodox and religiously involved.	4.625248596720302
3428. upon second thought we were	forced to realize that we have very few reliable historical benchmarks	against which we might compare the present situation and that conclusions	that present-day students are more or less religious	could not be defended on the basis of our data.	5.859743274567074
3429. as we looked more intently	at the content of our belief and the extent of religious participation	we received the impression that many of the religious convictions	expressed represented a conventional acceptance of low intensity.	4.770977457331977
3430. but here again comparative benchmarks are lacking and we do not	know in any case what measure of profoundity and intensity to expect	from healthy young secure and relatively inexperienced persons;	after all feelings of immortality and invulnerability are standard illusions	of youth.	4.847463006315385
3431. nor are optimistic and socially-oriented themes at	all rare in the distinctive religious history of this country.	4.658881251916754
3432. kluckhohn recently has summarized evidence regarding changes in values	during a period of years primarily 1935-1955 but extending much farther	back in some instances.	5.482717806588174
3433. a variety of data are assembled to bear	upon such alleged changes as diminished puritan morality work-success	ethic individualism achievement lessened emphasis on future-time	orientation in favor of sociability moral relativism consideration and	tolerance conformity hedonistic present-time orientation.	3.8483218368583154
3434. although	he questions the extent and nature of the alleged revival of religion	and the alleged increase in conformity and thinks that hedonistic	present-time orientation does not have the meaning usually attributed	to it he does conclude that americans increasingly enjoy leisure	without guilt do not stress achievement so much as formerly are more	accepting of group harmony as a goal more tolerant of diversity and	aware of other cultures.	4.8594915125585265
3435. from new jersey morgan hastened to the headquarters of washington	at whitemarsh pennsylvania arriving there on november 18th.	4.477431245060599

3437. morgan himself had sciatica again.	6.094118058689911
3438. even on his tough constitution	the exposure and strenuous activity were beginning to tell in earnest.	6.258183461747524

3440. in order to prevent this washington hastened	to dispatch several units to reinforce the fort including a force	under the marquis de lafayette containing some 160 of morgan's	riflemen all who were fit for duty at this time the rest having no shoes.	5.2799899782459185

3463. apparently still sensitive	about the idea with which general gates had approached him at saratoga	namely that george washington be replaced morgan was vehement	in his support of the commander-in-chief during the campaign around	philadelphia.	3.881270798181214

3468. in	late december the american army moved from whitemarsh to valley	forge and although the distance was only 13 miles the journey took	more than a week because of the bad weather the barefooted and almost	naked men.	5.047095514379757

3514. when the	negotiations began his quarrel with the king of france was temporarily	in abeyance and he had no intention of reviving it so long as there	was hope that french money would come to pay the troops who under	charles of valois	the papal vicar of tuscany were so valuable in	the crusade against the colonna cardinals and their sicilian allies.	5.227909099868875

3688. it would seem that the wheel had turned full circle.	8.255642930312332
3689. in fact modern scholarly opinion in the main has not retreated	all the way back to the destructive scepticism of the first half of the	nineteenth century.	5.006772410262463
3690. although one meets with occasional extremists like	zachrisson or very recently arthur wade-evans the majority of	scholars have taken a middle position between the extremes of scepticism	and gullibility.	5.3499881591367
3691. most now admit that bede gildas nennius and	the anglo-saxon chronicles cannot be the infallible guides to early	english history that guest freeman and green thought them to be.	3.8713478202439124
3692. as rh hodgkin has remarked: the critical methods of	the nineteenth century shattered most of this picturesque narrative.	5.8768009336449625
3693. on	the other hand the consensus of opinion is that used with caution	and in conjunction with other types of evidence the native sources still	provide a valid rough outline for the english settlement of southern	britain.	4.023176604828358
3694. as sir charles oman once said it is no longer fashionable	to declare that we can say nothing certain about old english	origins.	6.765758248189125
3695. therefore in one way kemble and lappenberg	have been vindicated.	5.741027248562998
3696. their conclusions concerning the untrustworthiness	of the west saxon annals the confused chronology of bede the	unreliability of the early positions of the anglo-saxon genealogies	and the mythological elements contained in nennius are now mostly accepted.	5.038284077310446
3697. nevertheless in another way modern historians still labor in	the vineyard of the oxford school.	4.586116821838751
3698. for it is their catastrophic concept	of the anglo-saxon invasions rather than kemble's gradualist	approach which dominates the field.	6.722928853390084
3699. despite the rejection of the traditional	accounts on many points of detail as late as 1948 it was still	possible to postulate a massive and comparatively sudden	influx of germans as the type of invasions.	4.061033083888245
3700. at	this point of course the issue has become complicated by a development	unforeseen by lappenberg and kemble.	5.966617726469975
3701. they however much they were	in disagreement with the late victorians over the method by which	britain was germanized agreed with them that the end result was the	complete extinction of the previous celtic population and civilization.	3.648461782576242
3702. but beginning for all practical purposes with frederick seebohm's	english village community scholars have had to reckon	with a theory involving institutional and agrarian continuity between	roman and anglo-saxon times which is completely at odds with the reigning	concept of the anglo-saxon invasions.	4.991309851771062
3703. against seebohm formidable	foes have taken the field notably f w maitland whose	domesday book and beyond was written expressly for this purpose	and sir paul vinogradoff whose the growth of the manor had	a similar aim.	3.933456070891631
3704. largely due to their efforts the catastrophic invasion-theory	has maintained its position although seebohm has always found	supporters.	5.454336586728915
3705. hl gray in his english field systems and	zachrisson's romans kelts and saxons defended in part the	seebohm thesis while at the present time hpr finberg and	gordon copley seem to fall into the celtic survivalist camp.	3.8679842306182626
3706. this	is nevertheless a minority view.	9.926945921249153
3707. most scholars while willing to accept	a survival of celtic art forms and a considerable proportion	of the celtic population reject any institutional legacy from	pre-anglo-saxon britain.	3.912318952129464
3708. therefore it is plain that the	clear distinctions of the nineteenth century are no longer with us.	7.09412692000062
3709. in the main stream of historical thinking is a group of scholars hm	chadwick rh hodgkin sir frank stenton et al	who are in varying degrees sceptical of the native traditions of the conquest	but who defend the catastrophic type of invasion suggested by	them.	3.8317497744116324
3710. they in effect have compromised the opposing positions of the	nineteenth century.	6.4370827295769395
3711. on the other side are the celtic survivalists who	have taken a tack divergent from both these schools of nineteenth century	thought.	4.65762074864686
3712. as a group they should be favorable to a concept of gradual	germanic infiltration although the specialist nature of much of	their work eg seebohm gray and finberg tends to obscure	their sympathies.	5.697584351120707
3713. those who do have occasion to deal with the invasions	in a more general way like tw shore and arthur wade-evans	are on the side of a gradual and often peaceful germanic penetration	into britain.	4.50504886328511
3714. wade-evans in fact denies that there were any anglo-saxon	invasions at all other than a minor jutish foray in ad	514.	5.4738267710351725
3715. now omitting for a moment some recent developments	we can say the saxon shore hypothesis of lappenberg and kemble has	undergone virtual eclipse in this century.	4.099872269975866
3716. it is no longer possible	to say that a sceptical attitude towards the received accounts of the	invasions almost automatically produces a shore occupied by interpretation.	5.781910320998562
3717. everyone is more or less sceptical and virtually no one has	been willing to accept lappenberg or kemble's position on that	point.	4.319924020728383
3718. one reason is of course that the new scepticism has been willing	to maintain the general picture of the invasions as portrayed in	the traditional sources.	6.826464812356217
3719. the few scholars who have adopted the shore	occupied by interpretation howorth shore and wade-evans	have all been celtic survivalists.	3.753506231366399
3720. moreover they have done so in rather	special circumstances.	8.47166250640164
3721. the primary reason for the abandonment	of the shore occupied by thesis has been the assimilation and	accumulation of archaeological evidence the most striking feature	of early english studies in this century.	3.800267477029604
3722. again omitting recent developments	et	leeds' dictum of 1913 has stood unchallenged: so far	as archaeology is concerned there is not the least warrant for the	second of these theories.	6.120548778816774
3723. even earlier haverfield	had come to the same conclusion.	7.81346290912735
3724. what they meant was that there	was no evidence to show that the south and east coasts of britain received	germanic settlers conspicuously earlier than some other parts of	england.	6.127118796645901
3725. that is there was no trace of anglo-saxons in britain	as early as the late third century to which time the archaeological	evidence for the erection of the saxon shore forts was beginning to	point.	4.038510948977839
3726. in the face of a clear judgment from archaeology therefore it	became impossible for a time for scholars to re-adopt the shore settled	by theory.	6.11633808891851
3727. in recent years however a wind of change	seems to be blowing through early english historical circles.	4.814296653587412
3728. the	great increase in the amount of archaeological activity and therefore	information in the years immediately preceeding and following the second	world war has brought to light data which has changed the complection	of the saxon shore dispute.	5.4986205957494425
3729. where there were none fifteen years	ago several scholars currently are edging their way cautiously towards	the acceptance of the shore occupied by position.	4.562276164963491
3730. we must	therefore have a look at the new archaeological material and re-examine	the literary and place-name evidence which bears upon the problem.	6.2357399080586475
3731. what exactly are we trying to prove?	6.1298613796617545
3732.  we know that the	saxon shore was a phenonenon of late roman defensive policy; in	other words its existence belongs to the period of roman britain.	5.64004546978759
3733. so	whenever the romans finally withdrew from the island the saxon shore	disappeared in the first decade of the fifth century.	4.7643667594349415
3734. we also know	that the saxon shore as reflected in the notitia was created	as a part of the theodosian reorganization of britain	.	6.520366742773251
3735. my argument is that there was no saxon shore prior to that	time even though the forts had been in existence since the time of carausius.	5.364212384427733
3736. therefore what we must prove or disprove is that there were	saxons in the broad sense in which we must construe the word in	the area of the saxon shore at the time it was called the saxon shore.	5.802120824895193
3737. that is we must find saxons in east anglia kent sussex and	hampshire in the last half of the fourth century.	5.4427328472253445
3738. the problem	in other words is strictly a chronological one.	5.804273692121158
3739. in gaul the saxon	element on its saxon shore was plainly visible because there the	saxons were an intrusive element in the population.	3.9020296841728688
3740. in britain obviously	the archaeological and place-name characteristics of the saxon	shore region are bound to be saxon.	5.639487880205433
3741. it is a matter of trying to	sort out an earlier fourth-century saxon element from the later fifth-century	mainstream of anglo-saxon invasions.	4.644282570427119
3742. this naturally will	be difficult to do since both the archaeological and place-name evidence	in this period with some fortunate exceptions is insufficient	for precise chronological purposes.	5.022249927506418
3743. it might be well to consider	the literary evidence first because it can provide us with an answer	to one important question; namely is the idea that there were saxon	mercenaries in england at all reasonable?	4.122154249574925
3744. 	to do so something was necessary beyond volunteering because there was	little glamour or romance in the european war; it meant instead	hardship dirt and death.	4.96038068518468
3745. baker gave leonard wood credit for	the initiation of the draft of soldiers; from the general's idea	a chain reaction occurred.	3.8880356915934375
3746. wood took the proposal to chief of staff	hugh l scott who passed it on to baker a month before the actual	declaration of war against germany.	4.9944842899864135
3747. the secretary of war gave	his assent after studying the history of the draft in the american	civil war as well as the british volunteer system in world war 1.	4.780455520159121
3748. he concluded that selective service would not only prevent the disorganization	of essential war industries but would avoid the undesirable	moral effects of the british reliance on enlistment only- where	the feeling of the people was whipped into a frenzy by girls pinning	white feathers on reluctant young men orators preaching hate of the	germans and newspapers exaggerating enemy outrages to make men enlist	out of motives of revenge and retaliation.	4.747512427633195
3749. baker took the plan	to wilson who said: baker this is plainly right on any ground.	4.131860641767443
3750. start to prepare the necessary legislation so that if i am obliged	to go to congress the bills will be ready for immediate consideration.	6.125155971560061
3751. the result was that by secret agreement draft machinery was actually	ready long before the country knew that the device was to take	the place of the volunteering method which theodore roosevelt favored.	3.722919338969694
3752. before the draft act was passed baker had confidentially briefed	governors sheriffs and prospective draft board members on the administration	of the measure- and the confidence was kept so well that	only one newspaper learned what was going on.	4.989491283621731
3753. it was baker working	through provost marshal enoch crowder and major hugh s	johnson who arranged for a secret printing by the	million of selective service blanks- again before the act was passed-	until corridors in the government printing office were full	and the basement of the washington post office was stacked to the ceiling.	3.39601533910963
3754. general crowder proposed that regular army officers select	the draftees in cities and towns throughout the nation; it was baker	who thought of lessening the shock which conscription always brings	to a country by substituting greetings from your neighbors for	the recruiting sergeant and registration in familiar voting places	rather than at military installations.	4.47225628332693
3755. even so the draft act	encountered rough sledding in its progress through the congress.	5.1656322938649994
3756. democratic	speaker champ clark saw little difference between a conscript	and a convict.	6.313578918748103
3757. democrat stanley h dent chairman of the	house military affairs committee declined to introduce the bill.	4.131860641767443
3758. democratic floor leader claude kitchin would have no part of the	measure.	6.351780007650003
3759. in the judgment of chief of staff scott it was ironic that	the draft policy of a democratic president aimed at germany had	to be pushed through the house of representatives by the ranking minority	member of the military affairs committee- a republican jew	born in germany! he was julius kahn for whom the chief of staff	thought no honor could be too great.	3.542139112144504
3760. after kahn's death in 1924	scott wrote: may he rest in peace with the eternal gratitude	of his adopted country.	6.064035876480036
3761. in spite of powerful opposition the	draft act finally passed congress on may 17 1917.	4.910098961533947
3762. in early june	ten million young men registered by name and number.	6.36952578460199
3763. the day passed	without incident in spite of the warning of senator james a reed	of missouri: baker you will have the streets of our american	cities running with blood on registration day.	4.311793692789923
3764. on july 20 the	first drawing of numbers occurred in the senate office building before	a distinguished group of congressmen and high army officers.	5.97087538942129
3765. secretary	of war baker blindfolded put his hand into a large glass	bowl and drew the initial number of those to be called.	3.7992019768996257
3766. a man in mississippi wired: thanks for drawing 258- that's	me.	7.658794110349265
3767. he was the first of 2800000 called to the army through the	selective service system.	6.473969954431645
3768. it was one thing to call men to the	colors; it was another to house feed and train them.	5.806340429512213
3769. the existing	army posts were wholly inadequate.	4.863481152584087
3770. in a matter of months the war	department built thirty-two camps each one accommodating fifty thousand	men- sixteen were under canvas in the south and sixteen with frame	structures in the north.	6.036156286893496
3771. it was a gargantuan task; a typical	cantonment in the north had twelve hundred buildings an electric-sewer-water	system and twenty-five miles of roads.	4.5727109070236915
3772. at camp taylor in kentucky	a barracks was built in an hour and a half from timber that had	been standing in mississippi forests one week before.	5.942582802207591
3773. the total	operation	was a construction project comparable in magnitude with the panama	canal but in 1917 time was in short supply; in three months	the army spent three-quarters as much as had been expended on the big	ditch in ten years.	3.65496001305017
3774. in later years josephus danielswas	to	claim that world war 1 was the first in american history in which	there was great concern for both the health and morals of our soldiers.	5.900965816743726
3775. it was the first american war in which the death rate from disease	was lower than that from battle due to the provision of trained	medical personnel compulsory	vaccination rigorous camp sanitation and adequate hospital	facilities.	4.559090241907752
3776. to the middle of september 1918 there had been fewer than	10000 deaths from disease in the new army.	8.163282073179532
3777. this enviable record	would have been maintained but for a great and unexpected disaster which	struck	the world with murderous stealth.	4.002073520551352
3778. it was the influenza pandemic	of 1918-19.	10.19569482407052
3779. the malady was popularly known as the spanish flu	from the alleged locale of its origin.	4.309094164532878
3780. the world-wide total of deaths	from spanish flu was around twenty million; in the united	states 300000 succumbed to it.	5.3193369749789285
3781. in mid-september 1918 the influenza-pneumonia	pandemic swept through every american military camp; during	the eight-week blitz attack 25000 soldiers died from the disease	and the death rate increased almost	fifty times to 4 per week per 1000 men.	3.6086633441991207
3782. in spite of this catastrophe	the final mortality figure from disease in the american army	during world war 1 was 15 per 1000 per year contrasted with	110 per 1000 per year in the mexican war and 65 in the american civil	war.	5.8333892875250974
3783. both secretary of war baker and secretary of navy	daniels devoted much time and effort to the problem of providing	reasonably normal and wholesome activities in camp for the millions of	men who had been removed from their home environment.	4.052879478643481
3784. their policy	ran counter to the traditional idea that a good fighter was usually a	libertine and that in sex affairs god-given passion was a proof	of manliness.	5.370502873146525
3785. baker moved first; six days after war was declared	he appointed raymond fosdick chairman of the commission on training	camp activities.	4.67067137369406
3786. fosdick a brother of minister	harry emerson fosdick was a graduate of princeton and a member of	phi beta kappa and the american philosophical association.	5.785340986586341
3787. his	assignment was not a new one because baker had sent him to the mexican	border in 1916 to investigate lurid newspaper stories about lack	of discipline drunkenness and venereal disease in american military	camps.	3.9664589213220576
3788. fosdick had found the installations surrounded by a battery of	saloons and houses of prostitution with filles de joie from all	over the country flocking to san antonio laredo and el paso to	woman the cribs.	4.720729423757435
3789. he also ascertained that many officers were	indifferent to the problem including commanding general frederick	funston who gave fosdick the nickname of reverend.	4.326506282085711
3790. on the basis	of the long chronicle of military history funston and his brethren	assumed that the issue was insoluble and that anyone interested in a	mission like fosdick's was an impractical idealist or a do-gooder.	5.190897901877469
3791. during the brief mexican venture fosdick's report to the	secretary recommended a definite stand by the war department against	the saloon and the excesses of prostitution.	4.000540513596827
3792. the problem involved military	necessity as much as morality for in pre-penicillin days venereal	disease was a crippling disability.	6.001032136155983
3793. fosdick insisted that a strong	word was needed from washington and it was immediately forthcoming.	4.7890584090463415
3794. baker put the cribs and the saloons out of bounds ordered the	co-operation of military officers with local law authorities and told	communities that the troops would be moved unless wholesome conditions	were restored.	4.8812784238657745
3795. both baker and fosdick knew that a substitute was	necessary that a verboten approach was not the real answer.	4.75370090067133
3796. they	were aware that soldiers went to town in more ways than one because	of the monotony of camp life to find the only release available in	the absence of movies reading rooms and playing fields with adequate	athletic equipment.	5.0449277346884065
3797. both knew that when trains stopped at texan crossroads	bored soldiers would sometimes enter to ask the passengers if	they had any reading material to spare even a newspaper.	3.7787043621853527
3798. there was	no time in the short mexican encounter to evolve a solution but the	area provided a proving ground for new departures in the near future.	6.030842003031511
3799. when the united states entered the first world war baker	made certain that the draft act of 1917 prohibited the sale of liquor	to men in uniform and that it provided for broad zones around the camps	in which prostitution was outlawed.	4.503757028681171
3800. even so fosdick as the new	chairman of the commission on training camp activities encountered	strong and vociferous opposition.	6.465401744694032
3801. new orleans had a notorious red-light	district extending over twenty-eight city blocks and the business-minded	mayor of the city journeyed to washington to present the	case for the god-given right of men to be men.	4.035840061128305
3802. in europe premier	clemenceau showing his animal proclivities as the tiger of	france asked pershing by letter for the creation of special houses	where the sexual desires of american men could be satisfied.	5.102873306457736
3803. when	fosdick showed the letter to baker his negative response was: for	god's sake raymond don't show this to the president or	he'll stop the war.	3.9600219251857176
3804. ultimately fosdick's fit to fight	slogan swept across the country and every well-known red-light district	in the united states was closed a hundred and ten of them.	6.416223040797761
3805. the	result was that the rate of venereal disease in the american army	was the lowest in our military history.	4.911494797967015
3806. this was the negative	side of the situation.	10.12493262960849
3807. affirmatively baker worked on the premise that	young men spontaneously prefer to be decent and that opportunities	for wholesome recreation are the best possible cure for irregularities	in conduct which arise from idleness and the baser temptations.	3.649478332160865
3808. the wholesome activities were to be provided by many organizations including	the ymca the knights of columbus the jewish welfare	board the american library association and the playground and	recreation association- private societies which voluntarily performed	the job that was taken over almost entirely by the special services	division of the army itself in world war 2.	4.685662555494843
3809. over these	voluntary agencies in 1917-18 the ctca served as a co-ordinating	body in carrying out what survey called the most stupendous	piece of social work in modern times.	3.9977050167218504
3810. under fosdick the first	executive officer of the ctca was richard byrd whose name in	later years was to become synonymous with activities at the polar antipodes.	5.456235603148095

3815. in the imagination of the nineteenth century the greek tragedians and	shakespeare stand side by side their affinity transcending all the	immense contrarieties of historical circumstance religious belief and	poetic form.	4.3520163814366475
3816. we no longer use the particular terms of lessing	and victor hugo.	7.103409871375322

3818. the word tragedy	encloses for us in a single span both the greek and the elizabethan	example.	6.226766259705523
3819. the sense of relationship overreaches the historical	truth that shakespeare may have known next to nothing of the actual	works of aeschylus sophocles and euripides.	3.900435537414337

3823. comparable visions of life are at work in antigone	and romeo and juliet.	4.44623081023859
3824. we see at once what victor hugo	means when he calls macbeth a northern scion of the house of atreus.	6.419256877299806

3836. the modes of the imagination implicit in	athenian tragedy continued to shape the life of the mind until the age	of descartes and newton.	6.014026432411453

3839. in greek tragedy as in shakespeare	mortal actions are encompassed by forces which transcend man.	4.372035985590015
3840. the reality	of orestes entails that of the furies; the weird sisters wait	for the soul of macbeth.	5.7752618271394605

3843. and the entirety of the natural world is party to the action.	5.5482010238626165

3845. in tragedy lightning	is a messenger.	6.563387531333404
3846. but it can no longer be so once benjamin franklin	has flown a kite to it.	7.599194905694129
3847. the	tragic stage is a platform extending precariously between heaven and	hell.	4.681571082223364

3849. oedipus and lear instruct us how little of	the world belongs to man.	4.411891185517149
3850. mortality is the pacing of a brief and dangerous	watch and to all sentinels whether at elsinore or on the battlements	at mycenae the coming of dawn has its breath of miracle.	5.12557429762256

3853. modern roosters have lost the art of crowing restless spirits back to	purgatory.	5.262433965344327

3857. tragedy presumes such a configuration.	6.094118058689911

3859. the same	metaphors of swift ascent and calamitous decline apply to oedipus	and macbeth because they applied also to alcibiades and essex.	3.6061566743622318
3860. and	the fate of such men has tragic relevance because it is public.	6.959613018790671
3861. agamemnon	creon and medea perform their tragic actions before the eyes	of the polis.	4.411891185517149
3862. similarly the sufferings of hamlet othello	or phedre engage the fortunes of the state.	6.168487314790686
3863. they are enacted at the	heart of the body politic.	6.500923153154542
3864. hence the natural setting of tragedy is the	palace gate the public square or the court chamber.	5.918570800985123
3865. greek and elizabethan	life and to a certain extent the life of versailles shared	this character of intense publicity.	4.440538099249936
3866. princes and factions clashed	in the open street and died on the open scaffold.	6.16177302337585
3867. with the	rise to power of the middle class the centre of gravity in human affairs	shifted from the public to the private.	5.164893450953947
3868. the art of defoe and richardson	is founded on an awareness of this great change.	5.954339018363231
3869. heretofore	an action had possessed the breadth of tragedy only if it involved high	personages and if it occurred in the public view.	4.53189712694044
3870. behind the tragic	hero stands the chorus the crowd or the observant courtier.	6.1692635755637975
3871. in the	eighteenth century there emerges for the first time the notion of a	private tragedy	number of elizabethan domestic tragedies such as the famous arden	.	4.70214174645063
3872. in la nouvelle-heloi^se and werther	tragedy is made intimate.	7.196162898152894
3873. and private tragedy became the chosen ground	not of drama but of the new unfolding art of the novel.	5.300436392515403
3874. the novel was not only the presenter of the new secular rationalistic	private world of the middle class.	7.669298615693461
3875. it served also as a literary form	exactly appropriate to the fragmented audience of modern urban culture.	4.395235068682567
3876. i have said before how difficult it is to make any precise statements	with regard to the character of the greek and elizabethan public.	7.777391549341244
3877. but one major fact seems undeniable.	7.055910750451842
3878. until the advent of rational	empiricism the controlling habits of the western mind were symbolic	and allegoric.	6.800215055052948
3879. available evidence regarding the natural world the	course of history and the varieties of human action were translated	into imaginative designs or mythologies.	3.873377036453748
3880. classic mythology and christianity	are such architectures of the imagination.	6.522871687113793
3881. they order the manifold	levels of reality and moral value along an axis of being which	extends from brute matter to the immaculate stars.	3.881607703916464
3882. there had not yet	supervened between understanding and expression the new languages of	mathematics and scientific formulas.	6.6660714807902375
3883. the poet was by definition a realist	his imaginings and parables being natural organizations of reality.	3.8146432153167833
3884. and in these organizations certain primal notions played a radiant	part radiant both in the sense of giving light and of being a pole	toward which all perspectives converge.	5.945964500922529
3885. i mean such concepts as the presence	of the supernatural in human affairs the sacraments of grace	and divine retribution the idea of preordainment	the prophecy of the witches to macbeth or god's covenant with	.	3.871494540769782
3886. i refer to the notion that the structure	of society is a microcosm of the cosmic design and that history	conforms to patterns of justice and chastisement as if it were a morality	play set in motion by the gods for our instruction.	5.299641353110235
3887. these	conceptions and the manner in which they were transposed into poetry or	engendered by poetic form are intrinsic to western life from the time	of aeschylus to that of shakespeare.	4.379825355362419
3888. and although they were as i	have indicated under increasing strain at the time of racine they	are still alive in his theatre.	6.307685972170698
3889. they are the essential force behind	the conventions of tragedy.	6.197778191328081
3890. they are as decisively present in the oresteia	and oedipus as in macbeth king lear and phedre.	6.339834855935751
3891. after the seventeenth century the audience ceased to	be an organic community to which these ideas and their attendant habits	of figurative language would be natural or immediately familiar.	3.8919756588255336
3892. concepts	such as grace damnation purgation blasphemy or the chain of	being which are everywhere implicit in classic and shakespearean tragedy	lose their vitality.	5.103675880876918
3893. they become philosophic abstractions of	a private and problematic relevance or mere catchwords in religious customs	which had in them a diminishing part of active belief.	3.802025626992866
3894. after shakespeare	the master spirits of western consciousness are no longer	the blind seers the poets or orpheus performing his art in the face	of hell.	5.294969244618011
3895. they are descartes newton and voltaire.	6.8027327880263675
3896. and their chroniclers	are not the dramatic poets but the prose novelists.	6.6419685246560425
3897. the	romantics were the immediate inheritors of this tremendous change.	4.855658467968249
3898. they were not yet prepared to accept it as irremediable.	9.064343074701084
3899. rousseau's	primitivism the anti-newtonian mythology of blake coleridge's	organic metaphysics victor hugo's image of the poets as the magi	and shelley's unacknowledged legislators are related elements	in the rear-guard action fought by the romantics against the new	scientific rationalism.	3.607607377986237
3900. from this action sprang the idea of somehow uniting	greek and shakespearean drama into a new total form capable	of restoring to life the ancient moral and poetic responses.	5.6381900673048655
3901. the dream	of achieving a synthesis between the sophoclean and the shakespearean	genius inspired the ambitions of poets and composers from the time	of shelley and victor hugo to that of bayreuth.	3.5827438200308235
3902. it could not really	be fulfilled.	11.68409790867645
3903. the conventions into which the romantics tried to breath	life no longer corresponded to the realities of thought and feeling.	3.95137208120356
3904. but the attempt itself produced a number of brilliant works and	these form a transition from the early romantic period to the new age	of ibsen and chekhov.	6.251667502126533
3905. the wedding of the hellenic to the northern	genius was one of the dominant motifs in goethe's thought.	4.3614936962717925
3906. his	italian journey was a poet's version of those perennial thrusts	across the alps of the german emperors of the middle ages.	5.870159021014225
3907. the dream	of a descent into the gardens of the south always drew german ambitions	toward rome and sicily.	4.394142038933159
3908. goethe asks in wilhelm meister	whether we know the land where the lemon trees flower and the light	of the mediterranean glows through torquato tasso and the roman	elegies.	5.059638752601076
3909. goethe believed that the germanic spirit with its	grave strength but flagrant streaks of brutality and intolerance should	be tempered with the old sensuous wisdom and humanism of the hellenic.	3.642767181284866
3910. on the narrower ground of poetic form he felt that in the drama	of the future the greek conception of tragic fate should be joined to	the shakespearean vision of tragic will.	5.4852625645013235
3911. the wager between god and	satan brings on the destiny of faust but faust assumes his role	voluntarily.	3.801129934204088
3912. the third act of faust 2 is a formal celebration	of the union between the germanic and the classic between	the spirit of euripides and that of romantic drama.	4.929687652654643
3913. the motif of faust's	love for helen of troy goes back to the sources of the faustian	legend.	4.99303862772145

3915. there can be no greater	magic than to wrest from death her in whom the flesh was all in whom	beauty was entirely pure because it was entirely corruptible.	4.432162621464411

3989. often the historian must consider the use of intuition or instinct	by those individuals or nations which he is studying.	4.863541221319791
3990. unconsciously	governments or races or institutions may enter into some undertaking	without fully realizing why they are doing so.	5.487755484166036
3991. they react in obedience	to an instinct or urge which has itself been impelled by natural	law.	4.314931266205686

3995. adams firmly contended	that the historian must never underrate the impact of the geographical	environment on history.	4.320280166246067
3996. here was another indispensable tool.	10.928100145593751
