3998. the failure	of greece to reach the imperial destiny that periclean athens	had seemed to promise was almost directly attributable to her physical	conformation.	5.089832262427427
3999. all areas of history were either favorably or adversely	affected by the geographical environment and no respectable historian	could pursue the study of history without a thorough knowledge of	geography.	4.049366058936784
4000. brooks adams was consistent in his admonishments	to historians about the necessary tools or insights they needed to possess.	5.330107587139294
4001. however as a practicing historian he himself has left few clues	to the amount of professional scholarship that he used when writing	history.	4.4835289737741215
4002. in fact if judgments are to be rendered upon the soundness	of his historicism they must be based on scanty evidence.	6.5787522500341
4003. what evidence	is available would seem to indicate that brooks unlike his older	brother henry had most of the methodological vices usually found	in the amateur.	4.952030733551955
4004. a credulousness a distaste for documentation an uncritical	reliance on contemporary accounts and a proneness to assume	a theory as true before adequate proof was provided were all evidences	of his failure to comprehend the use of the scientific method or to evaluate	the responsibilities of the historian to his reading public.	4.825261715055857
4005. this	is not to assume that his work was without merit but the validity	of his assumptions concerning the meaning of history must always be	considered against this background of an unprofessional approach.	4.057305008294136
4006. his credulity is perhaps best illustrated in his introduction to the	emancipation of massachusetts which purports to examine the	trials of moses and to draw a parallel between the leader of the israelite	exodus from egypt and the leadership of the puritan clergy in	colonial new england.	5.116539246582347
4007. much criticism has been leveled at this rather	forced analogy but what is equally significant is adams' complete	acceptance of the biblical record as good and trustworthy history.	4.05923726992119
4008. in light of the scholarly reappraisals engendered by the higher	criticism this is a most remarkable statement particularly coming	from one who was well known for his antifundamentalist views.	6.142413653011752
4009. the desire	to substantiate a thesis at the expense of sound research technique	smacks more of	the propagandist than the historian.	4.00562759368656
4010. a similar amateurish	characteristic is revealed in adams' failure to check the	accuracy and authenticity of his informational sources.	5.450107870776621
4011. if he found data	that fitted his general plan he used it and counted his sources trustworthy.	4.749687296638134
4012. conversely if statistics were uncovered which contradicted	a cherished theory the sources were denounced as faulty.	5.550554466109728
4013. such manipulations	are frequently encountered in his essay on the suppression	of the monasteries during the english reformation.	4.414160373195987
4014. adams depended largely	on the dispatches of foreign ambassadors and observers in england	claiming that the reports of such agents had to be accurate because	there were no newspapers.	5.405104860535776
4015. this is certainly an irrational dogmatism	in which the modern mind attempts to understand the spirit of the sixteenth	century on twentieth-century terms.	4.9119709013660815
4016. moreover he rejects the	contemporary accounts of englishmen casually adjudging them to be distorted	by prejudice because the opinions of englishmen are of no	great value.	5.492407580073311
4017. what is exposited by this observation is not the inherent	prejudices of englishmen but the anglophobia of brooks adams.	4.909174359834339
4018. in all fairness it must be admitted that adams made no pretense	at being an impartial historian.	6.8181704509232075
4019. impartiality to him meant an unwillingness	to generalize and to search for a synthesis.	4.448360245327874
4020. he deplored the	impact of german historiography on the writing of history terming	it a dismal monster.	5.751746395508077
4021. ranke and his disciples had reduced history	to a profession of dullness; brooks adams preferred the chronicles	of froissart or the style and theorizing of edward gibbon for	at least they took a stand on the issues about which they wrote.	3.458812742490038
4022. he wrote	eloquently to william james that impartial history was not only	impossible but undesirable.	5.948670829384279
4023. if the historian was convinced of his own	correctness then he should not allow his vision to become fogged by	disturbing facts.	4.2798809214220475
4024. it was history that must be in error not the historian.	6.971007363091392
4025. it was this basic trait that separated adams from the ranks	of professional historians and led him to commit time and time again what	was his most serious offense against the historical method- namely	the tendency to assume the truth of an hypothesis before submitting	it to the test of facts.	3.5576310832928124
4026. all of adams' work reflects this	dogmatic characteristic.	9.148868804219276
4027. no page seems to be complete without the statement	of at least one unproved generalization.	5.767094051023303
4028. one example of this	was his assertion that h all servile revolts must be dealt with by	physical force.	6.010876257963926
4029. there is no explanation of terms nor a qualification	that most such revolts have been dealt with by force- only a bald	dogmatism that they must because of some undefined compulsion be	so repelled.	3.903399556530306
4030. on matters of race he was similarly inflexible: most	of the modern latin races seem to have inherited h the rigidity	of the roman mind.	5.799478682271596
4031. he cites the french revolution as typifying	this rigidity but makes no mention of the italians who have been able	to	adapt to all types of circumstances.	4.219592710530442
4032. he pontificates that one	of the first signs of advancing civilization is the fall in the value	of women in men's eyes.	5.517285395048556
4033. it made no difference that most evidence	points to an opposite conclusion.	5.298715808955571
4034. for adams had made up his mind before	all the facts were available.	6.323738128928239
4035. all critics of adams and	his methods have observed this particular deficiency.	4.976568044153196
4036. j t shotwell	was appalled by such spurious history as that which attributed the	fall of the carolingian empire to the woolen trade and he urged adams	to transform his essay into a real history embodying not merely	those facts which fit into his theory but also the modifications	and exceptions.	4.664099410113018
4037. a m wergeland called the adams method literally	antihistorical while clive day maintained that the assumptions	were not confined to theories alone but were also applicable to straight	factual evidence.	3.72725939352501
4038. moreover stated day he always omits	facts which tend to disprove his hypothesis.	6.607120211838668
4039. even d a wasson	who compared the emancipation of massachusetts to the lifting	of a fog from ancient landscapes was also forced to admit the methodological	deficiencies of the author.	3.844334976769817
4040. in summary brooks adams	felt that the nature of history was order and that the order so discovered	was as much subject to historical laws as the forces of nature.	5.8453136137545725
4041. moreover he believed that most professional historians lacked some	of the essential instruments for a proper study of history.	4.503482051369168
4042. however	despite the insight of many of his observations his own conclusions	are open to suspicion because of his failure to employ at all times the	correct research methods.	5.777854497685512
4043. this should not prejudice an evaluation of	his findings but they were not the findings of a completely impartial	investigator.	4.455720521803332
4044. what was perhaps more important than his concept of	the nature of history and the historical method were those forces which	shaped the direction of his thought.	6.265438214721686
4045. in the final analysis his contribution	to american historiography was founded on almost intuitive insights	into religion economics and darwinism the three factors which	conditioned his search for a law of history.	3.9707313957589285
4046. brooks adams considered religion as an extremely significant	manifestation of man's fear of the unknown.	5.709233643418992
4047. but it was nothing	more than that.	8.543063809728357
4048. religion and the churches were institutions which	had been created by man not god.	5.949282378381776
4049. he did not deny god; he simply	did not believe that a creator intervened or interfered in human	affairs.	4.891655062494059
4050. the historian need not be concerned with the philosophical problems	suggested by religion.	6.832007516598666
4051. there was no evidence either of a positive	or negative type of the actions of a divine being in this world;	and since the historian should only be interested in strictly terrestrial	activity his research should eliminate the supernatural.	3.8970790287109995
4052. furthermore	he must regard religion as the expression of human forces.	6.289010577019261
4053. certainly he must recognize its power and attempt to ascertain its	influence on the flow of history but he must not confuse the natural	and the mundane with the divine.	3.939507862722654
4054. adams was not breaking new ground	when he claimed that the worship of an unseen power was in reality	a reflection of man's inability to cope with his environment.	5.061901042242228
4055. students	of anthropology and comparative religion had long been aware that	there was indeed a direct connection.	4.4571669282377435
4056. but adams was one of the first	to suggest that this human incompetence was the only motivating factor	behind religion.	7.015820651860829
4057. it was this fear which explained the development	of a priestly caste whose function in society was to mollify and appease	the angry deities.	4.06109563121252
4058. to keep themselves entrenched in power the	priests were forced to demonstrate their unique status through the miracle.	5.839175435567466
4059. it was the use of the supernatural that kept them in business.	7.122087681362724
4060. the german barbarians of the fourth century offered an excellent example:	the germans in the fourth century were a very simple	race who comprehended little of natural laws and who therefore referred	phenomena they did not understand to supernatural intervention.	4.930501694642445
4061. this intervention could only be controlled by priests and thus the	invasions caused a rapid rise in the influence of the sacred class.	4.2800231654883
4062. the	power of every ecclesiastical organization has always rested on the	miracle and the clergy have always proved their divine commission as	did elijah.	5.103675880876918
4063. adams contended that once such a special class	had been created it became a vested interest and sought to maintain	itself by assuming exclusive control over the relationships between	god and man.	3.6777050603077264

4188. his english friends it said had gone into training to keep	up with him vocally and with his allegro movements around the luncheon	table.	5.346487147377871
4189. the new york times editorialist wondered just who	would stop mr lewis and make him write a book.	4.4234280599246025
4190. lewis's	remarks about his marriage were suggestive enough to induce american	reporters to invade the offices of harcourt brace + company for	information to pursue mrs lewis to cromwell hall and after	she had returned to new york to ferret her out at the stanhope on	upper fifth avenue where she had taken an apartment.	4.755031163139416
4191. there to the	evening post she emphatically denied the divorce rumors and explained	that she had stayed behind because of the schooling of their son	which henceforth would be strictly american.	4.183554143263321
4192. these rumors of permanent	separation started up a whole crop of stories about her.	6.072932955837091
4193. one had	it that a friend protesting her snobbery said but gracie	you are an american aren't you?	4.34762191062725
4194.  and she replied i was born	in america but i was conceived in vienna.	7.262245722212815
4195. lewis	himself furthered these tales.	6.683325264329536
4196. he is said to have reported that once	when she went to a hospital to call on a friend after a serious operation	and the friend protested that it had been nothing she replied	well it was your healthy american peasant blood that pulled	you through.	5.48033932634402
4197. with these and similar tales he was entertaining his	english friends all of whom he was seeing when he was not showing	blackman the sights of london and its environs.	4.599872324070651
4198. at once upon	his arrival he telephoned lady sybil colefax who invited them to	tea and then lewis decided to give a party as a quick way of rounding	up his friends.	5.343883854032879
4199. he invited lady sybil lord thomson bechhofer	roberts and a half dozen others.	5.62431291813696
4200. it was a dinner party lewis had	been drinking during the afternoon and long before the party really	got under way he was quite drunk with the result that the party broke	up even before dinner was over.	5.324813017411758
4201. lewis at the head of the table would	leap up and move around behind the chairs of his guests making remarks	that when not highly offensive were at least highly inappropriate	and then presently he collapsed and was put to bed.	3.7081662258636445
4202. when	blackman emerged from the bedroom everyone was gone except the tolerant	lord thomson who stayed and chatted with him for half an hour	and then blackman lay awake most of that night despairing of what he	must expect on the continent.	4.69565759163433
4203. finally at dawn he fell asleep and	when he awoke and came into the living room he found lewis in his pajamas	before the fire smoking a cigarette.	4.09614618790318
4204. blackman said that he wanted	to apologize for not having prevented lewis from making that horrible	spectacle of himself that he should have seized him by the neck	at once and forcibly hauled him into his bedroom.	5.076089339863545
4205. lewis warned him never	to lay a hand on him and then blackman asked for his fare back	to the united states.	3.841511969386553
4206. lewis looked at him and began to cry and then	saying that he was going to make a promise he asked blackman to call	the porter and to tell him to take out all the liquor that he did	not want.	5.886623974811171
4207. and from now on for the rest of this trip i will only	drink what you agree that i should drink.	4.707334387960655
4208. blackman called the porter	and had him remove everything but one bottle of brandy and after	that they would have a cocktail or two before dinner or on one of their	walking trips beer or in france and italy wine in moderation.	5.086781070044102
4209. lewis gave him a guidebook tour of london and motoring and	walking took him to stratford but the london stay was for only ten	days and on the twentieth they took the train for southampton where	they spent the night for an early morning channel crossing.	3.796246461439901
4210. near	southampton in a considerable establishment lived homer vachell	a well-known pulp writer and his brother horace- both friends of	lewis's.	5.407067213161106
4211. he suggested that they call on these brothers who received	them pleasantly.	4.88329851797021
4212. then they returned to their hotel and got ready	for bed.	8.449785038412156
4213. it was late and blackman was ready to go to sleep but lewis	was not.	5.583803196458196
4214. he said we had a good time tonight didn't we earl?	8.511054939962097
4215. 	earl agreed and lewis said that it would have been very different	if his wife had been with him.	5.135752552768564
4216. then he kept blackman awake	for more than an hour while he did an imaginary dialogue between his wife	and himself in which discussing the evening he was continually berated.	5.2654973377031755
4217. he began the dialogue by having his wife announce that one does	not invade people's homes without warning them that one is coming	and went on from that with the entire catalogue of his social gaucheries.	3.874954087353991
4218. from 1613 on if the lists exist they contain between twenty to thirty	names.	6.399703025198675
4219. as the total number of incepting bachelors in 1629 was according	to masson two hundred fifty-nine	the twenty-four names listed in the ordo senioritatis for that	year constitute slightly less than one tenth of the total number of bachelors	who then incepted.	3.886499131088411
4220. there were four from st john's and	four from christ's three from pembroke and two from each of the	colleges jesus peterhouse queens' and trinity with caius	clare king's magdalene and sidney supplying one each in the ordo	senioritatis.	4.9636224269485325
4221. the list was headed by henry hutton of st	john's who was matriculated from st john's at easter	1625.	3.71780471901309
4222. he became a fellow of jesus in 1629 proceeded ma from	jesus in 1632 and was proctor in 1639-40.	5.645571143051672
4223. the second name was edward	kempe matriculated from queens' college at easter 1625.	4.530410915352612
4224. he proceeded ma in 1632 and bd in 1639 being made	fellow in 1632.	6.010295572574317
4225. he was ordained deacon 16 june and priest 22 december	1633.	5.301308389229969
4226. the third name was john ravencroft who was admitted	to the inner temple in november 1631.	5.531016674600635
4227. the fourth name was john	milton of christ's college followed by richard manningham	of peterhouse who matriculated 16 october 1624.	3.857661238739999
4228. venn gave his ba	as 1624 a mistake for 1629.	6.620561755940876
4229. manningham also proceeded ma	in 1632 and became a fellow of his college in that year.	4.131860641767443
4230. john	boutflower of christ's was twelfth in the list coming from perse	school under mr lovering as pensioner 20 april 1625 under mr	alsop.	5.103675880876918
4231. the fourteenth name was richard buckenham written	buckman admitted to christ's college under scott 2 july 1625.	3.7635883207428518
4232. the fifteenth name was thomas baldwin admitted to christ's	4 march 1625 under alsop.	5.289832921804139
4233. christ's college was well represented	that year in the ordo and the name highest on the list from that	college was milton's fourth in the entire university.	4.02519215720588
4234. small wonder	that milton later boasted of how well his work had been received	there since he attained a rank in the order of commencing bachelors higher	than that of any other inceptor from christ's of that year.	5.1008041578092795
4235. it is not possible to reconstruct fully the arrangements whereby	these honors lists were then made up or even how the names that they	contained assumed the order in which we find them.	4.193350676521198
4236. the process usually	began with a tutor boasting about a boy as chappell had boasted about	lightfoot to the higher officers of the college and university.	5.615889607435522
4237. then the various officers of the college might take up the case.	6.621526141825366
4238. it	would however reach the proctors and other officers in charge of the	public-school performances of the incepting bachelors and the place	that any individual obtained in the lists depended greatly on how he comported	himself in the public schools during his acts therein as he was	incepting.	5.090482735965537
4239. of course the higher officials could add or place a name	on the list wherever they wished.	4.763114160634027
4240. milton's name being fourth is neither	too high nor too low to be assigned to the arbitrary action of	vice-chancellor proctor master or other mighty hand.	5.037682432595579
4241. he evidently	earned the place assigned him.	5.937584561088178
4242. career	looking back from the spring of 1629 over the four years	of milton's undergraduate days certain phases of his college	career stand out as of permanent consequence to him and hence to us.	5.23869022615548
4243. of	course the principal factor in the whole experience was the kind of	education he received.	5.421268088329375
4244. it differed from what an undergraduate receives	today from any american college or university mainly in the certainty	of what he was forced to learn compared with the loose and widely	scattered information obtained today by most of our undergraduates.	5.257421695343723
4245. milton	was required to absorb and display an intensive and accurate knowledge	of latin grammar logic-rhetoric ethics physics or natural philosophy	metaphysics and latin greek and hebrew.	3.692532313021866
4246. he had also	sampled various special fields of learning being unable to miss some	study of divinity justinian.	6.0612077103682624
4247. above all	he had learned to write formal latin prose and verse to a remarkable	degree of artistry.	4.406010612944211
4248. he had learned to dispute devastatingly both formally	and informally in latin and according to the rules on any topic	pro or con drawn from almost any subject more especially from aristotle's	works.	5.619758405803548
4249. he could produce carefully constructed orations	set and formal speeches artfully and prayerfully made by writing and	rewriting with all the aid his tutor and others could provide and then	delivered verbatim from memory.	3.8871082265997017
4250. he had also learned to dispute extempore	remarkably well the main evidence for which of course is the presence	of his name in the honors list of 162829.	5.669889683062667
4251. he also displayed	the ability to write latin verse on almost any topic of dispute the	verses of course to be delivered from memory.	4.252787520174001
4252. then we have surviving	at least one instance of a poem prepared for another in naturam non	pati senium and perhaps also the de idea platonica.	5.496713565188327
4253. but	his greatest achievement in his own eyes and in the eyes of his colleagues	and teachers was his amazing ability to produce literary latin	pieces and he was often called on to do so.	4.5477139979347765
4254. these were his public	academic activities domi forisque in the college and in the university.	7.633138990211616
4255. and his performances attracted much attention as the frequency	of his surviving pieces in any calendar that may be set up for his	undergraduate activities testifies.	4.318896072884396
4256. his other activities are	not so easily recovered.	7.498775836491436
4257. his statements about sports and exercises of	a physical nature are suggestive but inconclusive.	4.437450999192512
4258. his later boastings	of his skill with the small sword are indicative of much time and	practice devoted to the use of that weapon.	5.926989679875185
4259. venn and others have dealt	with sports and pastimes at cambridge in milton's day with not very	specific results.	4.065890504560761
4260. milton himself uncommunicative as he is about	his lesser and nonliterary activities at least gives us some evidence	that he was a great walker under any and all conditions.	5.639703530916782
4261. his early	poems and some of his prose prolusions speak of wanderings in the city	and the neighboring country that may be extended to cambridge and its	surrounding countryside.	4.410369735751745
4262. the town itself and the reedy cam he	often visited as did all in the university.	5.451777835082632
4263. the churches the taverns	and the various other places of the town must have known his figure	well as he roved to and about them.	3.742113064800394
4264. the tiny hamlet of chesterton	to the north with the fens and marshes lying on down the ouse river	may have attracted him often as it did many other youths of the time.	4.761319455471749
4265. the gog magog hills to the southeast afforded him and all other	students a vantage point from which to view the town and university	of their dwelling.	3.7015430733703973
4266. the country about cambridge is flat and not particularly	spectacular in its scenery though it offers easy going to the	foot traveler.	5.150835275134894
4267. ball games especially football required some attention	and other organized sports may have attracted him as participant	or spectator.	3.996502389132312
4268. he smoked as did everybody and imbibed the various alcoholic	beverages of that day although his protestations while at cambridge	and after that he was no drunkard point to reasonable abstinence	from the wild drinking bouts of some of the undergraduates and we	must add of some of their elders including many of the regents or teachers.	5.376152885211174
4269. what manner of person does milton appear to have been	when as an undergraduate he resided at christ's college?	4.225263716808938
4270.  he was	then a slightly built young man of pleasing appearance medium stature	and handsome face.	5.811796091316399
4271. graceful as his fencing and dancing lessons had	taught him to be in addition to the natural grace of his slight wiry	frame he cut enough of a figure to have evoked a nickname in the college	to which he himself referred in prolusion 6: a quibusdam	audivi nuper domina.	3.8819259460890656
4272. that is if we can trust that most specious	of prolusions packed as it is with wit and persiflage.	6.743843673745461
4273. the domina	sounds real enough if we could only trust the conditions under	which we learn of its use; but anyone who would put much trust in any	phase of prolusion 6 except its illusive allusiveness deserves	whatever fate may be meted out to him by virtue of the egregiously	stilted banter.	3.3599196936371682
4274. in short the traditional epithet for milton of 'lady	of christ's' while eminently fitting rests only on this	baffling passage in the midst of the most treacherous piece of writing	milton left us.	5.7634153419525775
4275. aubrey's mention of it	comes from this prolusion through christopher	milton or edward phillips.	4.411891185517149
4276. it is not a question of truth or falsity;	the prolusion in which the autobiographic statement about the	epithet occurs is such a mass of intentionally buried allusions that	almost nothing in it can be accepted as true- or discarded as false.	5.67914905017274
4277. the entire exercise latin and english is most suggestive of the	kind of person milton had become at christ's during his undergraduate	career; the mere fact that he was selected though as a substitute	to act as interlocutor or moderator for it or perhaps we should say	with buck as 'father of the act' is in itself a difficult phase	of his development to grasp.	3.481928888606162
4278. milton was to act as the archfool the	supreme wit the lightly bantering pater pater liber who could	at once trip lightly over that which deserved such treatment or could	at will annihilate the common enemies of the college gathering and	with words alone.	4.829292425879523
4279. from an exercise involving merely raucous rough-and-tumble	comedy in his hands the performance turned into a revel of	wit and word play indecent at times but always learned pointed and	carefully aimed at some individuals present and at the whole assembly.	3.7993388570311883
4280. to do this successfully required great skill and a special talent	for both solemn and ribald raillery a talent not bestowed on many persons	but one with which milton was marked as being endowed and in which	at least in this performance he obviously reveled.	4.845208424452267
4281. it may be thought	unfortunate that he was called on entirely by accident to perform	if again we may trust the opening of the oratio for it marks	the beginning for us of his use of his peculiar form of witty word play	that even in this latin banter has in it the unmistakable element of	viciousness and an almost sadistic delight in verbally tormenting an	adversary.	3.784614660291554
4282. but the real beginnings of this development in him go back	to the opposing of grammar school and probably if it had not been this	occasion and these latin lines it would have been some others such	as the first prolusion that set off this streak in him of unbridled	and scathing verbal attack on an enemy.	5.015217034469591
4283. all western europe would hear	and listen to him in this same vein about the middle of the century.	5.170023412568413
4284. but these prolusions that we have surviving from the christ's	college days are only one phase of his existence then.	6.211218967270058
4285. perhaps	his most important private activity was the combination of reading	discussion with a few- if we can trust his writings to diodati and	the younger gill very few- congenial companions.	3.7102843265533374
4286. lines 23-36 of lycidas	later point to a friendship with edward king who entered	christ's college 9 june 1626.	5.557590362270223
4287. no other names among the young men	in residence at the time seem to have been even suggested by milton	as those of persons with whom he in any way consorted.	4.986348073968119
4288. but that scarcely	means that he was the aloof forbidding type of student who shared	few if any activities with his fellows the banter of the surviving	prolusions providing enough evidence to deny this.	5.6642358972233335
4289. apparently he was	not a participant in the college or university theatricals which he	once attacked as utterly unworthy performances;	but even in that famous passage milton was aiming not at the	theatricals as such but at their performance by 'persons either enter'd	or presently to enter into the ministry'.	3.6144543026794156
4290. the fact that he	nowhere mentioned theatrical performances as part of the activities of	the boys later in his hypothetical academy should not be taken	too seriously as evidence that he desired them to eschew such performances.	5.727224791699259
4291. perhaps in that short piece or letter written to hartlib in	which he sketched his scheme for educating young men he merely overlooked	that phase of their exercises.	3.8576208519307746
4292. writers of this class of science fiction have clearly in mind the assumptions	that man can master the principles of this cause-and-effect universe	and that such mastery will necessarily better the human lot.	5.076378581498351
4293. on	the other hand the bright vision of the future has been directly stated	in science fiction concerned with projecting ideal societies- science	fiction of course is related if sometimes distantly to that	utopian literature optimistic about science literature whose period	of greatest vigor in the late nineteenth and early twentieth centuries	produced edward bellamy's looking backward and h g	wells's a modern utopia.	3.780241290435278
4294. in arthur clarke's childhood's	end though written after the present flood of dystopias	began we can see the bright vision of science fiction clearly	defined.	5.281984428739887
4295. childhood's end- apparently indebted to kurd	lasswitz's utopian romance auf zwei planeten and	also to wells's histories of the future especially the world set	free-	describes	the bloodless conquest of earth by the overlords vastly superior	creatures who come to our world in order to prepare the human race for	its next stage of development an eventual merging with the composite	mind of the universe.	3.6405979535997477
4296. arriving just in time to stop men from turning	their planet into a radioactive wasteland the overlords unite earth	into one world in which justice order and benevolence prevail and	ignorance poverty and fear have ceased to exist.	5.043506774003533
4297. under their rule	earth becomes a technological utopia.	6.332870485884485
4298. both abolition of war and new	techniques of production particularly robot factories greatly increase	the world's wealth a situation described in the following passage	which has the true utopian ring: everything was so cheap that	the necessities of life were free provided as a public service by	the community as roads water street lighting and drainage had once	been.	4.660438642592516
4299. a man could travel anywhere he pleased eat whatever he fancied-	without handing over any money.	4.51092844006979
4300. with destructive tensions and	pressures removed men have the vigor and energy to construct a new human	life- rebuilding entire cities expanding facilities for entertainment	providing unlimited opportunities for education- indeed for	the first time giving everyone the chance to employ his talents to the	fullest.	4.85438420487043
4301. mankind as a result attains previously undreamed of levels	of civilization and culture a golden age which the overlords a very	evident symbol of science have helped produce by introducing reason	and the scientific method into human activities.	3.723941750937791
4302. thus science is the	savior of mankind and in this respect childhood's end only	blueprints in greater detail the vision of the future which though not	always so directly stated	has nevertheless been present in the minds	of most science-fiction writers.	5.724550653801039
4303. considering then the optimism	which has permeated science fiction for so long what is really remarkable	is that during the last twelve years many science-fiction writers	have turned about and attacked their own cherished vision of the future	have attacked the childhood's end kind of faith that science	and technology will inevitably better the human condition.	3.5197664953853147
4304. and they	have done this on a very large scale with a veritable flood of novels	and stories which are either dystopias or narratives of adventure	with dystopian elements.	5.016965913317602
4305. because of the means of publication- science-fiction	magazines and cheap paperbacks- and because dystopian science	fiction is still appearing in quantity the full range and extent	of this phenomenon can hardly be known though one fact is evident:	the science-fiction imagination has been immensely fertile in its extrapolations.	3.702704797639633
4306. among the dystopias for example isaac asimov's the	caves of steel portrays the deadly effects on human life	of the super-city of the future; james blish's a case of conscience	describes a world hiding from its own weapons of destruction	in underground shelters; ray bradbury's fahrenheit	451 presents a book-burning society in which wall television	and hearing-aid radios enslave men's minds; walter m miller	jr's a canticle for leibowitz finds men after	the great atomic disaster stumbling back to their previous level of	civilization and another catastrophe; frederick pohl's the midas	touch predicts an economy of abundance which in order	to remain prosperous must set its robots to consuming surplus production;	clifford d simak's how-2 tells of a future	when robots have taken over leaving men nothing to do; and robert	sheckley's the status civilization describes a world	which frightened by the powers of destruction science has given it	becomes static and conformist.	4.290548998395671
4307. a more complete list would also include	bradbury's the pedestrian philip k	dick's	solar lottery wilson	tucker's the long loud silence jack vance's	to live forever	gore vidal's messiah and	bernard wolfe's limbo as well as the three perhaps most	outstanding dystopias frederik pohl and c m kornbluth's	the space merchants kurt vonnegut's player	piano works which	we will later examine in detail.	3.5753725369693243
4308. the novels and stories like pohl's	drunkard's walk with the focus on adventure and	with the dystopian elements only a dim background- in this case an	uneasy overpopulated world in which the mass of people do uninteresting	routine jobs while a carefully selected university-trained elite	runs everything- are in all likelihood as numerous as dystopias.	4.763842723307709
4309. there is of course nothing new about dystopias for they belong	to a literary tradition which including also the closely related satiric	utopias stretches from at least as far back as the eighteenth century	and swift's gulliver's travels to the twentieth century	and zamiatin's we capek's war with the newts huxley's	brave new world e m forster's the machine	stops c s lewis's that hideous strength	and orwell's nineteen eighty-four and which in science fiction	is represented	before the present deluge as early as wells's trilogy the	time machine a story of the days to come and when	the sleeper wakes and as recently as jack williamson's with	folded hands the classic story of men replaced by their	own robots.	3.4319032661583204
4310. what makes the current phenomenon unique is that so	many science-fiction writers have reversed a trend and turned to writing	works critical of the impact of science and technology on human life.	5.467257636568163
4311. since the great flood of these dystopias has appeared only in the	last twelve years it seems fairly reasonable to assume that the chief	impetus was the 1949 publication of nineteen eighty-four an assumption	which is supported by the frequent echoes of such details as	room 101 along with education by conditioning from brave new world	a book to which science-fiction writers may well have returned	with new interest after reading the more powerful orwell dystopia.	3.3967126062917914
4312. not all recent science fiction however is dystopian for the	optimistic strain is still very much alive in mission of gravity	and childhood's end as we have seen as well as in many other	recent popular novels and stories like fred hoyle's the black	cloud; and among works of dystopian science fiction not	all provide intelligent criticism and very few have much merit as literature-	but then real quality has always been scarce in science fiction.	4.88314643603221
4313. in addition there are many areas of the human situation besides	the impact of science and technology which are examined for science-fiction	dystopias often extrapolate political social economic tendencies	only indirectly related to science and technology.	4.561368358676789
4314. nevertheless	with all these qualifications and exceptions the current dystopian	phenomenon remains impressive for its criticism that science and technology	instead of bringing utopia may well enslave dehumanize and even	destroy men.	4.815391403268571
4315. how effectively these warnings can be presented is seen	in pohl and kornbluth's the space merchants vonnegut's	player piano and wyndham's re-birth.	4.126862687011944
4316. easily	the best known of these three novels is the space merchants a	good example of a science-fiction dystopia which extrapolates much more	than the impact of science on human life though its most important	warning is in this area namely as to the use to which discoveries in	the behavioral sciences may be put.	5.070603245228561
4317. the novel which is not merely dystopian	but also brilliantly satiric describes a future america where	one-sixteenth of the population the men who run advertising agencies	and big corporations control the rest of the people the submerged	fifteen-sixteenths who are the workers and consumers with the government	being no more than a clearing house for pressures.	4.168477118891367
4318. like	ours the economy of the space merchants must constantly expand in order	to survive and like ours it is based on the principle of ever	increasing everybody's work and profits in the circle of consumption.	5.648467736456437
4319. the consequences of course have been dreadful: reckless expansion	has led to overpopulation pollution of the earth and depletion	of its natural resources.	4.42070514155706
4320. for example even the most successful executive	lives in a two-room apartment while ordinary people rent space in	the stairwells of office buildings in which to sleep at night; soyaburgers	have replaced meat and wood has become so precious that it is	saved for expensive jewelry; and the atmosphere is so befouled that	no one dares walk in the open without respirators or soot plugs.	4.860322465860534
4321. while the space merchants indicates as kingsley amis has	correctly observed some of the impending consequences of the growth	of industrial and commercial power and satirizes existing habits	in the advertising profession its warning and analysis penetrate	much deeper.	3.9495623746089272
4322. what is wrong with advertising is not only that it is	an outrage an assault on people's mental privacy or that it	is a major cause for a wasteful economy of abundance or that it contains	a coercive tendency.	5.382221983372897
4323. rather what kornbluth	and pohl are really doing is warning against the dangers inherent	in perfecting a science of man and his motives.	4.1066493507666735
4324. the space	merchants like such humanist documents as joseph wood krutch's	the measure of man and c s lewis's the abolition	of man considers what may result from the scientific study	of human nature.	4.7037670262739235
4325. if man is actually the product of his environment	and if science can discover the laws of human nature and the ways in which	environment determines what people do then someone- a someone	probably standing outside traditional systems of values- can turn around	and develop completely efficient means for controlling people.	3.7249664543646537
4326. thus	we will have a society consisting of the planners or conditioners	and the controlled.	6.3950491826433336
4327. and this of course is exactly what madison avenue	has been accused of doing albeit in a primitive way with its hidden	persuaders and what the space merchants accomplish with much	greater sophistication and precision.	4.1130979222168005
4328. pohl and kornbluth's	ad men have long since thrown out appeals to reason and developed techniques	of advertising which tie in with every basic trauma and neurosis	in american life which work on the libido of consumers which	are linked to the great prime motivations of the human spirit.	5.107555215736205
4329. as the hero mitchell courtenay explains before his conversion	the job of advertising is to convince people without letting them	know that they're being convinced.	4.042864218662398
4330. and to do this requires first	of all the kind of information about people which is provided by the	scientists in industrial anthropology and consumer research who for	example tell courtenay that three days is the optimum priming period	for a closed social circuit to be triggered with a catalytic cue-phrase-	which means that an effective propaganda technique is to send	an idea into circulation and then three days later reinforce or undermine	it.	4.858327090836032
4331. and the second requirement for convincing people without	their knowledge is artistic talent to prepare the words and pictures which	persuade by using the principles which the scientists have discovered.	4.320492872536565
4332. thus the copywriter in the world of the space merchants is the	person who in earlier ages might have been a lyric poet the person capable	of putting together words that stir and move and sing.	6.350769436862289
4333. as	courtenay explains here in this profession we reach into the souls	of men and women.	4.346493329290896
4334. and we do it by taking talent- and redirecting	it.	6.942007227477309
4335. now the basic question to be asked in this situation	is what motivates the manipulators that is what are their values?	4.3567819930649
4336. -	since as courtenay says nobody should play with lives the way	we do unless he's motivated by the highest ideals.	5.33084098673499
4337. but the only	ideal he can think of is sales! indeed again and again the	space merchants confirm the prediction of the humanists that the conditioners	and behavioral scientists once they have seen through human	nature will have nothing except their impulses and desires to guide	them.	3.7222264393763327
4338. we often say of a person that he looks young for his age	or old for his age.	5.693685624831177
4339. yet even in the more extreme of such cases	we seldom go very far astray in guessing what his age actually is.	4.789852066418782
4340. and	this means i suppose that almost invariably age reveals itself by	easily recognizable signs engraved on both the body and the mind.	5.530660324020607
4341. young	for his age means only the presence of some minor characteristic	not quite usual.	4.748284589293116
4342. stigmata quite sufficient for diagnosis are nevertheless	there.	7.698226595403342
4343. an assumption of youth or the presence of a few youthful	characteristics deceives no more successfully than rouge or dyed	hair.	4.792025824184004
4344. looking young for your age means for your age and	it means no more.	6.03219744133936
4345. a mind expressing itself in words may reveal	itself a little less obviously as old or young.	4.032285002619357
4346. its surface loses its	bloom and submits to its wrinkles in ways less immediately obvious	than the body does.	5.709941797253307
4347. youth may be and often is skeptical cynical or	despairing; age may be idealistic believing and much given to professions	of optimism.	3.906369919448577
4348. but there is nevertheless always a subtle difference	in the way in which supposedly similar opinions are held.	7.092161671165487
4349. the	pessimism of the young is defiant anxious to confess or even exaggerate	its ostensible gloom and so exuberant as to reveal the fact that	it regards	its ability to face up to the awful truth as more than enough to compensate	for the awfulness of that truth.	3.608304310689359
4350. similarly the optimism of age	protests too much.	7.907367817489904
4351. if it proclaims that the best is yet to be it always	arouses at least in the young either a suspicious question or perhaps	the exclamation of the negro youth who saw on a tombstone the	inscription i am not dead but sleeping.	4.156926458496278
4352. boy you ain't fooling	nobody but yourself.	7.603896187885215
4353. we may say of some unfortunates	that they were never young.	5.462722414021455
4354. we cannot truthfully say of anyone who has	succeeded in entering deep into his sixties that he was never old.	6.5998971337953165
4355. those famous lines of the greek anthology with which a fading beauty	dedicates her mirror at the shrine of a goddess reveal a wise attitude:	venus take my votive glass since i am not what i was what	from this day i shall be venus let me never see.	3.750445630114623
4356. no	good can come of contemplating the sad inevitable fact that once youth	has passed a worse and worse time still succeeds the former.	5.051766433984403
4357. but there are at least two reasons for contemplating one's mind	in even a cracked mirror.	5.738380810837608
4358. one is that there sometimes are real although	inadequate compensations in growing old.	8.058458096733133
4359. serenity if one is fortunate	enough to achieve it is not so good as joy but it is something.	5.5920255288215435

4364. many readers	of this department no doubt discount certain of my opinions for	the simple reason that they can guess pretty accurately even if they	have never actually been told what my age is.	5.156939712858829
4365. at least i should like	them to know that i know these discounts are being made.	5.4274230082236645
4366. let	me then glance into the mirror.	7.603896187885215
4367. i have known some	men and women who said that the selves they are told about or even remember	seem utter strangers to them now; that their remote past is as	discontinuous with their present selves as lacking in any conscious	likeness to their mature personality as the self of a butterfly may be	imagined discontinuous with that of the caterpillar it once was.	3.706320268475991

4371. fundamental values temperament and the way in which	one approaches a conviction change less of course than specific opinions.	4.509305662834427

4399. apropos of what some would	call cynicism i remember an anecdote the source of which i forget.	4.636802240769381

4412. without really changing the general	subject i take this opportunity to confess that i am troubled by	doubts not only about pacifism but also when asked to join in the protest	against a law that most of those who consider themselves humane	and liberal seem to regard as obviously barbarous; namely the law	that prescribes the death penalty for murder when there seem to be no	extenuating circumstances.	5.043625821426653

4420. for here if anywhere in contemporary literature is a major effort to	counterbalance existentialism and restore some of its former lustre to	the tarnished image of the species man or as malraux himself puts	it to make men conscious of the grandeur they ignore in themselves.	5.0259979217424835
4421. andre malraux's the walnut trees of altenburg	was written in the early years of the second world war during	a period of enforced leisure when he was taken prisoner by the germans	after the fall of france.	4.85846919052932
4422. the manuscript presumably after being	smuggled out of the country was published in switzerland in 1943.	6.727864355604274
4423. the work as it stands is not the entire book that malraux wrote at that	time- it is only the first section of a three-part novel called	la lutte avec l'ange; and this first section was somehow preserved	when the gestapo destroyed the rest.	3.728726390275355
4424. if we are to believe the list of titles printed in malraux's latest	book la metamorphose des dieux vol 1 he is	still	engaged in writing a large novel under his original title.	5.809770121343572
4425. but as he	remarks in his preface to the walnut trees a novel can hardly	ever be rewritten and when this one appears in its final form	the form of the first part h will no doubt be radically changed.	4.027394309114736
4426. malraux pretends perhaps with a trifle too self-conscious a modesty	that his fragmentary work will accordingly appeal only to the	curiosity of bibliophiles	and to connoisseurs of what might have	been.	4.847755985425517

4428. the theme of the walnut trees of altenburg is most closely	related to its immediate predecessor in malraux's array of novels:	man's hope.	4.9588489525022235
4429. this magnificent but greatly underestimated	book which bodies forth the very form and pressure of its time	as no other comparable creation has suffered severely from having	been written about an historical event- the spanish civil war-	that is still capable of fanning the smoldering fires of old political	feuds.	3.359145195096519
4430. even so apparently impartial a critic as w h frohock	has taken for granted that the book was originally intended as a piece	of loyalist propaganda; and has then gone on to argue with unimpeachable	consistency that all the obviously non-propagandistic aspects	of the book are simply inadvertent contradictions.	4.9258213129035395
4431. nothing	however could be farther from the truth.	5.3285636594893
4432. the whole purpose of	man's hope is to portray the tragic dialectic between means and	ends inherent in all organized political violence- and even when such	violence is a necessary and legitimate self-defense of liberty justice	and human dignity.	4.736042176689491
4433. nowhere before in malraux's pages have we	met such impassioned defenders of a quality of man which transcends	the realm of politics and even the realm of action altogether-	both the action of malraux's early anarchist-adventurers like perken	and garine and the self-sacrificing action of dedicated communists	like kyo gisors and katow in man's fate.	3.5878017188264133
4434. man engages	only a small part of himself in an action says old alvear the art-historian;	and the more the action claims to be total the smaller	is the part of man engaged.	5.473601582539634

4436. it is this larger theme of the quality	of man a quality that transcends the ideological and flows into	the human which now forms the pulsating heart of malraux's	artistic universe.	5.216834274839687
4437. malraux to be sure does not abandon the world	of violence combat and sudden death which has become his hallmark as	a creative artist and which is the only world apparently in which	his imagination can flame into life.	4.130371664827782
4438. the walnut trees of altenburg	includes not one war but two and throws in a turkish revolution	along with some guerrilla fighting in the desert for good measure.	4.732872541819942
4439. but	while war still serves as a catalyst for the values that malraux wishes	to express these values are no longer linked with the triumph or	defeat of any cause- whether that of an individual assertion of the	will-to-power or a collective attempt to escape from the humiliation	of oppression- as their necessary condition.	3.5245284270688892

4441. the walnut trees of altenburg	is composed in the form of a triptych with the two small side panels	framing and enclosing the main central episode of the novel.	3.939848499143848
4442. this	central episode consists of a series of staccato scenes set in the period	from the beginning of the present century up to the first world war.	7.886390572310304
4443. the framing scenes on the other hand both take place in the late	spring of 1940 just at the moment of the defeat of france in the	second great world conflict.	4.539328597140027
4444. the narrator is an alsatian serving with	the french army and he has the same name that malraux	himself was later to use in the resistance; like malraux he was also	serving in the tank corps before being captured and we learn as well	that in civilian life he had been a writer.	4.962807283577738

4487. while i fully agree with sir anthony's	contention i think that we must carry the analysis farther bearing	in mind that while common peril may be the measure of our need	the existence or absence of a positive sense of community must be the	measure of our capacity.	3.9839419439749775

4489. at the end of world war 2 free europe was	ready for a new beginning.	6.75735399143466
4490. the excesses of nationalism had brought	down upon europe a generation of tyranny and war and a return to the	old order of things seemed unthinkable.	4.795531641785159
4491. under these conditions a new	generation of europeans began to discover the bonds of long association	and shared values that for so long had been subordinated to nationalist	xenophobia.	3.9398223629379574
4492. a slow and painful trend toward unification has taken	hold a trend which may at any time be arrested and reversed but which	may also lead to a binding federation of europe.	5.036746701023358
4493. it may well be	that the unification of europe will prove inadequate that the survival	of free society will require nothing less than the confederation of	the entire western world.	4.289198339225906
4494. the movement toward european unity	has been expressed in two currents: federalism and functionalism	one looking to the constitution of a united states of europe the	other building on wartime precedents of practical coo^peration for the	solution of specific problems.	4.83639533852877
4495. thus far the advances made have been	almost entirely along functional lines.	5.00729073895379
4496. many factors contributed	to the growth of the european movement.	9.24552908235005
4497. in 1946 sir winston churchill	who had spoken often of european union during the war advocated	the formation of a kind of united states of europe.	4.70454801858179
4498. had	churchill been returned to office in 1945 it is just possible that	britain instead of standing fearfully aloof would have led europe	toward union.	5.3645674963869014

4501. another powerful factor in	the european movement was the threat of soviet aggression.	4.99966679011312
4502. the communist	coup in czechoslovakia in 1948 was followed immediately by the	conclusion of the brussels treaty a 50-year alliance among britain	france and the benelux countries.	4.698723859097317

4506. in 1952 the european coal and steel community was launched	placing the coal and steel production of france west germany italy	and benelux under a supranational high authority.	5.08990459393125
4507. for a time it	appeared that a common european army might be created but the project	for a european defense community was rejected by the french national	assembly in 1954.	4.149698683533787

4509. the overseas democracies	have generally encouraged the european unification movement	without seriously considering the wisdom of their own full participation	in a broader atlantic community.	3.966871661886913
4510. the united states and canada	belong only to nato and the new oecd.	7.766210365789379

4515. if a broader atlantic community is to	be formed- and my own judgment is that it lies within the realm of both	our needs and our capacity- a ready nucleus of machinery is at hand	in the nato alliance.	4.100823269750302

4525. the existence of a community is a state of mind- a conviction	that goals and values are widely shared that effective communication	is possible that mutual trust is reasonably assured.	3.7126023722784867

4905. exploration	to encourage exploration for domestic sources of minerals	the office of minerals exploration of the us	department of the interior offers financial assistance to firms	and individuals who desire to explore their properties or claims for	1 or more of the 32 mineral commodities listed in the ome regulations.	3.630505449328591
4906. this help is offered to applicants who ordinarily	would not undertake the exploration under present conditions or	circumstances at their sole expense and who are unable to obtain funds	from commercial sources on reasonable terms.	4.8880144092288225
4907. each applicant is required	to own or have sufficient interest in the property to be explored.	4.914985447326172
4908. the government will contract with an eligible applicant to pay up	to one-half of the cost of approved exploration work as it progresses.	5.6633495251233334
4909. the applicant pays the rest of the cost but his own time spent on the	work and charges for the use of equipment which he owns may be applied	toward his share of the cost.	4.397070158862798
4910. funds contributed by	the government are repaid by a royalty on production from the property.	5.659455227543579
4911. if nothing is produced there is no obligation to repay.	6.4729251202854154
4912. a 5-percent	royalty is paid on any production during the period the contract	is in effect; if the government certifies that production may be	possible from the property the royalty obligation continues for the	10-year period usually specified in the contract or until the government's	contribution is repaid with interest.	4.521578948656264

4915. only a very few of	the more advanced ones such as india and pakistan have developed	systematic techniques of programing.	4.465782385819627
4916. others have so-called development	plans but some of these are little more than lists of projects	collected from various ministries while others are statements of goals	without analysis of the actions required to attain them.	5.870033981972744
4917. only rarely	we	neither growth nor a development	program can be imposed on a country; it must express the nation's	own will and goal.	4.168621263828862
4918. nevertheless we can administer an aid program	in such a manner as to promote the development of responsible programing.	6.565009375279296
4919. first we can encourage responsibility by establishing	as conditions for assistance on a substantial and sustained scale the	definition of objectives and the assessment of costs.	3.9367604808057832
4920. second	we can make assistance for particular projects conditional on	the consistency of such projects with the program.	5.454336586728915
4921. third	we can offer technical help in the formulation of programs for development	which are adapted to the country's objectives and resources.	4.030379497536024
4922. this	includes assistance in- h assembling the basic economic financial	technological and educational information on which programing depends;	h surveying the needs and requirements over time of broad	sectors of the economy such as transport agriculture communication	industry and power; h designing the financial mechanisms of the	economy in ways that will promote growth without inflation; and h	administrative practices which will make possible the more effective	we must use	the application of conditions	in the allocation	of aid funds cannot of course be mechanical.	4.4271614564535
4923. it must	be recognized that countries at different stages of development have	very different capabilities of meeting such conditions.	4.395122545375294
4924. to insist	on a level of performance in programing and budgeting completely beyond	the capabilities of the recipient country would result in the frustration	of the basic objective of our development assistance to encourage	more rapid growth.	4.821665516767758
4925. in the more primitive areas where the capacity	to absorb and utilize external assistance is limited some activities	may be of such obvious priority that we may decide to support them	before a well worked out program is available.	3.784366757076687
4926. thus we might provide	limited assistance in such fields as education essential transport	communications and agricultural improvement despite the absence of	acceptable country programs.	5.507936846797572
4927. in such a case however we would encourage	the recipient country to get on with its programing task supply	it with substantial technical assistance in performing that task and	make it plain that an expansion or even a continuation of our assistance	to the country's development was conditional upon programing progress	being made.	3.5850007453484016
4928. at the other end of the spectrum where the	more advanced countries can be relied upon to make well thought through	decisions as to project priorities within a consistent program we should	be prepared to depart substantially from detailed project approval	as the basis for granting assistance and to move toward long-term support	in cooperation with other developed countries of the essential	foreign exchange requirements of the country's development program.	4.858676532442579
4929. a systematic approach to development budgeting and programing	is one important kind of self-help.	4.270512745051502
4930. it is vitally	important that the new us aid program should encourage all	of them since the main thrust for development must come from the less	developed countries themselves.	5.706646596686522
4931. external aid can only be marginal	although the margin as in the case of the marshall plan can be decisive.	5.128968236013997
4932. external aid can be effective only if it is a complement to self-help.	7.813356289256196
4933. us aid therefore should increasingly be designed to	provide incentives for countries to take the steps that only they themselves	can take.	4.340229011901879
4934. in establishing	conditions of self-help it is important that we not expect countries	to remake themselves in our image.	6.218283433202535
4935. open societies can take many forms	and within very broad limits recipients must be free to set their	own goals and to devise their own institutions to achieve those goals.	3.5846015628445467
4936. on the other hand it is no interference with sovereignty to point	out defects where they exist such as that a plan calls for factories	without power to run them or for institutions without trained personnel	to staff them.	5.38160444826329
4937. once we have made clear that we are genuinely concerned	with a country's development potential we can be blunt in suggesting	the technical conditions that must be met for development to occur.	4.308644722347639
4938. the major areas of self-help	are the following:	this includes not only development programing but also establishing	tax policies designed to raise equitably resources for investment;	fiscal and monetary policies designed to prevent serious inflation;	and regulatory policies aimed to attract the financial and managerial	resources of foreign investment and to prevent excessive luxury	the reduction of dependence on external	sources.	4.410142759865955
4939. with adequate attention to reducing dependence on imports and adopting	realistic exchange rates to encourage infant industries and spur exports.	4.163435386874098
4940. it also includes providing for the training of nationals to operate	tapping the energies of	for both economic and political reasons	all segments of the population must be able to share in the growth	of a country.	5.939240979496845
4941. otherwise development will not lead to longrun stability.	6.076938475589587
4942. in many societies what we	regard as corruption favoritism and personal influence are so accepted	as consistent with the mores of officialdom and so integral a part	of	routine administrative practice that any attempt to force their elimination	will be regarded by the local leadership as not only unwarranted	but unfriendly.	4.665857390831757
4943. yet an economy cannot get the most out of its resources	if dishonesty corruption and favoritism are widespread.	4.950407230437601
4944. moreover	tolerance by us of such practices results in serious waste and diversion	of aid resources and in the long run generates anti-american	sentiment of a kind peculiarly damaging to our political interest.	5.576792526242471
4945. some	of the most dramatic successes of communism in winning local support	can be traced to the identification- correct or not- of communist	regimes with personal honesty and pro-western regimes with corruption.	3.698357725976017
4946. a requirement of reasonably honest administration may be politically	uncomfortable in the short run but it is politically essential	in the long run.	5.676515830376243
4947. the united	states can use its aid as an incentive to self-help by responding with	aid on a sustained basis tailored to priority needs to those countries	making serious efforts in self-help.	3.4515469268983323
4948. in many instances it	can withhold or limit its aid to countries not yet willing to make such	efforts.	5.900785408612993
4949. there are other countries where with skillful diplomacy	we may be able by our aid to give encouragement to those groups	in government which would like to press forward with economic and social	reform measures to promote growth.	3.973200492687151

4951. even in these cases we should promote self-help by making it clear that	our supporting assistance is subject to reduction and ultimately to	termination.	4.7293706072483
4952. development	the most fundamental concept of	the new approach to economic aid is the focusing of our attention our	resources and our energies on the effort to promote the economic and	social development of the less developed countries.	5.154266620462654
4953. this is not a short-run	goal.	9.474062028631767

4955. how long it will take to show substantial success in this effort	will vary greatly from country to country.	4.493419224291226

4961. the specific reasons for a long-term approach the need to	many of the individual projects for	which development assistance is required call for expenditures over lengthy	periods.	3.7681100343646876
4962. dams river development schemes transportation networks	educational systems require years to construct.	6.093123995732186
4963. moreover on complex	projects design work must be completed and orders for machinery	and equipment placed months or even years before construction can commence.	4.172745624021586

4965. the	capital expansion programs of business firms involve multi-year budgeting	the need	to plan investment programs.	4.305414028832856
4966. several of	the more advanced of the less developed countries have found through	experience that they must plan their own complex investment programs for	at least 5 years forward and tentatively for considerably more than	that if they are to be sure that the various interdependent activities	involved are all to take place in the proper sequence.	5.944771556001775
4967. without such	forward planning investment funds are wasted because manufacturing facilities	are completed before there is power to operate them or before	there is transport to service them; or a skilled labor force is trained	before there are plants available in which they can be employed.	3.8280621442758016
4968. most important	of all the less developed countries must be persuaded to take the necessary	steps to allocate and commit their own resources.	5.882212969610807

5048. the practice of state-owned	vehicles for use of employees on business dates back over forty years.	5.624045970819654

5084. of state automobile practices	it	is difficult to pinpoint the time of origin of the state purchasing automobiles	for use of employees in rhode island.	6.5289621630268755
5085. few records are available	concerning the subject prior to 1940.	5.4291806815114345
5086. those that are available	shed little light.	10.046554100956959
5087. the registry of motor vehicles indicates that	at least one state automobile was registered as far back as 1917.	3.903457343307019
5088. it	should be enough to say that the practice of the state buying automobiles	is at least forty years old.	7.618718663638878
5089. the best reason that can be	advanced for the state adopting the practice was the advent of expanded	highway construction during the 1920s and '30s.	3.996504069214495
5090. at that time highway	engineers traveled rough and dirty roads to accomplish their duties.	7.1138207562853095
5091. using privately-owned vehicles was a personal hardship for such employees	and the matter of providing state transportation was felt perfectly	justifiable.	4.5543005374175225
5092. once the principle was established the increase	in state-owned vehicles came rapidly.	7.179544900430289

5095. this rate of increase	does not signify anything in itself.	4.987041256881453
5096. it does not indicate loose management	ineffective controls or poor policy.	8.439965501912711
5097. but it does show that automobiles	have increased steadily over the years and in almost the same	proportion to the increase of state employees.	4.513515179273017
5098. in the past twenty	years the ratio of state-owned automobiles per state employees has varied	from 1 to 22 then to 1 to 23 now.	5.703083417225485
5099. whether there were too few automobiles	in 1940 or too many now is problematical.	4.7505296763602916
5100. the fact is simply	that state-owned vehicles have remained in practically the same proportion	history and operation of the motor	pool.	6.13140083227211
5101. subsequent developments concerning the assignment use and management	of state automobiles can be related more clearly.	4.157554044369504
5102. prior to 1942	automobiles were the individual responsibility of the agency to which	assigned.	7.658985996292512
5103. this responsibility included all phases of management.	6.036066170183462
5104. it	embraced determining when to purchase and when to trade vehicles who	was to drive when and where repairs were to be made where gasoline	and automobile services were to be obtained and other allied matters.	5.617041063080036
5105. in 1942 however the nation was at war.	5.7202455055248365
5106. gasoline and automobile tires	were rationed commodities.	7.603896187885215
5107. the state was confronted with transportation	problems similar to those of the individual.	5.707762367174441
5108. it met these problems	by the creation of the state automobile maintenance unit	a centralized operation for the maintenance	and control of all state transportation.	6.266157360301137
5109. the motor pool then	as now had headquarter facilities in providence and other garages located	throughout the state.	3.7634143055761555
5110. it was organizationally the responsibility	of the department of public works and was financed on a rotary fund	basis with each agency of government contributing to the pool's operation.	5.578374410621998
5111. in 1951 the pool's operation was transferred to the newly-created	department of administration an agency established as the	central staff and auxiliary department of the state government.	4.181886836014643
5112. the management	of state-owned vehicles since that time has been described in	a recent report in the following manner:   under this new	management considerable progress appears to have been made.	5.154435343342229
5113. the agencies	of government are now billed for the actual cost of services provided	to each passenger car rather than the prior uniform charge for all	cars.	3.767750532590717
5114. whereas the maintenance rotary fund had in the past sustained	losses considerably beyond expectations the introduction of the cost-billing	system plus other control refinements has resulted in keeping	the fund on a proper working basis.	5.518574209335109
5115. one indication of the merits of	the new management is found in the fact that during the period 1951-1956	while total annual mileage put on the vehicles increased 35% the	total maintenance cost increased only 11%.	4.395565135178568
5116. in order	to further refine the management of passenger vehicles on july 1 1958	the actual title to every vehicle was transferred by executive	order to the division of methods research and office services.	4.848915820799214
5117. the objective behind this action was to place in one agency the responsibility	for the management assignment and replacement of all vehicles.	3.677026609786886
5118. this tied in closely with the	current attempt to upgrade state-owned cars to the extent that vehicles	are not retained beyond the point where maintenance costs	become excessive.	5.362015955648632
5119. moreover it allows the present management	to reassign vehicles so that mileage will be more uniformly	distributed throughout the fleet; for example if one driver puts on	22000 miles per year and another driver 8000 miles per year their	cars will be switched so that both cars will have 30000 miles after two	years rather than 44000 miles	and 16000 miles respectively.	3.420123134066361
5120. the motor pool is a completely	centralized and mechanized operation.	5.803860821377457
5121. it handles all types of	vehicle maintenance but concentrates more on service station activities	than on extensive vehicle repairs.	4.309941617365307
5122. it contracts with outside	repair garages for much of the latter work.	9.003526936177147
5123. where the pool excels is	in its compilation of maintenance and cost-data studies and analyses.	4.821697341274658
5124. pool records reveal in detail the cost per mile and miles per gallon	of each vehicle the miles traveled in one year or three years the periods	when vehicle costs become excessive and when cars should be traded	for sound economies.	4.669704854261235
5125. from this motor pool personnel develop other	meaningful and related data.	5.61920114426022
5126. in 1959-60 vehicles averaged an operating	cost of .	7.196162898152894
5127. based on this figure and considering depreciation	costs of vehicles pool personnel have determined that travel	in excess of 10000 miles annually is more economical by state car	than by payment of allowances for use of personally-owned vehicles.	3.6287722345492877
5128. they	estimate further that with sufficient experience and when cost-data	of compact cars is compiled the break-even point may be reduced to	7500 miles of travel per year.	4.919953094486945
5129. table 2 shows operating cost data of	state vehicles selected at random.	4.535752126583474
5130. one matter of concern to	the complete effectiveness of pool operations is the lack of adequate	central garage facilities.	6.29792330570903
5131. present pool quarters at two locations in	providence are crowded antiquated and in general make for inefficient	operation in terms of dispersement of personnel and duplication of	such operational needs as stock and repair equipment.	3.750451701031276

5133. the purchase of state-owned	vehicles is handled in the same manner as all other purchases	of the state.	4.718383369643341

5136. unit prices for state	vehicles are invariably lower than to the general public.	6.674689088089541
5137. the reasons	are obvious: it has no	federal excise or state sales tax to pay.	4.0485270579971635
5138. until 1958 the state was also	entitled to a special type of manufacturers' discount through the	dealers.	6.074301946356675
5139. in that ownership of all vehicles rests with the state	motor pool cars are paid for with funds appropriated to the agencies	but transferred to the rotary fund mentioned earlier.	3.8962603896975674
5140. this is a normal	governmental procedure which reflects more accurately cost-accounting	principles.	7.584675229623171
