5142. assignment and use policies	probably the most important of all matters	for review are the broad administrative policies governing the purchase	assignment use and management of state vehicles.	5.267304157933302
5143. the legislature's	role in policy determination in this area for years has been	confined almost solely to the amount of funds appropriated annually	for the purchase and operation of vehicles.	3.987003162060012
5144. the more meaningful policies	have been left to the judgment of the chief administrative officer	of the state- the director of administration.	6.0675171011712195
5145. there was a time some years ago when	local taxation by the cities and towns was sufficient to support their	own operations and a part of the cost of the state government as	well.	5.420114173380758
5146. for many years a state tax on cities and towns was paid by the	several municipalities to the state from the proceeds of the general property	tax.	6.51053406118285
5147. this tax was discontinued in 1936.	5.860285214927587
5148. since that time	the demands of the citizens for new and expanded services have placed	financial burdens on the state which could not have been foreseen in	earlier years.	6.29361416911308
5149. at the same time there has been an upgrading and expansion	of municipal services as well.	5.822801329653132
5150. thus there has come into being	a situation in which the state must raise all of its own revenues and	in addition must give assistance to its local governments.	6.2441213023095195
5151. this	financial assistance from the state has become necessary because	the local governments themselves found the property tax or at least at	the rates then existing insufficient for their requirements.	4.09102670589184
5152. consequently there have developed several forms of grants-in-aid and	shared taxes as well as the unrestricted grant to local governments	for general purposes whose adoption accompanied the introduction of a	sales tax at the state level.	5.525203355828479
5153. notwithstanding state aid the local	governments are continuing to seek additional revenue of their own	by strengthening the property tax.	3.9394316778493597
5154. this is being done both by the revaluation	of real property and by seeking out forms of personal property	hitherto neglected or ignored.	6.026132377249047
5155. taxation of tangible movable	property in rhode island has been generally of a hands off nature	due possibly to several reasons: local assessors in the main	are not well paid and have inadequate office staffs the numerous	categories of this component of personal property make locating extremely	difficult and the inexperience of the majority of assessors	problems of taxing personal	property.	3.3992003965199955
5156. and of movable tangible property in particular two are significant:	situs fair and equitable assessment of value.	6.0504390401147665
5157. these	problems are not local to rhode island but are recognized as common	to all states.	4.3225270261685695
5158. although the laws of the various	states in general specify the situs of property ie residence	or domicile of the owner or location of the property the exceptions	regarding boats airplanes mobile homes etc seem to add to	the uncertainty of the proper origination point for assessment.	4.97418409639776
5159. rhode island law specifies that all real estate is taxable in the	town in which it is situated.	4.614641270222381
5160. it also provides for the taxation of all	personal property belonging to inhabitants of the state both tangible	and intangible and the tangible personal property of non-residents	in this state.	5.828139341593011
5161. in defining personal property it specifically mentions	all ships or vessels at home or abroad.	4.3721244700667725
5162. intangible	property is taxable wherever the owner has a place of abode the greater	portion of the year.	5.594031732604857
5163. although a similar situs for tangible property	is mentioned in the statute this is cancelled out by the provision	that definite kinds of property and all other tangible property	situated or being in any town is taxable where the property is situated.	3.685958987712332
5164. this would seem to fix the tax situs of all movable personal property	at its location on december 31.	6.392992459471869
5165. both boats and aircraft would	fall within this category as well as motor vehicles.	5.532678347088327
5166. the location	of the latter now is determined for tax purposes at the time of registration	and it is now accepted practice to consider a motor vehicle	as being situated where it is garaged.	5.546186238726411
5167. obviously it would be impossible	to determine where every vehicle might be on the 31st day of december.	4.911157742702036
5168. in view of the acceptance accorded the status of motor vehicles	for tax purposes in the absence of any specific provision it would	seem entirely consistent to apply the same interpretation to boats or	aircraft.	5.8753881279509415
5169. a recent example of this problem is the flying of six	airplanes on december 31 1960 from the newport airpark in middletown	to the north central airport in smithfield.	3.962874001877746
5170. this situation	resulted in both towns claiming the tax and probably justifiably.	6.235752476069656
5171. middletown bases its claim on the general provision of the law that all	rateable property both tangible and intangible shall be taxed	to the owner thereof in the town in which such owner shall have had his	actual place of abode for the larger portion of the twelve months	next preceding the first day of april in each year.	3.806030231832548
5172. the	smithfield tax assessor in turn claims the tax under the provision	of law h and all other tangible personal property situated or being	in any town in or upon any h place of storage h shall be taxed	to such person h in the town where said property is situated.	4.535188750544296
5173. this problem of fair and equitable assessment	of value is a difficult one to solve in that the determination of	fair valuation is dependent on local assessors who in general are	non-professional	and part-time personnel taking an individualistic approach	to the problem.	3.7612992365637568
5174. this accounts for the wide variance in assessment	practices of movable tangible property in the various municipalities in	rhode island.	5.666094798501576
5175. this condition will undoubtedly continue until	such time as a state uniform system of evaluation is established	or through mutual agreement of the local assessing officials for a method	of standard assessment practice to be adopted.	3.7892914776620588
5176. the rhode	island public expenditure council in its publication once commented:	the most realistic way of facing up to this problem would	be to have the state take over full responsibility for assessing	all taxable property.	4.780151528748442
5177. an adequately staffed and equipped state assessing	office could apply uniform methods and standards which would go far	toward producing equitable assessments on all properties throughout	the state.	3.7979247938927747
5178. a single statewide assessing unit would eliminate the differences	and complications that are inherent in a system of 39 different	and independent assessing units.	5.355784073966382
5179. the institute of public	administration in its report to the state fiscal study commission	in 1959 recommended consolidating and centralizing all aspects	of property tax administration in a single state agency professionally	organized and equipped for the job.	3.720909864310434
5180. the resulting setup it was	declared would be similar to that which is in successful operation	in a number of metropolitan counties as large or larger than rhode	island.	5.931881983556387
5181. to determine the practice	and attitude of municipal governments concerning tangible movable property	a questionnaire was sent to all local government assessors or	boards of assessors in rhode island.	4.0735870737340445
5182. the replies from each	individual town are not given in detail because the questions asked the	personal opinion of the several assessors and are not necessarily the	established policy of the town in each case.	5.1894976421232055
5183. there are legitimate reasons	for differences of opinion among the assessors as a whole and among	the public officials in each town.	4.37346530383073
5184. these opinions of the assessors	are of significance in indicating what their thinking seems to be at	the present time.	6.101121878262878
5185. in reply to a question of whether they now	tax boats airplanes and other movable property excluding automobiles	nineteen said that they did and twenty that they did not.	4.05198584111277
5186. the wording	of the question was quite general and may have been subject to different	interpretations.	5.8691680610025765
5187. one assessor checked boats only another trailers	and tractors one mentioned house trailers and two others referred	to trailers without specifying the type.	4.041376835569566
5188. in two cases airplanes only	were indicated.	8.124467990507934
5189. it is difficult to tabulate exactly what was	meant in each individual situation but the conclusion may be drawn	that 21 towns do not assess movable personal property and of the remainder	only certain types are valued for tax purposes.	3.8573115443151407
5190. boats were indicated	specifically by only one of the five towns known to tax boats.	7.304041596771987
5191. it would seem then that movable property and equipment is not taxed	as a whole but that certain types are taxed in towns where this is bound	to be expedient for that particular kind of personal property.	3.8626392305847164
5192. so few answered the question relating to their efforts to assess	movable property that the results are inconclusive.	5.909381077682253
5193. only four towns indicated	that they made any more than a normal effort to list property	of this kind.	5.183940096276628
5194. of greater interest is a question as to whether	movable property was assessed according to its location or ownership.	6.676501770503539
5195. fifteen stated that it was according to location four by residence	of the owner and nineteen did not answer.	4.647628949362133
5196. twenty-seven assessors	stated that they were in favor of improved means for assessing movable	personal property and only five were opposed.	6.501820951253952
5197. seven others expressed	no opinion.	7.794039523550236
5198. on this point there was fairly general agreement that	assessors would like to do more than they are doing now.	7.48021767628702
5199. it is not	clear however whether they are thinking of all movable property or	only of boats trailers aircraft or certain other types of personal	property whose assessment would be advantageous to their particular towns.	3.729884110243962
5200. another question that was asked of the assessors was whether	they favored the assessment of movable property at its location or	at the residence of the owner.	5.098876504953099
5201. eighteen voted for assessment by the	town in which it is located and eleven preferred assessment by the town	in which the owner resides.	4.142011428992033
5202. ten others made no reply.	8.840894576046342
5203. of those who	have an opinion it seems that assessment by location is preferred.	5.324548254241674
5204. there	was one vote for location being the place where the property is	situated for the greater portion of the twelve months preceding the assessment	date.	5.72693282377105
5205. to summarize it may be said that there is no one	prevailing practice in rhode island with respect to the taxation	of movable property that assessors would like to see an improvement	and of those who have an opinion that assessment by the town of location	is preferred on the basis of their present knowledge.	4.937756853280104
5206. the need for	greater knowledge is evident from their replies.	6.566113871376985
5207. property	interest has been shown for a number	of years by local assessors in the possibility of taxing boats.	4.381490901122469
5208. assessors in rhode island are charged not only with placing a valuation	upon real and personal property but they also have the responsibility	to raise by a tax a sum not less than nor more than a specified	amount as ordered by a city council or financial town meeting.	4.968886324540994
5209. it has been obvious to the assessors particularly those in shore	communities that boats comprise the largest category of tangible personal	property which they have been unable to reach.	4.491881797706624
5210. through their	professional organization the rhode island tax officials association	the question of taxing boats long has been debated and discussed.	5.541166731394555
5211. no satisfactory solution has been found but this is due more to the	difficulties inherent in the problem than to a lack of interest or diligence	on the part of the assessors.	5.0595065301949145
5212. it has been estimated that	the value of boats in rhode island waters is something in excess	of fifty million dollars excluding commercial boats.	5.8851089954527405
5213. it is obvious that	this is a potential and lucrative source of revenue for the assessors	of those towns where a substantial amount of such property would be	subject to taxation.	3.923641497051162
5214. it is known that at least five towns	place some	value on some boats for tax purposes.	7.195184479506313
5215. however few are taxed and	the owners and location of most boats are unknown to the assessors on	the date of assessment of town valuations.	4.0240771587037205
5216. no one really knows	how many boats there actually are or what their aggregate value may	be.	6.363263733543404
5217. slightly more than 5000 boats were registered with the coast guard	prior to the recent passage of the state boating law.	4.541009256512224
5218. only a few	more than 10000 boats had been registered with the division of harbors	and rivers at the end of the 1960 boating season but many had	been taken out of the water early when the threat of a hurricane brought	the season to an early close.	5.919776523859772
5219. the assessors' association	meeting at narragansett in september 1960 devoted its session to a	discussion of the boat problem.	3.7179193381860367

5270. division	stated in its simplest terms the main job of the	planning division is to plan for the future of the state of rhode	island.	7.1876051331743955
5271. the activities of the planning division are defined in considerable	detail in the enabling act of the development council which	assigns to the agency both broad responsibilities and specific duties	in the field of planning.	3.6484230246968363
5272. two years ago the institute of	public administration issued an extremely comprehensive report entitled	state-local relations in metropolitan rhode island.	6.661689982483162
5273. as	the result of an exhaustive review of the recommendations contained in	this report plus an analysis of our own enabling act the planning	division developed a number of basic planning objectives which caused	a reorientation of its work program.	4.120311064757553
5274. these objectives are stated here	because of their importance in understanding the current activities	first priority will be given to	the preparation of a meaningful state guide plan to serve as a background	recognizing	the truth of the statement by the institute of public administration	that metropolian planning means or	should mean state planning the state guide plan will take into account	the metropolitan nature of many of rhode island's problems.	4.685617380984669
5275. it will continue to be an objective of this division to encourage	the acceptance of planning as a proper and continuing responsibility	of local government.	5.029022155065229
5276. to this end the community assistance program	of the planning division will continue to be operated as a staff function	to make available on a shared cost basis technical planning	assistance to those communities in the state unable to maintain their	the planning division will take the initiative	in encouraging planning cooperation at all levels of government;	among the operating departments of the state; between the cities	and towns of the state; and on a regional basis between the six new	on the basis that all citizens of the state	are entitled to benefit equally in the development of its resources	plans for the provision of essential services will	be based on need regardless of arbitrary political boundaries within	the state development budget	will reflect the capital needs of all the state agencies and the priority	of the projects in the budget will be based on the state plan.	4.658310631391594
5277. particular attention will	be given means of strengthening the economy of the state through the	development of industry and recreation.	4.696670946785143
5278. functionally the planning	division carries out four activities: long-range state planning	current state planning local planning assistance; and the preparation	of the state development budget.	5.051766433984403
5279. the planning division has embarked on the most complete and comprehensive	state planning program in the nation.	3.8769026757968397
5280. the long range aspects of	this program are divided into four distinct phases: basic mapping	inventory analysis and plan and policy formation.	5.2999824815312175
5281. the work program	as it was originally proposed was to take five years to complete.	4.726939249794418
5282. recent	events- particularly the necessity of providing planning information	for the statewide origindestination study of the department	of public works- indicate that this schedule will have to be accelerated.	6.376302289188441
5283. the basic mapping phase of the program has been completed and	basic	since accurate base maps are necessary for any planning	program the first step taken by the planning division to implement the	long range state plan has been to prepare two series of base maps-	one at a scale of 1 inch to a mile and the second a series of 26 sheets	at a scale of 1 inch to 2000 feet covering the entire state.	3.767067289522917
5284. with	these maps completed the inventory phase of the plan has been started.	6.872861709862811
5285. with the aid of matching federal funds available	under section 701 of the housing act of 1954 as amended the planning	division began a one year program july 1 1960 to complete the inventory	phase of the state planning program.	3.994045728023419
5286. this phase consists of four	items: urban land use rural land use physical features and public	utility service areas.	5.45818851704242
5287. since the validity of all subsequent planning	depends on the accuracy of the basic inventory information great care	is being taken that the inventory is as complete as possible.	4.3247548011987185
5288. the urban land use study carried out by the planning division staff	has consisted of identifying and mapping all urban land uses which are	of significance to statewide planning.	4.677883612152886
5289. the rural land use study is	being carried out under contract by the university of rhode island	and identifies all agricultural land uses in the state by type of use.	3.9984845391315322
5290. the mapping of important physical features such as slopes and types	of soil and the collection of all available information pertaining to	public utility service areas are being conducted as staff projects and	like the other two inventory projects are scheduled for completion	july 1 1961.	4.44433054918692
5291. the collection of information is meaningless	unless it is understood and used for a definite purpose.	3.942420685597969
5292. it is not within the scope of	this report elaborate in any great detail upon special districts in	rhode island.	5.980549813036615
5293. however a word should be mentioned in regard to them	as independent units of government.	5.223499201718311
5294. there are forty-seven special	district governments in rhode island	districts four housing authorities and the kent county water	.	5.996984900759701
5295. these forty-seven special purpose governments have the	authority to levy taxes to borrow money own property sue and be sued	and in general to exercise normal corporate powers.	3.736478075476027
5296. unlike cities	and towns however they do not have to submit any financial statements	to the state bureau of audits.	7.138473300207697
5297. it is not an exaggeration to say	that the state government has little or no fiscal control over these units	of government.	5.039134914707333
5298. in addition to the collection of service charges	the special districts levy annual property taxes of approximately $450000.	6.384670847065284
5299. a	review of practices in other states regarding fiscal uniformity is pertinent	to this report.	4.305414028832856
5300. included in the findings are:  forty-six	states including rhode island end their fiscal year on june	30.	6.004438176423661
5301. the other four states end on varying dates: alabama	new york and texas	.	4.585148982842573
5302. in sixteen states the fiscal year ending of the	cities is the same as that of the state: alaska arizona	california delaware massachusetts montana nevada new mexico	north carolina north dakota oklahoma oregon vermont	.	5.748691224818891
5303. in eleven states	the fiscal year of the cities ends on december 31 while the state fiscal	year ends on june 30	hampshire new jersey ohio south dakota utah washington	.	3.6872571296465737
5304. in eight states whose fiscal years close	on june 30 a majority of their cities close their fiscal year on december	31:	.	5.425304578814461
5305. one state alabama closes	its fiscal year on september 30 and all cities in the state with	one exception also close fiscal years on september 30.	4.294404436486582
5306. mississippi closes its fiscal year on june 30 while all of its cities	close their fiscal years on september 30.	5.520943077314587
5307. pennsylvania closes	its fiscal year on may 31.	5.4032093454026695
5308. all of its cities close their fiscal	years on december 31.	8.322543737162293
5309. the remaining twelve states have varying	fiscal years for the state city and local governments.	4.241336465945757
5310. however	only illinois oregon louisiana and rhode island have a situation	in which the sundry units of government vary widely in relation to fiscal	uniformity.	5.375751660322602
5311. an excellent summary of advantages concerning	the uniform fiscal year and coordinated fiscal calendars was contained	in a paper presented by a public finance authority recently.	3.9642356482184575
5312. he listed	among the values of fiscal uniformity:  the uniform fiscal	year requires compliance with common sense administration of local	finances: adoption of the budget or financial plan in advance of spending.	5.16084941818072
5313. the uniform fiscal year ensures conformance with another	common sense rule that of having cash in the bank before checks	are drawn.	3.6061427736109843
5314. it enables towns to make more economical purchases and to	take advantage of cash discounts.	6.424491095487325
5315. the uniform fiscal year promotes	more careful budgeting and strengthens control over expenditures.	4.012692518953268
5316. by fixing the tax rate in advance of spending upper limits are set	on expenditures.	6.2273417631016175
5317. the uniform fiscal year brings the town's	fiscal year into line with that of the schools which expend the largest	share of local disbursements.	4.221285330919581
5318. this greatly simplifies the town's	bookkeeping and financial reporting.	7.006468312365853
5319. the uniform fiscal	year eliminates interest charges on money borrowed in the form of tax	anticipation notes.	4.305571238319879
5320. furthermore tax collections not immediately needed	for current expenditures may be invested in short-term treasury notes	augmenting the town's miscellaneous revenues and reducing the tax	levy.	5.229078353365337
5321. the uniform fiscal year facilitates inter-town comparison	of revenues and expenditures.	4.200670158663773
5322. when towns have the same fiscal	year it is relatively easy to make meaningful comparisons; and as the	cost of local government increases the demand for such comparison also	increases.	5.962030723038709
5323. towns having different fiscal years are difficult to compare.	4.855658467968249
5324. of all advantages probably none is more important than	the elimination of tax anticipation notes.	6.7718936628812285
5325. borrowing in anticipation	of current taxes and other revenues is a routine procedure of the majority	of municipalities at all times.	3.9467684538002374
5326. it may be by bank loans sale	of notes or warrants or by the somewhat casual method of issuance and	registration of warrants.	5.823905697881438
5327. in any event it is a form of borrowing which	could be and should be rendered unnecessary.	6.178012508117614
5328. its elimination would	result in the saving of interest costs heavy when short-term money rates	are high and in freedom from dependence on credit which is not always	available when needed most.	5.154531500855507
5329. this type of borrowing can be reduced	to a minimum if quarterly installment payment of taxes is instituted	and the first payment placed near the opening of the fiscal year.	4.056320554139384
5330. any	approach	toward such a system looks toward saving and security.	6.522871687113793
5331. it should be noted that there are other and equally important reasons	for establishing meaningful intergovernmental reporting bases on a uniform	fiscal year.	5.399159918171722
5332. both the federal and state governments commence their	fiscal years on july 1.	6.778059077523185
5333. both units of government contribute increasingly	large sums of money to the several local governments in this	state as indicated below:    it has been said that when local	government revenues were mostly produced locally from the property	tax the lack of a uniform fiscal year was no great handicap; but with	the growth of state and federal fiscal aid the emphasis on equalization	and the state-local sharing of responsibility for certain important	functions this is no longer true.	3.8956659448775266
5334. the haphazard fiscal year calendar	is an obstacle to the planning of clear and efficient state-local	revenue and expenditure relationships.	5.040372803839409
5335. although	there are many sound reasons for adopting uniform and coordinated fiscal	years in rhode island there are also certain difficulties encountered.	4.220701333930838
5336. these involve more the mechanics employed in adjusting to fiscal	uniformity than they do actual actual disadvantages to the principle.	5.553891161768655
5337. one problem is a matter of shifting dates; the other is how to	finance the transition.	5.055677198332572
5338. little can be done about the changing	of dates.	8.697720814160544
5339. this is an inherent part of adjusting fiscal calendars.	6.165550706691331
5340. it	usually means a confused and disgruntled tax-paying public for a period	of time.	5.926734816808145
5341. but cooperation and understanding between local officials	and the citizenry help lessen this problem.	4.549528695919972
5342. the other problem	is the matter of financing the transition period in the several cities	and towns.	6.247059914472752
5343. this will be covered more fully later.	6.8910001276370085
5344. it should be kept	in mind that the ease or difficulty with which a town or city can	convert to the proposed plan is directly dependent upon the financial	condition of that town or city.	5.392713692527666
5345. fortunately there are no cities or towns	in the state with one or two possible exceptions that are in too	difficult a position to finance the proposed change.	4.556060747128479
5346. sacrifice will	have to be made in some cases but it is to the municipality's advantage	to finance the change-over for a short period of time rather than	pay interest on tax anticipation notes indefinitely.	6.7163148890408335
5347. fiscal calendars	the advantages of a uniform fiscal year and well	synchronized fiscal and tax collection calendars are sufficiently great	for rhode island municipalities to exert effort to secure them.	3.7228467551011133
5348. the	type of program desired can be determined by the nature and extent	of the adjustments needed.	6.1393793535393035
5349. two features are immediately evident.	7.194228478107291
5350. first	the present situation is too varied to be systematized by any single	formula.	6.12989474741227
5351. second the shift to a uniform july 1-june 30 fiscal year	will of itself improve the tax collection calendars of the great	majority of cities and towns.	3.9458616160753954
5352. there are at least two problems to consider:	one is a matter of adjusting the fiscal calendar; the other	is how to finance the adjustments when necessary.	6.252801674055868
5353. the latter matter	is considered in detail in a later section.	4.9847539164602885
5354. twelve cities and	towns in rhode island presently indicate some plans to establish a	uniform andor coordinated fiscal-tax year calendar.	5.43902246593565
5355. plans vary from	the talking stage to establishing special committees to accomplish	this end.	4.411891185517149
5356. what is important here is that many of the cities and towns	recognize the need for improved fiscal practices and are taking the	initiative to obtain them.	6.9589351302232325
5357. an analysis of the fiscal-tax collection	year calendars throughout the state indicates that transition	may not be as painful as is commonly thought.	4.193444410092113
5358. however it must be stressed	that much depends upon the financial condition of the individual	cities and towns involved.	6.695077822180136
5359. the adjustments needed to establish	a uniform and coordinated fiscal-tax collection year calendar throughout	rhode island based on a july 1-june 30 year are shown below.	3.675477134381489
5360. six cities and towns are presently on a	july 1-june 30 fiscal year and have coordinated their tax collection	year with it.	5.512715302422695
5361. no change is required for these towns.	6.039439933523581
5362. these municipalities	include: barrington lincoln middletown newport north	kingstown and south kingstown.	6.672929159659425
5363. one town and one city coventry and east providence require an adjustment	of their fiscal year only.	4.34762191062725
5364. this change will automatically adjust	their tax collection year calendar so as to make all tax installments	due and payable in the fiscal year collectible within that year.	5.240929249536284
5365. six cities and towns are now	on a july 1-june 30 fiscal year and will need only to adjust their	tax collection year calendar to establish uniformity.	3.868114896133369
5366. these cities and	towns include bristol glocester pawtucket cumberland central	falls and woonsocket.	6.439595567446343
5367. two cities	to be considered providence and cranston are an enigma.	5.208641873163047
5368. both have	excellent integration of their fiscal-tax collection year calendars.	7.279710921728837
5369. however neither of these two cities is on the desired july 1-june	30 fiscal year.	5.1257319590989505
5370. the adjustment to a uniform and coordinated fiscal	period could be accomplished relatively easy for them.	5.230782446082564
5371. in that	both cities end their fiscal years on september 30 they could levy taxes	for an interim period of nine months commencing with september	30 and ending with june 30.	3.6601760327854405
5372. these three installment dates would be:	october 26 january 26 and april 25 and november	15 february 16 and may 15.	5.4143090744001565
5373. both would start their new	fiscal year on july 1.	5.419053398104491
5374. their tax collection calendar could then be:	july 25 october 26 january 26 and april 25;	and august 15 november 15 february 17 and may 15.	5.154300802449603
5375. under this plan both cranston and providence would be on the uniform	fiscal year but would still be using the same installment periods.	4.452471099215811
5376. the remaining twenty-three towns have fiscal	years which end prior to june 30.	5.390500575037483
5377. all of these towns will require	adjustments of both their fiscal and tax collection years.	5.28997237623832
5378. assuming	an adjustment to the july 1-june 30 fiscal year the required adjustment	of the tax collection years and the towns involved are shown in table	3.	5.1646622214268945
5379. aside from the matter	of adjusting the fiscal and tax calendars there is the problem of financing	the adjustment when this is necessary.	5.108264631955414
5380. it should be emphasized	strongly that adjustments in fiscal dates or adoption of interim budgets	do not necessarily mean financing over and above normal governmental	requirements.	5.822775210569197
5381. in many communities there is simply no financial	problem; it is only a matter of adjusting accounting methods careful	fiscal planning and management or some like combination of techniques.	4.6324384840913835
5382. in other municipalities the difficulties in overcoming the financial	burden have been sufficiently great to dishearten proponents of	fiscal year changes.	5.760927526725712
5383. fortunately such cases in rhode island are more	the exception than the rule.	4.920353554239155
5384. as shown earlier in table 1	the several cities and towns use widely varied fiscal and tax collection	calendars.	5.942387776568827
5385. in addition no two rhode island communities are identical	in relation to their over-all financial condition.	4.676303695985141
5386. these factors	practically insure that no single financing formula is feasible; each	situation must be studied and a plan developed that takes into consideration	such factors as the effect of the existing and prospective	tax calendars the financial condition of the treasuries and the length	of the transition interval.	4.9238574220931595

5435. governor	as another thanksgiving draws near let us take time out from the often	hectic pace of our lives to try and recapture the feelings that filled	the hearts of the pilgrims on the first thanksgiving.	3.7536502494910122
5436. the	pilgrims gathered to thank the lord for his benevolence during	their first year in the new land.	6.268564885298751
5437. they had been through trying times	but their faith in the almighty had given them the courage and the strength	to meet and overcome the many problems and difficulties that were	the price they had to pay for freedom.	4.137828645072477
5438. and as the pilgrims bowed	their heads in humble gratitude they shared another feeling- the anticipation	of what the future held for them and their posterity.	5.927206314149294
5439. they	could not guess that from their concepts of liberty and freedom would	some day be born a new nation that for years would be the symbol of	hope to the oppressed countries of the world.	3.6867684774268006
5440. they simply turned to god	filled with gratitude and faith.	6.949555033903081
5441. we who are living today may	learn a valuable lesson from those who celebrated the first thanksgiving	day.	4.318670503113022
5442. the lord has shown time and time again his love for us.	5.886395533120762
5443. we have only to compare the liberty and high standard of living we	enjoy in this great country with the oppression and frugality of other	nations to realize with humble gratitude that god's providence has	been with us since the very beginning of our country.	3.6314465603410193
5444. and yet accompanying	our gratitude is the realization that we are living in a crucial	time.	7.548216715712433
5445. with world peace constantly being threatened most of us regard	the future skeptically and even with fear.	4.801131886173154
5446. it is at this time that	we should imitate the pilgrims by accompanying our prayers of thanks	with the conviction that we shall continue to be in dire need for	the lord's protection in the future if we are to have peace; now	therefore do i john a notte jr governor of the state of	rhode island and providence plantations proclaim thursday november	23rd 1961 as thanksgiving day   and so let us remember on	this day not only to thank the almighty who gave hope and courage	to the pilgrims but also to place our trust in him that he will continue	to protect us in the future as he has in the past.	5.21606299026823

5524. medical publication agency	the armed forces medical publication	agency established in 1949 has published since january 1950	the united states armed forces medical journal as a triservice	publication	to furnish material of professional interest to medical department	officers of the three military services.	4.74064884469114
5525. its supplement the medical	technicians bulletin supplied similar material to enlisted	medical personnel.	4.944411120347637
5526. these publications replaced the u s naval	medical bulletin published continuously from 1907 through 1959 as	well as the navy's hospital corps quarterly and the bulletin of	the u s army medical department published from 1922 to 1949.	5.141952303410967
5527. in addition their establishment made it unnecessary to begin publication	of a contemplated air force medical bulletin.	4.566888642089719
5528. estimated annual	savings resulting from publication of the journal and bulletin	on a triservice basis as compared with the cost of producing separate	periodicals for each service were between $65000 and $70000.	5.405091938554944
5529. additionally	on the many ships at sea and in the smaller naval stations	the availability of the journal removed the necessity of subscribing	to several additional journals of civilian origin over and above the	quantity now authorized in order to provide any reasonably comparable	coverage.	3.987388490367233

5531. each journal contained	articles of professional and clinical interest and departments	devoted to military medical news reviews of new books and other features	of interest to officers of the medical services.	3.9337807439314827
5532. the council	on national defense of the american medical association contributed	a brief article to each issue entitled this is your ama.	5.709968099545632
5533. beginning with the october 1959 issue of the journal	the method of production of copy for photo-offset reproduction was	changed from varityping to hot typesetting.	3.914569699171236
5534. this resulted in an improved	appearance but was followed by an increase in printing cost that	necessitated the institution of major economies to keep within the total	of allocated funds.	5.725658282510482
5535. the use of 100 instead of 140 substance paper	plus the adoption of side stapling beginning with the may 1960 issue	reduced costs sufficiently to allow completion of the fiscal year with	nearly $4000 in unexpended funds.	3.731258046672539
5536. two special issues were	published one for november 1959 on space medicine the other the	tenth anniversary issue for january 1960.	5.573443034137121

5539. occasional	features were published on historical medicine special reports bibliography	and collector's items.	4.535752126583474
5540. in may 1960 the armed	forces institute of pathology began a series of articles on the medical	museum and in june the institute started contributing	a regular monthly case for diagnosis.	5.502752028125733

5542. the armed	forces epidemiological board agreed to submit each month a report	for one of its 12 commissions so that each commission will report	once a year on some phase of its work calculated to be of particular interest	and value to medical officers of the armed forces.	4.892343811126889
5543. the first	report in this continuing series appeared in the september 1960 issue	of the journal.	4.290447041705321
5544. another recent achievement was the successful development of a method	for the complete combustion in a bomb calorimeter of a metal in fluorine	when the product is relatively non-volatile.	5.013185019821809
5545. this work gave a heat	of formation of aluminum fluoride which closely substantiates a value	which had been determined by a less direct method and raises this	property to 15 percent above that accepted a few years ago.	3.7432225759710085
5546. similar measurements	are being initiated to resolve a large discrepancy in the	heat of formation of another important combustion product beryllium fluoride.	5.306802021708014
5547. the development and testing of new apparatus to measure	other properties is nearing completion.	3.9374569952961833
5548. in one of these an exploding-wire	device to study systems thermodynamically up to 6000 f and	100 atmospheres pressure a major goal was achieved.	6.3136625786267695
5549. the accuracy of	measuring the total electrical energy entering an exploding wire during	a few microseconds was verified when two independent types of comparison	with the heat energy produced had an uncertainty of less than 2	percent.	3.374909738052478
5550. this agreement is considered very good for such short time intervals.	6.442246419515362
5551. the method of calibration employs a fixed resistance element	as a calorimeter.	4.453868181966725
5552. the element is inserted	in the discharge circuit in place of the exploding wire	and the calorimetric heating of the element is measured with high accuracy.	5.080191530335327
5553. this is used as a reference for comparing the ohmic heating and	the electrical energy obtained from the measured current through the	element and the measured voltage across the element.	4.039982419727331
5554. a high-speed	shutter has been developed in order to permit photographic observation	of any portion of the electrical wire explosion.	6.504796594327581
5555. the shutter consists	of two parts: a fast-opening part and a fast-closing part.	4.012715720819275
5556. using	edgerton's method the fast-closing action is obtained from the	blackening of a window by exploding a series of parallel lead wires.	5.682358984033063
5557. the fast-opening of the shutter consists of a piece of aluminum foil	placed directly in front of the camera lens so that	no light may pass into the camera.	4.523989952467027
5558. the opening action is obtained	when a capacitor charged to high voltage is suddenly discharged through	the foil.	5.1813340789152145
5559. during the discharge the magnetic forces set up by the	passage of current cause the edges of the foil to roll inward toward	its center line thus allowing light to pass into the camera.	3.895259869351364
5560. experiments	have shown that the shutter is 75 percent open in about 60-80 microseconds.	5.7836982265615156
5561. the shutter aperture may be made larger or smaller by changing	the foil area and adjusting the electrical energy input to the foil.	3.6263069595579034
5562. besides	the well-known hydrogen line at 21 cm wavelength the spectra of	extraterrestrial radio sources may contain sharp lines characteristic	of other atoms ions and small molecules.	4.96038068518468
5563. the detection and study	of such line spectra would add considerably to present information on	interstellar gas clouds and perhaps planetary atmospheres.	3.6061566743622318
5564. among the	most likely producers of detectable radio line spectra are the light	diatomic hydrides oh and ch; somewhat less likely sources	are the heavier hydrides sh sih and sch.	5.18254949947024
5565. very small	concentrations of these hydrides should be detectable; in interstellar	gas concentrations as low as f moleculesf may be sufficient	as compared to the f hydrogen atoms f required for detection of	the 21-cm line.	3.9111886197100874
5566. high sensitivity in radio telescopes is achieved	by reducing the bandwidth of the receiver; therefore only with	precise foreknowledge of the line frequencies is an astronomical	search for the radio spectra of these molecules feasible.	4.975876518692369
5567. to secure precise	measurements of these frequencies a research program in free radical	microwave spectroscopy has been started.	4.2865861276117085
5568. since conventional methods	are insensitive at the low frequencies of these molecular transitions	the paramagnetic resonance method is being used instead.	5.593100394250956
5569. this	involves the application of a strong magnetic field to the radical vapor	which shifts the low-frequency spectra to a conveniently high microwave	range where they may be measured with optimum sensitivity.	3.9926444843406887
5570. the first diatomic hydride investigated by the paramagnetic resonance	method was the oh radical.	6.045025091081321
5571. results of this experiment include	the frequencies of the two strong spectral lines by which oh may	be identified in interstellar gas; the frequencies are 1665.	3.992773030794978
5572. 36 f with an uncertainty of 0.	7.1581511048922275
5573. success in observing these	spectral lines has so far apparently been confined to the laboratory;	extraterrestrial observations have yet to be reported.	4.1497396161992715
5574. preparations	are being made for similar experiments on ch and sh	radicals.	6.289010577019261
5575. the bureau is pursuing	an active program to provide a temperature scale and thermometer calibration	services in the range 1.	4.018359308918941
5576. the efforts and accomplishments	fall into three main categories: absolute thermometry based	upon the velocity of sound in helium gas secondary thermometry involving	principally studies of the behavior of germanium resistors and helium-4	vapor-pressure measurements.	4.734318265569195
5577. an acoustical interferometer has been constructed and	used with helium gas as the thermometric fluid to measure temperatures	near 4.	4.132656825642804
5578. such an interferometer provides a means of absolute	temperature measurement and may be used as an alternative to	the gas thermometer.	6.8069368453603945
5579. when values of temperature derived with this instrument	were compared with the accepted values associated with liquid	helium-4 vapor pressures differences of about 10 and 7 millidegrees respectively	were found.	3.9650824589954015
5580. this result is preliminary and work is continuing.	7.006468312365853
5581. carbon resistors and impurity-doped	germanium resistors have been investigated for use as precision secondary	thermometers in the liquid helium temperature region.	3.8880356915934375
5582. several	germanium resistors have been thermally cycled from 300 to 4.	6.289010577019261
5583. 2 f and	their resistances have been found to be reproducible within 13 millidegree	when temperatures were derived from a vapor pressure thermometer	whose tubing is jacketed through most of the liquid helium.	4.3234223220778665

5585. 16	f at every 0.	6.683325264329536

5587. the reproducibilities	of helium vapor-pressure thermometers have been investigated	in conjunction with a constant temperature liquid helium bath	from 4.	3.7179193381860367
5588. surface temperature gradients have been found to	exist in liquid helium baths contained in 15-and 25-liter metallic storage	dewars.	5.6322467430336385
5589. the gradient was about one half of a millidegree at 4.	4.746354758338703
5590. 2	f but increased to several millidegrees for bath temperatures slightly	greater than the |l point.	5.659455227543579
5591. a hydrostatic head correction has	been neither necessary nor applicable in the determination of vapor pressures	or temperatures for the bulk liquid helium.	3.7782646401868343
5592. however the surface	temperature gradient can produce erroneous vapor-pressure measurements	for the bulk liquid helium unless precautions are taken to isolate	the tube	from the liquid helium surface.	5.519583110835459
5593. it has also been observed in helium	2 that large discrepancies can exist between surface vapor pressures	and those pressures measured by a vapor pressure thermometer.	4.275118314966933
5594. this	has been attributed to helium film flow in the vapor pressure thermometer.	6.103259258407421
5595. in this case also the design of the thermometer can be modified	pressure transducer for pvt	precise pressure-volume-temperature measurements on	corrosive gases are dependent on a sensitive yet rugged pressure transducer.	4.161925693265686
5596. a prototype which fulfills the requirements was developed and	thoroughly tested.	6.2272542153453445
5597. the transducer is a null-type instrument and employs	a stretched diaphragm 0.	4.672888964162827
5598. 001 in thick and 1 in in diameter.	6.806723317680827
5599. a small pressure unbalance displaces the diaphragm and changes the capacitance	between the diaphragm and an electrically insulated plate spaced	0.	4.033330859061411
5600. spherical concave backing surfaces	support the diaphragm when excessive pressures are applied and prevent	the stresses within the diaphragm from exceeding the elastic limit.	5.051766433984403
5601. over a temperature range from 25 to 200 f and at pressures up to	250 atm an overload of 300 psi applied for a period of one day	results in an uncertainty in the pressure of at most one millimeter	of mercury.	3.814608306325715
5602. a 6-year study of the	transport properties of air at elevated temperatures has been completed.	5.61618342048764
5603. this project was carried out under sponsorship of the ballistic	missile division of the air research and development command us	air force and had as its goal the investigation of the transport	by diffusion of the heat energy of chemical binding.	3.789648369275297
5604. a significant	effect discovered during the study is the existence of prandtl	numbers reaching values of more than unity in the nitrogen dissociation	region.	5.633085937730076
5605. another effect discovered is the large coefficient of thermal	diffusion tending to separate nitrogen from the oxygen when temperature	differences straddling the nitrogen dissociation region are present.	3.8701847702663192

5653. mr speaker for several years now the commuter	railroads serving our large metropolitan areas have found it increasingly	difficult to render the kind of service our expanding population	wants and is entitled to have.	4.083210467539255
5654. the causes of the decline of the commuter	railroads are many and complex- high taxes losses of revenue to	government subsidized highway and air carriers to name but two.	5.094636707275386
5655. and	the solutions to the problems of the commuter lines have been equally	varied ranging all the way from government ownership to complete	discontinuance of this important service.	4.363084442707603
5656. there have been a number	of sound plans proposed.	10.924256967553434

5659. though the number	of people flowing in and out of our metropolitan areas each day has increased	tremendously since world war 2 total annual rail commutation	dropped 124 million from 1947 to 1957.	4.402136693566461
5660. nowhere has this decline	been more painfully evident than in the new york city area.	9.300451605506172

5666. the new york central notes:   the freight traffic	most susceptible to raiding by the c + o-b + o provides	the backbone of central's revenues.	5.55602421991183

5668. if these services are to be maintained	the new york central must have the revenues to make them possible.	6.835780732871735
5669. the new york central today handles 60 percent of all	southbound commuter traffic coming into new york city.	4.571854598156102
5670. this is a	$14 million operation involving 3500 employees who work on commuter	traffic exclusively.	6.593343553411476
5671. a blow to this phase of the central's operations	would have serious economic consequences not only to the railroad	itself but to the 40000 people per day who are provided with efficient	reasonably priced transportation in and out of the city.	4.169573432380602
5672. there is a workable alternative to this potentially dangerous and harmful	c + o-b + o merger scheme-   the central	has pointed out.	5.748371203372182

5742. from its inception in 1920 with the passage of public law 236 66th	congress the purpose of the vocational rehabilitation program has been	to assist the states by means of grants-in-aid to return disabled	men and women to productive gainful employment.	5.5717798019747065
5743. the authority for	the program was renewed several times until the vocational rehabilitation	program was made permanent as title 5 of the social security	act in 1935.	3.666172677054029
5744. up to this time and for the next eight years the services	provided disabled persons consisted mainly of training counseling	and placement on a job.	6.508670905540949
5745. recognizing the limitations of such a program	the 78th congress in 1943 passed p l 113 which broadened	the concept of rehabilitation to include the provision of physical	restoration services to remove or reduce disabilities and which revised	the financing structure.	3.726705344794314
5746. despite the successful	rehabilitation of over a half million disabled persons in the first	eleven years after 1943 the existing program was still seen to be	inadequate to cope with the nation's backlog of an estimated two million	disabled.	5.317136674808195
5747. to assist the states therefore in rehabilitating handicapped	individuals so that they may prepare for and engage in remunerative	employment to the extent of their capabilities the 83rd	congress enacted the vocational rehabilitation amendments of 1954	.	4.072205585695871
5748. these amendments to the vocational rehabilitation	act were designed to help provide for more specialized rehabilitation	facilities for more sheltered and half-way workshops for	greater numbers of adequately trained personnel for more comprehensive	services to individuals	and for other administrative improvements to increase the program's	overall effectiveness.	4.814199429011714
5749. under the law as it	existed until 1943 the federal government made grants to the states	on the basis of population matching state expenditures on a 50-50	basis.	4.529891382870587
5750. under p l 113 78th congress the federal government	assumed responsibility for 100% of necessary state expenditures	in connection with administration and the counseling and placement of	the disabled and for 50% of the necessary costs of providing clients	with rehabilitation case services.	4.835957566104889
5751. throughout these years the statutory	authorization was for such sums as were necessary to carry out	the provisions of the act.	4.265676394216654
5752. the 1954 amendments completely changed	the financing of the vocational rehabilitation program providing	for a three-part grant structure- for extension	and improvement; and research demonstrations training and	traineeships for vocational rehabilitation- and in addition for	short-term training and instruction.	4.660089103703532

5799. at the entrance side of the shelter each roof beam is rested	on the inside 4 inches of the block wall.	4.742349508382915
5800. the outside 4-inch space is	filled by mortaring blocks on edge.	5.84279444232532
5801. the wooden bracing between the roof	beams is placed flush with the inside of the wall.	4.367543283959748
5802. mortar is poured	between this bracing and the 4-inch blocks on edge to complete the	wall thickness for radiation shielding.	5.2920541105344485
5803. the first one or two roof boards	are slipped into place across the roof beams from outside	the shelter.	4.566934253771491
5804. these boards are nailed to the roof beams by reaching up	through the open space between the beams from inside the shelter.	5.608615060826799
5805. concrete	blocks are passed between the beams and put on the boards.	4.672293985277969
5806. the	roof blocks are in two layers and are not mortared together.	6.320401143794262
5807. work on the roof continues in this way.	6.814625552236305
5808. the last roof boards are covered	with blocks from outside the shelter.	6.243753037324464
5809. when the roof blocks	are all in place the final rows of wall blocks are mortared into position.	4.4007736107941104

5850. radiation scatters somewhat like light.	8.18656221502958
5851. some will go around a corner.	6.293668596807881

5906. water rationing will be difficult	and should be planned carefully.	7.05201103877834
5907. a portable electric heater	is advisable for shelters in cold climates.	4.739296986216059
5908. it would take the chill from	the shelter in the beginning.	8.540096652106442
5909. even if the electric power fails after	an attack any time that the heater has been used will make the shelter	that much more comfortable.	4.579362842458748
5910. body heat in the close quarters will	help keep up the temperature.	6.093123995732186
5911. warm clothing and bedding of course	are essential.	5.3285636594893
5912. open-flame heating or cooking should be avoided.	7.1581511048922275

5915. an attack finds you without a prepared shelter	few areas if any	are as good as prepared shelters but they are worth knowing about.	4.362644093097757
5916. a family dwelling without a basement provides some natural shielding	from fallout radiation.	6.052165977823562
5917. on the ground floor the radiation would	be about half what it is outside.	6.400781910572412
5918. the best protection would be on	the ground floor in the central part of the house.	6.828403825396941
5919. a belowground	basement can cut the fallout radiation to one-tenth of the outside	level.	4.535919135532883

5922. large apartment buildings	of masonry or concrete provide better natural shelter than the usual	family dwellings.	5.708240189006601
5923. in general such apartments afford more protection	than smaller buildings because their walls are thick and there is	more space.	4.300037659051936

5926. the federal	government is aiding local governments in several places to survey residential	commercial and industrial buildings to determine what fallout	protection they would provide and for how many people.	4.814841894185875

5929. a former du pont official became a general motors vice president	and set about maximizing du pont's share of the general motors	market.	4.337631272894582
5930. lines of communications were established between the two	companies and several du pont products were actively promoted.	5.500517242345147
5931. within	a few years various du pont manufactured items were filling the entire	requirements of from four to seven of general motors' eight operating	divisions.	3.870467454600242
5932. the fisher body division long controlled by the	fisher brothers under a voting trust even though general motors owned	a majority of its stock followed an independent course for many years	but by 1947 and 1948 resistance had collapsed and its purchases	from du pont compared favorably with purchases by other general	motors divisions.	4.349922034968313
5933. competitors came to receive higher percentage	of general motors business in later years but it is likely	that this trend stemmed at least in part from the needs of general	motors outstripping du pont's capacity.	4.335256654731455
5934. the fact	that sticks out in this voluminous record is that the bulk of du pont's	production has always supplied the largest part of the requirements	of the one customer in the automobile industry connected to du pont	by a stock interest.	5.132027254830764
5935. the inference is overwhelming that du pont's	commanding position was promoted by its stock interest and was not gained	solely on competitive merit.	3.7726701856862173
5936. 353 u s at 605.	8.18656221502958
5937. this court agreed with the trial court that considerations of price	quality and service were not overlooked by either du pont or general	motors.	3.8110967500434594
5938. 353 u s at 606.	8.18656221502958
5939. however it determined that	neither this factor nor the fact that all concerned in high executive	posts in both companies acted honorably and fairly each in the	honest conviction that his actions were in the best interests of his own	company and without any design to overreach anyone including du pont's	competitors 353 u s at 607 outweighed the government's	claim for relief.	3.8161017384829305
5940. this claim as submitted to the district	court and dismissed by it 126 fsupp235 alleged violation	not only of  7 of the clayton act but also of   1 and 2 of	the sherman act.	5.013549696049522
5941. the latter provisions proscribe any contract combination	or conspiracy in restraint of interstate or foreign trade and	monopolization of or attempts combinations or conspiracies to monopolize	such trade.	3.7060676179447003
5942. however this court put to one side without consideration	the government's appeal from the dismissal of its sherman	act allegations.	6.236971111637127
5943. it rested its decision solely on  7 which reads	in pertinent part:   no corporation engaged in commerce	shall acquire directly or indirectly the whole or any part of	the stock or other share capital of another corporation engaged also in	commerce where the effect of such acquisition may be to substantially	lessen competition between the corporation whose stock is so acquired	and the corporation making the acquisition or to restrain such commerce	in any section or community or tend to create a monopoly of any	line of commerce.	3.3572824365019867
5944. this section shall not apply to corporations	purchasing such stock solely for investment and not using the same	by voting or otherwise to bring about or in attempting to bring about	the substantial lessening of competition h.	4.812458978076424
5945. the purpose	of this provision was thus explained in the court's opinion:	section 7 is designed to arrest in its incipiency not only	the substantial lessening of competition from the acquisition by one corporation	of the whole or any part of the stock of a competing corporation	but also to arrest in their incipiency restraints or monopolies	in a relevant market which as a reasonable probability appear at the	time of suit likely to result from the acquisition by one corporation	of all or any part of the stock of any other corporation.	3.5097471661804125
5946. the section	is violated whether or not actual restraints or monopolies or the substantial	lessening of competition have occurred or are intended h.	5.167889570828118
5947. 353 u s at 589.	6.094118058689911
5948. thus a finding of conspiracy to	restrain trade or attempt to monopolize was excluded from the court's	decision.	6.007332993062837
5949. indeed as already noted the court proceeded on the assumption	that the executives involved in the dealings between du pont	and general motors acted honorably and fairly and exercised	their business judgment only to serve what they deemed the best interests	of their own companies.	3.6423539512343
5950. this however did not bar finding that du	pont had become pre-eminent as a supplier of automotive fabrics and	finishes to general motors; that these products constituted a line	of commerce within the meaning of the clayton act; that general	motors' share of the market for these products was substantial;	and that competition for this share of the market was endangered	by the financial relationship between the two concerns:   the	statutory policy of fostering free competition is obviously furthered	when no supplier has an advantage over his competitors from an acquisition	of his customer's stock likely to have the effects condemned	by the statute.	4.858382283586592
5951. we repeat that the test of a violation of  7 is	whether at the time of suit there is a reasonable probability that	the acquisition is likely to result in the condemned restraints.	4.768318681242775
5952. the	conclusion upon this record is inescapable that such likelihood was proved	as to this acquisition h.	5.609866851460979
5953. 353 u s at 607.	6.094118058689911
5954. on	the basis of the findings which led to this conclusion the court remanded	the case to the district court to determine the appropriate	relief.	6.232264298973287
5955. the sole guidance given the court for discharging the task committed	to it was this:   the judgment must therefore be reversed	and the cause remanded to the district court for a determination	after further hearing of the equitable relief necessary and appropriate	in the public interest to eliminate the effects of the acquisition	offensive to the statute.	3.3115144812104393
5956. the district courts in the framing	of equitable decrees are clothed 'with large discretion to model	their judgments to fit the exigencies of the particular case'.	4.854705421889624
5957. international	salt co	v united states 332 u s 392	400-401.	5.066959048406199

5959. this brings us to the	course of the proceedings in the district court.	5.257893592068643

5961. the first pretrial conference- held to appoint amici curiae	to represent the interest of the stockholders of du pont and general	motors and to consider the procedure to be followed in the subsequent	hearings- took place on september 25 1957.	3.6742561253222483
5962. at the outset the	government's spokesman explained that counsel for the government	and for du pont had already held preliminary discussions with a view	to arriving at a relief plan that both sides could recommend to the court.	5.18974990679629
5963. du pont he said had proposed disenfranchisement of its general	motors stock along with other restrictions on the du pont-general	motors relationship.	3.993196949169283

5965. counsel for the government invited	du pont's views on this proposal before recommending a specific program	but stated that if the court desired or if counsel for du pont	thought further discussion would not be profitable the government	was prepared to submit a plan within thirty days.	3.7719655997277117
5966. counsel for	du pont indicated a preference for the submission of detailed plans by	both sides at an early date.	5.545724359929214

5970. the	government submitted its proposed decree on october 25 1957.	6.522871687113793
5971. the	plan called for divestiture by du pont of its 63000000 shares of general	motors stock by equal annual distributions to its stockholders	as a dividend over a period of ten years.	3.7564296214699735
5972. christiana securities company	and delaware realty + investment company major stockholders	in du pont and the stockholders of delaware were dealt with specially	by provisions requiring the annual sale by a trustee again over	a ten-year period of du pont's general motors stock allocable to	them as well as any general motors stock which christiana and delaware	owned outright.	4.646273905296105
5973. if in the trustee's judgment reasonable	market conditions did not prevail during any given year he was to	be allowed to petition the court for an extension of time within the	ten-year period.	3.891855077511628
5974. in addition the right to vote the general motors	stock held by du pont was to be vested in du pont's stockholders	other than christiana and delaware and the stockholders of delaware;	du pont christiana and delaware were to be enjoined from acquiring	stock in or exercising control over general motors; du pont	christiana and delaware were to be prohibited to have any director	or officer in common with general motors and vice versa; and	general motors and du pont were to be ordered to terminate any agreement	that provided for the purchase by general motors of any specified	percentage of its requirements of any du pont manufactured product	or for the grant of exclusive patent rights or for a grant by general	motors to du pont of a preferential right to make or sell any	chemical discovery of general motors or for the maintenance of any	joint commercial enterprise by the two companies.	4.652318978545477
5975. on motion of	the amici	curiae the court directed that a ruling be obtained from	the commissioner of internal revenue as to the federal income tax	consequences of the government's plan.	4.157546366713634
5976. on may 9 1958 the commissioner	announced his rulings.	8.407076258129385
5977. the annual dividends paid to du pont	stockholders in shares of general motors stock would be taxable as ordinary	income to the extent of du pont's earnings and profits.	3.7199327550983288
5978. the	measure for federal income tax purposes of the dividend to individual	stockholders would be the fair market value of the shares at the time	of each annual distribution.	5.700057332500061
5979. in the case of taxpaying corporate stockholders	the measure would be the lesser of the fair market value	of the shares or du pont's tax basis for them which is approximately	$2.	4.232464159802893
5980. the forced sale of the general motors stock owned	by or allocable to christiana delaware and the stockholders of	delaware and deposited with the trustee would result in a tax to those	parties at the capital gains rate.	4.723263736269264

5986. on june 6 1958 general motors submitted	its objections to the government's proposal.	6.783169957941411
5987. it argued inter	alia that a divestiture order would severely depress the market	value of the stock of both general motors and du pont with consequent	serious loss and hardship to hundreds of thousands of innocent	investors among them thousands of small trusts and charitable institutions;	that there would be a similar decline in the market values of	other automotive and chemical stocks with similar losses to the stockholders	of those companies; that the tremendous volume of general	motors stock hanging over the market for ten years would hamper the efforts	of general motors and other automobile manufacturers to raise	equity capital; and that all this would have a serious adverse effect	on the entire stock market and on general business activity.	3.4626122143288294

5990. these plans like du pont's contained provisions	for passing the vote on du pont's general motors shares on	to the ultimate stockholders of du pont christiana and delaware	except that officers and directors of the three companies their spouses	and other people living in their households as well as other specified	persons were to be totally disenfranchised.	5.178289702146338

5992. it is not a medieval mental quirk or an attitude unnourished by sense	to believe that husbands and wives should not be subjected to such	a risk or that such a possibility should not be permitted to endanger	the confidentiality of the marriage relationship.	5.65252372581404
5993. while it is easy	enough to ridicule hawkins' pronouncement in pleas of the crown	from a metaphysical point of view the concept of the oneness	of a married couple may reflect an abiding belief that the communion between	husband and wife is such that their actions are not always to be	regarded by the criminal law as if there were no marriage.	3.8937958747930344
5994. by	making inroads in the name of law enforcement into the protection which	congress has afforded to the marriage relationship the court today	continues in the path charted by the recent decision in wyatt	v united states 362 us 525 where the court held that	under the circumstances of that case a wife could be compelled to	testify against her husband over her objection.	4.53562165491199
5995. one need not waver in	his belief in virile law enforcement to insist that there are other	things in american life which are also of great importance and to which	even law enforcement must accommodate itself.	3.8577339189637097
5996. one of these is the	solidarity and the confidential relationship of marriage.	8.359485442124688
5997. the court's	opinion dogmatically asserts that the husband-wife conspiracy doctrine	does not in fact protect this relationship and that hence the doctrine	enthrones an unreality into a rule of law.	3.4363117066526185
5998. i am not	easily persuaded that a rule accepted by so many people for so many centuries	can be so lightly dismissed.	6.130138237631326
5999. but in any event i submit that	the power to depose belongs to congress not to this court.	4.7380760038166345
6000. petitioner who claims to be a conscientious objector was convicted	of violating  12 of the universal military training and service	act by refusing to be inducted into the armed forces.	5.348289069853542
6001. he claims	that he was denied due process of law in violation of the fifth amendment	because at a hearing before a hearing officer of the department	of justice he was not permitted to rebut statements attributed	to him by the local board and at the trial he was denied the right	to have the hearing officer's report and the original report of	the federal bureau of investigation as to his claim.	3.76917262542252
6002. held:	on the record in this case the administrative procedures prescribed	by the act were fully complied with; petitioner was not denied due	petitioner	was not denied due process in the administrative proceedings	because the statement in question was in his file to which he had access	and he had opportunities to rebut it both before the hearing officer	of the department of justice and before the appeal board.	4.955525300012632
6003. pp	petitioner was not entitled to have the hearing officer's	notes and report especially since he failed to show any particular	need for them and he did have a copy of the department of justice's	petitioner was not entitled either in the administrative hearing at	the department of justice or at his trial to inspect the original report	of the federal bureau of investigation since he was furnished	a resume of it did not challenge its accuracy and showed no particular	need for the original report.	3.7055140750439994
