6019. on november	13 1952 he was classified in class 1-a.	5.845184472862463
6020. on november 22	1952 he wrote the board protesting this classification.	7.837385430523038
6021. he again stated	that he was a regular minister; that he was devoting	an average	of 100 hours a month to actual preaching publicly in addition to	50 to 75 hours in other ministerial duties and that he opposed war in	any form.	3.988750692919443
6022. thereafter he was classified 1-o.	8.784620709559364
6023. on april 1 1953	after some six months of full-time pioneering petitioner discontinued	devoting 100 hours a month to preaching but failed to so	notify his local board.	4.02344597976867
6024. in a periodic review the local board on july	30 1953 reclassified him 1-a and upheld this classification	after a personal appearance by petitioner because of his willingness	to kill in defense of his church and home.	5.391907729201765
6025. upon administrative approval	of the reclassification he was ordered to report for induction on	june 11 1956 but failed to do so.	4.299420639580393
6026. he was not prosecuted however	and his case was subsequently reopened in the light of sicurella	v united states 348 us 385.	6.485034855640551
6027. he was again	reclassified 1-a by the local board.	5.857838793606712
6028. there followed a customary	department of justice hearing at which petitioner appeared.	7.266374309807031
6029. in	his report to the attorney general the hearing officer suggested that	the petitioner be exempt only from combatant training and service.	4.100680128095886
6030. on march 21 1957 however the department recommended approval of	the 1-a classification.	7.017654267018555
6031. its ground for this recommendation was	that while petitioner claimed before the local board august 17 1956	that he	was devoting 100 hours per month to actual preaching the headquarters	of the jehovah's witnesses reported that he was no longer doing so	and on the contrary had relinquished both his pioneer and bible	student servant positions.	3.6877328700500738
6032. it reported that he now devoted only some	6-12 hours per month to public preaching and from 20 to 25 hours per	month to church activities.	5.502269476747234
6033. his claim was therefore so highly exaggerated	the department concluded that it cast doubt upon his	veracity and consequently upon his sincerity and good faith.	3.8871364131460804
6034. the	appeal board furnished petitioner a copy of the recommendation.	7.044794725443932
6035. in	his answer thereto he advised the board that he had made no such statement	in 1956 and asserted that his only claim to pioneering	was in 1952.	4.148428677359658
6036. the appeal board however unanimously concurred in the	department's recommendation.	5.986278812405151
6037. upon return of the file to the local	board petitioner was again ordered to report for induction and this	prosecution followed his failure to do so.	4.281351419779694
6038. petitioner first contends	that the department denied him procedural due process by not giving	him timely opportunity before its final recommendation to the appeal	board to answer the statement of the local board as to his claim	of devoting 100 hours to actual preaching.	5.078654671633888
6039. but the statement of the	local board attributing this claim to petitioner was in his file.	4.758605404461791
6040. he	admitted that he knew it was open to him at all times and he could have	rebutted it before the hearing officer.	6.039746964985402
6041. this he failed to do asserting	that he did not know it to be in his file.	6.717955016159484
6042. apparently he never	took the trouble to find out.	7.813772383614806
6043. nevertheless he had ample opportunity	to contest the statement before the appeal board.	4.853931342455543
6044. after the recommendation	of the department is forwarded to the appeal board that is the	appropriate place for a registrant to lodge his denial.	6.027759355156761
6045. we found in gonzales v united states supra that this	was the controlling reason why copies of the recommendation should be	furnished a registrant.	4.090370086784502
6046. we said there that it was necessary that	a registrant be given an opportunity to rebut the department's	recommendation when it comes to the appeal board the agency with the	ultimate responsibility for classification.	5.918151463013703
6047. we fail to see how such procedure resulted in any prejudice to petitioner's	contention which was considered by the appeal board and	denied by it.	4.2280601511457645
6048. as was said in gonzales it is the appeal board	which renders the selective service determination considered 'final'	in the courts not to be overturned unless there is no basis in fact.	6.223956209850682
6049. estep v united states 327 us 114.	5.3285636594893
6050. 348	u	s at 412-413.	10.109203984689895
6051. but there are other contentions which might	be considered more difficult.	6.631628366943329
6052. at his trial petitioner sought to secure	through subpoena duces tecum the longhand notes of the department's	hearing officer evensen as well as his report thereon.	5.9373574457714
6053. petitioner	also claimed at trial the right to inspect the original federal	bureau of investigation reports to the department of justice.	4.840041070707386
6054. he alleged no specific procedural errors or evidence withheld; nor	did he elaborate just what favorable evidence the federal bureau of	investigation reports might disclose.	5.297404087658622
6055. section 6 of the	act	as we have held does require the department's recommendation to	be placed in a registrant's file.	4.074301706759351
6056. gonzales v united states	supra.	8.978076491592427
6057. but there is nothing in the act requiring the hearing	officer's report to be likewise turned over to the registrant.	5.405566451552143
6058. while	the regulations formerly required that the hearing officer's report	be placed in the registrant's file this requirement was eliminated	in 1952.	5.659388860470662
6059. moreover the hearing officer's report is but intradepartmental	is directed to the attorney general and of course is not	the recommendation of the department.	4.650626337757436
6060. it is not essentially different	from a memorandum of an attorney in the department of justice of	which the attorney general receives many and to which he may give	his approval or rejection.	5.904821903214464
6061. it is but part of the whole process within	the department that goes into the making of the final recommendation	to the appeal board.	5.2358047040097215
6062. it is also significant that neither this	report nor the hearing officer's notes were furnished to the appeal	board.	6.105042384548764
6063. hence the petitioner had full opportunity to traverse the only	conclusions of the department on file with the board.	4.435300799726281
6064. petitioner	knew that the department's recommendation was based not on the hearing	officer's report but on the statement of the local board in his	file.	5.91550600723518
6065. having had every opportunity to rebut the finding of the local	board before both the hearing officer and the appeal board petitioner	cannot now claim that he was denied due process because he did not succeed.	4.029812262766781
6066. it appears to us that the same reasoning applies to the	production of the hearing officer's report and notes at the trial.	5.724934411323171
6067. in addition petitioner has failed to show any particular need for the	report and notes.	5.100553226994082
6068. while there are now allegations of the withholding	of favorable evidence developed at the hearing and a denial of	a full and fair hearing no such claim was made by petitioner at	any stage of the administrative process.	5.234583702590621
6069. moreover his testimony at	trial never developed any such facts.	5.550554791318084
6070. in the light of these circumstances	as well as the fact that the issue at trial in this respect centered	entirely on the department's recommendation which petitioner	repudiated but which both the appeal board and the courts below found	supported by the record we find no relevancy in the hearing officer's	report and notes.	5.500720667220102
6071. finally petitioner says that he was entitled	to inspect the fbi report during the proceedings before the	hearing officer as well as at the trial.	4.947680305512093
6072. he did receive a resume of	it- the same that was furnished the appeal board- and he made no	claim of its inaccuracy.	5.809616916774567
6073. even now no such claim is asserted.	6.2572638365135
6074. he bases	his present contention on the general right to explore indicating that	he hopes to find some discrepancy in the resume.	5.508728503344085
6075. but this is fully	answered by united states v nugent supra.	5.953388598319098
6076. there we held	that the statutory scheme for review within the selective service	system h entitles conscientious objectors to no guarantee	that	the fbi reports must be produced for their inspection.	5.245808507661898
6077. even if we were not bound by nugent petitioner	here would not be entitled to the report.	5.557067089763978
6078. the recommendation of	the department- as well as the decision of the appeal board- was	based entirely on the local board file not on an fbi report.	5.659528150158568
6079. with this enlarged role in	mind i should like to make a few suggestions: what we in the united	states do or do not do will make a very large difference in what	happens in the rest of the world.	4.637786377000858
6080. we in this department must think about	foreign policy in its total context.	6.765111983205103
6081. we cannot regard foreign policy	as something left over after defense policy or trade policy or fiscal	policy has been extracted.	4.251623799514793
6082. foreign policy is the total involvement	of the american people with peoples and governments abroad.	6.6226260105895065
6083. that	means that if we are to achieve a new standard of leadership we must	think in terms of the total context of our situation.	5.387858089593633
6084. it is the concern	of the department of state that the american people are safe and	secure- defense is not a monopoly concern of the department of defense.	7.589030712653635
6085. it is also the concern of the department of state that our	trading relationships with the rest of the world are vigorous profitable	and active- this is not just a passing interest or a matter of	concern only to the department of commerce.	5.264666557271729
6086. we can no longer rely on	interdepartmental machinery somewhere upstairs to resolve differences	between this and other departments.	6.723383098746229
6087. assistant secretaries of	state will now carry an increased burden of active formulation and coordination	of policies.	4.275314164678009
6088. means must be found to enable us to keep in	touch as regularly and as efficiently as possible with our colleagues	in other departments concerned with foreign policy.	5.197396418037966
6089. i think we	need to concern ourselves also with the timeliness of action.	5.199997234648329
6090. every	policy officer cannot help but be a planning officer.	6.522871687113793
6091. unless we keep	our eyes on the horizon ahead we shall fail to bring ourselves on target	with the present.	4.239817207121867
6092. the movement of events is so fast the pace so	severe that an attempt to peer into the future is essential if we are	to think accurately about the present.	4.724029945165832
6093. if there is anything which we	can do in the executive branch of the government to speed up the processes	by which we come to decisions on matters on which we must act	promptly that in itself would be a major contribution to the conduct	of our affairs.	4.40218210003996
6094. action taken today is often far more valuable than action	taken several months later in response to a situation then out of	control.	5.453041194607851
6095. there will of course be times for delay and inaction.	6.604510074902812
6096. what i am suggesting is that when we delay or when we fail to act	we do so intentionally and not through inadvertence or through bureaucratic	or procedural difficulties.	5.627609059928511
6097. i also hope that we can	do something about reducing the infant mortality rate of ideas- an affliction	of all bureaucracies.	4.232734803887799
6098. we want to stimulate ideas from the bottom	to the top of the department.	8.09435447048132
6099. we want to make sure that our junior	colleagues realize that ideas are welcome that initiative goes right	down to the bottom and goes all the way to the top.	5.051754731160817
6100. i hope no one	expects that only presidential appointees are looked upon as sources	of ideas.	6.276229978278352
6101. the responsibility for taking the initiative in generating	ideas is that of every officer in the department who has a policy function	regardless of rank.	4.251372919511791
6102. further i would hope that we could	pay attention to little things.	7.257996247843564
6103. while observing the operations of	our government in various parts of the world i have felt that in many	situations where our policies were good we have tended to ignore minor	problems which spoiled our main effort.	4.338899602513836
6104. to cite only a few examples:	the wrong man in the wrong position perhaps even in a junior	position	abroad can be a source of great harm to our policy; the attitudes	of a un delegate who experiences difficulty in finding adequate	housing in new york city or of a foreign diplomat in similar	circumstances in our capital can be easily be directed against the united	states and all that it stands for.	5.6066371370553645
6105. dozens of seemingly small	matters go wrong all over the world.	5.499419847776101
6106. sometimes those who know about them	are too far down the line to be able to do anything about them.	7.2856552153664
6107. i	would hope that we could create the recognition in the department and	overseas that those who come across little things going wrong have the	responsibility for bringing these to the attention of those who can	do something about them.	3.9515831724237023
6108. if the department of state is to take	primary responsibility for foreign policy in washington it follows	that the ambassador is expected to take charge overseas.	6.114649532197321
6109. this does	not mean in a purely bureaucratic sense but in an active operational	interested responsible fashion.	4.28837774550632
6110. he is expected to know about what	is going on among the representatives of other agencies who are stationed	in his country.	6.3987028985992005
6111. he is expected to supervise to encourage to direct	to assist in any way he can.	5.510947376776048
6112. if any official operation abroad begins	to go wrong we shall look to the ambassador to find out why and	to get suggestions for remedial action.	5.946413149243083
6113. it occurred to me that you might be interested in some thoughts	which i expressed privately in recent years in the hope of clearing	up a certain confusion in the public mind about what foreign policy	is all about and what it means and of developing a certain compassion	for those who are carrying such responsibilities inside government.	4.190315054892849
6114. i tried to do so by calling to their attention some of the problems	that a senior departmental policy officer faces.	6.79719554181522
6115. this means practically	everybody in this room.	6.834975815604573
6116. whether it will strike home for you or not	will be for you to determine.	6.849538732239832
6117. the senior policy officer may	be moved to think hard about a problem by any of an infinite variety of	stimuli: an idea in his own head the suggestions of a colleague	a question from the secretary or the president a proposal by another	department a communication from a foreign government or an american	ambassador abroad the filing of an item for the agenda of the united	nations or of any other of dozens of international bodies a news	item read at the breakfast table a question to the president or the	secretary at a news conference a speech by a senator or congressman	an article in a periodical a resolution from a national organization	a request for assistance from some private american interests abroad	et cetera ad infinitum.	3.135141037421314
6118. the policy officer lives with his antennae	alerted for the questions which fall within his range of responsibility.	5.117232935020516
6119. his first thought is about the question itself: is	there a question here for american foreign policy and if so what is	it?	4.312391401913519
6120.  for he knows that the first and sometimes most difficult job	is to know what the question is- that when it is accurately identified	it sometimes answers itself and that the way in which it is posed	frequently shapes the answer.	6.945893806596213
6121. chewing it over with his colleagues	and in his own mind he reaches a tentative identification of the	question- tentative because it may change as he explores it further	and because if no tolerable answer can be found it may have to be changed	into one which can be answered.	4.092682490236718
6122. meanwhile he has been thinking	about the facts surrounding the problem facts which he knows can	never be complete and the general background much of which has already	been lost to history.	5.524031535805099
6123. he is appreciative of the expert help available	to him and draws these resources into play taking care to examine	at least some of the raw material which underlies their frequently	policy-oriented conclusions.	4.158352754391034
6124. he knows that he must give the expert his	place but he knows that he must also keep him in it.	6.224318541748135
6125. he is	already beginning to box the compass of alternative lines of action	including doing nothing.	4.374306644526472
6126. he knows that he is thinking about action in	relation to a future which can be perceived but dimly through a merciful	fog.	6.639901514732483
6127. but he takes his bearings from the great guidelines of policy	well-established precedents the commitments of the united states	under international charters and treaties basic statutes and well-understood	notions of the american people about how we are to conduct	ourselves in policy literature such as country papers and national security	council papers accumulated in the department.	4.1254497135511965
6128. he will	not be surprised to find that general principles produce conflicting	results in the factual situation with which he is confronted.	5.659998214484156
6129. he must	think about which of these principles must take precedence.	4.844213633027724
6130. he will	know that general policy papers written months before may not fit his	problem because of crucial changes in circumstance.	5.332721664636918
6131. he is aware that	every moderately important problem merges imperceptibly into every other	problem.	5.04060667774286
6132. he must deal with the question of how to manage a part	when it cannot be handled without relation to the whole- when the whole	is too large to grasp.	6.492415781970297
6133. he must think of others who have a	stake in the question and in its answer.	4.972407196602743
6134. who should be consulted among	his colleagues in the department or other departments and agencies	of the government?	6.1353963209443325
6135.  which american ambassadors could provide helpful	advice?	6.4727126427913975
6136.  are private interests sufficiently involved to be consulted?	8.10721517850258
6137. 	what is the probable attitude of other governments including	those less directly involved?	4.521612145192864
6138.  how and at what stage and in what sequence	are other governments to be consulted?	6.468826229435575
6139.    if action is indicated	what kind of action is relevant to the problem?	4.948349938606228
6140.  the selection	of the wrong tools can mean waste at best and at worst an unwanted	inflammation of the problem itself.	5.303342234273332
6141. can the president or the secretary	act under existing authority or will new legislation and new money	be required?	4.456457736319199
6142.  should the action be unilateral or multilateral?	8.124089380473041
6143. 	is the matter one for the united nations or some other international	body?	6.2372886339006275
6144.  for if so the path leads through a complex process of parliamentary	diplomacy which adds still another dimension to the problem.	5.557014396170859
6145. what type of action can	hope to win public support first in this country and then abroad?	5.167353201277015
6146. 	for the policy officer will know that action can almost never be secret	and that in general the effectiveness of policy will be conditioned	by the readiness of the country to sustain it.	5.301877783111335
6147. he is interested in	public opinion for two reasons: first because it is important in itself	and second because he knows that the american public cares about	a decent respect for the opinions of mankind.	4.9632307989521465
6148. and given probable	public attitudes- about which reasonably good estimates can be made-	what action is called for to insure necessary support?	5.644803042983258
6149.    may	i add a caution on this particular point?	5.066959048406199
6150.  we do not want policy	officers below the level of presidential appointees to concern themselves	too much with problems of domestic politics in recommending foreign	policy action.	6.053318293439974
6151. in the first place our business is foreign policy	and it is the business of the presidential leadership and his appointees	in the department to consider the domestic political aspects of	a problem.	4.488180327982316
6152. mr truman emphasized this point by saying you fellows	in the department of state don't know much about domestic politics.	5.962471688094592
6153. this is an important consideration.	9.068342801241181
6154. if we sit here	reading editorials and looking at public-opinion polls and other reports	that cross our desks we should realize that this is raw undigested	opinion expressed in the absence of leadership.	6.121577286181003
6155. what the american	people will do turns in large degree on their leadership.	5.048734885558309
6156. we cannot	test public opinion until the president and the leaders of the country	have gone to the public to explain what is required and have asked them	for support for the necessary action.	6.280235277605851
6157. i doubt for example that	3 months before the leadership began to talk about what came to be the	marshall plan any public-opinion expert would have said that the country	would have accepted such proposals.	4.057129580834343
6158. the problem in the	policy officer's mind thus begins to take shape as a galaxy of utterly	complicated factors- political military economic financial legal	legislative procedural administrative- to be sorted out and handled	within a political system which moves by consent in relation to	an external environment which cannot be under control.	4.5945726923850785
6159. and the	policy officer has the hounds of time snapping at his heels.	4.6424231631842945
6160. while there should be no general age limit or restriction to one	sex there will be particular projects requiring special maturity and	some open only to men or to women.	5.7456155078077815
6161. the peace corps should not pay	the expenses of a wife or family unless the wife is also accepted for	full-time peace corps work on the same project.	4.237570744244116
6162. there should	be no draft exemption because of peace corps service.	7.489789649007464
6163. in most cases	service in the corps will probably be considered a ground for temporary	deferment.	5.119106639832215
6164. peace corps volunteers obviously should not	be paid what they might earn in comparable activities in the united	states.	5.549618309824965
6165. nor would it be possible in many cases for them to live in	health or any effectiveness on what their counterparts abroad are paid.	4.387154261258263
6166. the guiding principle indeed should not be anything like compensation	for individual services.	6.076597153076951

6168. peace corps volunteers should be given	just enough to provide a minimum decent standard of living.	6.380764398468363

6175. the government should the peace corps be established?	5.761242796220414
6176. 	the idea	of a peace corps has captured the imagination of a great many people.	7.869385777516439
6177. support for it cuts across party regional ethnic and other lines.	4.598513348495876
6178. the peace corps therefore offers an opportunity to add a new dimension	to our approach to the world- an opportunity for the american	people to think anew and start afresh in their participation in world	development.	5.32763476403759
6179. for this the peace corps should be administered	by a small new alive agency operating as one component in our whole	overseas operation.	4.429305293393199

6184. the peace corps can either begin in very low gear with only preparatory	work undertaken between now and when congress finally appropriates	special funds for it- or it can be launched now and in earnest	by executive action with sufficient funds and made available from	existing mutual security appropriations to permit a number of substantial	projects to start this summer.	4.902758503371705

6190. what would the first projects be?	9.291389153414267
6191. 	in the first year there should	probably be considerable emphasis on teaching projects.	4.886962322668286

6194. the first year's projects	should also be spread through several countries in latin america	africa and asia.	5.774422942198309
6195. although the need for outside trained manpower exists in every	newly developing nation the readiness to receive such manpower or to	receive it from the united states will vary from country to country.	4.6525269158784095

6197. unfriendly political groups will no doubt do everything	in their power to promote active hostility.	4.474485582725863

6201. we should hope that peace corps projects will be truly	international and that our citizens will find themselves working alongside	citizens of the host country and also volunteers from other lands.	3.8521107750924255

6209. if it is decided to make a	small shift which may be required from military aid or special assistance	funds in order to carry out the purposes of the mutual security	act through this new peaceful program this will be a hopeful sign	to the world.	4.441894287753548

6384. continuing technical	problems involved in the use of this fuel coupled with significant	improvements in aircraft range through other means have now raised serious	questions about the value of the high-energy fuel program.	6.140119428888874
6385. as	a result the scope of this project has been sharply curtailed.	4.740858050060867
6386. these examples underscore the importance of even more searching evaluations	of new major development programs and even more penetrating and	far-ranging analyses of the potentialities of future technology.	5.479395666325546
6387. the	cost of developing a major weapon system is now so enormous that the	greatest care must be exercised in selecting new systems for development	in determining the most satisfactory rate of development and in	deciding the proper time at which either to place a system into production	or to abandon it.	3.3983640996371314
6388. the deterrent power	of our armed forces comes from both their nuclear retaliatory capability	and their capability to conduct other essential operations in any	form of war.	4.698723859097317
6389. the first capability is represented by a combination	of manned bombers carrier-based aircraft and intercontinental and intermediate	range missiles.	4.451782627363053
6390. the second capability is represented by our	deployed ground naval and air forces in essential forward areas together	with ready reserves capable of effecting early emergency reinforcement.	5.078020572782926
6391. the strategic air command is the principal element	of our long-range nuclear capability.	4.12596267992654
6392. one of the important and difficult	decisions which had to be made in this budget concerned the role	of the b-70 a long-range supersonic bomber.	6.866336271401596
6393. this aircraft which	was planned for initial operational use about 1965 would be complementary	to but likewise competitive with the four strategic ballistic missile	systems all of which are scheduled to become available earlier.	3.843235715326959
6394. the first atlas icbm's are now operational the first two	polaris submarines are expected to be operational this calendar year	and the first titan icbm's next year.	5.668129334007725
6395. the minuteman solid-fueled	icbm is planned to be operational about mid-1963.	4.200697917275358
6396. by	1965 several or all of these systems will have been fully tested and	their reliability established.	6.356763815251825
6397. thus the need for the b-70	as a strategic weapon system is doubtful.	6.111589549585077
6398. however i am recommending	that development work on the b-70 air-frame and engines be continued.	6.850244422162507
6399. it is expected that in 1963 two prototype aircraft will be available	for flight testing.	4.640121402322442
6400. by that time we should be in a much better	position to determine the value of that aircraft as a weapon system.	7.764349355712646
6401. i am recommending additional acquisitions of the improved version	of the b-52	and procurement of the b-58 supersonic medium bomber together with	the supporting refueling tankers in each case.	3.8936672318842644
6402. these additional modern	bombers will replace some of the older b-47 medium bombers;	one b-52 can do the work of several b-47's which it will replace.	6.38629391435888
6403. funds are also included in this budget to continue the equipping	of the b-52 wings with the hound dog air-to-surface missile.	3.985392805510451
6404. in the coming fiscal year additional quantities of atlas titan	and polaris missiles also will be procured.	6.2412757536498775

6443. this broad delegation leaves within our discretion	both the determination	of what degree of interference shall be considered excessive and the	methods by which such excessive interference shall be avoided.	3.6493237668380574
6444. the present proceeding is concerned with the standard broadcast	band from 540 kc to 1600 kc.	6.5315303796004605
6445. whenever two or more standard	broadcast stations operate simultaneously on the same or closely adjacent	frequencies each interferes to some extent with reception of	the other.	4.564724222034658
6446. the extent of such interference- which may be so slight	as to be undetectable at any point where either of the stations renders	a usable signal or may be so great as to virtually destroy the service	areas of both stations- depends on many factors among the principal	ones being the distance between the stations their respective	radiated power and of particular significance here the time of day.	4.753886010954104
6447. other factors playing a part in the the extent of am service	and interference are the frequency involved the time of year the position	of the year in the sunspot cycle ground conductivity along	the	transmission path atmospheric and manmade noise and others.	4.137666415981443
6448. with the	existence of these many factors some of them variable it obviously	has never been and is not now possible for the commission to make assignments	of am stations on a case-to-case basis which will insure	against any interference in any circumstances.	5.20621491977064
6449. rather such assignments	are made as they must be on the basis of certain overall rules	and standards representing to some extent a statistical approach to	the problem taking into account for each situation some of the variables	and averaging out others	in order to achieve the balance which must be struck between protection	against destructive interference and the assignment of a number of	stations large enough to afford optimum radio service to the nation.	3.8858884278955963
6450. an example of the overall standards applied is the 20-to-1 ratio established	for the determination of that degree of cochannel interference	which is regarded as objectionable.	5.811666692089389
6451. by this standard it is determined	that where two stations operating on the same frequency are involved	objectionable interference from station a exists at any point within	the service area of station b where station a's signal	is of an intensity one-twentieth or more of the strength of station b's	signal at that point.	3.8177720353890314
6452. the 20-to-1 ratio for cochannel	interference embodies one of the fundamental limiting principles which	we must always take into account in am assignments and allocations-	that signals from a particular station are potential sources	of objectionable interference over an area much greater than that within	which they provide useful service.	4.656625625449788
6453. a second fundamental principle	is that involved particularly in the present proceeding- the difference	between nighttime and daytime propagation conditions with respect	to the standard broadcast frequencies.	4.002097757272081
6454. this is a phenomenon familiar	to all radio listeners resulting from reflection of skywave signals at	night from the ionized layer in the upper atmosphere known as the ionosphere.	5.72654429496998
6455. all am stations radiate both skywave and groundwave signals	at all hours; but during the middle daytime hours these skywave	radiations are not reflected in any substantial quantity and during	this portion of the day both skywave service and skywave interference	are in general negligible.	3.927581585214505
6456. but during nighttime hours the skywave	radiations are reflected from the ionosphere thereby creating the possibility	of one station's rendering service via skywave at a much	greater distance than it can through its groundwave signal and at the	same time vastly complicating the interference problem because of the	still greater distance over which these skywave signals may cause interference	to the signals of stations on the same and closely adjacent	frequencies.	4.61201719520924
6457. because of the difference between daytime and nighttime	propagation conditions it has been necessary to evolve different allocation	structures for daytime and nighttime broadcasting in the am	band with many more stations operating during the day than at night.	4.245152697286862
6458. it was recognized years ago that the transition from daytime	to nighttime propagation conditions and vice versa is not an instantaneous	process but takes place over periods of time from roughly	2 hours before sunset until about 2 hours after sunset and again from	roughly 2 hours before sunrise until some 2 hours after sunrise.	4.687336588342195
6459. during	the period of about 4 hours around sunset skywave transmission conditions	are building up until full nighttime conditions prevail; during	the same period around sunrise skywave transmission is declining	until at about 2 hours after sunrise it reaches a point where it becomes	of little practical significance.	3.4990149887787396
6460. however in this case as elsewhere	it was necessary to arrive at a single standard to be applied to	all situations representing an averaging of conditions and thus to	fix particular points in time which would be considered the dividing points	between daytime and nighttime conditions.	5.69445340215214
6461. it was determined that	the hours of sunrise and sunset respectively should be used for this	purpose.	5.148396405692202
6462. accordingly the 1938-39 rules adopted these hours as limitations	upon the operation of daytime stations.	6.4748760330211095
6463. class 2 stations	operating on clear channels are required to cease operation or operate	under nighttime restrictions beginning either at local sunset	or sunset at the location of the dominant	class 1 station where located west of the class 2 station	.	3.8070846527267266
6464. the same restrictions apply	after local sunset in the case of class 3 stations operating on	regional channels which after that time are required to operate under	nighttime restrictions in order to protect each other.	5.633427499293251
6465. with respect	to nighttime assignments the degree of skywave service and interference	is determined by skywave curves	giving average skywave values.	4.592556059405676
6466. these curves were derived	by an analysis of extensive skywave measurement data.	6.597736666311408
6467. it was recognized	that skywave signals because of their reflected nature are of great	variability and subject to wide fluctuations in strength.	4.4961012071653705
6468. for this	reason the more uncertain skywave service was denominated secondary	in our rules as compared to the steadier more reliable groundwave	primary service and for both skywave service and skywave	interference signal strength is expressed in terms of percentage of	time a particular signal-intensity level is exceeded- 50 percent of	the time for skywave service 10 percent of the time for skywave interference.	5.0863599149571295
6469. as mentioned the allocation	of am stations represents a balance between protection against	interference and the provision of opportunity for an adequate number	of stations.	4.074610640354365
6470. the rules and policies to be applied in this process of	course must be based on objectives which represent what is to be desired	if radio service is to be of maximum use to the nation.	5.629870441876587
6471. our objectives	to provide some	to provide as many choices of	to provide service	of local origin to as many listeners as possible.	4.192993451968678
6472. since broadcast	frequencies are very limited in number these objectives are to some	extent inconsistent in that not all of them can be fully realized and	to the extent that each is realized there is a corresponding reduction	of the possibilities for fullest achievement of the others.	5.443377590108269
6473. accordingly	the commission has recognized that an optimum allocation pattern	for one frequency does not necessarily represent the best pattern	for other frequencies and has assigned different frequencies for use	by different classes of stations.	3.5652351826088364
6474. some 45 frequencies are assigned for	use primarily by dominant class 1- a or class 1-	b clear-channel stations designed to operate with adequate	power and to provide service- both groundwave and skywave-	over large areas and at great distances being protected against	interference to the degree necessary to achieve this objective.	4.773044822020194
6475. in dealing	with these frequencies the objective listed first above- provision	of service to all listeners- was predominant; the other objectives	were subordinated to it.	3.858377016419732
6476. the class 1 stations on these clear	channels are protected to their 0.	5.578519827945279
6477. 1-mvm groundwave contours	against daytime cochannel interference.	5.66037853959279
6478. with respect to skywave service	rendered at night class 1- a stations are the only stations	permitted to operate in the united states on clear channels specified	for class 1- a operation and so render skywave service	free	from cochannel interference whereever they may be received; class	1- b stations are protected at night to their 0.	5.148819114191836
6479. 5-mvm	50-percent	time skywave contours against cochannel interference.	5.66037853959279
6480. since	the provision of skywave service requires adequate freedom from interference	only class 1 stations are capable of rendering skywave service.	5.6099892424930635
6481. but nighttime operation by stations of other classes of course	entails skywave interference to groundwave service interference which	is substantial unless steps are taken to minimize it.	3.9601725656948963
6482. with	respect to other frequencies these are designated as regional or local	and assigned for use by class 3 and class 4 stations respectively	stations operating generally with lower power.	4.911638703765829
6483. in the allocation	pattern worked out for these frequencies the provision of long-range	service has to some extent been subordinated to the other two objectives-	assignment of multiple facilities and assignment of stations	in as many communities as possible.	3.849227487638811
6484. as mentioned the primary	allocation objective to be followed in the allocation of stations	on clear channels is the provision of widespread service free from	destructive interference.	5.2717257028606115
6485. during nighttime hours because of the intense	skywave propagation then prevailing no large number of stations can	be permitted to operate on one of these channels if the wide area	service for which these frequencies are assigned is to be rendered satisfactorily	by the dominant stations which must be relied upon to render	it.	4.221584911178089
6486. therefore under our longstanding allocation rules on some of	these channels no station other than the dominant	station is permitted to operate at night so that the 1- a	station can render service interference free wherever it can be received.	5.51243403829878
6487. on the remainder of the clear channels the dominant	stations are protected as described above and the relatively	small number of secondary stations permitted to operate	on these channels at night are required to operate directionally	andor with reduced power so as to protect the class 1 stations.	3.8938393603332346
6488. in the daytime on the other hand since skywave transmission is relatively	inefficient it is possible to assign a substantially larger number	of stations on these channels.	6.14889624006893
6489. additional class 2 assignments	for daytime operation can be made without causing destructive interference	to the class 1 stations or to each other and by their operation	provide additional service on these channels and additional local	outlets for a large number of communities.	4.076234919282008
6490. such additional daytime	class 2 assignments are appropriate if optimum use is to be made	of these frequencies and the commission has over the years made a large	number of them.	5.814945858481193
6491. similarly on the regional channels many class 3	stations have been assigned either to operate daytime only or to operate	nighttime with directional antennas andor lower power.	3.8033671795196144
6492. essentially the question presented for decision in the present daytime	skywave proceeding is whether our decision in 1938-1939 to	assign stations on the basis of daytime conditions from sunrise to sunset	is sound as a basis for am allocations or whether in the light	of later developments and new understanding skywave transmission	is of such significance during the hours immediately before sunset and	after sunrise that this condition should be taken into account and	some stations required to afford protection to other stations during these	hours.	4.681429672043007
6493. the decision	reached in 1938-39 was made after the accumulation of a large amount	of data and thorough study thereof.	4.067378922676922
6494. since then there has been a notable	increase in the number of stations and also the accumulation of additional	data and the development of new techniques for using it leading	to a better understanding of propagation phenomena.	6.631960577563879
6495. in 1947 affidavits	were filed with the commission by various clear-channel stations	alleging that extensive interference was being caused to the service	areas of these stations during daylight hours from class 2 stations	whose signals were being reflected from the ionosphere so as to	create skywave intereference.	3.439778608679341
6496. if you elect to use the standard deduction or the tax table and	later find you should have itemized your deductions you may do so by	filing an amended return within the time prescribed for filing a claim	for refund.	5.312898160693658
6497. see you may claim a refund page 135.	5.743251577089417
6498. the same	is true if you have itemized your deductions and later decide you should	have used the standard deduction or tax table.	5.251665274258999

6580. the one- or two-season hunt of which there have been too many recently	may do more harm than good; for such programs raise hopes of assistance	toward achieving excellence in scholarship and the arts which	are dashed when the programs are discontinued; and they are dashed	no less by lack of skill in making selections of men and women for development	toward the highest reaches of the mind and spirit.	4.79313472487662
6581. for	the making of selections on the basis of excellence requires that any	foundation making the selections shall have available the judgments	of a corps of advisors whose judgments are known to be good: such judgments	can be known to be good only by the records of those selected	by records made subsequent to their selection over considerable periods	of time.	3.611597567002463
6582. the central group of the foundation's advisors	are at any one period of time the members of our advisory board	consisting now of thirty-six men and women.	5.882494475368432
6583. they are chosen by the	foundation's board of trustees on the bases of their own first-rate	accomplishments in their different fields of scholarship and the arts.	4.349811797445124
6584. their locations in all parts of the united states and their locations	in the several kinds of educational and research institutions	that are the principal homes of our intellectual and artistic strengths	also are factors in the trustees' minds.	6.030660249494329
6585. for this concept of an	advisory board ancillary to the board of trustees we are indebted	to the late president of harvard university a lawrence lowell	a master of the subject of the structure of cultural institutions	and their administration.	4.488207027283123
6586. that we had the wit and wisdom to adopt mr	lowell's concept and make it the base for our processes of selection	is one reason why our selections have been it may be said truly	pretty uniformly good.	5.776350608962229
6587. for in accordance with mr lowell's	concept of an advisory board our selections are made by experienced	selectors who give both constancy and consistency to our processes	and our choices.	4.018000742671479
6588. and lest we should become too consistent in the	sense of becoming heedless of new fields of scholarship and new points	of view in the arts the foundation's board of trustees maintains	a trickle- not a flow!- of new members through the advisory board.	5.1218963660031225
6589. two committees of members of the advisory board constitute	the committees of selection- one for the selection of fellows	from canada the united states and the english-speaking caribbean	area and one for the selection of fellows from the latin american	republics and the republic of the philippines.	4.361524793183438
6590. to the members	of our advisory board and most specially to its members who constitute	our committees of selection the foundation is indebted for its	successes of choice of fellows.	5.236027030393506
6591. we are as we know utterly dependent	on the quality of advice we get; and quality of advice added to	devotion to the foundation's purposes and ideals we do get from	our advisory board in measures so full that they can be appreciated	only by those of us who work here every day.	4.249194705054442
6592. but the facts about	our advisory board and its members' duties are only one of several	sets of facts about the quest for advice both reliable and imaginative	on which to base our selections of fellows.	5.244900388182503
6593. for example the	interest of past members of the foundation's advisory board remains	such that they place their knowledge and judgments at our disposal	much as they had done when they were formally members of that board.	4.090380517404364
6594. and besides there are a large number of scholars artists composers	of music novelists poets essayists choreographers lawyers servants	of government and men of affairs- hundreds indeed- who serve	the foundation well with the advice they give us freely and gratis	out of their experience.	5.3091333938600656
6595. to all the foundation gives the kind	of thanks which are more than thanks: to them we are grateful beyond	the possibility of conveying in words how grateful we are.	3.961406859566443
6596. it is a truism of business that no business can be better than	its board of directors and its top management.	5.991061694824048
6597. the same is true of	every foundation.	6.277306665283958
6598. during the biennium reviewed in this report our	board of trustees named able men younger than the rest of us to the	board and to top management to insure future continuance of the first-class	administration of the foundation's affairs:   dr	james brown fisk physicist president of the bell telephone laboratories	was elected to the board of trustees.	5.450877258627769
6599. he is a member	both of the national academy of sciences and of the american philosophical	society; and he has served our country well as a scientific	statesman on international commissions.	5.324097066612539
6600. dr gordon n	ray provost vice-president and professor of english in the university	of illinois was appointed associate secretary general.	5.683213587129919
6601. the trustees of the foundation appointed dr ray to that position	with the stated expectation that he would succeed the present secretary	general upon the latter's eventual retirement.	3.7953380149618456
6602. dr ray is	a fellow of the foundation- appointed thrice to assist his studies	of william makepeace thackeray and of h g wells- and	before his appointment to the foundation's executive staff had been	given our highest scholarly accolade appointment to the advisory board.	4.715424919011072
6603. referring further to the foundation's officers dr	james f mathias for eleven years our discerning colleague as	associate secretary was promoted to be secretary.	3.9126358397780323
6604. he is a historian	with the great merit of a historian's long view.	7.1942860595041545
6605. also appointed	to the foundation's staff as assistant secretary is mr	j kellum smith jr.	4.652261509300707
6606. mr smith like the present secretary	general is a lawyer; and lawyers- with the great virtues	that they are trained to read the fine print carefully and are	able out of professional experience to arrive at imaginative solutions	to difficult problems in many fields- are indispensable even in a foundation	office.	4.876351654707575
6607. the present secretary general has been the	foundation's principal administrative officer continuously since the	foundation's establishment thirty-five years ago.	4.03962495138101
6608. but even he will	not last indefinitely and the above-noted new arrangements are quite	simply made to assure qualitative continuity in the foundation's	policies and practices.	5.458769907943132
6609. the effective recognition of excellence and	its nurture has to be learned and is not learned in a day nor even	in a year.	4.271797793719789
6610. we are not given to lamentations neither personally	nor in these reports.	7.943506744648829
6611. on the contrary if this be an apocalyptic	era as is commonly said we see it as an era of opportunity.	4.7221800276425245
6612. for	granting that there are great present-day problems to be solved these	problems make great demands; and by their demanding tend to create	resources of men's minds and hearts which problems with easy answers	do not bring forth.	4.915845732117427
6613. of this examples are legion: pericles speaking	his funeral oration in ancient greece's extremity after thermopylae	and making it a testament of freedom; jefferson writing the	declaration of independence amid the catastrophes of revolution;	christ preaching the sermon on the mount close to his ultimate sacrifice;	shakespeare speaking with the indescribable gusto of the	elizabethan voice- keats's words- in the days of the spanish	armada's threats; isaac newton at the age of twenty-three	industriously calculating logarithms to two and fifty places during	the great plague year in england 1665; winston churchill's	olympian optimistic and resolute sayings when britain stood alone	against the armed forces of tyranny less than twenty years ago; the	present-day explorations of outer space answering age-old questions	of science and philosophy in the face of possible wars of extinction.	3.4775793756594546
6614. forsan et haec olim meminisse iuvabit as the roman poet	virgil declared with much more historical sense than most writers	of today.	5.160513208686437
6615. it gives indeed cause for rejoicing to remember what many	catastrophes of the past produced; and it is to be noted also that	confidence should grow from remembering that great men often appeared	in the past to turn local catastrophe into future good for all mankind.	4.220337100432756
6616. for example out of the social evils of the english industrial	revolution came the novels of charles dickens; and his genius	moved his readers to seek solutions of those evils for all western men-	until today- in the industrialized west these social evils	substantially do not exist.	5.265944105799031
6617. the solutions were not arrived at by any	theoreticians of the karl marx stripe but by men of government- lawyers	most of them- and men of business.	3.540600977135349
6618. these were educated men	who as mr justice holmes was fond of saying formed their inductions	out of experience under the burden of responsibility.	5.5563050522599715
6619. that is	to put it realistically they had to run their businesses at a profit	or they had to get the votes to get elected.	4.490416656030654
6620. nevertheless they made	naught of marx's prophecy that capitalism would never pay the workers-	to use marx's word- more than a subsistence wage with	the consequence that increased productivity must inevitably find its	way into the capitalists' pockets with the result in turn that the	gap between the rich and the poor would irrevocably widen and the misery	of the poor increase.	4.7353236791743045
6621. but as all understand who have eyes	to see nothing of the kind has happened; indeed the contrary has	happened.	4.655350912549271
6622. the gulf between the rich and the poor has narrowed	in the industrialized western world to the point that the word	poor is hardly applicable.	5.201204537477738
6623. and the reason this could happen is	clear: men of government business men lawyers and all who concerned	themselves with the welfare of their fellow men did not let their	concern to run their businesses at a profit restrict the development of	freedom and opportunity.	3.7313604275060768
6624. some would say that they were not permitted	to run their businesses only for profit; and even putting it that	way would not prove that marx was anything but wrong.	5.670824586095048
6625. sir henry	sumner maine a hundred years before communism was a force to be	reckoned with wrote his brilliant legal generalization that the	progress of society is from status to contract.	3.7926219827352505
6626. the essence of contract	is that one is free to make a choice of what one will or will not	do.	6.007215445176732
6627. hence the condition of freedom is a necessary condition for choice.	5.110726632091657
6628. the greater the range of freedom for individual men the greater	the range of choice; the greater the range of choice the greater	the rate of change.	5.316074882533905
6629. for change is dependent on the possibilities that	individual men glimpse for the future.	4.983740533146882
6630. but when there is not freedom	and opportunity to choose men- individual men- must remain in status	and society does not cannot progress.	6.161622664695081
6631. the eternal truth	is that progress- due as it always is to individual creative genius-	is just as dependent on freedom as human life is dependent on the	beating of the heart.	3.4642567743409387
6632. and lest anybody think that considerations	such as these are not germane in a foundation report let me enlighten	them with the truths that under communism there would have been	no capital with which to endow the foundation and that there would	not be that individual freedom within which the fellows might proceed	untrammeled in every way toward their discoveries their creative	efforts for the good of mankind.	4.870583868420237
6633. during the year 1959	we granted 354 fellowships; in 1960 we granted 334.	5.391949965348877
6634. as heretofore	our fellowships are available to assist research in all fields of	knowledge and creative effort in all the arts.	6.175497827079075
6635. we do not favor one field	over another: we think that all inquiry all scholarly and artistic	creation is good- provided only that it contributes to a sense	and understanding of the true ends of life as all first-rate scholarship	and artistic creation does.	4.077304018992075
6636. indeed if pressed we would say what	the late robert henri american painter said to a pupil anything	will do for a subject: it's what you do with it that counts.	5.355038768229942
6637. thus we have no part and want none in current discussions	of the relative importance of science the social studies the humanities	the creative arts.	4.2774234168139165
6638. we want no part in such discussions because	we think them largely futile; and we think them largely futile because	for true excellence of accomplishment every scholar and every	artist must cross boundaries of knowledge and boundaries of points of	view.	4.982242050514858
6639. when the brown + sharpe manufacturing company reached its	125th year as a going industrial concern during 1958 it became an almost	unique institution in the mechanical world.	3.9604899507606004
6640. with its history	standing astride all but the very beginnings of the industrial revolution	brown + sharpe has become over the years a singular monument	to the mechanical foresight of its founder joseph r brown and	a world-renowned synonym for precision and progress in metalworking technology.	5.064908200443816
6641. joseph r brown grew up in the bustle and enterprise	of new england between 1810 and 1830.	4.475325344765706
6642. he was early exposed to	the mechanical world and in his youth often helped his father david	brown master clock and watchmaker as he plied his trade.	5.38554865407053
6643. at the	age of 17 he became an apprentice machinist at the shop of walcott +	harris in valley falls rhode island and following two or three	other jobs in quick succession after graduation he went into business	for himself in 1831 making lathes and small tools.	3.535055955687678
6644. this enterprise	led to a father-and-son combination beginning in 1833 under the name	d brown + son a business which eventually grew into the modern	corporation we now call brown + sharpe.	4.835778582113481
6645. the years of joseph's	partnership with his father were numbered.	4.915149536450179
6646. in 1838 a devastating	fire gutted their small shop and soon thereafter david brown moved	west to illinois settling on a land grant in his declining years.	5.034535399228868
6647. joseph brown continued in business by himself quickly rebuilding	the establishment which had been lost in the fire and beginning those	first steps which were to establish him as a pioneer in raising the	standards of accuracy of machine shop practice throughout the world.	3.7322505831215196
6648. much of his genius of course sprang from his familiarity with	clock movements.	6.783617006423975
6649. during these early years the repair of watches and	clocks and the building of special clocks for church steeples formed	an important part of the young man's occupation.	4.462029135088973
6650. he became particularly	interested in graduating and precision measurement during the 1840's	and his thinking along these lines developed considerably during	this period.	5.368619595951285
6651. but his business also grew and we are told that mr	brown found it	increasingly difficult to devote as much time to his	creative thinking as his inclinations led him to desire.	4.043711726526524
6652. it must have	been with some pleasure and relief that on september 12 1848 joseph	brown made the momentous entry in his job book in his characteristically	cryptic style lucian sharpe came to work for me this day	as an apprentice.	5.03842756883523
6653. the young apprentice apparently did well	by mr brown for in the third year of his apprenticeship lucian	was offered a full partnership in the firm; the company became j	r brown + sharpe and entered into a new and important	period of its development.	3.8204185844998078
6654. mr sharpe's arrival in the business	did indeed provide what mr brown had most coveted- time for tinkering	and the opportunity of carrying out in the back room those	developments in precision graduation which most interested him at that	time.	5.252085779296424
6655. by 1853 the new partnership announced the precision	vernier caliper as the first fruit of their joint efforts.	4.6745299156181765
6656. the basic	significance of this invention helped them to follow it rapidly in 1855	by the development of a unique precision gear cutting and dividing	engine.	5.131803526523291
6657. that development in turn formed the foundation of still more	significant expansions in later years- in gear cutting in circular	graduating in index drilling and in many other fields where accuracy	was a paramount requirement.	3.7128913213837444
6658. throughout their careers both	mr brown and mr sharpe were interested in the problem of setting	up standards of measurement for the mechanical trades.	6.30707358867085
6659. several	efforts were made in this direction and though not all of them survive	to this day the brown + sharpe wire gage system was eventually adopted	as the american standard and is still in common use today.	3.9846401456827842
6660. as one development followed another the company's reputation for	precision in the graduating field brought it broader and broader opportunities	for expansion in precision manufacture.	5.271897011214115
6661. in 1858 the partnership	began manufacturing the willcox + gibbs sewing machine.	4.742197349412644
6662. as the story goes mr gibbs who originally came from the back	counties of the commonwealth of virginia saw an illustration in a	magazine of the famous howe sewing machine.	5.674650468490449
6663. curious as to what made	it work he built a crude model of it in wood and filed a piece of steel	until he succeeded in making a metal pickup for the thread enabling	the crude machine to take stitches.	3.8791857067977378
6664. when he showed this model as his	solution as to how the howe sewing machine operated he was	told he was wrong and discovered to his amazement that the howe	machine which was unknown to him in detail used two threads while	the one that he had perfected used only one.	5.296678998985319
6665. thus was invented the	single thread sewing machine which mr gibbs in partnership with	mr willcox decided to bring to brown + sharpe with the proposal	that the small company undertake its manufacture.	3.706119061034101
6666. the new work	was a boon to the partnership not only for its own value but particularly	for the stimulation it provided to the imagination of j r	brown toward yet further developments for production equipment.	5.141779729483408
6667. the turret screw machine now known as the brown + sharpe hand	screw machine takes its ancestry directly from mr brown's efforts	to introduce equipment to simplify the manufacture of the sewing	machine.	3.8177337364971935
6668. mr brown made important additions to the arts in screw machine	design by drastically improving the means for revolving the turret	by introducing automatic feeding devices for the stock and reversible	tap and die holders.	5.167973913694062
6669. in 1861 mr brown's attention	was called to yet another basic production problem- the manufacture	of twist drills.	4.197910220104564
6670. at that time during the civil war union muskets	were being manufactured in providence and the drills to drill them	were being hand-filed with rattail files.	6.221528343341205
6671. this process neither satisfied	the urgent production schedules nor mr brown's imagination	of the possibilities in the situation.	4.2525908972579245
6672. the child of this problem was	mr brown's famous serial no 1 universal milling machine	the archtype from which is descended today's universal knee-type	milling machine used throughout the world.	4.831790232223155
6673. the original machine bearing	its famous serial number is still on exhibition at the brown + sharpe	precision center in providence.	3.857090307923501
6674. during the civil war	period mr brown also invented the brown + sharpe formed tooth	gear cutter a basic invention which ultimately revolutionized the world's	gear manufacturing industry by changing its basic economics.	5.165855015528541
6675. up until that time it had been possible to make cutters for making gear	teeth but they were good for only one sharpening.	4.608417030626148
6676. as soon as the	time came for re-sharpening the precise form of the gear tooth was lost	and a new cutter had to be made.	6.099486385151695
6677. this process made the economical	manufacture of gears questionable until some way could be found to permit	the repeated re-sharpening of gear tooth cutters without the loss	of the precision form.	3.623144432688742
6678. mr brown's invention achieved this and	as a byproduct formed the cornerstone of brown + sharpe's position	of leadership in the gear making equipment field which lasted until	the 1920's when superceded by other methods.	4.841065215222533
6679. the micrometer	caliper as a common workshop tool also owes much to j r brown.	3.991360822643165
6680. although mr brown was not himself its inventor	it is typical that his intuition first conceived the importance	of mass producing this basic tool for general use.	5.263448575947424
6681. so it was	that when mr brown and mr sharpe first saw the french tool	on exhibition in paris in 1868 they brought a sample with them to the	united states and started brown + sharpe in yet another field where	it retains its leadership to this day.	3.5881644275423707
6682. the final achievement	of mr brown's long and interesting mechanical career runs a	close second in importance to his development of the universal milling	machine.	5.360545175752686
6683. that achievement was his creation of the universal grinding	machine which made its appearance in 1876 at the philadelphia centennial	exposition.	4.165196044658232
6684. this machine like its milling counterpart was	the antecedent of a machine-family used to this very day in precision	metalworking shops throughout the world.	5.183437337510168
6685. along with j r brown's	other major developments the universal grinding machine was profoundly	influential in setting the course of brown + sharpe for many	years to come.	4.136351589490087
6686. following mr brown's death there came	forward in the brown + sharpe organization many other men who contributed	greatly to the development of the company.	6.013368287007806
6687. one such man was samuel	darling.	7.990669676751336
6688. as head of the firm darling + swartz mr	darling began by challenging brown + sharpe to its keenest competition	during the 1850's and early 60's.	5.84152353241309
6689. in 1868 however a truce	was called between the companies and the partnership of darling brown	+ sharpe was formed.	4.060816172838175
6690. between that year and the buying out of mr	darling's interest in 1892 a large portion of the company's precision	tool business was carried out under the name of darling brown	+ sharpe and to this day many old precision tools are in use still	bearing that famous trademark.	5.171557459245469
6691. perhaps the outstanding standard	bearer of mr brown's tradition for accuracy was mr oscar	j beale whose mechanical genius closely paralleled that of	mr brown and whose particular forte was the development of the exceedingly	accurate measuring machinery that enabled brown + sharpe	to manufacture gages and therefore its products with an accuracy exceeding	anything then available elsewhere in the world.	3.616209978606658
6692. also important	on the brown + sharpe scene at the turn of the century was	mr richmond viall works superintendent of the company from	1876 to 1910.	6.2173757926825965
6693. mr viall possessed remarkable talents for the leadership	and development of men.	4.855576152371108
6694. he was an ardent champion of the brown	+ sharpe apprentice program and personal counselor to countless able	men who first developed their industrial talents with the company.	5.367895040438286
6695. in one sense it can be said that one of the most important brown + sharpe	products over the years has been the men who began work with the	company and subsequently came to places of industrial eminence throughout	the nation and even abroad.	5.1121599909796025
6696. commencing with the death of	lucian sharpe in 1899 the name of henry d sharpe was for more	than 50 years closely interwoven with the destiny of the company.	5.310088739516755
6697. during	his presidency the company's physical plant was enormously expanded	and the length and breadth of the brown + sharpe machine tool	line became the greatest in the world.	3.854223481982572
6698. during the early part of this	century the brown + sharpe works in providence were unchallenged	as the largest single manufacturing facility devoted exclusively to	precision machinery and tool manufacture anywhere in the world.	5.541288018773964
6699. during these years the company's product line followed the basic tenets	laid down by mr brown.	4.965387517891601
6700. it expanded from hand screw machines	to automatic screw machines from simple formed-tooth gear cutting machines	to gear hobbing machines and a large contract gear manufacturing	business from rudimentary belt-driven universal milling machines to	a broad line of elaborately controlled knee-type and manufacturing type	milling machines.	4.751609680148722
6701. in the grinding machine field expansion went far	from universal grinders alone and took in cylindrical grinders surface	grinders and a wide variety of special and semi-special models.	4.01339663839761
6702. in 1951 henry d sharpe jr succeeded his father and	continued	the company's development as a major factor in the metal-working	equipment business.	5.874674454412075
6703. the company is still broadening its line and	is now active on four major fronts.	4.3488593696246935
6704. the machine tool division	is currently producing brown + sharpe single spindle automatic screw	machines grinding machines of many types and knee and bed-type	milling machines.	4.812281899547261
6705. recently added is the brown + sharpe turret drilling	machine which introduces the company to an entirely new field of tool	development.	4.128003184536013
6706. in the industrial products division the company	manufactures and markets a wide line of precision gaging and inspection	equipment machinists' tools- including micrometers vernier	calipers and accessories.	5.168882230108415
6707. in the cutting tool division	the principal products include a wide variety of high speed steel milling	cutters end mills and saws.	4.348288352734535

7058. it has recently become practical to use the	radio emission of the moon and planets as a new source of information	about these bodies and their atmospheres.	5.589620395929571
7059. the results of present observations	of the thermal radio emission of the moon are consistent with	the very low thermal conductivity of the surface layer which was derived	from the variation in the infrared emission during eclipses	.	3.5055437304685153
7060. when sufficiently accurate and complete measurements	are available it will be possible to set limits on the thermal	and electrical characteristics of the surface and subsurface materials	of the moon.	5.690161301695787
7061. observations of the radio emission of a planet	which has an extensive atmosphere will probe the atmosphere to a greater	extent than those using shorter wave lengths and should in some cases	give otherwise unobtainable information about the characteristics	of the solid surface.	3.5410813590579524
7062. radio observations of venus and jupiter have	already supplied unexpected experimental data on the physical conditions	of these planets.	6.001515367472971
7063. the observed intensity of the radio emission of	venus is much higher than the expected thermal intensity although the	spectrum indicated by measurements at wave lengths near 3 cm and	1o cm is like that of a black body at about 6oo` k.	3.591025301485718
7064. this result	suggests a very high temperature at the solid surface of the planet	although there is the possibility that the observed radiation may be	a combination of both thermal and non-thermal components and that the	observed spectrum is that of a black body merely by coincidence.	5.4130880601294225
7065. for	the case of jupiter the radio emission spectrum is definitely not like	the spectrum of a black-body radiator and it seems very likely that	the radiation reaching the earth is a combination of thermal radiation	from the atmosphere and non-thermal components.	3.62753852331871
7066. of the remaining	planets only mars and saturn have been observed as radio sources	and not very much information is available.	5.861590198257548
7067. mars has been observed	twice at about 3-cm wave length and the intensity of the observed	radiation is in reasonable agreement with the thermal radiation which	might be predicted on the basis of the known temperature of mars.	3.739927447186872
7068. the low intensity of the radiation from saturn has limited observations	but again the measured radiation seems to be consistent with a thermal	origin.	5.284539804943991
7069. no attempts to measure the radio emission of the remaining	planets have been reported and because of their distances small	diameters or low temperatures the thermal radiation at radio wave lengths	reaching the earth from these sources is expected to be of very	low intensity.	4.232403852581044
7070. in spite of this the very large radio reflectors and	improved amplifying techniques which are now becoming available should	make it possible to observe the radio emission of most of the planets	in a few years.	5.687927971518806
7071. the study of the radio emission of the moon	and planets began with the detection of the thermal radiation of the moon	at 1.	4.239474118490714
7072. 25-cm wave length by dicke and beringer.	7.1581511048922275
7073. this was	followed by a comprehensive series of observations of the 1.	4.64192548420022
7074. 25-cm	emission of the moon over three lunar cycles by piddington and minnett	.	5.926734816808145
7075. they deduced from their measurements that the radio emission	from the whole disk of the moon varied during a lunation in a roughly	sinusoidal fashion; that the amplitude of the variation was considerably	less than the amplitude of the variation in the infrared emission	as measured by pettit and nicholson;	and that the maximum of the radio emission came about 3-12 days after	full	moon which is again in contrast to the infrared emission which reaches	its maximum at full moon.	3.3128992406858786
7076. piddington and minnett explained	their observations by pointing out that rocklike materials which are likely	to make up the surface of the moon would be partially transparent	to radio waves although opaque to infrared radiation.	5.386377291273841
7077. the infrared	emission could then be assumed to originate at the surface of the moon	while the radio emission originates at some depth beneath the surface	where the temperature variation due to solar radiation is reduced	in amplitude and shifted in phase.	3.503586638171082
7078. since the absorption of radio waves	in rocklike material varies with wave length it should be possible	to sample the temperature variation at different depths beneath the surface	and possibly detect changes in the structure or composition of the	lunar surface material.	5.162884252216841
7079. the radio emission of a planet was	first detected in 1955 when burke and franklin identified the	origin of interference-like radio noise on their records at about 15	meters wave length as emission from jupiter.	3.4607534044690613

7096. the concept of apparent	black-body temperature is used to describe the radiation received from	the moon and the planets.	6.179471886205675
7097. the received radiation is compared with the	radiation from a hypothetical black body which subtends the same solid	angle as the visible disk of the planet.	3.497753656590105
7098. the apparent black-body	disk temperature is the temperature which must be assumed for the	black body in order that the intensity of its radiation should equal that	of the observed radiation.	4.943670359356213
7099. the use of this concept does not specify	the origin of the radiation and only if the planet really radiates	as a black body will the apparent black-body temperature correspond	to the physical temperature of the emitting material.	3.6938400437478918
