7137. experiments were made on an electric arc applying a porous	graphite anode cooled by a transpiring gas.	4.060235568763422
7138. thus the	energy transferred from the arc to the anode was partly fed back into	the arc.	6.021965529294785
7139. it was shown that by proper anode design the net energy loss	of the arc to the anode could be reduced to approximately 15% of the	total arc energy a detailed energy balance of the anode was established.	3.801805505008355
7140. the anode ablation could be reduced to a negligible amount.	6.600686554928239
7141. the dependence	of the arc voltage upon the mass flow velocity of the transpirating	gas was investigated for various arc lengths and currents between	100 amp and 200 amp.	3.5229678800761963
7142. qualitative observations were made and	high-speed motion pictures were taken to study flow phenomena in the	arc at various mass flow velocities.	5.160513208686437
7143. the high heat	fluxes existing at the electrode surfaces of electric arcs necessitate	extensive cooling to prevent electrode ablation.	4.025752497958087
7144. the cooling requirements	are particularly severe at the anode.	5.998227019452429
7145. in free burning electric	arcs for instance approximately 90% of the total arc power is transferred	to the anode giving rise to local heat fluxes in excess of	f as measured by the authors- the exact value depending on the arc	atmosphere.	3.767475899641324
7146. in plasma generators as currently commercially available	for industrial use or as high temperature research tools often more than	50% of the total energy input is being transferred to the co0ling	medium of the anode.	5.113016420253648
7147. the higher heat transfer rates at the anode	compared with those at the cathode can be explained by the physical	phenomena occurring in free burning arcs.	3.8170619506713757
7148. in plasma generators the	superimposed forced convection may modify the picture somewhat.	6.370453158772714
7149. the heat	transfer to the anode is due to the following effects: 1.	4.727757290668442
7150. heat	of condensation plus kinetic energy of the electrons impinging	on the anode.	6.093123995732186
7151. this energy transfer depends on the current the	temperature in the arc column the anode material and the conditions	in the anode sheath.	4.128177984271262
7152. heat transfer by molecular conduction as well	as by radiation from the arc column.	5.836381488750392
7153. the heat transfer to	the anode in free burning arcs is enhanced by a hot gas jet flowing from	the cathode towards the anode with velocities up f.	3.5050988515911787
7154. this phenomenon	has been experimentally investigated in detail by maecker	.	6.6993653757925555
7155. the pressure gradient producing the jet is due to the nature of the	magnetic field in the arc	.	5.138326247447363
7156. hence the flow conditions at the anode of free	burning arcs resemble those near a stagnation point.	5.918608559133053
7157. it is apparent	from the above and from experimental evidence that the cooling requirements	for the anode of free burning arcs are large compared with	those for the cathode.	3.852010767427344
7158. the gas flow through a plasma generator will modify	these conditions; however the anode is still the part receiving	the largest heat flux.	5.086350174945562
7159. an attempt to improve the life of the anodes	or the efficiency of the plasma generators must therefore aim at	a reduction of the anode loss.	4.423988831234164
7160. the following possibilities exist for	achieving this: 1.	7.167210679324329
7161. the use of high voltages and low currents by proper	design to reduce electron heat transfer to the anode for a given	power output.	3.9384151138169137
7162. continuous motion of the arc contact area at the anode	by flow or magnetic forces.	5.699223288067105
7163. feed back of the energy transferred	to the anode by applying gas transpiration through the anode.	4.830277357944147
7164. the third method was to our knowledge successfully applied for the	first time by c sheer and co-workers.	5.795252424573479
7165. the purpose of	the present study is to study the thermal conditions and to establish	an energy balance for a transpiration cooled anode as well as the effect	of blowing on the arc voltage.	3.9380188832823966

7448. there are considerable differences between	the requirements for textile and hard-surface cleaning.	6.91450949012057
7449. exclusive	of esthetic values such as high- or low-foam level perfume content	etc the requirements for the organic active used in washing textiles	are high.	3.8439997618966375
7450. no matter how they are formulated a large number of organic	actives are simply not suitable for this application since they	do not give adequate soil removal.	6.195674410814954
7451. this is best demonstrated by practical	washing tests in which cloth articles are repeatedly washed with	the same detergent formulation.	4.358801928111699
7452. a good formulation will keep the clothes	clean and white after many washings; whereas with a poor formulation	the clothes exhibit a build-up of tattle-tale grey and dirty	spots- sometimes with bad results even after the first wash.	5.074726139888361
7453. since	practical washing procedures are both lengthy and expensive a number	of laboratory tests have been developed for the numerical evaluation	of detergents.	4.074465217873082
7454. harris has indicated that two devices the launder-ometer	and terg-o-tometer are most widely used for rapid detergent	testing and he has listed the commercially available standard soiled	fabrics.	5.209655400596317
7455. also given are several laboratory wash procedures in general	use.	5.37342174860599
7456. the soiled fabrics used for rapid testing of detergent formulations	are made in such a way that only part of the soil is removed by	even the best detergent formulation in a single wash.	5.796119736464846
7457. in this way	numerical values for the relative efficacy of various detergent formulations	can be obtained by measuring the reflectance of the	cloth swatches before and after washing.	4.219669906591711
7458. soil redeposition is evaluated	by washing clean swatches with the dirty ones.	6.153820661871595
7459. as is the case with	the surface-active agent the requirements for builders to be used in	detergent compositions for washing textiles are also high.	4.483099819609477
7460. large numbers	of potential builders have been investigated but none have been	found to be as effective as the polyphosphates over the relatively wide	range of conditions met in practice.	4.956540402939004
7461. the problems of hard-surface	cleaning are not nearly as complex.	5.192878750720373
7462. in hard-surface cleaning the	inorganic salts are more important than the organic active.	6.787668978990182
7463. indeed	when the proper inorganic constituents are employed practically any	wetting or surface-active agent will do a reasonably good job when present	in sufficient amount in a hard-surface cleaning formulation.	3.738201918147265
7464. hydroxides	orthophosphates borates carbonates and silicates are important	inorganic ingredients of hard-surface cleaners.	6.093123995732186
7465. in addition the	polyphosphates are also used probably acting more as peptizing agents	than anything else.	4.800953176424609
7466. the importance of the inorganic constituents in	hard-surface cleaning has been emphasized in a number of papers.	6.247470092473489
7467. chemistry of washing	although there is no question	but that the process of washing fabrics involves a number of phenomena	which are related together in an extremely complicated way and that	these phenomena and their interrelations are not well understood at the	present this section attempts to present briefly an up-to-date picture	of the physical chemistry of washing either fabrics or hard surfaces.	3.7248102700808188
7468. the purpose of washing is obviously to remove soils which are arbitrarily	classed in the four major categories given below:	dirt which is here defined as particulate material which is usually	inorganic and is very often extremely finely divided so as to exhibit	colloidal properties.	4.737205037140556
7469. greasy soils which are typified by	hydrocarbons and fats.	5.066959048406199
7470. stains which include the wide variety of nonparticulate	materials which give color even when present in very low concentration	on the soiled object.	5.491548481406992
7471. miscellaneous soils which primarily	include sticky substances and colorless liquids which evaporate to leave	a residue.	4.21292691591616
7472. the dirt on the soiled objects is mechanically	held by surface irregularities to some extent.	5.201822978274158
7473. however a major factor	in binding dirt is the attraction between surfaces that goes under	the name of van der waal's forces.	4.091972267801938
7474. this is a theoretically complicated	dipole interaction which causes any extremely small uncharged particle	to agglomerate with other small uncharged particles or to stick	to an uncharged surface.	5.385619016940795
7475. obviously if colloidal particles bear charges	of opposite sign or if one kind is charged and the other kind is	not the attraction will be intensified and the tendency to agglomerate	will be greatly reinforced.	3.9242718575207656
7476. likewise a charged particle will tend	to stick to an uncharged surface and vice versa and a charged particle	will be very strongly attracted to a surface exhibiting an opposite	charge.	4.815391403268571
7477. in addition dirt particles can be held onto a soiled surface	by sticky substances or by the surface tension of liquids including	liquid greases.	4.116579930554575
7478. greases stains and miscellaneous soils	are usually sorbed onto the soiled surface.	6.093123995732186
7479. in most cases these soils	are taken up as liquids through capillary action.	5.243035068466114
7480. in an essentially	static system an oil cannot be replaced by water on a surface unless	the interfacial tensions of the water phase are reduced by a surface-active	agent.	5.6632975893037445
7481. the washing process whereby soils are removed consists	basically of applying mechanical action to loosen the dirt particles	and dried matter in the presence of water which helps to float off	the debris and acts to some extent as a dissolving and solvating	agent.	3.472694289947275
7482. greasy soils are hardly removed by washing in plain water;	and	natural waters in addition often contain impurities such as calcium	salts which can react with soils to make them more difficult to remove.	4.873699127315271
7483. the detergent active is that substance	which primarily acts to remove greasy soils.	4.012715720819275
7484. the other constituents	in a built detergent assist in this and in the removal of dirty stains	and the hydrophilic sticky or dried soils.	6.0083822953435515
7485. as is well known	detergent actives belong to the chemical class consisting of moderately	high molecular weight and highly polar molecules which exhibit the	property of forming micelles in solution.	4.018445304893243
7486. physicochemical investigations	of anionic surfactants including the soaps have shown that there	is little polymerization or agglomeration of the chain anions below	a certain region of concentration called the critical micelle concentration.	4.839007203939244
7487. below the critical micelle concentration monomers and some	dimers are present.	5.260981873755177
7488. in the critical micelle region there is	a rapid agglomeration or polymerization to give the micelles which have	a degree of polymerization averaging around 60-80.	5.462573646497722
7489. for anionics	these micelles appear to be roughly spherical assemblages in which	the hydrocarbon tails come together so that the polar groups	face outward towards the aqueous continuous phase.	4.2718552534613945
7490. obviously	hydrophobic	substances such as greases oils or particles having	a greasy or oily surface are more at home in the center of a micelle	than in the aqueous phase.	5.969498882438924
7491. micelles can imbibe and hold a considerable	amount of oleophilic substances so that the micelle volume may be	increased as much as approximately two-fold.	4.506334870184685
7492. although the matter has	not been unequivocally demonstrated the available data show that micelles	in themselves do not contribute significantly to the detergency process.	5.550854909281888
7493. related to micelle formation is the technologically important	ability of detergent actives to congregate at oil-water interfaces	in such a manner that the polar end of the molecule is directed	towards the aqueous phase and the hydrocarbon chain towards the	oily phase.	3.736567535821713
7494. in the cleaning process sorbed greasy soils become coated	in this manner with an oriented film of surfactant.	5.671719354955688
7495. then during washing	the greasy soil rolls back at the edges so that emulsified droplets	can disengage themselves from the sorbed oil mass with the aid of	mechanical action and enter the aqueous phase.	3.9252658001412355
7496. obviously a substance	which is permanently or temporarily sorbed on the surface in place of	the soil will tend to accelerate this process and effectively push off	the greasy soil.	5.142993547683909
7497. substances other than detergent actives also	tend to be strongly sorbed from aqueous media onto surfaces of other	contiguous condensed phases.	3.8880356915934375
7498. this is particularly true of highly charged	ions especially those ions which fall into the class of polyelectrolytes.	6.730722384390768
7499. whereas the usual organic surface-active agent is strongly	sorbed at oil-water interfaces the highly charged ions are most strongly	sorbed at interfaces between water and insoluble materials exhibiting	an ionic structure.	3.7291233604238996
7500. thus for aqueous	media we can think of the idealized organic active as an oleophilic	or hydrophobic surface-active agent and of an idealized builder as	a oleophobic or hydrophilic surface-active agent.	5.495044329270998
7501. from the equilibrium	sorption data which are available it seems logical to expect	that polyphosphate ions would be strongly sorbed on the surface of	the dirt so as to give it a greatly increased	negative charge.	4.397301677400404
7502. the charged particles then repel each other and are	also repelled from the charged surface which almost invariably bears	a negative charge under washing conditions.	4.982708624345451
7503. the negatively charged dirt	particles then leave the surface and go into the aqueous phase.	3.911162329557564
7504. this	hypothesis is evolved in analogy to the demonstrated action of organic	actives in detergency.	5.980332303617451
7505. it does not consider the kinetic effects	of the phosphate builders on sorption-desorption phenomena which will	be discussed later.	4.862577264219526
7506. the crude picture of	the detergency process thus far developed can be represented as: f	the influence of mechanical action on the particles of free soil may	be compared to that of kinetic energy on a molecular scale.	4.755467026449081
7507. freed soil	must be dispersed and protected against flocculation.	5.066959048406199
7508. cleaned cloth	must be protected against the redeposition of dispersed soil.	6.289010577019261
7509. it is	evident that the requirements imposed by these effects upon any one	detergent constituent acting alone are severe.	4.309941617365307
7510. upon consideration	of the variety of soils and fabrics normally encountered in the washing	process it is little wonder that the use of a number of detergent	constituents having synergistic properties has gained widespread	acceptance.	6.044102946432084
7511. in the over-all process it is difficult to assign a	pure role to each constituent of a built-detergent formulation;	and indeed there is no more reason to separate the interrelated roles	of the active builder antiredeposition agent etc than there	is to assign individual actions to each of the numerous isomers making	up a given commercial organic active.	3.791610257001554
7512. the thermal exchange of chlorine between f and liquid f is	readily measurable at temperatures in the range of 180` and above.	5.097076243535302
7513. the	photochemical exchange occurs with a quantum yield of the order of	unity in the liquid phase at 65` using light absorbed only by the f.	4.096677091064432
7514. in the gas phase with f of f and f of f quantum yields	of the	order of f have been observed at 85`.	5.4920563317026
7515. despite extensive attempts	to obtain highly pure reagents serious difficulty was experienced in	obtaining reproducible rates of reaction.	4.414295446924475
7516. it appears possible to set	a lower limit of about f for the activation energy of the abstraction	of a chlorine atom from a carbon tetrachloride molecule by a chlorine	atom to form f radical.	4.963807891160672
7517. the rate of the gas phase exchange reaction	appears to be proportional to the first power of the absorbed light	intensity indicating that the radical intermediates are removed at	the walls or by reaction with an impurity rather than by bimolecular	radical combination reactions.	3.8083172306992346
7518. because of the simplicity	of the molecules isotopic exchange reactions between elemental	halogens and the corresponding carbon tetrahalides would appear to offer	particularly fruitful possibilities for obtaining unambiguous basic	kinetic data.	5.5539123869968705
7519. it would appear that it should be possible to determine	unique mechanisms for the thermal and photochemical reactions in both	the liquid and gas phases and to determine values for activation energies	of some of the intermediate reactions of atoms and free radicals	as well as information on the heat of dissociation of the carbon-halogen	bond.	3.8899641271096304
7520. the reaction of chlorine with carbon tetrachloride seemed	particularly suited for such studies.	5.70123384720487
7521. it should be possible to prepare	very pure chlorine by oxidation of inorganic chlorides on a vacuum	system followed by multiple distillation of the liquid.	4.360329005625983
7522. it should be	possible to free carbon tetrachloride of any interfering substances by	the usual purification methods followed by prechlorination prior to	addition of radioactive chlorine.	5.544083196933352
7523. furthermore the exchange would not	be expected to be sensitive to trace amounts of impurities because it	would not be apt to be a chain reaction since the activation energy for	abstraction of chlorine by a chlorine atom would be expected to be	too high; also it would be expected that f would compete very effectively	with any impurities as a scavenger for f radicals.	3.831158883457096
7524. contrary	to these expectations we have found it impossible to obtain the degree	of reproducibility one would wish even with extensive efforts to prepare	especially pure reagents.	5.010346701729108
7525. we are reporting these investigations	here briefly because of their relevancy to problems of the study of apparently	simple exchange reactions of chlorine and because the results	furnish some information on the activation energy for abstraction of	chlorine atoms from carbon tetrachloride.	3.9904687137534345

7585. the poynting-robertson effect	which is a retardation of the orbital motion of particles	by the relativistic aberration of the repulsive force of the impinging	solar radiation causes the dust to spiral into the sun in times much	shorter than the age of the earth.	3.4223487589658865
7586. the radial velocity varies inversely	as the particle size- a 1000-|m-diameter particle near the	orbit of mars would reach the sun in about 60 million years.	4.818241178340229
7587. whipple	extends the effects to include the solar-corpuscular-radiation	pressure which increases both the minimum particle size and the drag.	4.091788710050971
7588. further the corpuscular radiation ie the solar-wind protons	must sputter away the surface atoms of the dust and cause a slow	diminution in size with a resultant increase in both the poynting-robertson	effect and the ratio of the repulsive force to the gravitational	force.	4.901314314952811
7589. the poynting-robertson effect causes the semi-major	axis of orbits to diminish more rapidly than the semi-minor axis	with a consequent tendency toward circular orbits as the particles move	toward the sun.	3.418595292505811
7590. also planetary gravitational attraction increases	the dust concentration near the plane of the ecliptic as the sun is	approached.	6.0627891124288675
7591. at one astronomical unit from the sun	the dust orbits are probably nearly circular.	5.089191801677756
7592. if such is the case	the particles within a distance of about f km of the earth	will	have relative to the earth a kinetic energy less than their potential	energy and they will be captured into orbits about the earth.	5.397925425440887
7593. de	jager has calculated the times required for these particles	to reach the atmosphere under the influence of the poynting-robertson	effect which in this case causes the orbits to become more and more	eccentric	without changing the semi-major axis.	3.917252240733431
7594. this effect can give rise to	a blanket of micrometeorites around the earth.	6.05670322839548
7595. since there is	a continual loss of micrometeoritic material in space because of the	radiation effects there must be a continual replenishment: otherwise	micrometeorites would have disappeared from interplanetary space.	4.140749025886731
7596. there	are several possible sources.	9.7465835513508
7597. according to whipple cometary	debris is sufficient to replenish the material spiraling into the	sun maintaining a fairly steady state.	4.463270901083843
7598. asteroidal collisions are also	thought to contribute material.	7.1581511048922275
7599. it is also possible that some of	the dust in the vicinity of the earth originated from meteoritic impacts	upon the moon.	4.798204400924747
7600. one cannot make a very satisfactory guess about the micrometeorite	flux in space.	6.771945903196035
7601. even in the neighborhood of the earth where information	has been obtained both directly and indirectly the derived flux	values vary by at least four orders of magnitude.	4.739715318610234
7602. this large discrepancy	demonstrates the inadequacies of the experimental methods and the	lack of understanding of the various phenomena involved.	6.102003712651571
7603. beyond a	few million kilometers from the earth but still in the region of the	earth's orbit a prediction of the flux of dust is even more unreliable.	4.21682140130143
7604. at greater distances from the sun the situation is still less	certain.	7.595877401808909
7605. there are several sources of evidence on the micrometeorite	environment.	5.618130110242501
7606. direct information has been obtained from rockets	and satellites equipped with impact sensors.	5.926734816808145
7607. in addition the size	distribution obtained from visual and radar observations of meteors may	be extrapolated to the micrometeorite domain.	4.4572444246318
7608. from the brightness of	the f component of the solar corona and the brightness of the zodiacal	light an estimate of the particle sizes concentrations and spatial	distribution can be derived for regions of space near the ecliptic	plane.	5.080684079903548
7609. another important source of evidence only recently receiving	much attention is the analysis of atmospheric dust for a meteoritic	component.	4.130172867308324
7610. the cores of deep-sea sediments and content of collectors	in remote regions are valuable in this category.	5.055834108035586
7611. the data provide a	measure of the total mass of cosmic material incident upon the earth.	4.1835186564154885
7612. the direct evidence on the micrometeorite environment near the	earth is	obtained from piezoelectric sensors	and from wire gages; these instruments are installed on rockets satellites	and space probes.	4.669056410444599
7613. statistically the most significant data have	been collected from the sensors on 1958 alpha	1958 delta 2.	4.162654673811288
7614. these	vehicles with large sensitive areas have collected data for long enough	times to give reliable impact rates for the periods of exposure.	5.103675880876918
7615. many other vehicles with smaller sensitive-area exposure-time products	contribute some information.	5.41724406730245
7616. the impact rate on 1958 alpha	for 153 events was f for particles of mass greater than f	; this mass threshold was derived from the detector calibration	and an assumed impact velocity of f.	4.633660833714064
7617. the data show daily and diurnal	variations.	4.863391169911775
7618. ninety per cent of the 153 recorded impacts occurred	between midnight and noon and from day to day the variation of the rate	was as much as an order of magnitude.	5.689044289741813
7619. one may conclude that most	of the detected micrometeoritic material is concentrated in orbital streams	which intersect the earth's orbit.	4.260478711379705

7678. biological warfare is the intentional use of	living microorganisms or their toxic products for the purpose of destroying	or reducing the military effectiveness of man.	5.3446255698423695
7679. it is the exploitation	of the inherent potential of infectious disease agents by scientific	research and development resulting in the production of bw	weapons systems.	4.428225999244087
7680. man may also be injured secondarily by damage to	his food crops or domestic animals.	6.727332517316316
7681. biological warfare is considered	to be primarily a strategic weapon.	4.855658467968249
7682. the major reason for this	is that it has no quick-kill effect.	7.142737853212844
7683. the incubation period of infectious	disease plus a variable period of illness even before a lethal effect	render this weapon unsuitable for hand-to-hand encounter.	3.5473748551672966
7684. a man	can be an effective fighting machine throughout the incubation period	of most infectious diseases.	5.61618342048764
7685. thus an enemy would probably use this weapon	for attack on static population centers such as large cities.	4.390101277304171
7686. an important operational procedure in bw for an enemy would	be to create an areosol or cloud of agent over the target area.	5.259064580175611
7687. this	concept has stimulated much basic research concerning the behavior of	particulate biological materials the pathogenesis of respiratory infections	the medical management of such diseases and defense against their	occurrence.	3.6345709407778486
7688. the biological and physical properties of infectious	particles have been studied intensively during the past fifteen	years.	5.649814519147625
7689. much new equipment and many unique techniques have been developed	for the quantitative exposure of experimental animals to aerosols	of infectious agents contained in particles of specified dimensional	characteristics.	3.8430028608922515
7690. much information has been gathered relative to quantitative	sampling and assesment techniques.	6.812007724078037
7691. much of the older experimental	work on respiratory infections was accomplished by very artificial	procedures.	5.497888014072812
7692. the intranasal instillation of a fluid suspension of infectious	agent in an anesthetized animal is far different from exposure	through natural respiration to aerosolized organisms.	4.730701665605607
7693. the	importance of particle size in such aerosols has been thoroughly demonstrated.	4.5796824776775376
7694. the natural anatomical and physiological defensive features	of the upper respiratory tract such as the turbinates of the nose and	the cilia of the trachea and larger bronchi are capable of impinging	out the larger particles to which we are ordinarily exposed in our daily	existence.	4.913386288340856
7695. very small particles however in a size range of 1 to	4 microns in diameter are capable of passing these impinging barriers	and entering the alveolar bed of the lungs.	3.8087151001579396
7696. this area is highly susceptible	to infection.	7.868635035332621
7697. the entrance and retention of infectious particles	in the alveoli amounts almost to an intratissue inoculation.	4.047573047182283
7698. the	relationship between particle size and infectious dose is illustrated	in table 1.	6.093123995732186
7699. in considering bw defense it must be recognized	that a number of critical meterological parameters must be met for	an aerosol to exhibit optimum effect.	4.527388718914488
7700. for example bright sunlight	is rapidly destructive for living microorganisms suspended in air.	6.904545100246854
7701. there	are optimal humidity requirements for various agents when airborne.	5.107382135220606
7702. neutral or inversion meteorological conditions are necessary for a	cloud to travel along the surface.	5.824161186330043
7703. it will rise during lapse conditions.	7.40570921770135
7704. there are of course certain times during the 24-hour daily cycle	when most of these conditions will be met.	6.442076465913757
7705. certain other properties	of small particles in addition to those already mentioned in	connection with penetration of the respiratory tract are noteworthy	in defense considerations.	4.246302666297868
7706. the smaller the particle the further it will	travel downwind before settling out.	5.3903136109608445
7707. an aerosol of such small particles.	6.289211072338518
7708. moreover diffuses through structures in much the same manner as	a gas.	8.589359955517697
7709. there may be a number of secondary effects resulting from diffusion	through buildings such as widespread contamination of kitchens	restaurants food stores hospitals etc.	5.081577909588992
7710. depending on the organism	there may be multiplication in some food or beverage products ie	in milk for example.	5.674909110162678
7711. the secondary consequences from this could	be very serious and must be taken into consideration in planning for	defense.	4.614060554648273
7712. something of the behavior of clouds of small particles	can be illustrated by the following field trials:   in the	first trial an inert substance was disseminated from a boat travelling	some ten miles off shore under appropriately selected meteorological	conditions.	5.0364367355862765
7713. zinc cadmium sulfide in particles of 2 microns in size were	disseminated.	4.535752126583474
7714. this material fluoresces under ultraviolet light which	facilitates its sampling and assessment.	6.235752476069656

7719. these dosages could have been increased	by increasing the source strength which was small in this case.	4.633305032963158
7720. the behavior of a biological aerosol on a much smaller scale is illustrated	by a specific field trial conducted with a non-pathogenic organism.	4.875034741801757

7739. a number of unique medical	problems might be created when man is exposed to an infectious	agent through the respiratory route rather than by the natural portal	of entry.	4.212959418400998
7740. some agents have been shown to be much more toxic or infectious	to experimental animals when exposed to aerosols of optimum particle	size than by the natural portal.	5.3028650435049665
7741. botulinal toxin for example is several	thousand-fold more toxic by this route than when given per os.	4.060235568763422
7742. in some instances a different clinical disease picture may result from	this route of exposure making diagnosis difficult.	6.193786614794088
7743. in tularemia produced	by aerosol exposure one would not expect to find the classical	ulcer of rabbit fever on a finger.	4.486094322886018
7744. an enemy would obviously	choose an agent that is believed to be highly infectious.	6.714977205994818
7745. agents	that are known to cause frequent infections among laboratory workers	such as those causing q fever tularemia brucellosis glanders	coccidioidomycosis etc belong in this category.	3.7976722852565925
7746. an agent	would	likely be selected which would possess sufficient viability and virulence	stability to meet realistic minimal logistic requirements.	5.644907441465999
7747. it	is obviously a proper goal of research to improve on this property.	4.854667000300735
7748. in this connection it should be capable of being disseminated without	excessive destruction.	8.341195177970292
7749. moreover it should not be so fastidious in	its growth requirements as to make production on a militarily significant	scale improbable.	4.729189346525724
7750. an aggressor would use an agent against	which there was a minimal naturally acquired or artificially induced	immunity in a target population.	5.886324603188227
7751. a solid immunity is the one effective	circumstance whereby attack by a specific agent can be neutralized.	4.322262450091603
7752. it must be remembered however that there are many agents for which	there is no solid immunity and a partial or low-grade immunity may be	broken by an appropriate dose of agent.	5.94808327909752
7753. there is a broad spectrum	of organisms from which selection for a specified military purpose	might be made.	4.710895710751804
7754. an enemy might choose an acutely debilitating microorganism	a chronic disease producer or one causing a high rate of lethality.	5.596293414950129
7755. it is possible that certain mutational forms may be produced	such as antibiotic resistant strains.	5.02494131811462
7756. mutants may also be developed	with changes in biochemical properties that are of importance in	identification.	6.142940442770809
7757. all of these considerations are of critical importance	in considering defense and medical management.	5.478986776367038
7758. biological agents	are of course highly host-specific.	7.603896187885215
7759. they do not destroy physical	structures as is true of high explosives.	6.102985810144642
7760. this may be of overriding	importance in considering military objectives.	8.986624875328587
7761. the question	of epidemic disease merits some discussion.	4.641934589711508
7762. only a limited effort has	been devoted to this problem.	7.946360307921188
7763. some of those who question the value	of bw have assumed that the only potential would be in the establishment	of epidemics.	5.542715251087509
7764. they then point out that with our present lack	of knowledge of all the factors concerned in the rise and fall	of epidemics it is unlikely that a planned episode could be initiated.	5.3827877240867
7765. they argue further that our knowledge	and resources in preventive medicine would make it possible to control	such an outbreak of disease.	4.074012177613654
7766. this is why this approach to bw	defense has not been given major attention.	7.512750557974913
7767. our major problem	is what an enemy might accomplish in an initial attack on a target.	4.662737090751071
7768. this	of course does not eliminate from consideration for this purpose	agents that are associated naturally with epidemic disease.	5.368720319504203
7769. a hypothetical	example will illustrate this point.	5.582714954590994
7770. let us assume that it would	be possible for an enemy to create an aerosol of the causative agent	of epidemic typhus over city a and	that a large number of cases of typhus fever resulted therefrom.	5.279777857438431
7771. no epidemic	was initiated nor was one expected because the population in city	a was not lousy.	4.442552725349841

7777. the major defensive problems are concerned	with the possibility of overt military delivery of biological agents from	appropriate disseminating devices.	4.277361071149232

7780. if it is possible for an enemy to put an atomic bomb on	a city it should be equally possible to put a cloud of biological agent	over that city.	6.411236430024877
7781. biological agents are moreover suitable	for delivery through enemy sabotage which imposes many problems in defense.	4.131860641767443
