7879. apart from the honeybee practically all bees and bumblebees	hibernate in a state of torpor.	5.2637717802067
7880. occasionally you may come across one	or two bumblebees in the cold season when you are turning over sods	in your garden but you have to be a really keen observer to see them	at all.	6.247841426960491
7881. they keep their wings and feet pressed tightly against their	bodies and in spite of their often colorful attire you may very well	mistake them for lumps of dirt.	4.036032401129938
7882. i must add at once that these animals	are what we call queens young females that have mated in the previous	summer or autumn.	5.430824761915665
7883. it is on them alone that the future of their	race depends for all their relatives	have perished with the arrival of the cold weather.	4.599921222882983
7884. even some of the queens will die before the winter is over falling	prey to enemies or disease.	6.838128693956658
7885. the survivors emerge on some nice sunny	day in march or april when the temperature is close to 50` f	and there is not too much wind.	4.125047835100353
7886. now the thing for us to do is to find	ourselves a couple of those wonderful flowering currants such as the	red ribes sanguineum of our pacific northwest or otherwise a	good sloe tree or perhaps some nice pussy willow in bloom preferably	one with male or staminate catkins.	5.281714202272664
7887. the blooms of ribes and of	the willow and sloe are the places where large numbers of our early insects	will assemble: honeybees bumblebees and other wild bees and	also various kinds of flies.	3.5520348436467497
7888. it is a happy buzzing crowd.	9.38154089296143
7889. each	male willow catkin is composed of a large number of small flowers.	5.406777728305719
7890. it is not difficult to see that the stamens of the catkin are always	arranged in pairs and that each individual flower is nothing but one	such pair standing on a green black-tipped little scale.	5.748323052834323
7891. by scrutinizing	the flowers one can also notice that the scale bears one or two	tiny warts.	4.423403845799093
7892. those are the nectaries or honey glands	.	8.419480063502792
7893. the staminate willow catkins then provide their visitors with	both nectar and pollen; a marvelous arrangement for it provides	exactly what the bee queens need to make their beebread a combination	of honey and pollen with which the young of all species are fed.	3.4682939222897478
7894. the	only exception to this is certain bees that have become parasites.	6.13607296909417
7895. i	will deal with these later on.	5.66037853959279
7896. quite often honeybees form a	majority on the willow catkins.	7.098773703336195
7897. as we have already seen in the first	chapter bumblebees are bigger hairier and much more colorful than honeybees	exhibiting various combinations of black yellow white and	orange.	4.595465500341729
7898. let us not try to key them out at this stage of the game and	let us just call them bombus; there must be several dozen species	in the	united states alone.	5.734447421462723
7899. if you really insist on knowing their names	an excellent book on the north american species is bumblebees and	their ways by o e plath.	4.278838228556342
7900. if we manage to keep track	of a bombus queen after she has left her feeding place we may	discover the snug little hideout which she has fixed up for herself	when she woke up from her winter sleep.	4.995903670848946
7901. as befits a queen a bumblebee	female is rather choosy and may spend considerable time searching for	a suitable nesting place.	4.124525134549778
7902. most species seem to prefer a ready-made	hollow such as a deserted mouse nest a bird house or the hole made	by a woodpecker; some show a definite liking for making their nest in	moss.	5.146577995222095
7903. once she has made up her mind the queen starts out by constructing	in her chosen abode a small floor of dried grass or some	woolly material.	3.9121403161888026
7904. on this she builds an egg compartment or egg	cell which is filled with that famous pollen-and-nectar mixture	called beebread.	6.043012859990127
7905. she also builds one or two waxen cups which she fills	with honey.	5.624194353923653
7906. then a group of eggs is deposited in a cavity in the	beebread loaf and the egg compartment is closed.	6.206915310745472
7907. the queen afterward	keeps incubating and guarding her eggs like a mother hen taking a sip	from time to time from the rather liquid honey in her honey pots.	3.6555899080909233
7908. when	the larvae hatch they feed on the beebread although they also receive	extra honey meals from their mother.	5.599140021399795
7909. she continues to add to the	pollen supply as needed.	5.862553457708852
7910. the larvae kept warm by the queen	are full grown in about ten days.	5.289832921804139
7911. each now makes a tough papery cocoon	and pupates.	5.665895349263116
7912. after another two weeks the first young emerge four	to eight small daughters that begin to play the role of worker bees	collecting pollen and nectar in the field and caring for the new young	generation while the queen retires to a life of egg laying.	5.721041408414785
7913. the first	worker bees do not mate or lay eggs; males and mating females do not	emerge until later in the season.	3.7875529292528007
7914. the broods of workers that appear	later tend to be bigger than the first ones probably because they are	better fed.	5.461167788887066
7915. by the middle of the summer many of the larvae apparently	receive such a good diet that it is optimal and it is then	that young queens begin to appear.	5.437848789725472
7916. simultaneously males or drones are	produced mostly from the unfertilized eggs of workers although a	few may be produced by the queen.	5.1874962597884675
7917. the young queens and drones leave the	nest and mate and after a short period of freedom the fertilized	young	queens will begin to dig in for the winter.	3.775076681395285
7918. it is an amazing fact that	in some species this will happen while the summer is still in full	swing for instance in august.	5.756784989929781
7919. the temperature then is still very	high.	5.057856772203119
7920. at the old nest the queen will in the early fall cease to lay	the fertilized eggs that will produce females.	6.164936605962905
7921. as a result the proportion	of males increases and eventually the old	colony will die out completely.	5.073148692484897
7922. the nest itself the structure that	in some cases housed about 2000 individuals when the season was at its	peak is now rapidly destroyed by the scavenging larvae of certain	beetles and moths.	4.625409175914988
7923. not always though does the development of	a bumblebee colony take place in the smooth fashion we have just described.	5.075483388636414
7924. some members of the bee family have become idlers social parasites	that live at the expense of their hardworking relatives.	6.823268238721179
7925. bumblebees	can thus suffer severely from the onslaughts of psithyrus the	cuckoo-bumblebee as it is called in some european countries.	4.400000046402277
7926. female individuals of psithyrus look deceptively like the workers	and queens of the bumblebees they victimize.	5.550554466109728
7927. the one sure way to tell	victim and villain apart is to examine the hind legs which in the	case of the idler psithyrus lack the pollen baskets- naturally!	the female parasite spends much time in her efforts to find a nest	of her host.	3.6779228883958126
7928. when she succeeds she usually manages to slip in unobtrusively	to deposit an egg on a completed loaf of beebread before the	bumblebees seal the egg compartment.	5.373624434626581
7929. the hosts never seem to recognize	that something is amiss so that the compartment afterward is sealed	normally.	4.232417194317309
7930. thus the larvae of the intruder can develop at the expense	of the rightful inhabitants and the store of beebread.	6.077300499815015
7931. later on they	and the mother psithyrus are fed by the bombus workers.	5.097702819157361
7932. worse still in a number of cases it has been claimed that the psithyrus	female kills off the bombus queen.	6.417250040564039
7933. but let us return	after this gruesome interlude to our willow catkins in the spring;	there are other wild bees that command our attention.	4.024699092531897
7934. it	is almost certain that some of these usually a trifle smaller than the	honeybees are andrenas or mining bees.	6.54339060674585
7935. there are about 200 different	kinds of andrena in europe alone.	5.531535184963606
7936. one of my favorites is a	armata a species very common in england where it is sometimes	referred to as the lawn bee.	6.549779983650396
7937. the females like to burrow in the short	turf of well-kept lawns where their little mounds of earth often appear	by the hundreds.	3.5754695776410808
7938. almost equal in size to a honeybee.	8.225583361287285
7939. a armata	is much more beautiful in color at least in the female of the species:	a rich velvety rusty red.	4.174666273462686
7940. the males are much duller.	6.916419102612548
7941. after having mated an andrena female digs a hole straight down	into the ground forming a burrow about the size of a lead pencil.	4.4562415284148305
7942. the bottom part of a burrow has a number of side tunnels or cells	each of which is provided with an egg plus a store of beebread.	6.000513577189058
7943. the	development of the andrena larvae is very rapid so that by the	end of spring they have already pupated and become adults.	3.876351786477489
7944. but they	are still enclosed in their larval cells and remain there throughout	the summer fall and winter.	5.716111592903478
7945. their appearance next spring coincides	in an almost uncanny way with the flowering of their host plants.	4.406691061974044
7946. in the sacramento valley in california for instance it has been observed	that there was not one day's difference between the emergence	of the andrenas and the opening of the willow catkins.	5.9017477601058115
7947. this must be	due to a completely identical response to the weather in the plant and	the animal.	4.747814520553368
7948. after the male and female andrenas have mated	the cycle is repeated.	7.122997276302844
7949. although andrena is gregarious so that we	may find hundreds and hundreds of burrows together we must still call	it a solitary bee.	4.076878331542105
7950. its life history is much simpler than that of the	truly colonial bumblebees and can serve as an example of the life	cycle of many other species.	6.6188093102249175
7951. after all social life in the group of	the bees is by no means general although it certainly is a striking	feature.	5.389607658642227
7952. on the basis of its life history we like to think that andrena	is more primitive than the bumblebees.	6.881480480606168
7953. the way in which it transports	its pollen is not so perfect either.	6.055867381464014
7954. it lacks pollen baskets	and possesses only a large number of long branched hairs on its legs	on which the pollen grains will collect.	5.807734597337795
7955. still andrena will	do a reasonably good job so that an animal with a full pollen load looks	like a gay little piece of yellow down floating in the wind.	4.05943021019976
7956. closely related to the andrenas are the nomias or alkali bees.	6.888555761659698
7957. nomia	melanderi can be found in tremendous numbers in certain parts of	the united states west of the great plains for example in utah	and central washington.	5.122887970364154
7958. in the united states department of agriculture's	yearbook of agriculture 1952 which is devoted entirely	to insects george e bohart mentions a site in utah which	was estimated to contain 200000 nesting females.	5.4280740019093185
7959. often the burrows	are only an inch or two apart and the bee cities cover several acres.	4.46950923222447
7960. the life history of the alkali bee is similar to that of andrena	but the first activity of the adults does not take place until summer	and the individuals hibernate in the prepupal stage.	5.186573299515237
7961. in most places	there are two generations a year a second brood of adults appearing	late in the summer.	4.358298174411469
7962. i must plead guilty to a special sympathy	for nomias.	7.538481764483632
7963. this may just be pride in my adopted state of washington	but certainly i love to visit their mound cities near yakima and	prosser in july or august when the bees are in their most active	period.	3.7031607831739852
7964. the name alkali bee indicates that one has to look for	them in rather inhospitable places.	5.7896019259703175
7965. sometimes although by no means	always these are indeed alkaline.	5.449556966879603
7966. the thing is that these bees love	a fine-grained soil that is moist; yet the water in the ground should	not be stagnant either.	5.280004180189393
7967. where does	one find such conditions?	7.423081379936514
7968.  the best chance of course is offered by	gently sloping terrain where the water remains close to the surface and	where the air is dry so that a high evaporation leaves salty deposits	which permit only sparse plant growth.	5.511764188853852
7969. many other snakes at maturity are already more	than half their final length.	5.0128905873554634
7970. laurence m klauber put length at maturity	at two thirds the ultimate length for some rattlesnakes and charles	c carpenter's data on michigan garter and ribbon snakes	show that the smallest gravid females are more than	half as long as the biggest adults.	4.955411624172483
7971. felix kopstein states that when	the snake reaches its maturity it has already reached about its maximal	length but goes on to cite the reticulate python as an exception	with maximum length approximately three times that at maturity.	3.5434088196138775
7972. it is hard to understand how he concluded that most snakes do not grow	appreciably after attaining maturity; he was working with species	of java so perhaps some tropical snakes are unusual in this respect.	5.375536874283829
7973. certain individual giants recorded later did fail to show a reasonable	difference after maturity but it is impossible to know whether this	is due to captive conditions.	4.304979450920648
7974. additional records of slow growth have	been omitted.	7.594335062792461
7975. it is possible to make a few generalizations about	the six giants themselves.	6.333000460807043
7976. there seems to be a rough correlation	between the initial and ultimate lengths starting with the smallest	and ending with the largest.	7.190964890665672
7977. data on the	former are scanty but there can be little doubt that the latter is sometimes	born at a length greater than that of any of the others thereby	lending support to the belief that the anaconda does indeed attain	the greatest length.	4.569977667500817
7978. for four of the six	there is also a correlation	between size at maturity and maximum length the boa constrictor	being the smallest and the indian python the next in size at the	former stage.	5.256198002143801
7979. let us speculate a little on the maximum size	of the anaconda.	5.883370199357393
7980. if in a certain part of the range it starts life 1	foot longer than do any of the other giants and reaches	maturity at let us guess 18 inches longer than the others a	quadrupling of the maturity length would result in a maximum of	40 feet.	5.980414301721512
7981. when it comes to rate of early growth the indian	python leads with a figure of about 3 feet 6 inches per year for the	first two years more or less.	4.156302753949498
7982. the african rock python a close second	is followed in turn by the reticulate python.	5.201876437247893
7983. there are few data	on the boa constrictor those for the anaconda are unconvincing and	there is nothing at all on the amethystine python.	4.453100544531684
7984. it seems likely that	the indian python comes out ahead because records of its growth have	been made more carefully and frequently; it responds exceptionally	well to captivity and does not reach proportions that make it hard to	keep.	5.193856263869798
7985. i cannot make sense out of the figures for post maturity	growth; at best the annual increase appears to be a matter of inches	rather than feet.	5.427482812088249
7986. until better records have been kept over longer	periods of time and much more is known about the maximum dimensions	it will be wise to refrain from drawing conclusions.	5.453069069733021
7987. it is often	stated	that the largest snakes require five years to attain maturity but	this apparently is an overestimation.	4.3299456649741925
7988. the best way to determine the	correct figure is by direct observation of pairs isolated	from birth a method that produced surprising results: maturing of	a male indian python in less than two years his mate in less than three;	data on the boa constrictor about match this.	4.98637094485019
7989. another approach	is to estimate from the rate of growth and the smallest size at	maturity.	4.9280506607195775
7990. results from this approach amply confirm the direct observations:	about three years are required there being a possible slight	difference between males and females in the time required.	4.981436963190621
7991. only the	amethystine python and the anaconda must be excluded for lack or paucity	of data.	4.6476765555391015
7992. the following information on snakes varying greatly	in size shows when considered	with the foregoing that there is probably no correlation between	the length of a snake and the time required for it to mature.	5.154043912516527
7993. oliver	in his summary of the habits of the snakes of the united states	could supply data on the maturing period for only three species in addition	to the rattlers which i shall consider separately.	4.092006731155346
7994. these three	were much alike: lined snake one year and	nine months; red-bellied snake two years; cottonmouth	two years.	5.685332476552206
7995. klauber investigated the rattlesnakes	carefully himself and also summarized what others have found.	4.411891185517149
7996. he	concluded that in the southern species which are rapidly growing types	females mate at the age of two and a half and bear the first young	when they are three.	6.1091254470650025
7997. other herpetologists have ascertained that in	the northern united states the prairie rattlesnake may not give first	birth until it is four or even five years old and that the young may	be born every other year rather than annually.	3.949282242195145
7998. carpenter's study	showed that female common garter and ribbon snakes of michigan mature	at about the age of two.	5.926406216047044
7999. oversized monsters are	never brought home either alive or preserved and field measurements	are obviously open to doubt because of the universal tendency to exaggerate	dimensions.	4.087288139519799
8000. measurements of skins are of little value; every	snake hide is noticeably longer than its carcass and intentional stretching	presents no difficulty to the unscrupulous explorer.	5.025020029471358
8001. in	spite of all the pitfalls there is a certain amount of agreement on	some of the giants.	5.158212579626619
8002. the anaconda proves to be the fly in the ointment	but the reason for this is not clear; the relatively wild conditions	still found in tropical south america might be responsible.	5.821810828360531
8003. there are three levels on which to treat the subject.	6.200454921942639
8004. the first is	the strictly scientific which demands concrete proof and therefore may	err on the conservative side by waiting for evidence in the flesh.	5.257777717385663
8005. this	approach rejects virtually all field measurements.	5.66037853959279
8006. the next level	attempts to weigh varied evidence and come to a balanced sensible conclusion;	field measurements by experienced explorers are not rejected	and even reports of a less scientific nature are duly evaluated.	5.045717440048942
8007. the third level leans on a belief that a lot of smoke means some fire.	4.777959108919227
8008. the argument against this last approach is comparable to that which	rejects stories about hoop snakes about snakes that break themselves	into many pieces and join up again or even of ghosts that chase people	out of graveyards; the mere piling up of testimony does not prove	to the scientific mind the existence of hoop snakes joint snakes	or ghosts.	4.536244462674305
8009. oliver has recently used the second-level approach	with the largest snakes and has come to these conclusions: the anaconda	reaches a length of at least 37 feet the reticulate python 33	the african rock python 25 the amethystine python at least 22 the indian	python 20 and the boa constrictor 18-12.	3.458686139277494
8010. bernard heuvelmans	also treats of the largest snakes but on the third level and	is chiefly concerned with the anaconda.	6.696269159364874
8011. he reasons that as anacondas	30 feet long are often found some might be 38 and occasional monstrous	freaks over 50.	4.062570897459965
8012. he rejects dimensions of 70 feet and more.	7.08339902922487
8013. his thirteenth chapter includes many exciting accounts of huge serpents	with prodigious strength but these seem to be given to complete his	picture not to be believed.	4.729236476102189
8014. detailed information on record	lengths of the giants is given in the section that follows.	6.216816962892334
8015. of the six giants	discussions of the giants one by one will include	as far as possible data on these aspects of growth: size at which	life is started and at which sexual maturity is reached; time required	to reach maturity; rate of growth both before and after this crucial	stage; and maximum length with confirmation or amplification	of oliver's figures.	3.5315620348187196
8016. definite information on the growth of senile	individuals is lacking.	7.368640540112057
8017. at birth this species varies	considerably in size.	6.253555021987419
8018. a brood of twenty-eight born at brookfield	zoo near chicago ranged in length from 22 to 33-12 inches and averaged	29 inches.	5.130892137311206
8019. lawrence e griffin gives measurements of nineteen	young anacondas presumably members of a brood from south america;	the extreme measurements of these fall between the lower limit	of the brookfield brood and its average.	3.6799954472096905
8020. raymond l ditmars	had	two broods that averaged 27 inches.	6.871310905805299
8021. r r mole and f w	urich give approximately 20 inches as the average length of a brood	of thirty from the region of the orinoco estuaries.	3.786293054710708
8022. william beebe	reports 26 inches and 2.	8.797427849966851
8023. 4 ounces	for the length and the weight of a young anaconda from british guiana.	5.136365463356661
8024. in contrast ditmars recorded the average length of seventy-two	young of a 19-foot female as 38 inches and four young were born in london	at a length of 35 or 36 inches and a weight of from 14 to 16 ounces.	4.8606829902517426
8025. beebe had a 3-foot anaconda that weighed only 9.	4.888267284578986
8026. a difference	between subspecies might explain the great range in size.	6.2272542153453445
8027. i have little information on the anaconda's rate of growth.	5.554654442659949
8028. hans	schweizer had one that increased from 19-12 inches to 5 feet 3 inches	in five years and j j quelch records a growth of from less	than 4 feet to nearly 10 in about six years.	4.77269164379042
8029. it is very unlikely that	either of these anacondas was growing at a normal rate.	4.778971191982454
8030. in 1948	afranio do amaral the noted brazilian herpetologist wrote a	technical paper on the giant snakes.	5.749063957568586
8031. he concluded that the anaconda's	maximum length is 12 or 13 meters which would approximate	from 39 to 42 feet.	4.0259827113566224
8032. thus	his estimate lies between oliver's suggestion of at least 37 feet	and the 50-foot monstrous freaks intimated by heuvelmans.	5.68406502361092
8033. the most convincing recent measurement of an anaconda was made in	eastern colombia by roberto lamon a petroleum geologist of the richmond	oil company and reported in 1944 by emmett r dunn.	3.6015486617497627
8034. however	as a field measurement it is open to question.	6.7967143480171766
8035. oliver's 37-12	feet is partly based on this report and can be accepted as probable.	4.616902939296685
8036. however many herpetologists remain skeptical and would prefer	a tentative maximum of about 30 feet.	6.156708853337442
8037. it is possible that especially	large anacondas will prove to belong to subspecies limited to	a small area.	4.9933461900187215
8038. in snakes difference in size is a common characteristic	of subspecies.	6.810760190647317
8039. a colombian female's brood	of sixteen boa constrictors born in the staten island zoo averaged	20 inches.	4.510907327550696
8040. this birth length seems to be typical.	9.105883425071719
8041. when some thirteen	records of newly and recently born individuals are collated little	or no correlation between length and distribution can be detected.	4.028949025177298
8042. the	range is from 14 to 25 inches; the former figure is based on a somewhat	unusual birth of four by a central american female	the latter on a normal	newly born individual.	5.242432822159938
8043. however as so many of the records are	not certainly based on newborn snakes these data must be taken tentatively;	final conclusions will have to await the measurements of broods	from definite localities.	4.794900131007287
8044. alphonse r hoge's measurements	of several very young specimens from brazil suggest that at birth the	female is slightly larger than the male.	5.189188081913731
8045. i have surprisingly little	information on the size and age at maturity.	5.78378802300703
8046. carl kauffeld has	written to me of sexual activity in february 1943 of young born in march	1940.	5.454336586728915
8047. one female collected on an island off the coast of nicaragua	was gravid and measured 4 feet 8 inches from snout to vent	.	3.9636849426372627
8048. the female from central	america which gave birth to four was only 3 feet 11 inches long.	5.2160527574722
8049. what data there are on growth indicate considerable variation	in rate; unfortunately no one has kept complete records of one individual	whereas many have been made for a very short period of time.	3.973060173778179
8050. the results are too varied to allow generalization.	6.269735228050855
8051. the bronchus and pulmonary artery in this lung type maintain a close	relationship throughout.	3.93777821379478
8052. the pulmonary vein however without the limiting	supportive tissue septa as in type 1 follows a more direct	path	to the hilum and does not maintain this close relationship	.	4.899826976576284
8053. another marked difference is noted here.	6.2808977011565155
8054. the pulmonary artery	in addition to supplying the distal portion of the respiratory bronchiole	the alveolar duct and the alveoli continues on and directly supplies	the thin pleura.	5.048884329962631
8055. the bronchial artery except for a	small number of short branches in the hilum contributes none of the	pleural blood supply.	3.6398110151839265
8056. it does as in type 1 supply the hilar lymph	nodes the pulmonary artery the pulmonary vein the bronchi and the	bronchioles- terminating in a common capillary bed with the pulmonary	artery at the level of the respiratory bronchiole.	5.423929410220658
8057. no bronchial artery-pulmonary	artery anastomoses were noted in this group.	5.398430130358392
8058. lung	type 3 is to some degree a composite of types 1	and 2.	6.426288423503717
8059. it is characterized by the presence of incompletely developed	secondary lobules; well defined but haphazardly arranged interlobular	septa and a thick remarkably vascular pleura.	4.233044353903801
8060. the	most distal airways are similar to those found in type 1 being	composed of numerous apparently true terminal bronchioles and occasional	poorly developed respiratory bronchioles.	5.12581433512635
8061. in this	instance because of incomplete septation the secondary lobule does	not constitute in itself what appears to be a small individual lung	as in type 1.	4.578495628228417
8062. air-drifts from one area to another are therefore	conceivable.	6.806723317680827
8063. distally the bronchus is situated between a pulmonary artery	on one side and a pulmonary vein on the other as in type 1	.	4.27392098830005
8064. this relationship however is not maintained centrally.	7.7829086337725455
8065. here the pulmonary vein as in type 2 is noted to draw away from	the bronchus and to follow a more direct independent course to the	hilum.	4.027823189779386
8066. the bronchial artery in its course and distribution	differs somewhat from that found in other mammals.	5.124518734431128
8067. as seen in	types 1 and 2 it supplies the hilar lymph nodes vasa vasorum	to the pulmonary artery and vein the bronchi and the terminal bronchioles.	3.838030088052129
8068. as in type 1 it provides arterial blood to the interlobular	septa and an extremely rich anastomotic pleural supply is seen	.	5.883076846300642
8069. this pleural supply is derived both from hilar and interlobular	bronchial artery branches.	4.508640324326541
8070. such a dual derivation was strikingly	demonstrated during the injection process where initial filling	would be noted to occur in several isolated pleural vessels at once.	5.398170341682986
8071. some	of these were obviously filling from interlobular branches of the	bronchial arteries while others were filling from direct hilar branches	following along the pleural surface.	3.8225928423997066
8072. with completion of filling net-like	anastomoses were noted to be present between these separately	derived branches.	6.332724300488806
8073. an unusual increase in the number of bronchial arteries	present within the substance of the lung was noted.	5.311977189252624
8074. this was accounted	for primarily by the presence of a bronchial artery closely following	the pulmonary artery.	6.969257908783622
8075. the diameter of this bronchial artery was	much too large for it to be a mere vasa vasorum.	4.643607578048647
8076. in distal regions its diameter would be one-fourth to one-fifth that	of the pulmonary artery.	5.873314012191854
8077. this vessel could be followed to the parenchyma	where it directly provided bronchial arterial blood to the alveolar	capillary bed.	4.170680475539628
8078. also three other direct pathways	of alveolar bronchial arterial supply were noted: via the pleura;	through the interlobular septa; and along the terminal bronchiole	.	5.549313822137067
8079. one bronchial arteriolar-pulmonary arteriolar	anastomosis was noted at the terminal bronchiolar level.	4.968782988500926
8080. it is evident that many marked and striking differences	exist between lungs when an inter-species comparison is made.	5.896889278803231
8081. the	significance of these differences has not been studied nor has the existence	of corresponding physiologic differences been determined.	4.444943206438216
8082. however	the dynamics of airflow from morphologic considerations alone	may conceivably be different in the monkey than in the horse.	5.950264281099699
8083. the volume	and perhaps even the characteristics of bronchial arterial blood	flow might be different in the dog than in the horse.	4.058346358229448
8084. also interlobular	air drifts may be all but nonexistent in the cow; probably occur	in the horse much as in the human being; and in contrast are present	to a relatively immense degree on a segmental basis in the dog where	lobules are absent.	5.096549414749884
8085. a reason	for such wide variation in the pulmonary morphology is entirely lacking	at present.	4.2705665792608904
8086. within certain wide limits anatomy dictates function	and if one is permitted to speculate potential pathology should	be included in this statement as well.	5.733961775657424
8087. for example the marked susceptibility	of the monkey to respiratory infection might be related to its	delicate long alveolar ducts and short large bronchioles situated	within a parenchyma entirely lacking in protective supportive tissue	barriers such as those found in types 1 and 3.	3.7286306995461422
8088. one might also	wonder if monkeys are capable of developing bronchiolitis as we know	it in man or the horse.	6.201200584111125
8089. in addition it would be difficult to imagine	chronic generalized emphysema occurring in a cow considering its marked	lobular development but conversely not difficult to imagine this	occurring in the horse or the dog.	4.360914975849539
8090. anatomically the horse lung	appears to be remarkably like that of man insofar as this can be ascertained	from comparison of our findings in the horse with those of	others in the human being.	5.273022128427911
8091. the only area in which	one might find major disagreement in this matter is in regard to the alveolar	distribution of the bronchial arteries.	4.800328869712734
8092. as early as 1858 le	fort claimed an alveolar distribution of the bronchial arteries in human	beings.	6.710349824574992
8093. in 1951 this was reaffirmed by cudkowicz.	5.783339828072867
8094. the opposition	to this point of view has its staunchest support in the work of miller	.	7.027480915468255
8095. apparently however miller has relied heavily on the	anatomy in dogs and cats and he has been criticized for using pathologic	human material in his normal study.	4.248202766621436
8096. although miller	noted in 1907 that a difference in the pleural blood supply existed	between animals nowhere in his published works is it found that he	did a comparative study of the intrapulmonary features of various mammalian	lungs other than in the dog and cat.	5.456767455024118
8097. the meaning of this variation in distribution of the bronchial	artery as found in the horse is not clear.	5.017661657255528
8098. however this artery is known	to be a nutrient vessel with a distribution primarily to the proximal	airways and supportive tissues of the lung.	5.6533866000352075
8099. the alveoli and respiratory	bronchioles are primarily diffusing tissues.	4.465110340486763
8100. theoretically they	are capable of extracting their required oxygen either from the surrounding	air or from pulmonary arterial	blood.	5.454336586728915
8101. therefore an explanation of this alveolar	bronchial artery supply might be the nutritive requirement of an increased	amount of supportive tissue not primarily diffusing in nature	in the region of the alveolus.	3.862964342966114
8102. if this be true the possibility exists	that an occlusive lesion of the bronchial arteries might cause widespread	degeneration of supportive tissue similar to that seen in generalized	emphysema.	5.419913629665037
8103. one would not expect such an event to occur in animals	possessing lungs of types 1 or 2.	4.2644076163558715
8104. the presence of normally	occurring bronchial artery-pulmonary artery anastomoses was first	noted in 1721 by ruysch and thereafter by many others.	5.26917449293315
8105. nakamura	verloop von	hayek have all claimed their normal but	relatively nonfunctional existence in the human being.	4.479108556611168
8106. miller	is the principal antagonist of this viewpoint.	7.1581511048922275
8107. in criticism of the latter's	views his conclusions were based upon dog lung injection studies	in which all of the vascular channels were first filled with a solution	under pressure and then were injected with various sized colored	particles designed to stop at the arteriolar level.	3.6717662387906236
8108. as early as 1913	ghoreyeb and karsner demonstrated with perfusion studies in dogs	that bronchial artery flow would remain constant at a certain low level	when pressure was maintained in the pulmonary artery and vein but that	increases in bronchial artery flow would occur in response to a relative	drop in pulmonary artery pressure.	4.86514629517822
8109. berry brailsford and daly	in 1931 and nakamura in 1958 reaffirmed this.	4.535752126583474
8110. our own studies in which	bronchial artery-pulmonary artery anastomoses were demonstrated	were accomplished by injecting the bronchial artery first with no pressure	on the pulmonary artery or vein and then by injecting the pulmonary	artery and vein afterwards.	4.847815278206955
8111. it is distinctly possible therefore	that simultaneous pressures in all three vessels would have rendered	the shunts inoperable and hence uninjectable.	4.092657374942762
8112. this viewpoint is further	supported by verloop's demonstration of thickened bronchial	artery and arteriolar muscular coats which are capable of acting	as valves.	5.379282932642032
8113. in other words the anastomoses between the bronchial artery	and pulmonary artery should be considered as functional or demand	shunts.	4.593433665880127
8114. in addition little work has been done on a comparative	basis in regard to the normal existence of bronchial artery-pulmonary	artery anastomoses.	7.031900616966709
8115. verloop found these shunts	in the human being but was unable to find them in rats.	4.548690463699263
8116. ellis grindlay	and edwards also were unable to find them in rats.	6.093123995732186
8117. nakamura	was unable to demonstrate their existence either by anatomic	or physiologic methods in dogs.	4.343393044170812
8118. the possibility that the absence	or presence of these shunts is species-dependent is therefore inferred.	5.716552357398849
8119. certainly the mere fact of failing to demonstrate them in one	or another species does not conclusively deny their existence in that	species.	4.041277629021142
8120. it is however highly suggestive and agrees well with our own	findings in which we also failed to demonstrate normally occurring	bronchial artery-pulmonary artery shunts in certain species especially	the dog.	5.2913324568812445
8121. in conclusion these findings suggest the need for	a comparative physiology pathology and histology of mammalian lungs.	4.198063122201366
8122. in addition a detailed interspecies survey of the incidence of generalized	pulmonary emphysema in mammals would be interesting and pertinent.	6.016103925737747
8123. also for the present great caution should be exercised in the	choice of an experimental animal for pulmonary studies if they are to	be applied to man.	4.313411657883509
8124. this is especially so if the dog cat or monkey are	to be used in view of their marked anatomical differences from man.	6.597775340686662
8125. finally it is suggested that in many respects the horse lung may be	anatomically more comparable to that of the human than any other presently	known species.	5.3195380470131415
8126. the main subgross anatomical features	of the lungs of various mammals are presented.	5.812800448054867
8127. a tabulation of these	features permits the lungs to be grouped into three distinctive subgross	types.	4.1807151652587695
8128. type 1 is represented by the cow sheep and pig;	type 2 by the dog cat and monkey; type 3 by the horse.	5.3564833323418855
8129. lobularity is extremely well developed in type 1; absent in type	2; imperfectly developed in type 3.	4.060235568763422
8130. the pleura and interlobular	septa are thick in types 1 and 3.	5.506908456901043
8131. the pleura is extremely	thin in type 2 and septa are absent.	4.099370333146802
8132. arterial supply to the pleura	in types 1 and 3 is provided by the bronchial artery and	in type 2 by the pulmonary artery.	5.162566083429658
8133. in types 1 2 and 3	the bronchial artery terminates in a capillary bed shared in common	with the pulmonary artery at the level of the distal bronchiole.	4.080922224003057
8134. in	type 3 the bronchial artery also provides blood directly to the	alveolar capillary bed.	5.7836982265615156
8135. true terminal bronchioles comprise the most frequent	form taken by the distal airways in types 1 and 3 although	small numbers of poorly developed respiratory bronchioles are present.	3.903053570380299
8136. well developed respiratory bronchioles on the other hand appear	to be the only form taken by the distal airways in type 2.	6.57900651875463
8137. in	type 1 the pulmonary vein closely follows the course of the bronchus	and the pulmonary artery from the periphery to the hilum.	4.336984396955402
8138. this maybe	due to the heavy interlobular connective tissue barriers present.	6.6594593691211506
8139. in	type 3 this general relationship is maintained peripherally but	not centrally where the pulmonary vein follows a more independent path	to the hilum as is the case throughout the lung in type 2.	3.6395690672968875
8140. some of the features of the top portions of figure 1 and figure	2 were mentioned in discussing table 1.	6.7206543598807835
8141. first the onset profile	spreads across approximately 12 years for boys and 10 years for girls.	4.751429395043408
8142. in contrast 20 of the 21 lines in the completion profile	are bunched and extend over a	much shorter period approximately 30 months for boys and 40 months for	girls.	5.012747054373685
8143. the maturity chart for each sex demonstrates clearly that	onset is a phenomenon of infancy and early childhood whereas completion	is a phenomenon of the later portion of adolescence.	3.496190402669647
8144. second for	both sexes the 21 transverse lines in the onset profile vary more	in individual spread than those in the completion profile.	5.739114395429178
8145. although	the standard deviation values on which spread of the lines are based	are relatively larger for those centers which begin to ossify early	there are considerable differences in this value between	centers having the closely timed onsets.	3.747718989248961
8146. third the process of calcification	is seen to begin later and to continue much longer for these	boys than for the girls a fact which confirms data for other groups of	children.	5.611673018686978
8147. the onset profile and completion profile are constructed	to serve as norms for children.	3.93777821379478
8148. it is convenient to classify	a child's onset ages and completion ages as advanced moderate	or delayed according to whether the child's	age equivalent dots appeared to the left of upon or	to the right of the appropriate short transverse line.	5.260322401208518
8149. when a dot	appears close to the end of the transverse line the moderate	rating may be further classified according to the position of the dot	with respect to the vertical marking denoting the mean age.	4.931255777386706
8150. such classifications	may be called somewhat advanced or somewhat delayed	as the case may be reserving moderate for dots upon or close	to the mean.	5.5301990775752365
8151. in the lower portion of each chart the skeletal	age of boy 34 and girl 2 may be similarly classified.	4.2619839153054295
8152. there the middle one of the three curves denotes mean skeletal age	for the maturity series boys and girls.	7.3283824067448355
8153. the upper curve denotes	the mean plus one standard deviation and the lower curve represents	the mean minus one standard deviation.	3.7098848353901546
8154. thus a child's skeletal	age dots may be classified as advanced when they appear above	the middle curve moderate when they appear immediately above	or below the middle curve and delayed when they appear below	the lower curve.	5.009104245133069
8155. to summarize the purpose of the skeletal maturity	chart: each contains two kinds of skeletal maturity norms which	show two quite different methods of depicting developmental level	of growth centers.	4.063800213092056
8156. first the upper portion requires series of films	for every child consisting of those from hand elbow shoulder knee	and foot.	5.81287429621968
8157. the lower portion necessitates only films of hand.	4.638798138420154
8158. second the upper portion permits comparison of maturity levels of an	equal number of growth centers from the long short and round bones	of the five regions.	5.218469079373505
8159. the lower portion permits comparison of maturity	levels of short and round bones predominantly since only two long bones	are included in hand and wrist as a region.	3.563540707545236
8160. third the upper portion	deals with only two indicators of developmental level onset and	completion.	6.332272047539903
8161. the lower portion utilizes the full complement of intermediate	maturity indicators of each hand center as well as their onset	and completion.	4.205002805774687
8162. fourth the two indicators are for the most part	widely separated chronologically with the extensive age gap occurring	during childhood for all but one growth center.	5.372523855724029
8163. the lower portion provides	a rating at any stage between infancy and adulthood.	4.129223139860112
8164. onsets	completions and skeletal ages of boy 34 and girl 2	may be directly compared and classified using only those skeletal ages	which appear immediately below the onset profile and the completion	profile.	4.785185163797336
8165. it may be assumed that differences in ratings due to selection	of growth centers from specific regions of the body will be small	according to existing tables of onset age and completion age for	centers throughout the body.	3.9516263249448436
8166. accordingly maturity level ratings by	means of the upper portion and lower portion of the chart respectively	should be somewhat similar since skeletal age assessments are dependent	upon onsets during infancy and upon completions during adolescence.	5.301632453772893
8167. it is clear that there are some differences in the ratings but	there is substantial agreement.	5.830308148027501
8168. since a skeletal age rating can	be made at any age during growth from elbow shoulder knee or foot	as well as hand it seems to be the method of choice when one wishes	to study most aspects of skeletal developmental progress during childhood.	5.469973006108593
8169. as stated earlier in the paper onsets and completions-	particularly the former- provide a different tool or indicator of expectancy	in osseous development each within a limited age period.	3.8246625472664957
8170. such	an indicator or indicators are needed as means of recognizing specific	periods of delay in skeletal developmental progress.	5.368720319504203
8171. it	was stated earlier that one purpose of this study was to extend the analysis	of variability of onset and completion in each of the 21 growth	centers somewhat beyond that provided by the data in tables 1 and	2.	3.9107851364682946
8172. as one approach to doing this figures 3 and 4 have been constructed	from the mean ages and the individual onset and completion ages for	boy 34 and girl 2.	5.099270129983066
8173. the differences between onset age and completion age	with respect to the corresponding mean age have been brought into juxtaposition	by means of a series of arrows.	3.84183726326958
8174. the data for boy 34 appear	in figure 3 and for girl 2 in figure 4.	5.124468832995878
8175. the numbering system used	in tables 1 and 2 and figures 1 and 2 was continued for the 21 growth	centers.	3.6398110151839265
8176. the dot on one end of each arrow indicates	extent of difference in months between the child's onset age and the	corresponding mean age for the growth center.	4.875246385008431
8177. the tip of the	arrow represents extent of difference between the child's completion	age and the corresponding mean age for the growth center.	3.932392994678624
8178. thus the	alignment of the dots and tips respectively indicate individual	variability of the 21 growth centers of each child with respect	to the mean values for these boys and girls.	5.106931317408671
8179. the direction in which	the arrow points shows how the maturity level of the growth center was	changed at completion from the level at onset.	3.721145399537687
8180. when the dot	and tip coincide the classification used in this paper is same	schedule.	6.515032901707807
8181. the length of the arrow indicates amount of slowing or	acceleration at completion over that at onset and the difference	in months can be read roughly by referring the arrow to the age scale	along the base of each figure or more precisely by referring to the	original data in the appropriate tables.	3.4865187914599263
8182. the difference between	the sequence of onset of ossification for the sexes governs the numbering	sequence in figures 3 and 4.	5.134628608309722
8183. this difference is readily clarified	by referring to table 1.	5.114100767216323
8184. for example arrow 17 in figure 3 portrays	the proximal radial epiphysis for boy 34 whereas the same epiphysis	for girl 2 is portrayed by arrow 18 in figure 4.	5.197462691738133
8185. for the boy	this epiphysis was markedly delayed at onset but near the mean at completion.	4.666833584152916
8186. thus the span of its ossification was shortened and the center's	ability to catch up in ossification is demonstrated.	5.90608818218209
8187. in	contrast for the girl the epiphysis was slightly advanced at onset	and delayed at completion.	4.21292691591616
8188. obviously the slowing for her may have	occurred at any point between onset and completion.	6.224060048845365
8189. the skeletal	age curve in the lower portion of figure 2 shows that slowing may have	occurred for her during the prepubescent period.	3.715806407134142
8190. length of the shaft	of these arrows may be evaluated according to the standard deviation	values for each center in table 1.	6.202267965431782
8191. we have attempted to simplify	the extensive task of analyzing onset ages and completion ages of	each child- more than 1700 values for the entire group- by constructing	figures for each of the 21 centers so that the data for all 34	boys and 34 of the girls will appear together for each growth center.	3.81292743808928
8192. figures 5 and 6 are examples of our method of analyzing the results for	each growth center.	5.597211921163548
8193. forty other figures similar to 5 and 6 and the	original data used in the construction of all figures and tables in this	monograph have been included in the appendix.	4.18595084726166
8194. the principles	used in making each arrow for figures 3 and 4 were applied to the	construction of figures 5 and 6 as well as all figures in the appendix.	5.198993279567991
8195. one growth center in a short bone- distal phalanx of the second	finger- was chosen as an example for discussion here primarily because	epiphyseal-diaphyseal fusion the maturity indicator for completion	in long and short bones occurs in this center for girls near the	menarche and for boys near their comparable pubescent stage.	3.5697789874782706
8196. its completion	thus becomes one of the convenient maturity indicators to include	in studies of growth dietary patterns and health during adolescence.	6.14600209262349
8197. the following summary based on figures 5 and 6 is an	example of one way of interpreting the 42 figures constructed from onset	ages and completion ages of individual children with respect to the	appropriate mean age for each growth center.	3.5340487835317806

8206. accordingly girls 31 29 33 21 26 13 3 4	14 32 24 25 34 23 6 15 22 and 16 may be said to have the same	schedule at onset and completion.	5.691349396803217

8209. as an example of the interpretation	of an arrow in the figure which exceeds four months in shaft	length in conjunction with its position in the figure: girl 2 had	a delayed onset and further delayed completion.	4.373361278284804

8215. after the 42 figures	had been drawn like figures 5 and 6 classifications of the onset	ages and completion ages were summarized from them.	4.115145666435148
8216. interestingly enough the effect of the digitalis glycosides is inhibited	by a high concentration of potassium in the incubation medium and	b.	5.801012276309364
8217. organification	the precise mechanism for organification of iodine	in the thyroid is not as yet completely understood.	4.5706784434185925
8218. however the formation	of organically bound iodine mainly mono-iodotyrosine can be	accomplished in cell-free systems.	6.680084120695932
8219. in the absence of additions to the	homogenate the product formed is an iodinated particulate protein	and kirkwood 1953; taurog potter and chaikoff 1955;	taurog potter tong and chaikoff 1956; serif and kirkwood	.	3.8736758075976625
8220. this iodoprotein does not	appear	to be the same as what is normally present in the thyroid and there	is no evidence so far that thyroglobulin can be iodinated in vitro	by cell-free systems.	5.499450122426613
8221. in addition the iodoamino acid formed in largest	quantity in the intact thyroid is di-iodotyrosine.	4.899313385068642
8222. if tyrosine	and a system generating hydrogen peroxide are added to a cell-free homogenate	of the thyroid large quantities of free mono-iodotyrosine can	be formed.	5.3507628114783214
8223. it is not clear whether this system	bears any resemblance to the in vivo iodinating mechanism and a system	generating peroxide has not been identified in thyroid tissue.	4.493181738950445
8224. on chemical	grounds it seems most likely that iodide is first converted to	f and then to f as the active iodinating species.	5.733298783197748
8225. in the thyroid	gland it appears that proteins are iodinated	and that free tyrosine and thyronine are not iodinated.	4.263048142963745
8226. iodination of	tyrosine however is not enough for the synthesis of hormone.	7.198989861131925
8227. the mono-	and di-iodotyrosine must be coupled to form tri-iodothyronine and	thyroxine.	4.200697917275358
8228. the mechanism of this coupling has been studied in some detail	with non-enzymatic systems in vitro and can be simulated by certain	di-iodotyrosine analogues.	4.9757508263879044
8229. there	is so far no evidence to indicate conclusively that this coupling is	under enzymatic control.	4.578755707379631
8230. the chemical nature of the iodocompounds	is discussed below.	7.241065261249337
8231. little is known of the synthetic mechanisms for formation of	thyroglobulin.	4.959317770675048
8232. its synthesis has not been demonstrated in cell-free systems	nor has its synthesis by systems with intact thyroid cells in	vitro been unequivocally proven.	5.66731071490181
8233. there is some reason to think that thyroglobulin	synthesis may proceed independently of iodination for in	certain transplantable tumours of the rat thyroid containing essentially	no iodinated thyroglobulin a protein that appears to be thyroglobulin	has been observed in ultracentrifuge experiments	.	4.1421857582480355
8234. similar findings have been noted in a patient with	congenital absence of the organification enzymes whose thyroid tissue	could only concentrate iodide.	5.5730014248072015
8235. in addition depending on availability	of dietary iodine thyroglobulin may contain varying quantities of	iodine.	4.944203324355901
8236. since the circulating thyroid hormones are	the amino acids thyroxine and tri-iodothyronine	it is clear that some mechanism must exist in the thyroid gland for their	release from proteins before secretion.	5.399104436391561
8237. the presence of several proteases	and peptidases has been demonstrated in the thyroid.	4.4679511038027435
8238. one of	the proteases has ph optimum of about 3.	7.849721082160569
8239. 7 and another of about 5.	6.0988709231978
8240. the finding that the concentration of one of these proteases	is increased in thyroid glands from tsh-treated animals suggests	that this protease may be active in vivo.	5.609160599258905
8241. there is no conclusive	evidence yet that either of the proteases has been prepared in highly	purified form nor is their specificity known.	4.312744482492503
8242. a study of their activity	on thyroglobulin has shown that thyroxine is not preferentially released	and that the degradation proceeds stepwise with the formation	of macromolecular intermediates.	5.1842193244099875
8243. besides proteolytic enzymes the thyroid possesses de-iodinating enzymes.	5.65598634557722
8244. a microsomal de-iodinase with a ph optimum of around 8 and requiring	reduced triphosphopyridine nucleotide for activity has been	identified in the thyroid.	5.075549610928492
8245. this de-iodinating enzyme	is effective against mono- and di-iodotyrosine but does not de-iodinate	thyroxine or tri-iodothyronine.	4.4302420610554645
8246. it is assumed that the iodine released	from the iodotyrosines remains in the iodide pool of the thyroid	where it is oxidised and re-incorporated into thyroglobulin.	5.173833500533577
8247. the thyroxine	and tri-iodothyronine released by proteolysis and so escaping	de-iodination presumably diffuse into the blood stream.	3.9101694773051827
8248. it has been	shown that thyroglobulin binds thyroxine but the binding does not appear	to be particularly strong.	6.219064013260369
8249. it has been suggested that the plasma	thyroxine-binding proteins which have an extremely high affinity for	thyroxine compete with thyroglobulin for thyroxine	.	4.813524538168834
8250. antithyroid drugs are of two	general types.	7.603896187885215
8251. one type has a small univalent anion of the	thiocyanate-perchlorate-fluoroboride	type.	5.393655842266432
8252. this ion inhibits thyroid hormone synthesis	by interfering with iodide concentration in the thyroid.	5.902992870979968
8253. it does	not appear to affect the iodinating mechanism as such.	5.4344581981622975
8254. the other	group of antithyroid agents or drugs is typified by thiouracil.	5.506908456901043
8255. these	drugs have no effect on the iodide concentrating mechanism but they	inhibit organification.	4.745046394980813
8256. the mechanism of action of these drugs has not	been completely worked out but certain of them appear to act by reducing	the oxidised form of iodine before it can iodinate thyroglobulin	.	4.549302574745209
8257. on the other hand there are a few antithyroid drugs	of this same general type such as resorcinol possessing no reducing	activity and possibly acting through formation of a complex with molecular	iodine.	4.469385124840239
8258. any of the antithyroid drugs of either type if given	in large enough doses for a long period of time will cause goitre owing	to inhibition of thyroid hormone synthesis with production of hypothyroidism.	5.926330946693845
8259. the anterior lobe of the pituitary then responds by an increased	output of tsh causing the thyroid to enlarge.	3.676867685470798
8260. the effect	of drugs that act on the iodide-concentrating mechanism can be counteracted	by addition of relatively large amounts of iodine to the diet.	4.85382417020242
8261. the antithyroid drugs of the thiouracil type however are not antagonised	by such means.	3.93777821379478
8262. besides those of the thiouracil and resorcinol	types certain antithyroid drugs have been found in naturally occurring	foods.	7.138531689784262
8263. the most conclusively identified is l-5-vinyl-2-thio-oxazolidone	which was isolated from rutabaga.	4.87808895356117
8264. it is presumed	to occur in other members of the brassica family.	8.026374665675387
8265. there is some	evidence that naturally occurring goitrogens may play a role in the development	of goitre particularly in tasmania and australia	.	4.798159584616605
8266. there it seems that the goitrogen ingested by	dairy	animals is itself inactive but is converted in the animal to an active	goitrogen which is then secreted in the milk.	5.499326090851605
8267. besides the presence of goitrogens in the diet the level of	iodine itself in the diet plays a major role in governing the activity	of the thyroid gland.	4.1507405265260955
8268. in the experimental animal and in man gross	deficiency in dietary iodine causes thyroid hyperplasia hypertrophy and	increased thyroid activity	.	5.5767915675413535
8269. in man the normal level of iodine in the diet and the level necessary	to prevent development of goitre is about 100 |mg per day.	3.781391090931543
8270. with	lower levels thyroid hypertrophy and increased thyroid blood-flow	enable the thyroid to accumulate a larger proportion of the daily intake	of iodine.	5.287113923804318
8271. further the gland is able to re-use a larger fraction	of the thyroid hormone de-iodinated peripherally.	5.021962504055717
8272. in the presence of	a low iodine intake thyroglobulin labelled in vivo with f is found	to contain more mono-iodotyrosine than normal the amounts of di-iodotyrosine	and iodothyronines being correspondingly reduced.	5.148654890917254
8273. this appears	to result from both a reduced amount of the iodine substrate and a more	rapid secretion of newly iodinated thyroglobulin.	3.9930958898744646
8274. if the deficiency	persists long enough it is reasonable to suppose that the f label	will reflect the f distribution in the thyroglobulin.	6.087738968270601
8275. similar results	might be expected from the influence of drugs or pathological conditions	that limit iodide trapping or organification or accelerate thyroglobulin	proteolysis.	4.242441179728759
8276. the	name thyroid-stimulating hormone has been given to a substance	found in the anterior pituitary gland of all species of animal so	far	tested for its presence.	5.211554892213611
8277. the hormone has also been called thyrotrophin	or thyrotrophic hormone.	4.448767001522802
8278. at the present time we do not know by what	biochemical mechanism tsh acts on the thyroid but for bio-assay	of the hormone there are a number of properties by which its activity	may be estimated including release of iodine from the thyroid increase	in thyroid weight increase in mean height of the follicular cells	and increase in the thyroidal uptake of f.	5.317669899007057
8279. here we shall restrict	discussion to those methods that appear sufficiently sensitive and precise	for determining the concentration of tsh in blood.	4.2424682984083235
8280. brown	has reviewed generally the various methods of assaying tsh	and the reader is referred to her paper for further information on	the subject.	5.216505686369262
8281. tsh	as long ago as 1851 it was pointed out by niepce	that there is a connection between the pituitary and the thyroid.	4.2891925776588735
8282. this connection was clarified by smith and smith who showed	that saline extracts of fresh bovine pituitary glands could re-activate	the atrophied thyroids of hypophysectomised tadpoles.	5.022076087277668
8283. the first attempts	to isolate tsh came a decade later when janssen and loeser	used trichloroacetic acid to separate the soluble tsh	from insoluble impurities.	3.8708067597668383
8284. after their work other investigators applied	salt-fractionation techniques to the problem as well as fractionation	with organic solvents such as acetone.	6.768559246692567
8285. albert has concluded	that the most active preparations of tsh made during this period	from 1931 to 1945 were probably about 100 to 300 times as potent	as the starting material.	3.602552419698558
8286. much of this work has been reviewed by	white.	9.311394049680187
8287. developments up to about 1957 have	been discussed by sonenberg.	5.127573824759733
8288. in the last few years	the application of chromatographic and other modern techniques to the	problem of isolating tsh has led to further purification	.	6.269178917327523
8289. the most	active preparations obtained by these two groups of investigators	appear to be similar in potency composition and physical properties.	3.6398110151839265
8290. two problems present themselves in considering any hormone in	blood.	7.31704589425193
8291. first is the circulating form of the hormone the same as that	found in the gland where it is synthesised and stored?	4.779546457858139
8292.  second what	is its concentration in normal circumstances and in what circumstances	will this concentration depart from the normal level and in which direction?	5.681940952138211
8293. 	it is therefore necessary to consider the properties of pituitary	tsh if the fragmentary chemical information about blood	tsh is to be discussed rationally.	4.199510035050647
8294. the importance of knowing in	what chemical forms the hormone may exist is accentuated by the recent	observation that there exists an abnormally long-acting tsh in	blood drawn from many thyrotoxic patients.	4.838273046914822
8295. whether this	abnormal tsh differs chemically from pituitary tsh or	is alternatively normal tsh with its period of effectiveness	modified	by some other blood constituent cannot be decided without chemical	study of the activity in the blood of these patients and a comparison	of the substance responsible for the blood activity with pituitary	tsh.	3.639382535351704
8296. in evaluating data on the concentration of tsh	in blood one must examine critically the bio-assay methods used	to obtain them.	5.761822353065682
8297. the introduction of the united states pharmacopoeia	reference standard in 1952 and the redefinition and equating of the	usp and international units of thyroid-stimulating activity have	made it possible to compare results published by different investigators	since that time.	3.7324549561098905
8298. we should like to re-emphasise the importance of	stating results solely in terms of international units of tsh activity	and of avoiding the re-introduction of biological units.	5.910556959488304
8299. for	the most part this discussion will be confined to results obtained since	a.	4.447943492246375
8300. standard preparations	the international	unit	adopted to make possible the comparison of results from different	laboratories has been defined as the	amount of activity present in 13.	5.1642753035472735
8301. 5 mg of the international standard	preparation.	7.772019286463683
8302. the international unit is equipotent with the usp	unit adopted in 1952 which was defined as the amount of activity	present in 20 mg of the usp reference substance.	5.034116947674421
8303. muscle weakness is now recognized as an uncommon though	serious complication of steroid therapy with most of the synthetic	adrenal corticosteroids in clinical use.	4.253637547457992
8304. although biopsies have	shown structural changes in some of the reported cases of steroid-induced	weakness this case provides the only example known to us in which	necropsy afforded the opportunity for extensive study of multiple muscle	groups.	5.375139635505346
