8491. a study of the distribution of wtv	antigen within the pseudophloem cells indicates that it is irregularly	distributed in the cytoplasm.	4.9637290821025815
8492. wound-tumor virus is a leafhopper	transmitted virus not easily transmissible by mechanical inoculation	.	5.926734816808145
8493. the concentration	and	apparent localization of the wtv antigen in pseudophloem tissue	of the tumor may indicate that the virus preferentially multiplies	in the phloem and may need to be directly placed in this tissue in order	to infect plants.	3.5181013735470574
8494. since emotional reactions in the higher vertebrates depend on	individual experience and are aroused in man in addition by complex	symbols one would expect that the hypothalamus could be excited from	the cortex.	5.127253997674029
8495. in experiments with topical application of strychnine on	the cerebral cortex the transmission of impulses from the cortex to the	hypothalamus was demonstrated.	3.9020296841728688
8496. moreover the responsiveness of the	hypothalamus to nociceptive stimulation is greatly increased under these	conditions.	6.48510023292904
8497. even more complex and obviously cortically induced forms	of emotional arousal could be elicited in monkey a on seeing	monkey b in emotional stress.	4.278075067386682
8498. a previously	extinguished conditioned reaction was restored in monkey a	and was associated	with typical signs of emotional excitement including sympathetic	discharges.	5.258925197803143
8499. it seems to follow that by and large an antagonism	exists between the paleo- and the neocortex as far as emotional reactivity	is concerned and that the balance between the two systems determines	the emotional responsiveness of the organism.	4.76245653278906
8500. in addition the	neocortical-hypothalamic relations play a great role in primates as	mirsky's interesting experiment on the communication of affect	demonstrates.	5.889125548798454
8501. but even in relatively primitive laboratory animals	such as the rat sex activity closely identified with the hypothalamus	and the visceral brain is enhanced by the neocortex.	4.085356220045806
8502. maclean stressed	correctly the importance of the visceral brain for preservation of	the individual and the species as evidenced by the influence of the	limbic brain on emotions related to fight	and flight and also on sexual functions.	5.157462699120497
8503. it should be added that in	man	neocortical-hypothalamic interrelations probably play a role in the fusion	of emotional processes with those underlying perception memory	imagination and creativity.	4.735893314085573
8504. previous experiences are obviously	of great importance for the qualitative and quantitative emotional	response.	5.977280472119866
8505. the visceral brain as well as the neocortex is known to contribute	to memory but this topic is beyond the scope of this	paper.	4.3641679199876915
8506. after	this brief discussion of neo- paleocortical and cortico-hypothalamic	relations let us return once more to the problem of hypothalamic balance	and its physiological and pathological significance.	5.690825926952447
8507. facilitatory	processes take place between neocortex and hypothalamus via ascending	and descending pathways.	4.535752126583474
8508. thus cortico-fugal discharges induced by topical	application of strychnine to a minute area in the neocortex summate	with spikes present in the hypothalamus and cause increased convulsive	discharges.	5.514841514791466
8509. on the other hand the temporary reduction in hypothalamic	excitability through the injection of a barbiturate into the posterior	hypothalamus causes a lessening in frequency and amplitude of	cortical strychnine spikes until the hypothalamic excitability is restored.	3.9230522652773447
8510. apparently a positive feedback exists between the posterior hypothalamus	and the cerebral cortex.	6.426137665239366
8511. consequently if for any reason	the hypothalamic excitability falls below the physiological level the	lessened hypothalamic-cortical discharges lead to a diminished state	of activity in the cortex with consequent reduction in the cortico-fugal	discharges.	3.6110207650110904
8512. obviously a vicious cycle develops.	9.48847593294957
8513. this tendency can	be broken either by restoring hypothalamic excitability directly or	via cortico-hypothalamic pathways.	4.473164702223352
8514. it is believed that drug therapy	and electroshock involve the former and psychotherapy the latter mechanism.	6.368795082194251
8515. before we comment further on these pathological conditions	we should remember that changes in the state of the hypothalamus within	physiological limits distinguish sleep from wakefulness.	4.909496300681809
8516. thus	a low intensity of hypothalamic-cortical discharges prevails in sleep	and a high one during wakefulness resulting in synchronous eeg	potentials in the former and asynchrony in the latter condition.	5.152757981461299
8517. moreover	the dominance in parasympathetic action	at the hypothalamic level induces by its peripheral	action the autonomic symptoms of sleep and by its action on the	cortex a lessening in the reactivity of the sensory and motor apparatus	of the somatic nervous system.	3.439508000987916
8518. with the dominance of the sympathetic	division of the hypothalamus the opposite changes occur.	6.585094152016664
8519. since	electrical stimulation of the posterior hypothalamus produces the effects	of wakefulness while stimulation of the anterior hypothalamus induces	sleep it may be said that the reactivity of the whole organism is	altered by a change in the autonomic reactivity of the hypothalamus.	4.352649091821039
8520. similar effects can be induced reflexly via the baroreceptor reflexes	in man and animals.	6.016507148100051
8521. of particular importance is the study of	the actions of drugs in this respect.	4.964619777773032
8522. although no drugs act exclusively	on the hypothalamus or a part of it there is sufficient specificity	to distinguish drugs which shift the hypothalamic balance to the sympathetic	side from those which produce a parasympathetic dominance.	5.660658122304141
8523. the	former comprise analeptic and psychoactive drugs the latter the tranquilizers.	4.681571082223364
8524. specific differences exist in the action of different drugs	belonging to the same group as for instance between reserpine and	chlorpromazine.	6.070679601328896
8525. important as these differences are they should not	obscure the basic fact that by shifting the hypothalamic balance sufficiently	to the parasympathetic side we produce depressions whereas	a shift in the opposite direction causes excitatory effects and eventually	maniclike changes.	3.6908244318982235
8526. the emotional states produced by drugs influence	the cortical potentials in a characteristic manner; synchrony	prevails in the eeg of the experimental animal after administration	of tranquilizers but asynchrony after application of analeptic and	psychoactive drugs.	4.546220371272326
8527. the shock therapies act likewise on the	hypothalamic balance.	4.465075916986007
8528. physiological experiments and clinical observations	have shown that these procedures influence the hypothalamically controlled	hypophyseal secretions and increase sympathetic discharges.	5.2920541105344485
8529. they shift the hypothalamic balance to the sympathetic side.	5.404475899071562
8530. this explains	the beneficial effect of electroshock therapy in certain depressions	and a shift in the reaction from hypo- to normal reactivity of the	sympathetic system as shown by the mecholyl test.	5.080054984114679
8531. some investigators	have found a parallelism between remissions and return of the sympathetic	reactivity of the hypothalamus to the normal level as indicated	by the mecholyl test and conversely between clinical impairment and	increasing deviation of this test from the norm.	3.6811068292437894
8532. nevertheless the	theory that the determining influence of the hypothalamic balance has	a profound influence on the clinical behavior of neuropsychiatric patients	has not yet been tested on an adequate number of patients.	5.237815566651125
8533. the	mecholyl and noradrenalin tests applied with certain precautions are	reliable indicators of this central autonomic balance but for the sake	of correlating autonomic and clinical states and of studying the effect	of certain therapeutic procedures on central autonomic reactions	additional tests seem to be desirable.	3.687250018495851
8534. it was assumed that the	shift in autonomic hypothalamic balance occurring spontaneously in	neuropsychiatric	patients from the application of certain therapeutic procedures	follows the pattern known from the sleep-wakefulness cycle.	5.352196915008661
8535. a change in the balance to the parasympathetic side leads in the normal	individual to sleep or in special circumstances to cardiovascular	collapse or nausea and vomiting.	4.128852084161068
8536. in both conditions the emotional and	perceptual sensitivity is diminished but no depression occurs such	as is seen clinically or may be produced in normal persons by drugs.	5.17992496103097
8537. the	fundamental differences between physiological and pathological states	of parasympathetic dominance remain to be	elucidated.	4.411891185517149
8538. perhaps a clue to these and related problems lies	in the fact that changes in the intensity of hypothalamic discharges	which are associated with changes in its balance lead also to qualitative	alterations in reactivity.	5.619298930488499
8539. a state of parasympathetic tuning	of the hypothalamus induced experimentally causes not only an increase	in the parsympathetic reactivity of this structure to direct and	reflexly induced stimuli but leads also to an autonomic reversal:	a stimulus acting sympathetically under control conditions elicits in	this state of tuning a parasympathetic response! furthermore conditioned	reactions are fundamentally altered when the hypothalamic sympathetic	reactivity is augmented beyond a critical level and several types	of behavioral changes probably related to the degree of central autonomic	tuning are observed.	3.358938393458611
8540. if for instance such a change is	produced by one or a few insulin comas or electroshocks previously	inhibited conditioned reactions reappear.	5.492200299236217
8541. however if these procedures	are applied more often conditioned emotional responses are temporarily	abolished.	4.965158605006454
8542. in other studies loss of differentiation in previously	established conditioned reflexes resulted from repeated convulsive	treatments suggesting a fundamental disturbance in the balance	between excitatory and inhibitory cerebral processes.	5.263589074363882
8543. it has	further been shown that: an experimental neurosis in its initial	stages is associated with a reversible shift in the central autonomic	balance; drugs altering the hypothalamic balance alter conditioned	reactions; in a state of depression the positive conditioned	stimulus may fail to elicit a conditioned reaction but cause an increased	synchrony instead of the excitatory desynchronizing	effect on the eeg.	3.7190094107420184
8544. these are few and seemingly disjointed data	but they illustrate the important fact that fundamental alterations	in conditioned reactions occur in a variety of states in which the hypothalamic	balance has been altered by physiological experimentation	pharmacological action or clinical processes.	5.429432321903111
8545. basis of some form of psychotherapy	the foregoing remarks	imply	that the hypothalamic balance plays a crucial role at the crossroads	between physiological and pathological forms of emotion.	3.888795927176761
8546. if this is	the case one would expect that not only the various procedures just	mentioned which alter the hypothalamic balance would influence emotional	state and behavior but that emotion itself would act likewise.	5.4228364045479704
8547. we	pointed out that emotional excitement may lead to psychosomatic disorders	and neurotic symptoms particularly in certain types of personality	but it is also known that the reliving of a strong emotion	may cure a battle neurosis.	3.779550949343035
8548. this phenomenon raises the question	whether the guidance of the emotions for therapeutic ends may not	have an even wider application in the area of the neuroses.	5.826896165911303
8549. being	a strictly	physiological procedure one may expect from such a study additional	information on the nature of the emotional process itself.	4.503426141925652
8550. wolpe's experiments and therapeutic work lie in this area.	6.522871687113793
8551. he showed	convincingly that anxiety is a learned reaction and	is the basis of experimental and clinical neuroses and assumed therefore	that the neuronal changes which underlie the neuroses are functional	and reversible.	3.8718950552717915
8552. an important observation of pavlov served as a	guide post to achieve such a reversibility by physiological means.	5.642796806206975
8553. in	a conditioning experiment he demonstrated the antagonism between feeding	and pain.	4.90652447747638
8554. a mild electrical shock served as a conditioned stimulus	and was followed by feeding.	6.125352549970901
8555. the pain became thus the symbol for food	and elicited salivary secretion.	4.4522095096831
8556. even when the	intensity of the shocks was increased gradually it failed to evoke	any signs of pain.	6.206406319443832
8557. since strong nociceptive stimuli produce an experimental	neurosis during which the animals fail to eat in the experimental	situation wolpe thought that he could utilize the feeding-pain antagonism	to inhibit the neurotic symptoms through feeding.	3.8819954968507884
8558. appropriate	experiments showed that this is indeed possible.	8.972501692321265
8559. he then applied	this	principle of reciprocal inhibition to human neuroses.	5.560558657254296

8936. these societies can expect to face difficult times.	7.630283945429465
8937. as the historic	processes of modernization gradually gain momentum their cohesion	will be threatened by divisive forces the gaps between rulers and	subjects town and country will widen; new aspirants for power will	emerge whose ambitions far exceed their competence; old rulers may	lose their nerve and their sense of direction.	3.4767349067322773

8953. most countries in this second category share	the difficulty of having many of the structures of a modern political	and social system without the modern standards of performance required	to make them effective.	4.076357337102832

8955. the colonial period has generally left people believing that government	can if it wishes provide all manner of services for them-	and that with independence free men do not have to work to realize the	benefits of modern life.	3.743101157532715
8956. for example in accordance with the fashion	of the times most transitional societies have announced economic development	plans of varying numbers of years; such is the mystique of	planning that people expect that fulfillment of the plan will follow	automatically upon its announcement.	5.351704536885061
8957. the civil services in such societies	are generally inadequate to deal competently with the problems facing	them; and their members often equate a government career with security	and status rather than with sacrifice self-discipline and competence.	3.396385422347032
8958. american policy should press constantly the view that	until these governments demand efficiency and effectiveness of their	bureaucracies there is not the slightest hope that they will either modernize	of democratize their societies.	5.782886268632087
8959. we should spread the view that	planning and national development are serious matters which call for	effort as well as enthusiasm.	4.89389470757858
8960. above all we should seek to encourage	the leaders of these societies to accept the unpleasant fact that they	are responsible for their fates.	5.7186098565892625
8961. only within the framework of a mature	relationship characterized by honest appraisals of performance can	we provide telling assistance.	4.347493182251874
8962. with respect to those countries whose	leaders prefer to live with their illusions we can afford to wait	for in time their comparative lack of progress will become clear for all	to see.	5.339675020241304
8963. our technical assistance to these countries should	place special emphasis on inducing the central governments to assume the	role of advisor and guide which at an earlier stage foreign experts	assumed in dealing with the central governments.	3.7322241997648997
8964. we should encourage	the governments to develop their own technical assistance to communities	state and provincial governments rural communities and other smaller	groups making certain that no important segment of the economy is	neglected.	5.320763387376736
8965. simultaneously we should be underlining the interrelationships	of technical progress in various fields showing how agricultural	training can be introduced into education how health affects labor	productivity how small business can benefit the rural farm community	and above all how progress in each field relates to national progress.	3.4588703563932515
8966. efforts such as the community development program in the philippines	have demonstrated that transitional societies can work toward	balanced national development.	5.832902274791602
8967. to achieve this goal of balanced development	communications between the central government and the local communities	must be such that the needs and aspirations of the people themselves	are effectively taken into account.	4.477856495836598
8968. if modernization programs	are imposed from above without the understanding and cooperation of	the people they will encounter grave difficulties.	5.664181435963597
8969. land reform	is likely to be a pressing issue in many of these countries.	6.6235277192257005
8970. it should	be american policy not only to encourage effective land reform	programs but also to underline the relation of such reforms to the economic	growth and modernization of the society.	5.608052801592143
8971. as an isolated policy	land reform is likely to be politically disruptive; as part of a larger	development effort however it may gain wide acceptance.	5.339636821426662
8972. it should	also be recognized that the problem of rural tenancy cannot be solved	by administrative decrees alone.	6.70091036931843
8973. land reform programs need to be	supplemented with programs for promoting rural credits and technical assistance	in agriculture.	4.09680761620383
8974. lastly governmental and private planners	will at this stage begin to see large capital requirements looming	ahead.	5.724071237696648
8975. by holding out prospects for external capital assistance the	united states can provide strong incentives to prepare for the concerted	economic drive necessary to achieve self-sustaining growth.	3.82951812698378
8976. modernizing societies	at a third stage in the modernization	process are such countries as india brazil the philippines and	taiwan which are ready and committed to move into the stage of self-sustaining	growth.	5.074433871657863
8977. they must continue to satisfy basic capital needs;	and there persists the dual problem of maintaining operational unity	around a national program of modernization while simultaneously decentralizing	participation in the program to wider and wider groups.	3.7826743528889133
8978. but these countries have made big strides toward developing the necessary	human and social overhead capital; they have established reasonably	stable and effective governmental institutions at national and local	levels; and they have begun to develop a capacity to deal realistically	and simultaneously with all the major sectors of their economies.	4.953553659358183
8979. on the economic front the first priority of these countries	is to mobilize a vastly increased volume of resources.	4.309157056228794
8980. several related	tasks must be carried out if self-sustaining growth is to be achieved.	8.090980472462304
8981. these countries must formulate a comprehensive long-term program	covering the objectives of both the private and the public sectors	of the economy.	4.282689700678104
8982. they must in their planning be able to count on at least	tentative commitments of foreign capital assistance over periods	of several years.	6.138933127297629
8983. capital imports drawn from a number of sources must	be employed and combined skillfully enough to permit domestic investment	programming to go forward.	4.216302073162282
8984. capital flows must be coordinated with	national needs and planning.	6.522871687113793
8985. finally a balance must be effected among	project finance utilization of agricultural surpluses and general	balance of payments support.	4.296125541903337
8986. thus although the agenda of external	assistance in the economic sphere are cumulative and many of the	policies suggested for nations in the earlier stages remain relevant	the basic purpose of american economic policy during the later stages	of development should be to assure that movement into a stage of self-sustaining	growth is not prevented by lack of foreign exchange.	4.968455750776203
8987. there remain many political and administrative problems to be solved.	5.641702390061126
8988. for one thing although considerable numbers of men have been trained	bureaucracies are still deficient in many respects; even the	famed indian civil service is not fully adequate to the tremendous	range of tasks it has undertaken.	5.107108426197848
8989. technical assistance in training middle-	and upper-level management personnel is still needed in many cases.	4.245362623818629
8990. there are also more basic problems.	10.118080246421345
8991. this is the stage at which democratic	developments must take place if the society is to become an	open community of creative people.	4.217579574944413
8992. nevertheless impulses still exist	among the ruling elite to rationalize and thus to perpetuate the need	for centralized and authoritarian practices.	5.597414555320442
8993. another great danger is	that the emerging middle class will feel itself increasingly alienated	from the political leaders who still justify their dominance by reference	to the struggle for independence or the early phase of nationalism.	3.672790725939303
8994. the capacity of intellectuals and members of the new professional	classes to contribute creatively to national development is likely to	be destroyed by a constraining sense of inferiority toward both their	own political class and their colleagues and professional counterparts	in the west.	5.072150874407012
8995. particularly when based upon a single dominant party	governments may respond to such a situation by claiming a monopoly of	understanding about the national interest.	3.725131536371901
8996. convinced of the wisdom of	their own actions and reassured by the promises of their economic development	programs governments may fail to push outward to win more	and more people to the national effort becoming instead more rigid and	inflexible in their policies.	4.778776177296164
8997. american policy toward such societies	should stress our sympathy for the emerging social and professional	classes.	4.848846624571699
8998. it should attempt to communicate both an appreciation	of professional standards and an understanding of the tremendous powers	and potentialities of genuinely open and pluralistic societies.	6.005630318411373
8999. we	have every obligation to take seriously their claims to being democratic	and free countries; we also have in consequence the duty to appraise	realistically and honestly their performance and to communicate	our judgments to their leaders in frank but friendly ways.	3.507008336253105
9000. factor	we have emphasized that the modernizing process in each society	will take a considerable period of time.	5.610183044423355
9001. with the exception of	treaty-making foreign relations were historically concerned for the	most part with conditions of short or at least measurable duration.	4.908342761650614
9002. foreign	policy now takes on a different perspective and must become skilled	not merely at response but also at projection.	5.670054857772145
9003. american and free-world	policies can marginally affect the pace of transition; but basically	that pace depends on changes in the supply of resources and in	the human attitudes political institutions and social structure which	each society must generate.	3.779094983301935
9004. it follows that any effective policy toward	the underdeveloped countries must have a realistically long working	horizon.	6.949658107617871
9005. it must be marked by a patience and persistence which have	not always been its trademark.	5.1544731091808735
9006. this condition affects not only	the conception but also the legislative and financial support of foreign	policy especially in the context of economic aid.	6.037368705366322
9007. the place of	religion in the simple preliterate societies is quite definite; as	a complex it fits into the whole social organization and functions dominantly	in every part of it.	3.762698880705594
9008. in societies like ours however its place	is less clear and more complex.	6.179276972815976
9009. with the diversity of religious viewpoints	there are differences of opinion as to the essential features	of religion; and there are different opinions as to the essential	functions of religion.	4.791252561183742
9010. nevertheless for most of the population of heterogeneous	advanced societies though less for the less religious portion	religion does perform certain modal individual and social functions.	6.2715819948687495
9011. although the inner functions of religion are not of direct	significance in social organization they have important indirect consequences.	4.403479597760111
9012. if the inner functions of religion are performed the individual	is a composed ordered motivated and emotionally secure associate;	he is not greatly frustrated and he is not anomic; he is	better fitted to perform his social life among his fellows.	5.225419374903635
9013. there are	several closely related inner functions.	7.229157546564095
9014. in the last analysis	religion is the means of inducing formulating expressing enhancing	implementing and perpetuating man's deepest experience- the religious.	5.979170548327797
9015. man is first religious; the instrumentalities follow.	6.494006347560702
9016. religion	seeks to satisfy human needs of great pertinence.	6.806723317680827
9017. the significant	things in it at the higher religious levels are the inner emotional	mental and spiritual occurrences that fill the pressing human needs	of self-preservation self-pacification and self-completion.	3.5923671468629204
9018. the chief	experience is the sensing of communion and in the higher religions	of a harmonious relationship with the supernatural power.	5.4791514353657575
9019. related to	this is the fact that most of the higher religions define for the individual	his place in the universe and give him a feeling that he is relatively	secure in an ordered dependable universe.	5.010990367388003
9020. man has the experience	of being helpfully allied with what he cannot fully understand;	he is a coordinate part of all of the mysterious energy and being and	movement.	5.948731048823774
9021. the universe is a safe and permanent home.	5.075315958858594
9022. a number	of religions also satisfy for many the need of being linked with the	ultimate and eternal.	5.853991709885976
9023. death is not permanent defeat and disappearance;	man has a second chance.	4.749331410112551
9024. he is not lost in the abyss of endless	time; he has endless being.	7.746559239154671
9025. religion at its best also offers the	experience of spiritual fulfillment by inviting man into the highest realm	of the spirit.	3.8880356915934375
9026. religion can summate epitomize relate and conserve	all the highest ideals and values- ethical aesthetic and religious-	of man formed in his culture.	5.103675880876918
9027. there is also the possibility	among higher religions of experiencing consistent meaning in life	and enjoying guidance and expansiveness.	5.038631305413246
9028. the kind of religious experience	that most moderns seek not only provides clarifies and relates	human yearnings values ideals and purposes; it also provides facilities	and incitements for the development of personality sociality	and creativeness.	5.1864353748163
9029. under the religious impulse whether theistic or	humanistic men have joy in living; life leads somewhere.	4.642392281852646
9030. religion	at its best is out in front ever beckoning and leading on and as lippman	put it mobilizing all man's scattered energies in one triumphant	sense of his own infinite importance.	5.169303252539972
9031. at the same	time	that religion binds the individual helpfully to the supernatural and	gives him cosmic peace and a sense of supreme fulfillment it also has	great therapeutic value for him.	4.107360896505182
9032. it gives him aid comfort even solace	in meeting mundane life situations where his own unassisted practical	knowledge and skill are felt by him to be inadequate.	5.5540622557976915
9033. he is confronted	with the recurrent crises such as great natural catastrophes and	the great transitions of life- marriage incurable disease widowhood	old age the certainty of death.	3.9915518801180743
9034. he has to cope with frustration	and other emotional disturbance and anomie.	8.14195328704718
9035. his religious beliefs provide	him with plausible explanations for many conditions which cause	him great concern and his religious faith makes possible fortitude equanimity	and consolation enabling him to endure colossal misfortune	fear frustration uncertainty suffering evil and danger.	3.4992294503403554
9036. religion	usually also includes a principle of compensation mainly in a promised	perfect future state.	5.7836982265615156
9037. the belief in immortality where held	functions as a redress for the ills and disappointments of the here	and now.	3.6768367662181762
9038. the tensions accompanying a repressive consciousness of wrongdoing	or sinning or some tormenting secret are relieved for the less	self-contained or self-sufficient by confession repentance and penance.	4.669145759890817
9039. the feeling of individual inferiority defeat or humilation growing	out of various social situations or individual deficiencies or failures	is compensated for by communion in worship or prayer with a friendly	but all-victorious father-god as well as by sympathetic fellowship	with others who share this faith and by opportunities in religious	acts for giving vent to emotions and energies.	3.428663868663587
9040. in providing	for these inner individual functions religion undertakes in behalf	of individual peace of mind and well-being services for which there is	no other institution.	5.358772432765396
9041. in addition to the functions of religion	within man there have always been the outer social functions for the	community and society.	4.696000464926153
9042. the two have never been separable.	8.077677005219657
9043. religion	is vitally necessary in both societal maintenance and regulation.	4.855658467968249
9044. the value-system of a community or society is always correlated with	and to a degree dependent upon a more or less shared system of religious	beliefs and convictions.	5.042220124258352
9045. the religion supports re-enforces	reaffirms and maintains the fundamental values.	4.320730508808147
9046. even in the united	states with its freedom of religious belief and worship and its vast	denominational differentiation there is a general consensus regarding	the basic christian values.	6.822865909550303
9047. this is demonstrated especially when there	is awareness of radically different value orientation elsewhere;	for example americans rally to christian values vis-a-vis those	of atheistic communism.	4.0454570001799555
9048. in america also all of our major religious bodies	officially sanction a universalistic ethic which is reflective of	our common religion.	5.85865105009894
9049. even the non-church members- the freewheelers	marginal religionists and so on- have the values of christian civilization	internalized in them.	4.528558399904909
9050. furthermore religion tends to integrate	the whole range of values from the highest or ultimate values of god	to the intermediary and subordinate values; for example those regarding	material objects and pragmatic ends.	5.110573077301918
9051. finally it gives sanctity	more than human legitimacy and even through super-empirical reference	transcendent and supernatural importance to some values; for example	marriage as a sacrament much law-breaking as sinful occasionally	the state as a divine instrument.	3.6535383725553663
9052. it places certain values at least	beyond questioning and tampering.	7.689268745923757
9053. closely related to this	function is the fact that the religious system provides a body of ultimate	ends for the society which are compatible with the supreme eternal	ends.	4.596527152062705
9054. this something leads to a conception of an over-all social	plan with a meaning interpretable in terms of ultimate ends; for example	a plan that fulfills the will of god which advances the kingdom	of god which involves social life as part of the grand design.	5.467031944645958
9055. this explains some group ends and provides a justification of their	primacy.	4.789456337513211
9056. it gives social guidance and direction and makes for programs	of social action.	6.738732510197011
9057. finally it gives meaning to much social endeavor	and logic consistency and meaning to life.	4.641305706895583
9058. in general there is no	society so secularized as to be completely without religiously inspired	transcendental ends.	6.633960199254832
9059. some	of the oldest most persistent and most cohesive forms of social groupings	have grown out of religion.	4.177396032884076
9060. these groups have varied widely from	mere families primitive totemic groups and small modern cults and	sects to the memberships of great denominations and great widely	dispersed world religions.	5.019041591892522
9061. religion fosters group life in various ways.	5.3285636594893
9062. the common ultimate values ends and goals fostered by religion are	a most important factor.	5.4890628405123625
9063. without a system of values there can be no	society.	6.864429706882687
9064. where such a value system prevails it always unifies all	who possess it; it enables members of the society to operate as a system.	5.9155406509217
9065. the beliefs of a religion also reflecting the values are expressed	in creeds dogmas and doctrines and form what durkheim calls a credo.	3.5473748551672966
9066. as he points out a religious group cannot exist without a collective	credo and the more extensive the credo the more unified and strong	is the group.	5.606158451658095
9067. the credo unifies and socializes men by attaching	them completely to an identical body of doctrine; the more extensive	and firm the body of doctrine the firmer the group.	3.6267791784963044
9068. the religious	symbolism and especially the closely related rites and worship	forms constitute a powerful bond for the members of the particular faith.	5.433724058565319
9069. the religion in fact is an expression of the unity of the group	small or large.	4.469380230733164
9070. the common codes for religious action as such and	in their ethical aspects for everyday moral behavior bind the devotees	together.	5.0995364467391315
9071. these are ways of jointly participating in significantly	symbolized standardized and ordered religiously sanctified behavior.	4.720734897723555
9072. the codes are mechanism for training in and directing and enforcing	uniform social interaction and for continually and publicly reasserting	the solidarity of the group.	4.751884320492174
9073. durkheim noted long ago that	religion as h a unified system of beliefs and practices relative	to sacred things h unites into one single moral community h	all	those who adhere to them.	3.562115886365008
9074. his view is that every religion pertains	to	a community and conversely every community is in one aspect a religious	unit.	5.674941972410823
9075. this is brought out in the common religious ethos that prevails	even in the denominationally diverse audiences at many secular	semi-public and public occasions in the united states; and it is	evidenced in the prayers offered in the frequent religious allusions	and in the confirmation of points on religious grounds.	3.993850363213731
9076. the	unifying effect of religion is also brought out in the fact that historically	peoples have clung together as more or less cohesive cultural	units with religion as the dominant bond even though spatially dispersed	and not politically organized.	5.497371982168858
9077. the jews for 2500 years have been	a prime example though the adherents of any world or interpeople religion	are cases in point.	3.6038842595995173
9078. it might be pointed out that the integrating	function of religion for good or ill has often supported or been	identified with other groupings- political nationality language class	racial sociability even economic.	5.687379081655061
9079. religion usually exercises	a stabilizing-conserving function.	6.094118058689911
9080. as such it acts as an anchor	for the people.	7.863338418950815
9081. there is a marked tendency for religions once firmly	established to resist change not only in their own doctrines and policies	and practices but also in secular affairs having religious relevance.	4.534622962951788
9082. it has thus been a significant factor in the conservation of	social values though also in some measure an obstacle to the creation	or diffusion of new ones.	5.600825653172288
9083. it tends to support the longstanding precious	sentiments the traditional ways of thinking and the customary ways	of living.	4.630570760044813
9084. as yinger has pointed out the h reliance on symbols	on tradition on sacred writings on the cultivation of emotional	feelings of identity and harmony with sacred values turns one to the	past far more than to the future.	5.208843682609572
9085. historically religion has also	functioned as a tremendous engine of vindication enforcement sanction	and perpetuation of various other institutions.	4.113952705112461
9086. at the same	time that religion exercises a conserving influence it also energizes	and motivates both individuals and groups.	6.070227054784718
9087. much of the important	individual and social action has been owing to religious incentives.	5.456036415712056
9088. the	great ultimate ends of religion have served as magnificent beacon	lights that lured people toward them with an almost irresistible force	mobilizing energies and inducing sacrifices; for example the crusades	mission efforts just wars.	5.359483399699403
9089. much effort has been expended in the	sincere effort to apply the teaching and admonitions of religion.	4.716685382082387
9090. the	insuperable reward systems that most religions embody have great motivating	effects.	6.289010577019261
9091. religion provides the most attractive rewards either	in this world or the next for those who not merely abide by its norms	but who engage in good works.	3.939760520728359
9092. religion usually acts as a	powerful	aid in social control enforcing what men should or should not	do.	5.550554466109728
9093. among primitive peoples the sanctions and dictates of religion were	more binding than any of the other controls exercised by the group;	and in modern societies such influence is still great.	4.343004377977767
9094. religion has	its own supernatural prescriptions that are at the same time codes	of behavior for the here and now.	6.399613837091756
9095. overwhelmed with the care of five young children and concerned about	persistent economic difficulties due to her husband's marginal income	her defense of denial was excessively strong.	3.728293694774503
9096. thus the lack of effective	recognition of the responsibilities involved in caring for two	babies showed signs of becoming a disabling problem.	6.3234259961731185
9097. the result dramatically	visible in a matter of days in the family's disrupted daily	functioning was a phobic-like fear that some terrible harm would befall	the second twin whose birth had not been anticipated.	4.0940016616059225
9098. soon mrs	b's fears threatened to burst into a full-blown panic concerning	the welfare of the entire family.	6.818706034275398
9099. inability to care for the other	children difficulty in feeding the babies who seemed colicky bone-weary	fatigue repeated crying episodes and short tempers reflected	the family's helplessness in coping with the stressful situation.	3.86534223963105
9100. clearly	this was a family in crisis.	7.603896187885215
9101. mrs b compared her	feelings of weakness to her feelings of weakness and helplessness at	the time of her mother's death when she was eight as well as her subsequent	anger at her father for remarrying.	4.134093104697482
9102. her previous traumatic experiences	flashed through her mind as if they had happened yesterday.	7.363862828758647

9104. in the family's own words they	had reached the crisis peak- either the situation will give or	we	will break!   direct confrontation and acceptance of mrs	b's anger against the second baby soon dissipated her fears	of annihilation.	4.8303392488591985
9105. abreaction of her anxiety and guilt concerning the	death of her parents when linked up with her current feelings of anger	and her fears of loss abandonment and annihilation produced further	relief of tension.	3.570030604897045
9106. in a joint interview mr and mrs b were	helped to understand the meaning of a younger son's wandering away	from home in terms of his feelings of displacement in reaction to the	arrival of the twins.	6.036311509704082
9107. the father accurately perceiving the child's	needs not only respected them as worthy of his attention but immediately	satisfied them by taking him on his lap along with the twins	saying i have a big lap; there is room for you too johnnie.	3.6015710948071327
9108. simultaneously a variety of environmental supports- a calm but	not	too motherly homemaker referral for temporary economic aid intelligent	use of nursing care accompaniment to the well-baby clinic for medical	advice on the twins' feeding problem- combined to prevent further	development of predictable pathological mechanisms.	4.769865972940817
9109. follow-up visits	of the nurse and social worker indicated continued success in the	care of the new babies as well as a marked improvement in the family's	day-to-day mental health and social functioning.	4.348441367094314
9110. as seen	in the b family there must be an attempt to help the client develop	conscious awareness of the problem especially in the absence of a	formal request for assistance.	6.986140052845859
9111. the lack of awareness usually springs	from deep but disguised anxiety often assuming the superficial guise	of not knowing or not caring.	3.9183075420218025
9112. the unhealthy use of denial	in the initial reaction to a stress must be handled through the medium	of a positive controlled transference.	4.909413046003364
9113. in general the approach is	more active than passive more out-reaching than reflective.	5.03712926943698
9114. while some	regression is inevitable it is discouraged rather than encouraged	so that the transference does not follow the stages of planned regression	associated with certain casework adaptations of the psychoanalytic	model for insight therapy.	4.921856710707761
9115. to establish an emotionally meaningful	relationship the worker must demonstrate actual or potential helpfulness	immediately preferably within the first interview by meeting	the client's specific needs.	3.977821522320952
9116. these needs usually concern the reduction	of guilt and some relief of tension.	6.242131469445269
9117. the initial interview must	be therapeutic rather than purely exploratory in an information-seeking	sense.	4.012553355630973
9118. in this relationship-building stage the worker must communicate	confidence in the client's ability to deal with the problem.	6.610673745751884
9119. in	so doing he implicitly offers the positive contagion of hope as a kind	of maturational dynamic to counteract feelings of helplessness and hopelessness	generally associated with the first stages of stress impact.	3.9299082753051904
9120. thus the client receives enough ego support to engage in constructive	efforts on his own behalf.	6.804566306632
9121. here there is a specific preventive component	which applies in a more generalized sense to any casework situation.	5.404813321844953
9122. we are preventing or averting pathogenic phenomena such as undue	regression unhealthy suppression and repression excessive use of	denial and crippling guilt turned against the self.	5.3937854540584365
9123. while some suppression	and some denial are not only necessary but healthy the worker's	clinical knowledge must determine how these defenses are being used	what healthy shifts in defensive adaptation are indicated and when	efforts at bringing about change can be most effectively timed.	3.5540642565033944
9124. in steering the family toward ego-adaptive and away from maladaptive	responses the worker uses time-honored focused casework techniques	of specific emotional support clarification and anticipatory guidance.	5.080079763494645
9125. over a relatively short period of time usually about four to twelve	weeks the worker must be able to shift the focus back and forth	between immediate external stressful exigencies	and the key emotionally relevant issues	which are often in a dramatic preconscious breakthrough reactivated	by the crisis situation and hence once again amenable to resolution.	3.6666886482419594

9127. then too the utmost clinical flexibility is necessary in judiciously	combining carefully timed family-oriented home visits single and group	office interviews and appropriate telephone follow-up calls if	the worker is to be genuinely accessible and if the predicted unhealthy	outcome is to be actually averted in accordance with the principles	of preventive intervention.	3.9590155910757057
9128. in addition in many cases a variety of	concrete social resources- homemaker day care medical and financial	aid- must be reasonably available for the reality support needed to	bolster the family in its individual and collective coping and integrative	efforts.	5.001333606650236
9129. at certain critical stages and only for sound diagnostic	reasons it may be important to accompany family members in their use	of these resources if their problem-solving behavior is to be constructive	rather than defeating.	4.202698029309344
9130. while expensive in time and involving	a great deal of adaptation on the part of the worker	willingness to leave the sanctity of his office and enter actively into	techniques of accompaniment were found to be of	tremendous value when in the service of specific preventive objectives.	5.609986834138077
9131. finally whatever the techniques used a twin goal is common to all	preventive casework service: to cushion or reduce the force of the	stress impact while at the same time to encourage and support family	members to mobilize and use their ego capacities.	3.992707083945967
9132. having outlined	an approach to the theory and practice of preventive casework we	now address ourselves to our final question: what place should brief	crisis-oriented preventive casework occupy in our total spectrum of	services?	5.239856569699982
9133.  we should first recognize our tendency to develop a hierarchy	of values locating brief treatment at the bottom and long-term	intensive service at the top instead of seeing the services as part	of a continuum each important in its own right.	4.065728176765892
9134. this problem is perhaps	as old as social casework itself.	6.955826337463657
9135. almost three decades ago bertha	reynolds undertook a study of short-contact interviewing because of	her conviction that short-term casework had an important but neglected	place in our network of social services.	3.828594801028171
9136. her conclusion has been borne	out in the experience of many practitioners: h short-contact	interviewing is neither a truncated nor a telescoped experience but	is of the same essential quality as the so-called intensive case work.	5.4358429162114605
9137. thus	casework involving a limited number of interviews is still to be	regarded in terms of the quality of service rendered rather than of the	quantity of time expended.	4.4858165272525925
9138. that we are experiencing an upsurge	of interest in the many formulations and preventive adaptations of	brief treatment in social casework is evident from even a small sampling	of current literature.	5.728042441843345
9139. especially noteworthy is levinger's finding	that the length of treatment per se is not a reliable indicator of	successful outcome.	5.05403736322192
9140. according to a number of studies the important	predictors are the nature and management of the client's anxiety as	well as the accessibility of the helping person.	6.316686738667231
9141. for example the level	of improvement noted in a recent experiment with a short course of	immediate treatment for parent-child relationship problems compared favorably	with the results reported by typical child guidance clinics where	the hours spent in purely diagnostic study may equal or exceed the	number of hours devoted to actual treatment interviews in the experimental	project.	3.5487709986249865
9142. of startling significance too is the assertion that	it was possible to carry out this program with only a 6 percent attrition	rate as compared with a rate of 59 percent reported for a comparable	group of families who were receiving help in traditionally operated	child guidance services.	5.069267120231708
9143. these reports refer to a level of secondary	prevention in a child guidance clinic approached by the customary route	of voluntary referral by the family or by other professional people.	3.8547265985074683
9144. similarities to the approach which i have described are evident in	the prompt establishment of a helping relationship quick appraisal of	key issues and the immediate mobilization of treatment plans as the	essential dynamics in helping to further the ego's coping efforts in	dealing with the interplay of inner and outer stresses.	4.812966658090606
9145. while there	are many different possibilities for the timing of casework intervention	the experiments recently reported from a variety of traditional settings	all point up the importance of an immediate response to the client's	initial need for help.	4.173597601235721
9146. in some programs treatment is concentrated	over a short period of time while in others after the initial	contact is established flexible spacing of interviews has been experimentally	used with apparent success.	5.330860021380479
9147. willingness to take the risk of	early and direct interpretation	is another prominent	feature in these efforts.	4.832300725985777
9148. my aim in mentioning this factor obviously	is not to give license to wild therapy but rather to encourage	us to use the time-honored clinical casework skills we already possess	and to use them with greater confidence precision and professional	pride.	5.044482875346966
9149. though there is obviously great need for continued	experimentation with various types of short-term intervention to further	efforts in developing an operational definition of prevention at	the secondary- or perhaps in some instances primary- level the	place of short-term intervention has already been documented by a number	of investigators in a wide variety of settings.	3.813162751671681
9150. woodward for example	has emphasized the need for a broad spectrum of services including	very brief services in connection with critical situations.	6.307658372147986
9151. ideally	brief treatment should be arrived at as a treatment of choice	rather	than as a treatment of chance.	4.060235568763422

9153. further research in the meaning	of crises as experienced by the consumers of traditional social casework	services- including attempts to develop a typology of family structures	crisis problems reaction mechanisms and differential treatment	approaches- and the establishment of new experimental programs are	imperative social needs which should command the best efforts of caseworkers	in collaboration with community planners.	3.5426538255212745
9154. our literature	is already replete with a fantastic number of suggestions for preventive	agency programming ranging from the immediately practical to the	globally utopian.	5.602711438603816

9158. tension management and communication of sentiment	are the processes involved in the functioning of the element of sentiment	or feeling.	5.885215140950714
9159. one of the devices for tension management is preferential	mating.	5.896104442595052

9161. the relative geographical isolation	of the brandywine population makes for a limited choice in mating.	3.9935911302161977
9162. it would seem necessary that members of this population provide support	for one another since it is not provided by the larger society.	7.1403182418399975
9163. the	supportive relations can apparently be achieved in geographical and	social isolation.	4.681571082223364

9166. maintenance of the status	quo might seem to be the appropriate goal or objective of this population	today.	7.3415162967965495

9168. prior to world war	2 there was a higher percentage of endogamous marriages than after	world war 2.	6.480881475648193
9169. the norms as elements refer	to all criteria for judging the character or conduct of both individual	and group actions in any social system.	3.5473748551672966
9170. the process of evaluation	assigns varying positive and negative priorities or values to elements.	6.067824799181713
9171. the elements and processes become evident in a study of mate	selection in this population.	4.229164941255479
9172. from the evidence it may be conjectured	that core-core marriages are the preferred unions for core males and	females; core-marginal marriages still belong in the category of	permissive unions; and core-negro marriages are proscribed for core	members.	5.331818774286162
9173. the element of status-roles and associated	processes have not been sufficiently investigated for this population	to permit any type of conjectures about them.	3.884868188918348
9174. there is some indication from a limited number of interviews with members	of the population that the element of power primarily the voluntary	influence of non-authoritative power has been exerted on actors in	the system particularly in regard to mate selection.	5.337165153235136

9176. again size of the group may have	some influence on the strength of group controls.	8.515680990019264
9177. interviews	with members of the brandywine population were attempted in	order	to discover the ranking of the various families in the population.	4.564589483427425

9181. despite the	increasing rate of exogamous marriages the population has been able	to sustain at least to some degree the consciousness of its intermediate	status in society.	4.135718316452961

9184. the negative	sanctions applied to core-negro marriages for core members act as	indicators of expected adherence to group norms.	4.994484465085144

9187. the comprehensive or master	processes activate all or some of the elements within the social system	and subsystems.	4.428336399497846

9191. in the study of marriage	patterns for this group consanguinity produces the structural system-	a system of affinities- which in turn maintains the system of	consanguinity.	4.333006201540889
9192. subgroups of various types have been found within this	system.	7.158070988320716

9198. the present study relates	to the theory of functional systems.	7.203195618665451
9199. it is hypothesized that fertility	is a function of the social system when the population as a whole	is considered and a function of the subsystems when the two-fold division	of core families and marginal families is considered.	3.7932229455864017
9200. the four	functional problems of a social system are to some extent solved by	the subsystems within this population.	5.20231115954611
9201. by means of geographical isolation	and high fertility rates inbreeding can be fostered and the pattern	of isolation from the greater society maintained.	4.350538488719384
9202. in order to attain	the goal of group solidarity and to relieve tension the high fertility	rate provides more group members for mate selection and the clustering	of members in groups fosters acceptance of group controls.	5.0749334741610586
9203. to	maintain their intermediate position in the larger society it is not	only necessary that members of this population be visible but	that their numbers be great enough to be recognized as a separate distinct	grouping or system in society.	3.787033645151271
9204. as mentioned above where families	are concentrated in larger numbers group controls seem strongest and	most effective.	6.00841409160081

9207. integration has to do with the inter-relation	of parts.	6.6981945098552895
9208. the problem of solidarity and morale again involves	the concept of values.	6.766383365648476
9209. the values placed by the brandywine population	upon maintaining a certain homogeneity a certain separate racial	identity and therefore a certain separate social status are important	for the morale of the system.	3.4424568323300933
9210. since morale is closely related to	pattern maintenance and integration the higher the morale and solidarity	the better the system can solve the problems of the system.	5.685006894073456
9211. in this	respect it would seem that the greater the social distance between	the brandywine population and the white and negro populations within	the same general locality the greater the possibility for higher morale	and solidarity within the brandywine population.	3.846494442032678

9214. the population can thereby replenish itself and actually grow larger.	5.642803662039175
9215. of particular utility in the analysis of the	development persistence and change of social systems has been the	use of the master or comprehensive processes.	4.074717198241315

9219. institutionalization though undoubtedly	all six processes are operative within the whole social system	and its subsystems two processes that are of crucial importance to	this study will be singled out for particular emphasis:	in discussing the process of communication loomis defines	it as the process by which information decisions and directives	are transmitted among actors and the ways in which knowledge opinions	and attitudes are formed or modified by interaction.	3.4939498861452245
9220. communication	may be facilitated by means of the high visibility within the larger	community.	7.199518608225492

9233. there is an oral	tradition among the members of the population in regard to the origin	and subsequent separate status of the group in the larger society.	5.722030768137811

9235. the fact of indian ancestry and free status during the days	of slavery are important distinctions made by members of the group.	4.466529055080324

9243. where boundary maintenance describes the boundaries	or limits of the group systemic linkage is defined as the	process whereby one or more of the elements of at least two social systems	is articulated in such a manner that the two systems in some ways	and on some occasions may be viewed as a single unit.	4.467471542463989
9244. a royal decree issued in 1910 two years after the belgian government	assumed authority for the administration of the congo prescribed	the registration of all adult males by chiefdoms.	5.243674302685534
9245. further decrees	along this line were issued in 1916 and 1919.	5.222690638719159

9308. in short scientific sampling was introduced in place of subjective	sampling.	7.695437384055787

9310. sample	units were drawn systematically	within these strata.	7.603896187885215
9311. different	sampling ratios were applied under different conditions.	5.3285636594893
9312. higher	proportions were sampled in urban and mixed communities than in rural	areas.	6.093123995732186
9313. about 11 percent of the total population was covered in the new	investigation as compared with about 3 percent in the previous inquiries.	4.74616125118612
9314. uniform questions definitions	and procedures were enforced throughout the whole country.	6.514061772105443
9315. data	were obtained separately on three classes of persons: residents	present; visitors.	4.681571082223364
9316. in the	reports summary results are given for both the de facto	and de jure populations; but the subsequent analysis	of characteristics is reported only for the de jure population	.	5.192655756546096
9317. these	changes represent in effect a shift from an administrative compilation	of data obtained through procedures designed primarily to serve	political and economic objectives to a systematic sampling census	of the whole african population.	3.541081760441852
9318. the population registration	system still has important functions.	6.235502562047283
9319. it supplies local data which are	useful in administration and which can be used as a basis for intensive	studies in particular situations.	5.333940495696552

9322. it is still used in making current population	estimates in post-census years though the value of these estimates	is open to question.	6.727457899878345
9323. finally it may have certain very important	less obvious values.	5.868682488315122
9324. even though the registers may have an incomplete	record of persons present in a particular area or include persons	no longer living there they contain precise information on ages by date	of birth for some of the persons present	and supplementary information	for many others.	5.526030852924829
9325. the quality of the census	data can therefore be greatly improved by the use of the registration	records in conjunction with the field inquiries.	4.835833867807278
9326. furthermore it may	be possible to estimate the error due to bias in method	in each of these sources on such subjects	as fertility mortality and migration during a given interval by using	information from two largely independent sources in conjunction.	4.9465485534989
9327. the first sampling census in the congo extended over a three-year	period 1955-57; the results were still being processed in 1959.	4.314861116897903

9574. the	most striking aspect of the interaction demonstrated is the marked decrement	in performance suffered by the highly anxious children in unstructured	schools.	5.689413270532165

9577. the child with high anxiety may	first direct his anxiety-released energy toward achievement but because	his distress severely reduces the abilities of discrimination and	memorization of complex symbols the child may fail in his initial attempts	to master the problem.	3.416580127900165
9578. failure confirms the threat and the intensity	of anxiety is increased as the required learning becomes more	difficult so that by the time the child reaches the third grade the	decrement in performance is pronounced.	5.422267382722903

9589. analysis means the evaluation of subparts the comparative	ratings of parts the comprehension of the meaning of isolated elements.	4.468279098171313
9590. analysis in roleplaying is usually done for the purpose of understanding	strong and weak points of an individual or as a process to	eliminate weak parts and strengthen good parts.	5.442093756317687
9591. up to this point stress has been placed on roleplaying in terms	of individuals.	5.2189111115511615
9592. roleplaying can be done for quite a different purpose:	to evaluate procedures regardless of individuals.	6.55022661311875
9593. for example:	a sales presentation can be analyzed and evaluated through roleplaying.	4.860544455631979
9594. let us now put some flesh on the theoretical bones	we have assembled by giving illustrations of roleplaying used for evaluation	and analysis.	5.571754001317639
9595. one should keep in mind that many of the exciting	possiblities of roleplaying are largely unexplored and have not been	used in industry to the extent that they have been in military and other	areas.	5.143166477085
9596. the president of a small firm selling restaurant	products had considerable difficulty in finding suitable salesmen	for his business.	6.223222724948401
9597. interviewing checking references training the	salesmen having them go with more experienced salesmen was expensive-	and the rate of attrition due to resignations or unsatisfactory	performance was too high.	3.8570150827840775
9598. it was his experience that only one good salesman	was found out of every seven hired- and only one was hired out	of every seven interviewed.	5.60116006507343
9599. roleplaying was offered as a solution-	and the procedure worked as follows: all candidates were invited	to a hotel conference room where the president explained the difficulty	he had and how unnecessary it seemed to him to hire people who	just did not work out.	3.4210831767297694
9600. in place of asking salesmen to fill questionnaires	checking their references interviewing them asking them to	be tried out he told them he would prefer to test them.	5.3329958404119155
9601. each person	was to enter the testing room carrying a suitcase of samples.	5.26770618777313
9602. each salesman	was to read a sheet containing a description of the product.	7.534801050691307
9603. in	the testing room he was to make successively three presentations	to three different people.	5.174876878772072
9604. in the testing room three of the veteran	salesmen served as antagonists.	7.334663401144309
9605. one handled the salesman in a	friendly manner another in a rough manner and the third in a hesitating	manner.	4.394668889274165
9606. each was told to purchase material if he felt like it.	6.662802494804541
9607. the	antagonists came in one at a time and did not see or hear the other	presentations.	4.989731904182336
9608. after each presentation the antagonist wrote his judgment	of the salesmen; and so did the observers consisting of the	president three of his salesmen and a psychologist.	5.280087232288597
9609. ten salesmen	were tested in the morning and ten more in the afternoon.	5.796303606361578
9610. this procedure	was repeated one day a month for four months.	7.583686433967309
9611. the batting average	of one success out of seven increased to one out of three.	4.24115658475916
9612. the president	of the firm calculating expenses alone felt his costs had dropped	one-half while success in selection had improved over one hundred	per cent.	4.941911761853857
9613. the reason for the value of this procedure was simply	that the applicants were tested at work in different situations	by the judgment of a number of experts who could see how the salesmen	conducted themselves with different but typical restaurant owners	and managers.	4.066060568238567
9614. they were in a sense tried out in realistic situations.	9.200067417691738
9615. from the point of view of the applicants less time	was wasted in being evaluated- and they got a meal out of it as well	as some insights into their performances.	4.888364737527616
9616. another use of roleplaying	for evaluation illustrates how this procedure can be used in	real life situations without special equipment or special assistants during	the daily course of work.	5.441661646709816
9617. the position of receptionist was	opened in a large office and an announcement was made to the other	girls already working that they could apply for this job which had higher	prestige and slightly higher salary than typing and clerking positions.	4.0293258361397974
9618. all applicants were generally familiar with the work of the receptionist.	9.42048601487167
9619. at the end of work one day the personnel man took the applicants	one at a time asked them to sit behind the receptionist's desk	and he then played the role of a number of people who might come to	the receptionist with a number of queries and for a number of purposes.	4.89979488785693
9620. each girl was independently tested by the personnel man and	he served not only as the director but as the antagonist and the observer.	5.879107059075077
9621. somewhat to his surprise he found that one girl whom	he would never have considered for the job since she had appeared somewhat	mousy and also had been in the office a relatively short time did	the most outstanding job of playing the role of receptionist showing	wit sparkle and aplomb.	3.83807336099242
9622. she was hired and was found to be entirely	satisfactory when she played the role eight hours a day.	5.961350900238809
9623. in considering roleplaying for analysis we enter a more complex area	since we are now no longer dealing with a simple over-all decision	but rather with the examination and evaluation of many elements seen	in dynamic functioning.	3.8102176280763382
9624. some cases in evidence of the use of roleplaying	for analysis may help explain the procedure.	6.970826393369029
9625. an engineer	had been made the works manager of a firm supplanting a retired employee	who had been considered outstandingly successful.	4.197709273283732
9626. the engineer had	more than seven years of experience in the firm was well trained was	considered a hard worker was respected by his fellow engineers for	his technical competence and was regarded as a comer.	5.109529840945311

9630. despite the fact that he	was regarded as an outstanding engineer he seemed to be a very poor	administrator although no one quite knew what was wrong with him.	7.446662721791791
9631. at	the insistence of his own supervisor- the president of the firm he	enrolled in a course designed to develop leaders.	5.12795802167037
9632. he played	a number of typical situations before observers other supervisors who	kept notes and then explained to him in detail what he did they thought	was wrong.	5.475693999189526

9641. the engineer turned works	manager had a particular view of life- and refused to change it.	4.047421028257421

9644. another case may be given in illustration of a successful	use of analysis and also of the employment of a procedure for intensive	analysis.	5.737785423445898
9645. in a course for supermarket operators a district manager	who had been recently appointed to his position after being outstandingly	successful as a store manager found that in supervising other	managers he was having a difficult time.	3.651648517148363
