9653. how this	was accomplished may be described since this sometimes is a crucial	problem.	4.9124883643716295
9654. the director helped tailor-make a check list of the district	manager's errors by asking various observers to write out sentences	commenting on the mistakes they felt he made.	4.996086858939229
9655. these errors were	then collected and written on a blackboard condensing similar ideas.	4.646674038929972
9656. eighteen errors were located and then the director asked each individual	to vote whether or not they felt that this manager had made the	particular errors.	5.784668573399627
9657. they were asked to vote true if they thought	they had seen him make the error false if they thought he had	not; and cannot say if they were not certain.	4.174496259786594
9658. the manager	sat behind the group so he could see and count the hands that went	up and the director wrote the numbers on the blackboard.	4.875144845172444
9659. no comments	were made during the voting.	6.496368235605577
9660. the results looked as follows: f.	6.889845812922657
9661. the first eight of these eighteen statements which received	at least one-half of the votes were duplicated to form an analysis	checklist for the particular manager and when this particular manager	roleplayed in other situations the members checked any items that appeared.	3.6263907085763583
9662. to prevent the manager from deliberately controlling himself	only during the sessions they were rather lengthy	the situations were imperfectly described to the manager so that	he would not know what to expect new antagonists were brought on the	scene unexpectedly and the antagonists were instructed to deliberately	behave in such ways as to upset the manager and get him to operate in	a manner for which he had been previously criticized.	4.9169747322345385
9663. after	every session the check marks were totaled up and graphed and in this	way the supervisor's progress was charted.	3.9394316778493597
9664. in life	we learn to play our roles and we freeze into patterns which become	so habitual that we are not really aware of what we do.	5.9480365461840385
9665. we can see	others more clearly than we can see ourselves and others can see us	better than we see ourselves.	4.437408360044618
9666. to learn what we do is the first step	for improvement.	7.6978901630058125
9667. to accept the validity of the judgments of others is	the second step.	5.551967680244899
9668. to want to change is the third step.	8.15140997347829
9669. to practice new	procedures under guided supervision and with constant feedback is the	fourth step.	4.589552729078203
9670. to use these new ways in daily life is the last step.	6.631159245939393
9671. roleplaying used for analysis follows these general steps leading to	training.	4.681571082223364
9672. when an evaluative situation is set up and no concern	is with the details that lead to an over-all estimate we say that	roleplaying is used for evaluation.	5.635354365286218
9673. observers can see a person engaged	in spontaneous behavior and watch him operating in a totalistic fashion.	4.161252085715236
9674. this behavior is more veridical- or true than other	testing behavior for some types of evaluation and so can give quick and	accurate estimates of complex functioning.	5.070853695560179
9675. while roleplaying	for testing is not too well understood at the present time it represents	one of the major uses of this procedure.	4.949868682025845
9676. training	the objective of this chapter is to clarify	the distinctions between spontaneity theory and other training concepts.	5.603835476123842
9677. in addition the basic approach utilized in applying roleplaying will	be reviewed.	5.499625213097211
9678. the goal will be to provide the reader with an integrated	rationale to aid him in applying roleplaying techniques in this	unique training area.	5.33705881357474
9679. the reasons for extracting this particular roleplaying	application from the previous discussion of training are twofold:	spontaneity training theory is unique and relatively new.	3.9529138472318244
9680. it is not easy for the therapist to discern when in the patient's	communicating an introject has appeared and is holding sway.	6.074102962474111
9681. one	learns to become alert to changes in his vocal tone- to his voice's	suddenly shifting to a quality not like his usual one a quality	which sounds somehow artificial or in some instances parrotlike.	3.6240728360657233
9682. the	content of his words may lapse back into monotonous repetition as	if a phonograph needle were stuck in one groove; only seldom is it so	simple as to be a matter of his obviously parroting some timeworn axiom	common to our culture which he has evidently heard over and over	from a parent until he experiences it as part of him.	5.110349963844537
9683. one hebephrenic	woman often became submerged in what felt to me like a somehow	phony experience of pseudo-emotion during which despite her wracking	sobs and streaming cheeks i felt only a cold annoyance with her.	3.756337090043235
9684. eventually such incidents became more sporadic and more sharply demarcated	from her day-after-day behavior and in one particular session	after several minutes of such behavior- which as usual went on	without any accompanying words from her- she asked eagerly did	you see granny?	4.712439386413646
9685.  at first i did not know what she meant; i	thought she must be seeing me as some one who had just come from	seeing	her grandmother in their distant home-city.	4.4381410484798165
9686. then i realized that	she had been deliberately showing me this time what granny was like;	and when i replied in this spirit she corroborated my hunch.	5.338726580026118
9687. at another phase in the therapy when a pathogenic mother-introject	began to emerge more and more upon the investigative scene she muttered	in a low but intense voice to herself i hate that woman inside	me! i could evoke no further elaboration from her about this;	but a few seconds later she was standing directly across the room	from me looking me in the eyes and saying in a scathingly condemnatory	tone your	father despises you! again i at first misconstrued	this disconcertingly intense communication and i quickly cast	through my mind to account for her being able to speak with such utter	conviction of an opinion held by my father now several years deceased.	3.309916016699004
9688. then i replied coldly if you despise me why don't you	say so directly?	6.648516183671919
9689.  she looked confused at this and i felt sure	it had been a wrong response for me to make.	4.7067588918524095
9690. it then occurred to me to	ask is that what that woman told you?	6.349105412557767
9691.  she clearly agreed	that this had been the case.	6.427080753896314
9692. i realized now that she had been showing	me in what impressed me as being a very accurate way something her	mother had once said to her; it was as if she was showing me one of	the reasons why she hated that woman inside her.	4.895254463185932
9693. what had been an unmanageably	powerful introject was now despite its continuing charge	of energy disconcerting to me sufficiently within control of her ego	that she could use it to show me what this introjected mother was like.	3.786882433602605
9694. earlier this woman had been so filled with a chaotic variety	of introjects that at times when she was in her room alone it would	sound to a passerby as though there were several different persons in	the room as she would vocalize in various kinds of voice.	5.0235313186321235
9695. a somewhat	less fragmented hebephrenic patient of mine who used to often seclude	herself in her room often sounded through the closed door- as i	would find on passing by between our sessions- for all the world	like two persons a scolding mother and a defensive child.	3.477231082723157
9696. particularly	hard for the therapist to grasp are those instances in which	the patient is manifesting an introject traceable to something in the	therapist some aspect of the therapist of which the latter is himself	only poorly aware and the recognition of which as a part of himself	he finds distinctly unwelcome.	5.278631582023682
9697. i have found time and again that	some bit of particularly annoying and intractable behavior on the part	of a patient rests in the final analysis on this basis; and only	when i can acknowledge this to myself as being indeed an aspect of	my personality does it cease to be a prominently troublesome aspect of	the patient's behavior.	3.8121678515110666
9698. for example one hebephrenic man used to	annoy me month after month by saying whenever i got up to leave and	made my fairly steoreotyped comment that i would be seeing him on the	following day or whenever you're welcome in a notably condescending	fashion- as though it were his due for me to thank him	for the privilege of spending the hour with him and he were thus pointing	up my failure to utter a humbly grateful thank you to him	at the end of each session.	4.951970961999116
9699. eventually it became clear to me partly	with the aid of another schizophrenic patient who could point out my	condescension to me somewhat more directly that this man with his	condescending	you're welcome was very accurately personifying	an element of obnoxious condescension which had been present in my own	demeanor over these months on each of these occasions when i had	bid him good-bye with the consoling note each time that the healing	christ would be stooping to dispense this succor to the poor suffered	again on the morrow.	3.4467414002024146
9700. another patient a paranoid woman for many	months infuriated not only me but the ward-personnel and her fellow	patients by arrogantly behaving as though she owned the whole building	as though she were the only person in it whose needs were to be met.	5.1732937683374125
9701. this behavior on her part subsided only after i had come to see the	uncomfortably close similarity between on the one hand her arranging	the ventilation of the common living room to her own liking or turning	the television off or on without regard to the wishes of the others	and on the other hand my own coming stolidly into her room despite	her persistent and vociferous objections bringing my big easy chair	with me usually shutting the windows of her room which she preferred	to keep in a very cold state and plunking myself down in my chair-	in short behaving as if i owned her room.	3.5339446989170993
9702. here a variety of meanings and emotions are concentrated or reduced	in their communicative expression to some comparatively simple-seeming	verbal or nonverbal statement.	5.963275724252206
9703. one finds for example	that a terse and stereotyped	verbal expression seeming at first to be	a mere hollow convention reveals itself over the months of therapy	as the vehicle for expressing the most varied and intense feelings and	the most unconventional of meanings.	3.552098127917611
9704. more than anything it is the	therapist's intuitive sensing of these latent meanings in the stereotype	which helps these meanings to become revealed something like a spread-out	deck of cards on sporadic occasions over the passage of the	patient's and his months of work together.	4.949169659482776
9705. one cannot assume of course	that all these accumulated meanings were inherent in the stereotype	at the beginning of the therapy or at any one time later on when	the stereotype was uttered; probably it is correct to think of it as	a matter of a well-grooved stereotyped mode of expression- and no	or but a few other communicational grooves as yet- being there	available for the patient's use as newly-emerging emotions and	ideas well up in him over the course of months.	3.7525418439355334
9706. but it is true that the	therapist can sense when he hears this stereotype that there are	at this moment many emotional determinants at work in it a blurred babel	of indistinct voices which have yet to become clearly delineated from	one another.	5.29432003186666
9707. sometimes it is not a verbal stereotype- a	how are you now?	6.926831541718639
9708.  or an i want to go home or whatever-	but a nonverbal one which reveals itself gradually as the condensed	expression of more than one latent meaning.	6.31450691500057
9709. a hebephrenic man used	to give a repetitious wave of his hand a number of times during his	largely-silent	hours with his therapist.	4.241511144138369
9710. when the therapist came to feel	on sufficiently sure ground with him to ask him what is that	bill- hello or farewell?	5.892919640269328
9711.  the patient replied both dearie-	two in one.	4.886251421296035
9712. of all the possible forms of nonverbal expression	that which seems best to give release and communicational expression	to complex and undifferentiated feelings is laughter.	5.834972290784974
9713. it is	no coincidence that the hebephrenic patient the most severely dedifferentiated	of all schizophrenic patients shows as one of his characteristic	symptoms laughter- laughter which now makes one feel scorned	or hated which now makes one feel like weeping or which now gives	one a glimpse of the bleak and empty expanse of man's despair; and	which more often than all these conveys a welter of feelings which	could in no way be	conveyed by any number of words words which are so	unlike this welter in being formed and discrete from one another.	3.4691245697695834
9714. to	a much less full extent the hebephrenic person's belching or flatus	has a comparable communicative function; in working with these patients	the therapist eventually gets to do some at least private mulling	over of the possible meaning of a belch or the passage of flatus	not only because he is reduced to this for lack of anything else to analyze	but also because he learns that even these animal-like sounds constitute	forms of communication in which from time to time quite different	things are being said long before the patient can become sufficiently	aware of these as distinct feelings and concepts to say them	in words.	4.43815304199037
9715. as i have been intimating in the schizophrenic-	and perhaps also in the dreams of the neurotic; this is a question	which i have no wish to take up- condensation is a phenomenon in which	one finds not a condensed expression of various feelings and ideas	which are at an unconscious level well sorted out but rather a condensed	expression of feelings and ideas which even in the unconscious	have yet to become well differentiated from one another.	3.7283440414386892
9716. freeman	cameron and mcghie in their description of the disturbances of thinking	found in chronic schizophrenic patients say in regard to condensation	that h the lack of adequate discrimination between the	self and the environment and the objects contained therein h in itself	is the prototypical condensation.	5.096880308395448
9717. in my experience a	great many of the patient's more puzzling verbal communications are	so for the reason that concrete meanings have not become differentiated	from figurative meanings in his subjective experience.	4.185369352337986
9718. thus he may	be referring to some concrete thing or incident in his immediate environment	by some symbolic-sounding hyperbolic reference to transcendental	events on the global scene.	5.319971656659983
9719. recently for example a paranoid woman's	large-scale philosophizing in the session about the intrusive	curiosity which has become in her opinion a deplorable characteristic	of mid-twentieth-century human culture developed itself before the	end of the session into a suspicion that i was surreptitiously peeking	at her partially exposed breast as indeed i was.	3.598774750614673
9720. or equally	often a concretistic-seeming particularistic-seeming statement may consist	with its mundane exterior in a form of poetry- may be full	of meaning and emotion when interpreted as a figurative expression:	a metaphor a smile an allegory or some other symbolic mode of speaking.	5.052925323655561
9721. of such hidden meanings the patient himself is more often	than not entirely unaware.	4.907793198558288
9722. his subjective experience may be a remarkably	concretistic one.	8.416851912998347
9723. one hebephrenic women confided to me i	live in a world of words as if to her words were fully concrete	objects; burnham in his excellent article concerning schizophrenic	communication includes mention of similar clinical material.	4.022157513725853
9724. a borderline schizophrenic young man told me that to him the various	theoretical concepts about which he had been expounding in a most articulate	fashion during session after session with me were like great	cubes of almost tangibly solid matter up in the air above him; as he	spoke i was reminded of the great bales of cargo which are swung high	in the air from a docked steamship.	5.185143170228826
9725. the many linguistic techniques for reducing the amount of dictionary	information that have been proposed all organize the dictionary's	contents around prefixes stems suffixes etc.	3.9675209984489586
9726. a significant	reduction	in the voume of store information is thus realized especially	for a highly inflected language such as russian.	5.258925197803143
9727. for english the reduction	in size is less striking.	5.52448632359536
9728. this approach requires that:	each text word be separated into smaller elements to establish a correspondence	between the occurrence and dictionary entries and the information	retrieved from several entries in the dictionary be synthesized	into a description of the particular word.	5.154550010946664
9729. the logical scheme used	to accomplish the former influences the placement of information in	the dictionary file.	3.814698927498042
9730. implementation of the latter requires storage of	information needed only for synthesis.	6.96445723381674
9731. we suggest the application	of certain data-processing techniques as a solution to the problem.	5.107518784889501
9732. but first we must define two terms so that their meaning will be	clearly understood:  form- any unique sequence of alphabetic	characters that can appear in a language preceded and followed	by a space.	4.922165479551762
9733. occurrence- an instance of a form in text.	5.066959048406199
9734. we propose a method for selecting only dictionary information	required by the text being translated and a means for passing the information	directly to the occurrences in text.	5.087562364432138
9735. we accomplish this by compiling	a list of text forms as text is read by the computer.	4.318670503113022
9736. a random-storage	scheme based on the spelling of forms provides an economical	way to compile this text-form list.	5.89047460015503
9737. dictionary forms found to match	forms in the text list are marked.	4.535752126583474
9738. a location in the computer store	is also named for each marked form; dictionary information about the	form stored at this location can be retrieved directly by occurrences	of the form in text.	4.737638784068538
9739. finally information is retrieved from the dictionary	as required by stages of the translation process- the grammatic	description for sentence-structure determination equivalent-choice	information for semantic analysis and target-language equivalents	for output construction.	3.827721743515095
9740. the dictionary is a form dictionary	at least in the sense that complete forms are used as the basis for matching	text occurrences with dictionary entries.	5.952258027209325
9741. also the dictionary	is divided into at least two parts: the list of dictionary forms and	the file of information that pertains to these forms.	4.594877136226703
9742. a more detailed	description of dictionary operations- text lookup and dictionary	modification- give a clearer picture.	5.9442944788845
9743. text lookup as we will	describe it consists of three steps.	5.1555726509103605
9744. the first is compiling a list	of text forms assigning an information cell to each and replacing text	occurrences with the information cell assigned to the form of each	occurrence.	5.3451027561732385
9745. for this step the computer memory is separated into three	regions: cells in the w-region are used for storage of the forms	in the text-form list; cells in the x-region and y region	are reserved as information cells for text forms.	3.6325744712302357
9746. when an occurrence	f is isolated during text reading a random memory address f	the address of a cell in the x-region is computed from the form	of f.	5.125721925080692
9747. let f denote the form of f.	7.9152540337068364
9748. if cell f has not previously	been assigned as the information cell of a form in the text-form	list it is now assigned as the information cell of f.	5.413728914253693
9749. the form itself	is stored in the next available cells of the w-region beginning	in cell f.	4.590566699084531
9750. the address f and the number of cells required to	store the form are written in f; the information cell f is saved	to represent the text occurrence.	5.1245285307660025
9751. text reading continues with the next	occurrence.	5.66037853959279
9752. let us assume that f is identical to the form	of an occurrence f which preceded f in the text.	5.745708738432951
9753. when this situation	exists the address f will equal f which was produced from f.	4.822226658937286
9754. if f was assigned as the information cell for f the routine can	detect that f is identical to f by comparing f with the form	stored at location f.	5.0457031707257185
9755. the address f is stored in the cell f.	4.320730508808147
9756. when	as in this case the two forms match the address f is saved to	represent the occurrence f.	5.976336753202418
9757. text reading continues with the next	occurrence.	5.66037853959279
9758. a third situation is possible.	9.231862163652615
9759. the formula for computing	random addresses from the form of each occurrence will not give a	distinct address for each distinct form.	4.044906074467617
9760. thus when more than one distinct	form leads to a particular cell in the x-region a chain of	information cells must be created to accommodate the forms one cell	in the chain for each form.	5.400625746634191
9761. if f leads to an address f that is equal	to the address computed from f even though f does not match f	the chain of information cells is extended from f by storing the	address of the next available cell in the y-region f in f.	3.5304784374382128
9762. the	cell f becomes the second information cell in the chain and is assigned	as the information cell of f.	5.2920541105344485
9763. a third cell can be added by storing	the address of another y-cell in f; similarly as many cells	are added as are required.	3.920284164508789
9764. each information cell in the chain contains	the address of the y-cell where the form to which it is assigned	is stored.	6.00729595227429
9765. each cell except the last in the chain also contains	the address of the y-cell that is the next element of the chain;	the absence of such a link in the last cell indicates the end of the	chain.	4.6934928263916245
9766. hence when the address f is computed from f the cell f	and	all y-cells in its chain must be inspected to determine whether	f is already in the form list or whether it should be added to the form	list and the chain.	5.417345627227592
9767. when the information cell for f has been determined	it is saved as a representation of f.	4.492664143575369
9768. text reading continues	with the next occurrence.	7.603896187885215
9769. text reading is terminated when	a pre-determined number of forms have been stored in the text-form list.	4.060235568763422
9770. this initiates the second step of glossary lookup- connecting the	information cell of forms in the text-form list to dictionary forms.	5.273154028911168
9771. each form represented by the dictionary is looked up in the text-form	list.	5.772214281725437
9772. each time a dictionary form matches a text form the information	cell of the matching text form is saved.	5.720729335189272
9773. the number of dictionary	forms skipped since the last one matched is also saved.	4.741820498547036
9774. these two pieces	of information for each dictionary form that is matched by a text	form constitute the table of dictionary usage.	5.611185526328496
9775. if each text form is	marked when matched with a dictionary form the text forms not contained	in the dictionary can be identified when all dictionary forms have	been read.	3.7869944843092105
9776. the appropriate action for handling these forms can be taken	at that time.	5.454300555224472
9777. each dictionary form is looked up in the text-form	list by the same method used to look up a new text occurrence in	the form list during text reading.	4.307068381503211
9778. a random address f that lies within	the x-region of memory mentioned earlier is computed from the	i-th dictionary form.	5.258925197803143
9779. if cell f is an information cell it and	any information cells in the y-region that have been linked to f	each contain an address in the w-region where a potentially matching	form is stored.	3.7049239243260446
9780. the dictionary form is compared with each of these	text forms.	5.904708967783999
9781. when a match is found an entry is made in the table of	dictionary usage.	5.495861426532788
9782. if cell f is not an information cell we conclude	that the i-th dictionary form is not in the text list.	6.647335070411993
9783. these	two steps essentially complete the lookup operation.	5.3285636594893
9784. the final step	merely uses the table of dictionary usage to select the dictionary information	that pertains to each form matched in the text-form list and	uses the list of information cells recorded in text order to attach	the appropriate information to each occurrence in text.	4.625163008649497
9785. the list of	text forms in the w-region of memory and the contents of the information	cells in the x and y-regions are no longer required.	3.633879381299229
9786. only	the assignment of the information cells is important.	6.997817953744141
9787. the	first stage of translation after glossary lookup is structural analysis	of the input text.	4.479502172811557
9788. the grammatical description of each occurrence in	the text must be retrieved from the dictionary to permit such an analysis.	4.889557281264576
9789. a description of this process will serve to illustrate how any	type of information can be retrieved from the dictionary and attached	to each text occurrence.	3.8837515834948118
9790. the grammatic descriptions of all forms	in the dictionary are recorded in a separate part of the dictionary	file.	5.681942804882661
9791. the order is identical to the ordering of the forms they describe.	4.318636346748716
9792. when entries are being retrieved from this file the table of dictionary	usage indicates which entries to skip and which entries to store	in the computer.	5.228557649848442
9793. this selection-rejection process takes place as the	file is read.	4.987041256881453
9794. each entry that is selected for storage is written into	the next available cells of the w-region.	5.832498387033187
9795. the address of the	first cell and the number of cells used is written in the information	cell for the form.	4.419101569812741
9796. when the complete file has been	read the grammatic descriptions for all text forms found in the dictionary	have been stored in the w-region; the information cell assigned	to each text form contains the address of the grammatic description	of the form it represents.	5.047442218095437
9797. hence the description of each text	occurrence can be retrieved by reading the list of text-ordered information-cell	addresses and outputting the description indicated by the information	cell for each occurrence.	4.122538332621795
9798. the only requirements on	dictionary information made by the text-lookup operation are that each	form represented by the dictionary be available for lookup in the text-form	list and that information for each form be available in a sequence	identical with the sequence of the forms.	5.0841561637272665
9799. this leaves the ordering	of entries variable.	5.860285214927587
9800. two very useful ways for modifying a form-dictionary	are the addition to the dictionary of complete paradigms	rather than single forms and the application of a single change to more	than one dictionary form.	5.561135099643173
9801. the former is intended to decrease the amount	of work necessary to extend dictionary coverage.	4.30550119960721
9802. the latter is useful	for modifying information about some or all forms of a word hence	reducing the work required to improve dictionary contents.	5.583405149239224
9803. applying	the techniques developed at harvard for generating a paradigm from	a representative form and its classification we can add all forms of	a word to the dictionary at once.	3.6754664226547398
9804. an extension of the principle would	permit entering a grammatic description of each form.	6.724976794579506
9805. equivalents could	be assigned to the paradigm either at the time it is added to the	dictionary or after the word has been studied in context.	4.252357095251678
9806. thus one can	think of a dictionary entry as a word rather than a form.	6.922567852897336
9807. if	all forms of a paradigm are grouped together within the dictionary	a considerable reduction in the amount of information required is possible.	4.176954915387961
9808. for example the inflected forms of a word can be represented	insofar as regular inflection allows by a stem and a set of endings to	be attached.	5.796747974328619
9809. the full forms can be derived from such information	just prior to the lookup of the form in the text-form list.	4.036959019284454
9810. similarly if the equivalents for the forms of a word do not vary the	equivalents need be entered only once with an indication that they	apply	to each form.	5.1526278479157215
9811. the dictionary system is in no way dependent upon	such summarization or designed around it.	4.066625838582634
9812. when irregularity and variation	prevent summarizing information is written in complete detail.	6.722408246988701
9813. entries	are summarized only when by doing so the amount of information	retained in the dictionary is reduced and the time required for dictionary	operations is decreased.	3.9979581465151512
9814. in sentences patterns of stress are determined by complex combinations	of influences that can only be suggested here.	5.666519788732026
9815. the tendency is toward	putting dominant stress at the end.	4.320699760725407
9816. there is a parallel to this tendency	in the assignment of time in long-known hymn tunes.	6.7824716396431945
9817. thus the	first lines of one of charles wesley's hymns are as follows.	5.696960357300556
9818. a charge to keep i have a god to glorify.	6.879448761674897
9819. in the	tune to which this hymn is most often sung boylston the syllables	have and fy ending their lines have twice the time any	other syllables have.	3.7477334548594032
9820. dominant stress is of course more than extended	duration and normally centers on syllables that would have primary stress	or phrase stress if the words or longer units they are parts of	were spoken alone: a dominant stress given to glorify would normally	center on its first syllable rather than its last.	4.745008460151349
9821. but the parallel	is significant.	8.225417453773382
9822. when the answer to what's wrong now?	10.132595614676253
9823.  is bill's	broken a chair dominant stress will usually be on the complement	a chair.	5.0128522087937215
9824. from the point of view of syntactic analysis the	head word in the statement is the predicator has broken and from	the point of view of meaning it would seem that the trouble centers	in the breaking; but dominant stress will be assigned to broken	only in rather exceptional versions of the sentence.	5.394631361696617
9825. in i know one	thing dominant stress will usually be on the complement one thing;	in one thing i know it will usually be on the predicator know.	4.04232723000672
9826. in small-town people are very friendly dominant stress will	generally be on the complement very friendly; in the double sentence	the smaller the town the friendlier the people it will generally	be on the subjects the town and the people.	4.794547048694151
9827. in what's	a linguist?	8.278437049563516
9828.  dominant stress will generally be on the subject	a linguist; in who's a linguist?	5.98311281725967
9829.  it will generally be on	the complement a linguist.	6.338916692628243
9830. dominant stress is on her luggage	both in that's her luggage where her luggage is the complement	and in there's her luggage where it is the subject.	5.740562434177765
9831. adverbial	second complements however are likely not to have dominant stress	when they terminate sentences.	4.457368157505818
9832. if the answer to what was that noise?	9.086842200844474
9833. 	is george put the cat out dominant stress will ordinarily	be on the first complement the cat not the second complement	out.	4.2432202266665495
9834. final adjuncts may or may not have dominant stress.	8.44302567589872
9835. if the	answer to what was that noise?	6.104300698969425
9836.  is george reads the news emotionally	dominant stress may or may not be on the adjunct emotionally.	7.330709876465173
9837. when prepositional complements are divided as in what are you	looking for?	5.004194486013785
9838.  they are likely to lose dominant stress.	9.79781098609094
9839. context	is of extreme importance.	6.683325264329536
9840. what is new in the context is likely	to be made more prominent than what is not.	6.689563641625232
9841. thus in a context in which	there has been discussion of snow but mention of local conditions is	new dominant stress will probably be on here in it rarely snows	here but in a context in which there has been discussion of local	weather but no mention of snow dominant stress will probably be on snows.	3.81233702146995
9842. the personal pronouns and substitute one are normally unstressed	because they refer to what is prominent in the immediate context.	5.451654387306854
9843. in i'll go with george dominant stress is probably on george;	but if george has just been mentioned prominently	what is said is probably	i'll go with him and dominant stress is probably on the preposition	with.	3.649274120968582
9844. when a gesture accompanies who's he?	9.703297777752711
9845.  the personal	pronoun has dominant stress because he has not been mentioned	previously.	4.736141159692586
9846. if both george and a piece of information george	does not have are prominent in the context but the idea of telling george	is new then dominant stress will probably be on tell in why	not tell george?	5.5172332086243
9847.  but when what is new in a particular context	is also fairly obvious there is normally only light stress or no stress	at all.	4.254360913335422
9848. thus the unstressed it of it rarely snows here gets	its significance from its use with snows: nothing can snow snow	but it.	5.621311585578762
9849. in there aren't many young people in the neighborhood	the modifier young takes dominant stress away from its head	people: the fact that the young creatures of interest are people	seems rather obvious.	4.244821227518181
9850. if women replaced people it would normally	have dominant stress.	7.317853478826358
9851. in i have things to do the word things	makes little real contribution to meaning and has weaker stress	than do.	4.282393580088321
9852. if work is substituted for things	it will have dominant stress.	7.210444879365008
9853. in i	know one thing dominant stress is likely to go to one rather than	to semantically pale thing.	5.205247092295074
9854. in i knew you when you were a child	and you were pretty then dominant stress on then implies that	the young woman spoken to is still pretty.	5.149825341712454
9855. dominant stress on pretty	would be almost insulting here.	5.066959048406199
9856. in the written language then	can be underlined or italicized to guide the reader here but much	of the time the written language simply depends on the reader's alertness	and a careless reader will have to back up and reread.	5.501615155090662
9857. often dominant stress simply indicates a centering of attention or emotion.	4.996423364102433
9858. thus in it's incredible what that boy can eat dominant stress	is likely to be on incredible and eat will have strong	stress also.	5.903411564758214
9859. in she has it in for george dominant stress will ordinarily	be on in where the notion of stored-up antipathy seems to	center.	3.9020296841728688
9860. in we're painting at our garage strong stress on at	indicates that the job being done is not real painting but simply an	effort at painting.	5.080079763494645
9861. where there is comparison or contrast dominant	stresses normally operate to center attention.	5.080503880302152
9862. thus in his friends	are stranger than his sisters' strong stresses are normal for his	and sisters' but in his friends are stranger than his sisters	strong stresses are normal for friends and sisters.	5.0303437295048985
9863. in	he's hurting himself more than he's hurting you both himself	and you have stronger stress than they would ordinarily have if	there were no contrast.	3.725131536371901
9864. in is she chinese or japanese?	8.128897452991986
9865.  the	desire to contrast the first parts of words which are alike in their last	components produces an exceptional disregard of the normal patterns	of stress of chinese and japanese.	3.6086939204672
9866. sometimes strong stress	serves to focus an important secondary relationship.	7.3206880346027505
9867. thus in mary	wrote an account of the trip first strong stress on mary marks	mary as the first in a series of people who wrote accounts of the trip	strong stress on wrote marks the writing as the first of a series	of actions of mary's concerned with an account of her trip	and strong stress	on trip makes the trip the first of a series of subjects about	which mary wrote accounts.	4.367860605364744
9868. in hunger stimulates man too the situation	is very similar.	6.866620409496401
9869. strong stress on hunger treats hunger as	an additional stimulus strong stress on stimulates treats stimulation	as an additional effect of hunger strong stress on man treats	man as an additional creature who responds to the stimulation of hunger.	3.4506452011778967
9870. here again in the written language it is possible to help the	reader get his stresses right by using underlining or italics but much	of the time there is simply reliance on his understanding in the light	of context.	5.361523579484514
9871. when a word represents a larger construction of	which it is the only expressed part it normally has more stress than	it would have in fully expressed construction.	4.542449002699743
9872. thus when yes i	have is the response to have you finished reading the paper?	6.457023084192658
9873. 	the stress on have which here represents have finished reading	the paper is quite strong.	4.21292691591616
9874. in mack's the leader at camp but	jack is here the is of the second main declarative represents	is the leader and therefore has stress.	5.388485670579262
9875. mack's the leader at	camp but jack's here with this is deprived of stress makes	here the complement in the clause.	3.8880356915934375
9876. in of all the suggestions that	were made his was the silliest the possessive his represents	his suggestion and is stressed.	5.896146749614966
9877. when go represents itself and	a complement in which	boat did jack go on?	4.837732554347947
9878.  it has strong stress; when it represents	only itself and on which is its complement	on has stronger stress	than go does.	5.947149455567476
9879. omission of a subordinator pronoun however does	not result in an increase in stress on a prepositional adverb for which	the subordinator pronoun would be object.	3.8851672241463446
9880. thus to has light stress	both in that was the conclusion that i came to and in that	was the conclusion i came to.	6.337284903034506
9881. but when to represents to consciousness	in that was the moment that i came to and similarly	in that was the moment i came to there is much stronger stress	on to.	4.773591809039818
9882. in i wanted to tell him but i was afraid to the final	to is lightly stressed because it represents to tell him.	5.802353971671299
9883. in	to tell him of course to is normally unstressed.	5.214061515621742
9884. when i	have instructions to leave is equivalent in meaning to i	have instructions that i am to leave this place dominant stress	is ordinarily on leave.	5.326976534635731
9885. when the same sequence is equivalent in	meaning to i have instructions which i am to leave dominant stress	is ordinarily on instructions.	4.2040173405147145
9886. it is clear that patterns	of stress sometimes	show construction unambiguously in the spoken language where	without the help of context it would be ambiguous in the written.	6.293016612129251
9887. i'll come by tuesday.	6.683325264329536
9888. i	can't be happy long without drinking water.	7.1581511048922275
9889. in the first of these	sentences if by is the complement of come and tuesday is	an adjunct of time equivalent to on tuesday there will be strong	stress on by in the spoken language; but if a complement for	come is implied and by tuesday is a prepositional unit used as	an adjunct by will be unstressed or lightly stressed at most.	3.6832250922469685
9890. in	the second sentence if drinking water is a gerundial clause and	without drinking water is roughly equivalent in meaning to unless	i drink water there will be stronger stress on water than on	drinking; but if drinking is a gerundial noun modifying water	and without drinking water is equivalent to without water	for drinking there will be stronger stress on drinking than on	water.	4.808078976403815
9891. but the use of stress in comparison and contrast for example	can undermine distinctions such as these.	5.031248891706761
9892. and patterns of stress	are not always unambiguous by any means.	6.665953002163231
9893. in the steiners have	busy	lives without visiting relatives only context can indicate whether visiting	relatives is equivalent in meaning to paying visits to relatives	or to relatives who are visiting them and in i looked	up the number and i looked up the chimney only the meanings	of number and chimney make it clear that up is syntactically	a second complement in the first sentence and a preposition followed	by its object in the second.	3.5026985541119173
9894. syllables are	linguistic units centering in peaks which are usually vocalic but as	has been noted are consonantal under certain circumstances and which	may or may not be combined with preceding andor following consonants	or combinations of consonants.	5.080052191702922
9895. syllables are genuine units but division	of words and sentences into them presents great difficulties.	4.21292691591616
9896. sometimes	even the number of syllables is not clear.	8.377542487490214
9897. doubt on this point	is strongest before l and  or r.	4.681571082223364
9898. from the point of view	of	word formation real might be expected to have two syllables.	8.163308864789583
9899. historically	re is the formative that is employed also in republic	and al is the common suffix.	4.131860641767443
9900. when ity is added	real clearly has two syllables.	7.696516088703085
9901. but there is every reason to regard	deal as a monosyllable and because of the fact that l commonly	has the quality of  when it follows vowel sounds deal seems	to be a perfectly satisfactory rhyme with real.	4.724035974504259
9902. it is obvious enough that linguists in general have been less	successful in coping with tone systems than with consonants or vowels.	5.544241669729324
9903. no single explanation is adequate to account for this.	5.613646290821733
9904. improvement	however is urgent and at least three things will be needed.	6.388781855087688
9905. the first is a wide-ranging sample of successful tonal analyses.	4.93965684388654
9906. even	beginning students in linguistics are made familiar with an appreciable	variety of consonant systems both in their general outlines and in	many specific details.	5.14920930941904
9907. an advanced student has read a considerable	number of descriptions of consonantal systems including some of the more	unusual types.	4.728099314062036
9908. by contrast even experienced linguists commonly know	no more of the range of possibilities in tone systems than the over-simple	distinction between register and contour languages.	5.973750010243533
9909. this limited	familiarity with the possible phenomena has severely hampered work	with tone.	4.775278578169377
9910. tone analysis will continue to be difficult and unsatisfactory	until a more representative selection of systems is familar to	every practicing field linguist.	5.637671124923923
9911. papers like these four if widely read	will contribute importantly to improvement of our analytic work.	4.131860641767443
9912. the second need is better field techniques.	7.439551532653989
9913. the great majority	of present-day linguists fall into one or more of a number of overlapping	types: those who are convinced that tone cannot be analysed those who	are personally scared of tone and tone languages generally those who	are convinced that tone is merely an unnecessary marginal feature in	those languages where it occurs those who have no idea how to proceed	with tone analysis those who take a simplistic view of the whole	matter.	3.8751153601869213
9914. the result has been neglect fumbling efforts or superficial	treatment.	7.185314972184344
9915. as these maladies overlap so must the cure.	5.822421640728078
9916. analyses such	as these four will simultaneously combat the assumptions that tone	is impossible and that it is simple.	6.585526054340024
9917. they will give suggestions that	can be worked up into field procedures.	5.300500315877244
9918. good field techniques will not	only equip linguists for better work but also help them overcome negative	attitudes.	5.954343312401235
9919. actually none of these papers says much directly about	field techniques.	5.649965535866708
9920. but it is worth pondering that very little has	been published on any phase of field techniques in linguistics.	6.441834098492443
9921. these	things have been disseminated by other means but always in the wake	of extensive publication of analytic results.	4.1091071816313445
9922. the third need	is for better theory.	7.5531223094256665
9923. we should expect that general phonologic theory	should be as adequate for tone as for consonants and vowels but it has	not been.	4.19129302912496
9924. this can only be for one of two reasons: either the two	are quite different and will require totally different theory	or our existing theories are insufficiently general.	5.6768376713478075
9925. if as i suspect the problem is largely of the second sort then development	of a theory better able to handle tone will result automatically	in better theory for all phonologic subsystems.	4.000238413358723
9926. one issue	that must be faced is the relative difficulty of analysis of different	phonologic subsystems.	6.260039061283256
9927. since tone systems typically comprise fewer	units than either consonant or vowel systems we might expect that they	would be the easiest part of a phonologic analysis.	4.137733729470427
9928. actual practice	does not often work out this way.	6.806723317680827
9929. tone systems are certainly more complex	than the number of units would suggest and often analytically	more difficult than much larger consonantal systems.	4.197378005581744
9930. welmers has	suggested one explanation.	8.978076491592427
9931. tone languages use for linguistic contrasts	speech parameters which also function heavily in nonlinguistic use.	4.21292691591616
9932. this may both divert the attention of the uninitiate and cause confusion	for the more knowledgeable.	6.803132564402433
9933. the problem is to disentangle the	linguistic features of pitch from the co-occurring nonlinguistic	features.	4.775825987940963
9934. of course something of the same sort occurs with other sectors of	the phonology: consonantal articulations have both a linguistic and	an individual component.	6.287070431064111
9935. but in general the individual variation is	a small thing added onto basic linguistic features of greater magnitude.	4.758260845212266
9936. with tone individual differences may be greater than the linguistic	contrasts which are superimposed on them.	6.029969712640202
9937. pitch differences from	one speaker to another or from one emotional state to another may far	exceed the small differences between tones.	3.841511969386553
9938. however any such suggestion	accounts for only some of the difficulties in hearing tone or in	developing a realistic attitude about tone but not for the analytic	difficulties that occur even when tone is meticulously recorded.	5.4050979833394175
9939. a second explanation is suggested by the material described in rowlands'	paper.	4.956710032778864
9940. tone and intonation often become seriously intermeshed.	7.1581511048922275
9941. neither can be adequately systematized until we are able to separate	the two and assign the observed phenomena individually to one or the	other.	4.425261780268382
9942. other pairs of phonologic subsystems also interact or overlap	in this way; for example duration sometimes figures in both the	vowel system and the intonation.	5.477463054054436
9943. some phonetic features for example	glottal catch or murmur are sometimes to be assigned to segmental phonemics	and sometimes to accentual systems.	4.094369307136436
9944. but no other two phonologic	systems are as difficult to disentangle as are tone and intonation in	some languages.	5.848288414670871
9945. this explanation of tone difficulties however does	not apply in all languages.	4.64192548420022
9946. in some	interaction of tone and intonation is restricted to the ends of intonation	spans.	6.397269258238096
9947. in many of the syllables intonation can be safely ignored	and much of the tonal analysis can be done without any study of intonation.	5.264271791762761
9948. still even in such languages tone analysis has not been as	simple as one might expect.	6.631361152996561
9949. a third explanation is suggested	by richardson's analysis of sukuma tone.	5.057558168975038
9950. there we see a basically	simple phonemic system enmeshed in a very complex and puzzling morphophonemic	system.	7.082941503072571
9951. while the phonemes can be very easily stated no one	is likely to be satisfied with the statement until phonemic occurrences	can be related in some way to morphemic units ie until the morphophonemics	is worked out or at least far enough that it seems reasonable	to expect success.	4.08388685086096
9952. in the typical tone language	tonal morphophonemics is of the same order of complexity as consonantal	morphophonemics.	6.598844113973106
9953. the phonemic systems which must support these morphophonemic	systems however are very different.	4.126437161889454
9954. the inventory of tones	is much smaller and commonly the contrasts range along one single	dimension pitch level.	5.280652153416978
9955. consonantal systems are not merely larger they	are multidimensional.	5.505556175977097
9956. morphophonemic rules may be thought of as joining	certain points in the system.	6.564108140383885
9957. the possibilities in the consonantal	system are very numerous and only a small portion of them are actually	used.	4.2244995596506785
9958. phonemes connected by a morphophonemic rule commonly show	a good bit of phonetic similarity possible because of the several dimensions	of contrast in the system.	5.490718726980992
9959. tonal morphophonemics in a common	case can do nothing but either raise or lower the tone.	4.131860641767443
9960. the possibilities	are few and the total number of rules may be considerably greater.	5.289832921804139
9961. often therefore there are a number of rules having the same	effect and commonly other sets of rules as well having the opposite	effect.	4.509307162511492
9962. tonal morphophonemics is much more confusing to the beginning	analyst than consonantal morphophonemics even when the total number	of rules is no greater.	5.510341104387857
9963. the difficulty of analysis of any subsystem	in the phonology is an inverse function of the size- smaller systems	are more troublesome- for any given degree of morphophonemic	complexity.	3.6376547833341233
9964. this hypothesis will account for a large part of the difficulties	of tonal analysis as well as the fact that vowel systems are	often more puzzling than consonantal systems.	7.578840654416736
9965. the statement of the system	is a different matter.	5.853191732838708
9966. smaller systems can of course be stated	much more succinctly.	7.094035153694507
9967. a phonemic system can be stated without reference	to morphophonemics but it cannot always be found without morphophonemics.	4.028644573802707

9969. the design of orthographies has received much less attention from	linguists than the problem deserves.	4.162804476583787
9970. there has been a tendency on the	part of many american linguists to assume that a phonemic transcription	will automatically be the best possible orthography and that the only	real problem will then be the social one of securing acceptance.	5.962823187655316
9971. most others have been content to give only the most	general attention to the broadest and most obvious features of the phonology	when designing orthographies.	4.531803854850072

9974. many of the suggested systems	seem to have only the most tenuous relationship to the language structures	that they purport to represent.	6.159481708987094
9975. linguists have not always been	more enlightened than practical people and sometimes have insisted	on incredibly trivial points while neglecting things of much greater	significance.	3.7605603237349414
9976. as a result many people have been confirmed in their	conviction that orthography design is not an activity to which experts	can contribute anything but confusion.	6.1641313378732265
